HEADLINE: Bargain-Hunting Aids Stocks; Dow Up 9.18

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stocks closed higher yesterday, buoyed by bargain-hunting after recent steep losses, but buyers were selective ahead of forthcoming third-quarter earnings reports.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.18 points to close at 3,287.87. In the broad market, winning issues led losers, 930 to 752, on volume of 188 million shares, compared with an active 205.4 million Wednesday. 
 But Ron Hill, an investment strategist at Brown Brothers Harriman, cautioned, "Third-quarter earnings season comes out next week, and it's not going to be pretty."
James Andrews, equity-trading manager at Janney Montgomery Scott, said he expected stocks to trade in a tight range until companies begin to report their earnings. "If a company comes out with any kind of negative situation, you can write that off as death," he said.
Analysts said the Presidential election was also moving closer to the forefront of investors' minds.
Gerald Simmons of Interstate/ Johnson Lane said the market "is trying to digest" the fact that Gov. Bill Clinton appears increasingly likely to win the election. While stock prices rose, "it was done with a lack of enthusiasm," the analyst said.
"The economy is still crummy," said Hersh Cohen, president of Shearson Asset Management. "The difference is now people realize it's crummy and will stay crummy."
 
Insurance Stocks Jump
 Gross domestic product -- the nation's output of goods and services -- grew at an anemic 1.5 percent rate in the second quarter, barely half the 2.9 percent rate in the first quarter, the Commerce Department said.
Insurers leaped on hopes that premium increases are likely near term. General Re jumped 8 1/8, to 102 1/2; American International rose 7 1/8, to 101 5/8; Marsh & McClennan gained 5 1/2, to 89; Chubb advanced 4 1/2, to 79 1/4; the St. Paul Companies rose 3 3/8, to 72, and CNA Financial climbed 3 7/8, to 91. But the Continental Corporation sank 6 1/8, to 24, after it urged a dividend cut and said its pretax loss from Hurricane Iniki would total $55 million.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 1.03, to 418.47. The American Stock Exchange index rose 1.03, to 380.94.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.56, to 229.98. The average share gained 8 cents. The Nasdaq over-the-counter index rose 2.97, to 585.93.

HEADLINE: G.D.P. Growth Is Lifted, But Jobless Claims Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The economy grew in the second quarter at a slightly less anemic rate than first thought, but new claims for unemployment benefits rose in mid-September for the fourth week in a row, the Government said today.
Consumer caution held the seasonally adjusted rise in the gross domestic product to an annual rate of 1.5 percent in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said, revising a previous estimate of 1.4 percent. 
 Separately, the Labor Department said 414,000 Americans filed applications for unemployment during the week ended Sept. 12, an increase of 15,000 partly attributed to claims from victims of Hurricane Andrew.
 
A Lasting Impression?
 Because of the volatility of the weekly reports, many analysts prefer to track a four-week moving average for claims, viewing it as a more reliable indicator of the labor market.
The average was 398,250 in the period ended Sept. 12, up from 390,500 a week earlier when it fell to the lowest since 387,250 during the period ended Oct. 6, 1990. The average was 409,250 during the period ended Aug. 29.
Analysts expect the mostly gloomy economic news to continue between now and the Presidential election Nov. 3.
"I can't see how the impression could possibly change before the election," said Paul W. Boltz, an economist for T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. "George Bush is stuck with family values at this point."
Next week, the Labor Department reports on September's jobless rate. Many economists fear that the end of a Federal summer-jobs program for teen-agers and job losses from the hurricane will cause an increase from the 7.6 percent August rate.
On Oct. 27, only a week before Election Day, the Government releases its first estimate of G.D.P. in the July-September period. In advance, economists were expecting at best a modest improvement compared with the second quarter.
"What the numbers show is the economy is not particularly buoyant," Paul Lally of R. H. Wrightson & Associates in New York said. "We're still struggling to get our head above water."
The second-quarter performance followed a moderate increase of 2.9 percent at an annual rate in the first three months. That's considered poor for just after a recession, but it still was the best growth since the early months of the Bush administration.
Behind the slowdown were American consumers, whose spending accounts for roughly two-thirds of all economic activity. Their outlays fell one-tenth of 1 percent in the second quarter after spurting 5.1 percent in the first. The decline included a 2.1 percent drop for durable goods -- big-ticket items such as autos and appliances.
"You can't sustain a recovery without strong consumption," said John M. Albertine, a Washington-based economic consultant.
Business investment in new equipment recorded a large 24.1 percent gain in the second quarter. Business investment in buildings fell at an eight-tenths of 1 percent rate, while spending for housing rose 12.6 percent.
Federal, state and local government spending fell 1.2 percent over all, led by a 5.2 percent drop in military expenditures.
Meanwhile, the Commerce agency said the after-tax profits of United States corporations edged 1.3 percent higher in the second quarter to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $232.7 billion, revised downward from last month's estimate of a 2.1 percent gain.
Still, analysts said profits were in good shape compared with a year ago because the latest advance came on top of a 10.8 percent jump in the first quarter, the best in four years.
The various changes translated into a G.D.P. increase at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $18.7 billion with total G.D.P. standing at a $4.89 trillion, after adjusting for inflation.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Saberhagen Is Eight-Ninths as Impressive as Gooden

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The 1993 starting rotation for the Mets remains an abstraction of blind optimism and genuine uncertainty. There will have to be an addition made, likely from outside the organization. And there will have to be a lot of medical hopes realized.
The concept, though, isn't altogether crazy, and the last two nights have infused the abstraction with an encouraging dose of realism. Barely 24 hours after Dwight Gooden turned in his first complete game of 1992, a 3-2 victory over the Cardinals, Bret Saberhagen calmly and economically posted eight shutout innings in what became a 4-3, 14-inning loss at Busch Stadium. 
 The Cardinals, after being held scoreless for 13 innings, scored four runs in the bottom of the 14th to negate Jeff Kent's three-run homer in the top of the inning.
Saberhagen, whose late-season quest has been more for peace of mind than any enhancement of statistics, pitched with blistering effectiveness. He required only 86 pitches to dispense with the Cardinals, allowing five hits and walking none.
So there could be life and power pitching after David Cone, after all.
"Can I be a quality starter game after game for the Mets next season?" Gooden asked tonight. "Yeah. They can rely on that."
"Myself, Saberhagen, Sid, Schourek, it's a solid four," said Gooden. "We'll need a fifth, and none of the big three will be able to have an off year. We'll have to set the tone."
The tenor of Saberhagen's return after his second setback with a problematic right index finger has heightened and sweetened of late. He started last week againt Montreal, working five capable innings and blowing away enough Expos to rekindle the excitement he had brought to the first third of this season. And tonight, he wasn't overpowering, but he was phenomenally adequate. He could undoubtedly have gone deeper into the game.
 
Aha! A Curveball!
 As for Gooden, his resurgence has been distinguished most intriguingly by his precious bit of discovery in a season of personal turmoil and professional mediocrity. Gooden has found his curveball.
"I can't even tell you the exact moment I felt I had it back," said Gooden. "But it's there, and it's right."
As a result, Gooden feels at least close to whole on the mound. And as a consequence of that, Gooden discovered himself on the field at Busch Stadium Wednesday night, the game over, nine innings on the scoreboard, the baseball still in his hand. It was his first complete game since June 1991.
"He's at the highest point of his season," said Mel Stottlemyre, the pitching coach for the Mets. "The consistency on his fastball is better. His release point is better. Best, the quality of pitches he's making when ahead in the count is much greater. He makes mistakes still, but not nearly as many."
It has been a season of scandal and embarrassment and fear and failure for Gooden.
"It's been worse than 1987," said Gooden, who missed a chunk of that season in rehabilitation for substance abuse. "There was the spring, Darryl's book, the shoulder. Bam, bam, bam."
The personal thumping has been replaced by the crackling of his curveball.
"I'll throw it in any spot now, three, four times in a row," said Gooden. "Early in the season, guys would see it and know I couldn't get it over. It was big and lazy and wild. They started to cheat on my fastball. And that, because of the shoulder, wasn't what it should have been, either."
Fresher, better equipped, Gooden began to last longer, to work easy innings, to humble lineups again. Since Aug. 2, Gooden has gone at least seven innings in seven of his eight starts.
 
INSIDE PITCH
 JOHN FRANCO will fly to Birmingham, Ala., Friday to be examined by Dr. JAMES ANDREWS. The closer for the Mets, who was set to have surgery to repair a damaged tendon in his pitching elbow after a recent diagnosis by the club's doctor, has wanted a second opinion. . . . DWIGHT GOODEN, saying his emotional allegiance was with nephew GARY SHEFFIELD of San Diego, said his baseball mind told him Pittsburgh's BARRY BONDS deserved the National League's most valuable player award. "He's earned every statistic he's got," Gooden said of Bonds. "No one pitches to him."

HEADLINE: Is Enlightened Ice Age Ushering In the 90's?

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
So Wayne Gretzky glides off the ice at about the same time that Manon Rheaume glides on. Is this the coincidence of a superstar's bad back and an expansion team's good publicity, or is it the face-off metaphor of the season? Could it mean that such faded stars as Gretzky, Larry Bird, Magic Johnson, Mike Tyson and Joe Montana will be replaced by someone newer and more interesting? Or could it actually mean that the Gross 80's are over in sports, that an era of explosive growth, traditional heroes and a school for scandal is finally giving way to the Net 90's reckoning over money, sex and morals?
Manon Rheaume became the first woman to play in one of the four major pro sports leagues last Wednesday night, spending a period in goal for the Tampa Bay Lightning in an exhibition game. That ice hockey made the breakthrough is significant; the weakest economically of the four major team sports, it also has the greatest potential to reach out and lure new fans, women as well as men. Meanwhile, there is a curious sense of stagnation among the others. Are they mature industries that have gone as far as they can, or is this just a period of retrenchment before the next leap forward? 
 One needs to be a football fan these days to follow that bouncing ball. The N.F.L. seems to have purged itself of the alkies, glass-eaters and 'roid rangers that once made it clownishly engaging (remember the Boz?), but without Hero Quarterbacks to replace them, it's all 'toons. While Montana, the Last Throwback, is still throwing in practice, it seems increasingly unlikely that his 14th season will happen. Montana, handsome, marketable, a scandal-free team player who performed hurt, was a direct descendant of Joe Namath who proves that everything old becomes new again. NFL Properties has just hired Old Joe as its signal-caller.
After pro basketball declared victory in Operation Olympic Storm (with no collateral damage, Nikes and Reeboks were fired into every country in the world), Bird retired and Magic floated a trial balloon about playing in New York. His confusion (or changing tactics) cooled the passion for Magic. What is he up to? When will he stand up and talk about why his plan to "be a spokesman for the virus" went awry? What happened to the President's Commission? Is Magic quiet because he's got a book coming out (smart publishing money says the Christmas bio sweeps will go to Schwarzkopf) or because of his return to active duty?
(Here's one marker of basketball fandom: At the wonderful SportsBooks store in L.A. several months ago, no one was buying Magic's book on AIDS and there was a run on signed copies of Jim Valvano's autobiography after reports he was undergoing cancer treatment, a logical extension of that Gross 80's symptom, the card show.)
Michael Jordan is still out there, of course, but his one-dimensionality gets old. On court he's a windup toy, off court he's a cardboard cutout to pose with. Time to get interested in Michael again when he joins the pro golf tour, even more when he joins the senior pro golf tour.
Baseball's most interesting 80's characters are not in the game, although former President Nixon is campaigning for Pete Rose's reinstatement on the "forgiveness" platform. That makes sense, but why doesn't he stump for Steinbrenner, too? And George will remember Dick when he triumphantly wades ashore next season. Meanwhile, the demonization of George has its flip side, the deification of Fay Vincent, who seems to have gotten more popular in the media since his dumping; he's shopping his autobiography now.
Baseball's playing heroes, Brett, Ripken, Puckett, are merely splendid players, while the more interesting likes of Jose Canseco, Rob Dibble and David Cone should be tested for testosterone poisoning. Darryl Strawberry will never make it mega; once the greatest prospect in the game, he was brought up too soon, for commercial reasons, and seasoned too fast and hot. Nelson Doubleday should donate his piece of the Mets to a mental health center for baseball players.
Which brings us back to the Only True Sport, ice hockey, secure enough in its manhood to let a woman play. Can you imagine what Adam Graves would do to any opposing player who hit a female teammate of his? The new rule in which wearing helmets is optional may be in preparation for female players.
This is all in refreshing contrast to tonight's show in Las Vegas in which Jimmy Connors, that mouthy momma's boy, plays Martina Navratilova in a retrograde, very 80's attempt to evoke the Bobby Riggs-Billie Jean King match of Sept. 20, 1973, which opened the 70's in sport, the Title IX decade of joyous progress for women stymied in the 80's, which some believe began when Larry Holmes beat Muhammad Ali on Oct. 2, 1980, and ended on June 11, 1992, when Evander Holyfield beat Arnold Schwarzenegger in bowling. Bowling!

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Bush Constitution

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
President Bush's veto of the family leave bill, announced at night to avoid public notice, actually deserves close attention. For it gives us an insight into Mr. Bush's view of what government should do in our society -- his view of politics and the Constitution.
The legislation would require employers of 50 or more people to grant them 12 weeks of unpaid leave for births or family emergencies. He was vetoing it, Mr. Bush's message said, because "we must have flexibility in our workplace to meet the challenge" of foreign economic competition. 
 Most major industrial countries have far more rigorous laws, requiring paid family leave. So Mr. Bush must have meant that, to compete, this country must allow worse working conditions.
But the President went on to make what was really a constitutional point. Policies on family leave, he said, must be "crafted at the workplace and not in Washington D.C."
That opposition to Federal action echoed what Vice President Quayle said on the MacNeil/Lehrer News hour last month. "If you start . . . having the government more involved" in such things as leave policy, he said, "I don't know where it stops. After we get through sick leave, what are you going to do, go to pensions, are you going to go to pay?"
The Federal Government has of course been involved for many years in pay and pensions. Since the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, it has set minimum wages and maximum hours. More recently there has been Federal pension reform legislation.
Could Dan Quayle have been ignorant of all that? Yes, he could. But he and President Bush could also be signaling a new conservative effort to undo Federal rules that protect the workplace.
The idea that the Federal Government should have no role in regulating working conditions would take us back 60 years. It is especially curious when you compare it with another Bush-Quayle proposal: Federal legislation to make radical changes in the country's civil injury law.
Our law on civil injuries (torts) has traditionally been made by state courts and legislatures, not by the Federal Government. The Bush-Quayle proposal would sweep away that tradition. For example, it would impose on all states the British doctrine that the losing party in a lawsuit pays the winner's legal fees.
Mr. Quayle's advisers, wanting something positive for him to do, came up with the idea of "tort reform." He touted the plan as a way to discourage expensive litigation, which he said cost us $300 billion a year. (The Quayle people, when asked, could provide no basis for that figure, which The Economist of London called "simply false." They evidently invented it.)
The real effect of the "reform" is likely to be to hurt ordinary middle-class people who are injured. For the British rule makes it much harder for them to sue when they are the victims of medical malpractice or defective industrial processes.
Consider a man disabled by what he says were toxic chemicals in a plant where he worked. If he sues, the company's lawyers will naturally go all out in its defense, running up big fees. If the disabled employee loses before a jury, he will be ordered to pay those fees. So suing over dangerous working conditions or products would be to gamble on bankruptcy.
It is striking, too, that Mr. Bush takes such a narrow view of what the Federal Government should do at the workplace while favoring a highly intrusive Federal role on sex and reproduction. He wants, and has achieved, Federal rules that deny many women access even to advice on abortion.
What it comes down to is this. In Mr. Bush's view of politics and the Constitution, employees have to win family leave and other rights in free-market bargaining with their employers. The Federal Government has no proper role there, but it should take over tort law and regulate sexual matters in this country.
Perhaps it takes George Bush and Dan Quayle too seriously to see some principle in their position on these issues. In all likelihood they are merely offering excuses to support the interests that support them: corporate employers, tort defendants, the Christian right. But it is important to see their lofty arguments for what they are, and for where they would take us.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Hello Again, Suckers

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
H. Ross Perot, having betrayed and suckered millions of Americans, is giving them one more chance to be betrayed and suckered again.
Before he cut and ran, the most attractive part of the first Ross Perot campaign was the people who believed in him, the volunteers. 
 They did not know much about Mr. Perot. Carefully and skillfully, he avoided telling them much. But they created his image out of their own desires and dreams.
If they had been hateful, if their desires had meant hurting or demeaning others, that could have been frightening. But I never saw a hate-placard. Neither, in conversation and correspondence, did I see or hear the belittling words and code language of the political nasties.
These people had a yearning, shared by so many other Americans, to take our politicians by the shoulder and shake them until they listened.
They did not want to tear America apart. They wanted change forward to new political ideas, but also change back to what they considered America had been and should be -- true, compassionate, clean. That kind of thing.
Sometimes outsiders who were uncertain about their eventual Presidential choice, but were unhappy with both parties, deluded themselves about the Perot movement. They thought that whatever his obvious shortcomings, at least Mr. Perot must share the passion of his followers for political decency and faithfulness.
So Americans gave more grace to him than to other candidates, particularly the grace of time. We kept waiting for Mr. Perot to put proposals and ideas where his ever-busy mouth was. Of course he never did, possessing neither the intellect nor the courage.
He just quit before putting anything on the table. He could not handle what every politician, every adult must handle -- the knowledge that he could not control the world. Sometimes it insists on testing you, questioning, challenging, defying, demanding accounting.
And he knew his advisers and employees were preparing proposals that would do what he had said he wanted -- ask sacrifice from almost all of American society. His bluff was being called.
So he concocted a few phony excuses, quit and ran out.
But he does not even have the class to stay out. After awhile he looked back, figured that he could now run on the political cheap. He would be risking nothing, daring nothing, and he would be getting all that TV time and press attention again. A fellow comes to miss that stuff.
So here he is again -- boasting about that tough economic plan, now a paperback best seller. And here he is again, prattling cynically about how his "volunteer movement" will make the decision about his running.
Both are true only to Mr. Perot's desire to get something for nothing. His economic platform is neither his nor a platform. He never adopted, debated or ran on it when he was a real candidate.
Now he has the exquisite gall to demand that the two legitimate candidates meet or match it. He knows he will never have to face a Congress with those proposals for higher taxes and lower benefits. They will remain safely in paperback.
And he knows that his "volunteer movement" is being manipulated by Dallas professionals and paid signature hunters. Ross Perot will decide finally if Ross Perot runs officially. He will pay no more attention to the desires of the volunteers than the day he deserted them.
The Bush and Clinton people have done nothing braver about Mr. Perot than sidle up to him. What? Upset his followers by telling the truth -- this man is telling you folks to bend over again so he can plant one more boot in your backside?
Obviously Ross Perot will not win. Democrats think the Governor is so far ahead that any defections to Ross Perot won't hurt much. They could be wrong; known to happen.
Mr. Bush could lose enough voters in Texas, Florida or New Jersey to guarantee them to Mr. Clinton. Losing any state to a genuine contender is one thing. Losing states to an in-and-out con man would not only unfairly hurt Mr. Bush but would besmirch American politics.
So listening to Mr. Perot now stirs the same stomach quease as listening to a lecture on moral principles from a defrocked clergyman. It is not only himself he degrades, but the congregation -- and the very words he utters.

HEADLINE: Do Government Rogues Traffic in Drugs?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Why is it that any time there is a voice suggesting there might be a connection between drug trafficking and rogue elements of our Government, there is a powerful one like A. M. Rosenthal's ("Movies, Drugs, Elections," column, Sept. 11) to deny this voice with catch phrases like "left-wing paranoia." 
 Now Mr. Rosenthal may not agree with the character who implies this in my movie "Bob Roberts," but certainly he can't tell me he hasn't heard these words before. If he hasn't, I suggest he read "The Politics of Heroin" by Alfred McCoy and "Acid Dreams: The C.I.A., LSD and the 60's Rebellion" by Martin A. Lee and Bruce Shlain, two exhaustively researched books that show connections between agencies of our Government and the proliferation of drug abuse in our country.
Certainly we need centers on addiction and drug abuse like those proposed by former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Joseph A. Califano, but more important, we need to begin providing a viable economic alternative to the drug business in areas where drug use is so prevalent.
We need tougher investigative journalism to start addressing, in some way, the common knowledge of the streets: that the war on drugs is being waged on the user, not the supplier, and that the war cannot be won because there is no will to find the source.
Mr. Rosenthal may not believe that the source is in any way connected to rogue operatives within Government, but a great many people do, and until he is able to refute these beliefs in more definitive terms than taking cheap shots at movies, people will continue to believe the charge.
Everything in "Bob Roberts" is something I have heard in America, on all sides of the political spectrum. Nothing is proved, there are no definitive answers, only questions raised. These questions might make Mr. Rosenthal uncomfortable, but maybe that is their purpose. It does no good to deny these frustrated, inquisitive voices a forum.
 
TIM ROBBINS
Writer and Director, "Bob Roberts"
New York, Sept. 16, 1992

HEADLINE: Clinton Hits Hard in New Jersey (Close), Relaxes in New York (Ahead)

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RAHWAY, N.J., Sept. 24

 BODY:
About 2,000 people came to hear Gov. Bill Clinton talk about health care at the Merck & Company headquarters here today, and with egalitarian self-interest, each came with a personal agenda for the candidate to address.
Gloria McGinty, a logistics controller at the big pharmaceutical concern, cares for her 84-year-old mother-in-law and she wanted to know if Governor Clinton shared her view that Medicaid coverage is unfair to the ailing elderly who receive home care. Wesley L. Shoop, a parasitologist in the Merck laboratories, was interested in whether the candidate's proposals to control medical costs would suppress pharmaceutical research investments. Charles L. Garay, president of a small air purification products plant on Hazelwood Avenue who is paying $500 a month in health-insurance premiums for his 75 employees, said suppressing medical costs was all he wanted to hear about. 
 They were the kinds of people that the Clinton-Gore campaign wanted to attract when, some time last week, they decided to schedule a major address on health-care issues in northern New Jersey.
It was not lost on local and state Democrats that President Bush made three visits to northern New Jersey since the campaign began, most recently to the Lincoln Technical Institute a few miles away in Union Township. This was Mr. Clinton's second visit, and was intended to counter President Bush's courtship of a state that has not voted Democratic in a Presidential race since Lyndon B. Johnson beat Barry M. Goldwater in 1964.
This time, however, the Democrats can smell a victory in the Garden State. "We are going to win it," declared Chester Holmes, a Rahway Councilman, who was here today.
A Star Ledger/Eagleton Poll taken Sept. 9-16 reported Mr. Clinton leading Mr. Bush 52 to 39 percent among those interviewed who said they were registered voters, a reversal of the candidates' standings in May, when Mr. Bush led by a wide margin.
The State Democratic Party picked Merck for the speech because it is a corporate leader in health-care policy issues, and because it offers "the kind of high-tech jobs Clinton is talking about creating," said Raymond J. Lesniak, a State Senator from Elizabeth and chairman of the State Democratic Committee.
"Little Rock called us and said they wanted to visit North Jersey and that they wanted the Governor to address health-care issues," Mr. Lesniak said, "and between Little Rock and here, we decided that Merck would be a good location, because it's a good company for New Jersey."
 
Inflation Rate Limits Prices
 And, he did not have to add, it has a company chairman, Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, who has long been active in Democratic Party politics, as well as a corporate policy of limiting price increases on most drugs to the rate of inflation, an important element in Mr. Clinton's health plan.
The local politicians were gratified that Governor Clinton invited Gov. Jim Florio, who is in trouble in the state because of his tax increases, to share the platform.
"Governor Clinton is standing by Florio, whatever the Republicans say," said Jon Shure, Mr. Florio's spokesman.
Most of the arrangements appear to have been worked out between the Clinton headquarters in Little Rock, Ark., and Governor Florio's office in Trenton. It was Mr. Florio's office that called the State and Community Relations department at Merck on Tuesday and asked for an invitation, said Kevin Colgan, a Merck spokesman. The speech outline was faxed from Little Rock at 9:23 this morning.
"It generally works this way," Mr. Shure said. "The strategy comes from Little Rock, the message comes from Little Rock and the geography comes from Little Rock. Then the people on the ground work out where is the best place to deliver the message."
 
Universal Health Coverage
 Mr. Clinton's speech stressed the day-to-day problems of Americans struggling with a health care system that he said was delivering inflated costs and reduced insurance. He spelled out his plan for universal health coverage with employer- or government-sponsored insurance. Prices would be controlled by state panels of business and medical experts, and insurance companies would have to take all applicants regardless of their age or health.
Except for some students from Montclair State College who were ejected for interrupting Mr. Clinton's speech by shouting slogans, the only mishap occurred after the speech, when a baby held up by its admiring mother threw up on Mr. Clinton's jacket front.
"That's what babies do," Mr. Clinton said cheerfully.
Mrs. McGinty said she was impressed with his speech: "I was leaning toward Mr. Clinton and I guess I'm leaning a little bit more."
Dr. Shoop, the parasitologist, said: "He came much closer to the middle than I expected. I thought we would hear much more of the 'Government can solve everything/New Deal' kind of thing. I was glad to hear him say that private enterprise has to stay in the center of this issue. But he's got a problem with putting limits on pharmaceutical prices. You can't cut income without hurting research."
But price controls were just what Mr. Garay, the businessman, wanted to hear.
"I'm still open-minded on who I'll vote for," he said, "but I sure like Clinton's platform on controlling medical costs, because that's what's eating up my business."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 29, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about an appearance by Gov. Bill Clinton at the headquarters of Merck & Company in Rahway, N.J., referred imprecisely to an invitation from Merck, which was solicited by the office of Gov. Jim Florio. Mr. Florio's office asked that Merck invite Mr. Clinton to appear, not that Mr. Florio be included.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ross Perot;
BUSH AND CLINTON TO SEND EMISSARIES TO PEROT MEETING

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

 BODY:
Responding to broad hints that Ross Perot will soon re-enter the Presidential race, President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton said yesterday that they would send emissaries to Dallas on Monday to talk to the Texas billionaire's followers. Each group of emissaries will try to convince the gathering that its candidate is the better alternative to a Perot candidacy.
Officials from both the Republican and Democratic campaigns said they had accepted an invitation from Mr. Perot to address a gathering on Monday of state leaders of United We Stand, America, the organization Mr. Perot set up and financed after he quit the Presidential contest on July 16. Mr. Perot will also attend the meetings. 
 Campaigning in Chicago today, Mr. Bush told reporters that he would be sending Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee; Senator Phil Gramm of Texas; Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development; Robert M. Teeter, chairman of the President's re-election committee, and Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser. Mr. Bush's representatives will address the group for two hours starting at 10 A.M. on Monday at a Dallas hotel.
 
Next, the Democrats
 Later that afternoon, the group will hear from the Arkansas Governor's emissaries. They will be Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma; Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; Vernon Jordan, a Washington lawyer and former head of the National Urban League, and Mickey Kantor, chairman of the Clinton campaign.
The meetings will be closed to reporters and will not be taped. Officials with Mr. Perot's group said the audience would comprise one state coordinator from each of the 50 states. It is unclear whether the group will take any votes on whether to endorse either Mr. Bush or Mr. Clinton.
 
Achieving His Goal
 The announcement yesterday by the two major parties that they would take part in the Perot volunteers' meeting further confused a political race that had been blurred all spring by the Texas billionaire's involvement, but had seemed to clarify after he pulled out two months ago. The willingness of the two campaigns to participate seemed to indicate that they had assurances that Mr. Perot's next step was not predetermined.
When he pulled out on the last day of the Democratic National Convention, Mr. Perot said it was less important for him to win the Presidency than it was for him to influence the debate and to make the major parties pay attention to his ideas and his grass-roots organization. The agreement by Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton to send representatives to Dallas makes it clear that Mr. Perot may finally be achieving that goal.
The executive director of the volunteers' group, Orson Swindle, yesterday denied a report in The Los Angeles Times that Mr. Perot would announce he was resuming his bid for the White House on CNN's "Larry King Live" television show Monday night.
"It's not true," Mr. Swindle said. "The unidentified source is truly unidentified and uninformed."
Further complicating a Presidential campaign that has become the most unusual in years and has just over five weeks to go, a top Republican on the Commission on Presidential Debates said yesterday that should Mr. Perot enter the race and the President continue his refusal to participate in debates sponsored by the commission, it is possible a debate might take place without Mr. Bush.
"If Bill Clinton agrees and George Bush doesn't agree, it will be just Clinton and Perot Oct. 4 in San Diego," said Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., former chairman of the Republican National Committee and co-chairman of the five-member, bipartisan debate commission. Mr. Clinton has already accepted the proposed format of having a single moderator. Mr. Bush, saying he would prefer involving a panel of questioners, has so far declined to participate in any commission-sponsored debates.
Mr. Fahrenkopf said that if Mr. Perot announced his candidacy on Monday the commission would determine if he met the criteria to be included in the debate. "If he meets the criteria, we have to invite him," Mr. Fahrenkopf said. "Next week could be an interesting week."
 
Support Put at 90%
 Speculation has been rampant that the mercurial Texan would once again challenge for the Presidency since he said on Tuesday that his decision to drop out of the race was a "mistake." Mr. Perot also said he wanted the state coordinators of his organization to poll their membership to determine if they wanted him to once again pursue the Presidency.
In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Swindle said the group had "been canvassing literally thousands and thousands of people, and 90 percent say they want him to."
But so far, Mr. Perot has given no indication that he actually wants to serve as President, or whether his efforts in recent months to get himself on the ballot and in recent days to inject himself into the campaign are all designed to bend the political process to his and his volunteers' will.
In recent weeks he has said that he may re-enter the race, but only as a means to insure that his campaign commercials are broadcast by the television networks. Federal regulations require television stations to permit political candidates to buy "reasonable" amounts of time for advertising. The regulations also require the stations to sell this time to candidates at the lowest rates paid by commercial advertisers. The stations have no obligation to sell advertising time to private individuals.
"I think he is trying to get the attention of the two parties," said James Squires, who was director of communications for the Perot Petition Committee. "He is saying to them: 'I don't want to do it. Don't make me do it.' "
 
Waning Influence
 Yet, Mr. Perot's flexing of political muscle comes when public opinion polls indicate that his stature has drastically diminished. A CBS News Poll released yesterday indicates that more voters have a negative opinion of Mr. Perot than at any time since he began flirting with the idea of running for President in February.
In the telephone survey of 1,758 registered voters, conducted Tuesday through Thursday, 47 percent said they had a negative view of Mr. Perot, 15 percent said they held him in a favorable light, 20 percent were undecided and 17 percent said they did not know enough to have an opinion. The survey had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Still, the two parties are apparently concerned about the perception that would be created if they refused to meet with a group of ordinary citizens, brought together under Mr. Perot's auspices.
In recent days, Mr. Perot has met with James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, and Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman. In those meetings Mr. Perot extended the invitation for the candidates to send representatives to Dallas to meet with his group.
 
Chance to 'Explain the Deficit'
 When asked why he was allowing Mr. Perot to drag him into a process that is not officially part of a Presidential campaign, Mr. Bush, campaigning in Chicago yesterday, said, "We were invited down to explain the deficit, and any chance we can talk to 50 people, less or more, about our plan for reducing the deficit, which is far better than Governor Clinton's plan for reducing the deficit, why, that's what we want to do."
Mr. Clinton said it was "fine with me" if Mr. Perot runs, and added, "I think he's got a real contribution to make to the country, and if he wants to get back in the race, that's up to him, but I think there are all kinds of ways that he can contribute."
In addition to the television appearance Monday night with Mr. King, Mr. Perot has agreed to appear on the NBC program "Today" on Monday and Tuesday mornings.
Mr. Perot's economic plan, as outlined in his recently published book, "United We Stand," contains a mix of tax increases and spending cuts that could be difficult to sell politically.
It includes increasing the gasoline taxes, raising the marginal income tax rates on the affluent to 33 percent from 31 percent and increasing fees for timber and mining. It also calls for tax increases on Social Security benefits for retired people with incomes of more than $25,000 a year for individuals and $32,000 a year for those filing jointly.

SERBS MAY HAVE KILLED 3,000
The United States has obtained reliable information that as many as 3,000 Muslim men, women and children were killed at Serbian-run detention camps near the Bosnian town of Brcko, officials said. 1

HEADLINE: Court Grants Boy Wish to Select His Parents

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 25

 BODY:
Gregory Kingsley, the determined 12-year-old boy who went to court to change his parents, realized his goal today when a juvenile court judge here ended the parental rights of his natural mother and allowed the boy's foster parents to adopt him.
The ruling by Thomas S. Kirk, a state circuit court judge, is believed to be the first time in which family rights were ended based on a legal action brought by a child. 
 After completing the unusual two-day trial at 7 P.M., Judge Kirk ruled that it was in the boy's best interests to take him from his mother, a 30-year-old unemployed waitress. He then approved the boy's adoption by George H. and Lizabeth Russ, who have been his foster parents since October.
The judge discounted testimony today that the youth's natural mother, Rachel Kingsley, had given up her children to foster care three times in the last few years for economic reasons, and each time had planned to give them up temporarily while she got back on her feet. In fact, Gregory lived with his mother for only seven months in the last eight years.
The judge said that "by clear and convincing evidence, almost beyond a reasonable doubt, the child has been abandoned and neglected by his mother and that it is in his manifest best interest" that Ms. Kingsley's parental rights be terminated so that Gregory can be adopted by the Russes.
Lawyers for Gregory's natural mother, who was not in the courtroom when the verdict was announced, said later that they planned to appeal the judge's decision to Florida's Fifth District Court of Appeals in Daytona Beach.
As soon as the judge ruled, Gregory turned back and smiled at Mrs. Russ. A moment later they hugged. Afterward, his family gave him a baseball cap and shirt embroidered with the number 9 to indicate that he is is their ninth child. When he took the witness stand today, the boy identified himself as Gregory Kingsley, even though the court papers were filed under the name Gregory K.
The New York Times, which usually avoids identifying children in court cases, has not previously published Gregory Kingsley's full name. But protecting his privacy is no longer an issue since his name is being used in court, with some of the proceedings broadcast live. His lawyer, noting that the name has been broadly disseminated, says he is not asking that it be withheld.
 
Bruising Day in Court
 The judge's ruling came after a bruising day in court for Ms. Kingsley, who had been fighting for several months to keep from losing the oldest of her three sons. Despite the testimony of two experts that she had improved her life and could provide a nurturing home for Gregory, Ms. Kinglsey at several moments in the trial was holding back tears or dabbing her eyes as the youth testified that he "did not love her as a mom."
Ms. Kingsley had left the courtroom and was in her lawyer's office when Judge Kirk ruled. "He's always going to be my son," she said at a news conference. "I don't care what anyone says. I just want Gregory to know that I love him very much, and he's always welcome to come back home."
Gregory's natural father, Ralph Kingsley, did not contest the adoption.
During the trial, Gregory was on the stand for more than an hour today, his shoulders just barely rising above the witness stand. Exhibiting a presence and sophistication unusual for a boy his age, the dark-haired sixth grader explained how he had met his foster father during a visit to the youth center where he had been placed.
Gregory said that for almost two years while he was in foster care his mother never visited, called or wrote to him. "I just thought she forgot about me," he said on the stand in an unemotional voice. Later he explained that after he was taken from foster care the first time, his mother had promised him he would never have to go back again. He was placed in foster homes twice after that, and Gregory testified that that was what had changed his feelings about his mother.
 
'She Didn't Care Any More'
 "I just thought she didn't care any more," he said, staring straight at his lawyer, Jerri A. Blair, and not turning to look at his natural mother 20 feet away. "I figured that if she breaks her promise she just doesn't care very much."
Earlier Mr. Russ had taken the stand and was questioned about wanting to adopt Gregory and encouraging the boy to take the route of suing to end his relationship with his natural mother. Mr. Russ said that when he first saw the boy on a visit to the boys shelter in Lake County as a member of a government commission on the needs of children, he noticed Gregory sitting by himself and could not get him out of his mind.
Mr. Russ said Gregory reminded him of his own younger brother, who had been in the care of their father, an alcoholic, after their mother died when he was 11. Mr. Russ, who was 23 at the time, said he had stolen his brother away and taken him to live with a sister rather than leave him with a father who would not take care of him.
After the trial, Mr. Russ said, "Let the law protect real families, not families in name only."
Mr. Russ's wife, Lizabeth, said on the stand that she feels sorry for Ms. Kingsley because she understood that the woman had been a victim of neglect as a child.
"I can't but feel that if she had a different childhood she'd be a different mother and this wouldn't be happening to her," Mrs. Russ said.
A number of witnesses appeared today to vouch for Ms. Kingsley's recent attempts to turn her life around. Among them was her father, Jimmy Maxwell Sutton, of Laurie, Mo., who said that after his first wife died when Rachel was 9 years old, she had helped him raise his other children.
Mr. Sutton's gravelly voice quivered at one point when he said he thought that his daughter deserved a break.
"She's had enough abuse, you know?" he said from the witness stand. "She's a victim of abuse here too." He said he believed the legal system had failed to protect his daughter's rights.
Even during the most intimate and disturbing testimony, Gregory seemed to remain in good spirits. He could often be seen playing a a hand-held electronic game. He and his foster sisters exchanged hard candy and after a break he returned to the courtroom drinking Mountain Dew.
A stark difference was apparent between Gregory and one of Ms. Kinglsey's other children, 11-year-old Jeremiah, who still lives with her. In contrast to Gregory's cool and easy-going manner, Jeremiah, appeared awkward and uncomfortable. Wearing a white suit whose sleeves were too short, he raised his left hand when Judge Kirk asked him to raise his right hand.
Jeremiah has been undergoing counseling and medical treatment for medical and emotional disorders.
Gregory's case has drawn widespread attention. Mr. Russ said that 15 television and movie producers had called him, and that an independent lawyer would handle those negotiations. Mr. Russ, a lawyer who represented himself in the trial, said he had talked to Gregory about taking the unusual step of seeking the right to sue because he feared that the state might take Gregory out of the Russ home if Mr. Russ had sued in his own name.
At the time, the state planned to reunite Gregory with his mother. Since then, the state has changed position and favored adoption by the Russes.

HEADLINE: Durables Orders Fell In August

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
New orders for durable goods fell in August, the third drop in four months, the Commerce Department said today, reflecting a surprising degree of business caution and arousing fresh doubts about economic recovery.
The one-tenth of 1 percent decline was considerably more serious than it appeared, analysts said, not only because they had expected a rebound from July's sizable drop but also because of its widespread nature and the fact that orders sank 3.7 percent when military equipment was excluded. 
 While airplanes and tanks generate real jobs and income, purchases of them result from political and national-security considerations rather than economic ones.
 
A 'Discomfort Quotient' Rises
 "My discomfort quotient has gone up," said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for Northern Trust Company. The Commerce Department's report "is just full of negatives."
Traders also perceived the report as negative, with stock prices suffering. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 37.55 points, to 3,250.32, extending its loss for the week to 76.73 points. But the negative news was positive for the bond market, which rose sharply. [Page 41.]
Figures the National Association of Realtors published today showed that sales of existing homes slipped 3.2 percent, to an annual pace of 3.34 million, last month despite the lowest mortgage rates since the early 1970's.
And another set of Commerce Department figures showed that personal income slumped one-half of 1 percent in August as the effects of Hurricane Andrew more than offset what would otherwise have been a rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent. Personal spending eased one-tenth of 1 percent.
 
Speculation of Fed Cut
 Mainly because of the decline in orders for durable goods -- a category of goods intended to last at least three years and including products as varied as videocassette recorders and jet engines -- speculation intensified that the Federal Reserve would decide to cut interest rates yet again.
Some analysts, in fact, did not rule out the possibility of a cut before next Friday's eagerly awaited report on the September job market, the final tally before Election Day. If the Fed does provide another dose of monetary stimulus, many analysts predict it would consist of a one-half-point cut in its discount rate and a quarter-point- cut in Federal funds, the overnight lending rate among commercial banks. Both now stand at 3 percent.
This, in turn, would almost certainly drive down the banks' prime lending rate, stuck at 6 percent since early summer.
Today's figures suggest "a very modest, lackluster recovery," said Roger M. Kubarych of Henry Kaufman & Company. "There's no sector that's leading the way," he added, pointing to one private survey of 30 industries that showed only a handful planning to raise investment by more than 5 percent in the year ahead.
The figures on durable goods showed not only weak orders last month but also a 1 percent drop in shipments and an eight-tenths of 1 percent drop in unfilled orders.
Like new orders, the fall in shipments was the third in the latest four months, while the decline in backlogs, a predictive indicator, was the 12th in a row.
 
A Terse Assessment
 "Bad," said Samuel D. Kahan of Fuju Bank, when asked to characterize the report. He said he did not think the economy was slipping back into recession, whose end most analysts still suggest will be placed in 1991, but he said there was no longer any margin for error.
"We are vulnerable to a shock," Mr. Kahan said, such as a default, a run on the dollar or a political development.
Orders for electronic equipment fell 4 percent in August while declines amounted to 1.4 percent in primary metals and six-tenths of 1 percent for industrial machinery and equipment. Transportation equipment jumped 4.2 percent, but this regained only about one-third of July's decline.
For military orders, a relatively small segment, the advance was 16.7 percent following a 21.5 percent skid in July.
New orders in capital goods industries slumped four-tenths of 1 percent over-all but dropped 2.9 percent for nonmilitary business excluding aircraft and parts.
Total orders for July were revised to show a somewhat lesser decline -- 2.7 percent instead of the 3.4 percent initially reported. The August total was $119.7 billion, down from $119.8 billion, the department found.
The consensus economic forecast had been for a 1.6 percent increase in August, and the small decline was considered a bad sign for employment at factories, business investment and economic growth generally.
Durable goods looked strong at the start of the year, but they faded after April. The lack of growth in orders has kept manufacturers from hiring, and the poor job market, in turn, has made consumers cautious about buying the big-ticket items that make up the durable-goods report.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Vetoes Abortion Bill And Backs Federal Pay Cut

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 25

 BODY:
President Bush announced two legislative actions this evening, vetoing a bill that would have permitted abortion counseling in federally financed clinics and asking Congress to approve a pay cut for the highest paid Federal employees, including the President.
The legislative documents were hurriedly issued by the White House press office as the President was preparing to leave here after a day of campaigning. Both announcements were made after the network news programs had already been prepared. The hour of disclosure assured that they would receive minimum press exposure, but in each case it was for a different reason. 
 In the case of the veto, the President was rejecting a bill that would lift the so-called "gag rule," which prohibits physicians and other workers in clinics that receive Federal money from counseling patients about the availability of abortions.
It was the second time this week that Mr. Bush had issued a veto on a difficult political issue in the evening. Last Tuesday he vetoed a bill after 9 P.M. that would have required employers to provide medical and personal emergency leaves.
 
'Symbol of Our Understanding'
 In the case of the pay cut proposal, the White House seemed eager to attract as little attention as possible to the proposed legislation. Mr. Bush had initially vowed in a campaign speech to carry out the pay cut on his own, as an executive action. But the White House later discovered to its chagrin that he did not have the legal authority to do that.
Although the White House announcement said the pay cut would be "a symbol of our understanding of the concerns of so many Americans," the President sent the proposal to Congress with the knowledge that it would not receive any action before the election, and in any case would only apply to the next Administration, whether Mr. Bush's or that of his challenger, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
Earlier today, Mr. Bush said Democrats were captives of the "government elite" and preoccupied with playing by a set of old rules, and he charged that Mr. Clinton's policies would cripple business competition.
Speaking to employees at the suburban headquarters of the Motorola Corporation and to a conference of executives involved in the research and development of high technology, Mr. Bush made an edgy and defensive assault on Mr. Clinton, who he said failed to promote new business approaches as Governor of Arkansas.
Mr. Bush said that Mr. Clinton had failed to improve his state's education system, was indecisive on major issues and that even his best intentions would be stunted by "pork-happy partisans" in Congress.
"He and his advisers talk about industrial policies, economic plans designed by a government elite," he told the Motorola conference in Schaumburg. "And the planners dictate the terms, pick winners. If you're lucky, they let the private sector have a piece of the action. And all of it is paid for with new tax dollars from the middle class."
The President's criticism of Mr. Clinton's record on education -- an issue on which he has praised the Governor in the past -- was a departure for Mr. Bush. "Three-quarters of Arkansas's high school graduates needed remedial education when they get to college," Mr. Bush said. "And so it's off for him to talk about high tech when the residents of his state have to worry about getting out of high school."
The Clinton campaign immediately dismissed Mr. Bush's remarks. George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director, cited the endorsements Mr. Clinton has received from 400 corporate executives.
"If Bill Clinton's so bad for the high-tech industry, why are all the leading high-tech companies supporting him?" he said.

HEADLINE: Kohl Says Monetary Line Aids Unity

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl today rejected attempts to blame German economic and monetary policy for the recent turmoil on European currency markets and said he would press for rapid political and economic union in the European Community.
"Germany is our fatherland; Europe is our future," Mr. Kohl told the German Parliament. His remarks only obliquely acknowledged the concern about being overwhelmed by Germany that underlay much of the opposition to the treaty on European Community monetary and political union, which was narrowly supported in a referendum in France on Sunday. 
 Instead, he insisted almost defiantly that Germans had been good Europeans even by keeping their currency so strong that Britain and Italy were forced to suspend participation in the European Monetary System.
Mr. Kohl had many warm words for France, especially for the referendum's endorsement of the treaty on European union agreed to in the Dutch city of Maastricht in December, and his speech seemed bound to encourage speculation that a mini-union with France and Germany at its core might emerge if the larger proposal fails.
"The current problems," he said about the monetary turmoil, stemmed from "divergent economic developments among member states that have arisen over the long term."
 
'Stability Policy' Defended
 "One-sided accusations of responsibility are beside the point," he said. "The events of the past weeks were not the result of German stability policy. To the contrary, stability policy is the essential basis for confidence in the currency markets and for orderly currency relationships."
"Stability policy," in Germany, means a policy aimed at keeping inflation down, and it is the reason the independent German central bank has kept interest rates high even though Britain and the United States are pleading for lower ones.
The central bank's primary responsibility, Mr. Kohl said, "is and remains that of assuring the soundness of the currency in Germany," and his Government supported that goal.
But the leader of the Social Democratic opposition, Bjorn Engholm, said Mr. Kohl's Government was really to blame because the high interest rates would not have been necessary if the Government had correctly calculated the cost of German reunification. When these costs soared, the Government was forced into heavy deficit spending, and the inflationary tendencies of the deficit led the central bank to boost interest rates as a countermeasure.
 
Approval Seen This Year
 Mr. Kohl repeated his pledge that the German Parliament will ratify the treaty by the end of the year. "If we all do not now exploit the opportunity offered by the Maastricht treaty, the community will be set back by many years," he said. Under terms of the treaty, all 12 members of the European Community must ratify it either in their parliaments or by national referendum before it can take effect.
Just as Germany seized the moment in 1989 and 1990 and achieved unification, he said, Europe now had to push ahead. "Waiting would be the wrong answer, and standing still would be a step backwards," he said.
The Chancellor acknowledged that all European leaders would have to do more to make clear that in a united Europe, individual nations, regions and even cities would retain their own identities and control their own political future. The European Community's bureaucracy in Brussels would make only those decisions that could not be made more effectively at a lower level, he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Germany is our fatherland; Europe is our future," Chancellor Helmut Kohl, center, said yesterday in an address to Parliament about the Maastricht treaty. He met with Friedrich Bohl, left, the Chancellery Minister, and Peter Struck of the Social Democratic faction before the session in Bonn. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: California Governor, in Reversal, Signs a Bill on Gay Rights in Jobs

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25

 BODY:
At a time when the debate over gay rights looms large in national politics, Gov. Pete Wilson signed into law today a measure that protects homosexuals against job discrimination.
The action by the Republican Governor, a year after he vetoed a similar bill, comes while other prominent Republicans are casting homosexuals as enemies of traditional family values. In the current climate, gay groups up and down the state were braced for another veto from Mr. Wilson and had mobilized for demonstrations this weekend, which will now be recast as celebrations. 
 The measure bans job-related discrimination based on sexual orientation for virtually all state and private workers, as last year's bill would have. It exempts religious organizations and businesses with fewer than five employees, and there is some confusion over whether teachers are covered or whether the state education code already protects them.
The measure departs from last year's by using a different administrative enforcement procedure, which Mr. Wilson said would be less burdensome to a business community staggered by recession.
 
Pessimism Reached Full Boil
 The pessimism of gay-rights advocates reached full boil during last month's Republican convention in Houston, when the podium rang with denouncements of homosexuals and the gay-rights movement. In addition, Oregon voters are considering a ballot measure that would classify homosexuality as "abnormal" and "perverse," and the House of Representatives on Thursday gutted a District of Columbia law that would have allowed city workers to obtain health benefits for their partners, of whatever sex.
But there have also been steps this week in the opposite direction. On Thursday, Gov. William Weld of Massachusetts granted gay state employees the same spousal bereavement rights as heterosexual couples and gave gay couples visitation rights in prisons and state hospitals. The Kentucky Supreme Court struck down the state's anti-sodomy law, ruling that it violated the constitutional privacy rights of homosexuals.
Many gay-rights advocates said those actions combined with Governor Wilson's surprise signature of the employment-protection bill are signs that the tide may be turning in their favor.
"I'm very optimistic," said Thomas B. Stoddard, a prominent gay-rights lawyer and former executive director of the Lamba Legal Defense and Education Fund in New York City. "This development, in combination with yesterday's developments, in combination with the political signs that the Republicans are throwing aside the family values message, suggests that the gay rights movement has finally tipped the scales."
His sentiments were echoed by David Smith, a spokesman for the Gay and Lesbian Community Services Center in Los Angeles, organizer of tonight's celebration there. "The prime-time gay bashing in Houston sent shock waves across our community," Mr. Smith said. "It looked like the religious right was poised to take over the leadership of the country. But this indicates there's hope. It looks like they have not infiltrated the Republican Party to the extent we had thought."
The reaction to Governor Wilson's action today was equally impassioned among conservative lobbyists. The Rev. Lou Sheldon, chairman of the Traditional Values Coalition in Anaheim, said in a telephone interview that Mr. Wilson had "opened the door for all kinds of special rights for perverted, sexually-addicted people." The measure, Rev. Shelton added, would "protect sex with animals and the rape of children as forms of political expression."
With Governor Wilson's signature, California becomes the seventh state, and by far the largest, to add sexual orientation to laws barring job discrimination. The other states are Wisconsin, Massachusetts, Hawaii, Connecticut, Vermont and New Jersey.
Many cities and localities have also passed such legislation, including New York City, which until today was the most populous jurisdiction in the nation with such protections.
The bill that Mr. Wilson signed, sponsored by Assemblyman Terry B. Friedman, a Los Angeles Democrat, is similar to last year's vetoed measure but has modifications aimed at addressing the objections posed by the Governor in that earlier veto message.
Last year's veto set off weeks of angry demonstrations in Los Angeles and Sacramento and near-riots in San Francisco, where protesters set fires and smashed windows at a state office building and caused $250,000 in damage.
The bill differs from last year's measure in its administrative remedy; it chooses a civil rather than a criminal approach. The original bill would have considered complaints under the state's Fair Employment and Housing Act, which metes out criminal penalties. The new bill instead processes complaints under the state labor code, which carries civil penalties.
Using the labor code to protect gay workers became possible after a state appellate court ruling last year. After that ruling, Governor Wilson directed the state labor commissioner to begin hearing complaints about discrimination based on sexual orientation. More than 70 have been adjudicated already, with all manner of outcome. The bill signed today codifies the recent court ruling, makes hundreds of thousands of people aware of their rights and is sure to inspire more widespread complaints.
Mr. Wilson and the California Chamber of Commerce say the civil remedy is prompt, efficient and less likely to lead to costly litigation. The bill's sponsor, Assemblyman Friedman, made the change agreeably and said he thought the new enforcement mechanism would be as effective as the one originally proposed.
Mr. Wilson's chief spokesman, Dan Schnur, insisted today that the Governor used "no political considerations whatsoever" in deciding to sign the measure, the same posture he took last year when Mr. Wilson was accused of vetoing the bill to avoid offending conservative Republicans.
But Mr. Wilson signed the bill against the backdrop of his recent jousting with the right wing of his party. Conservatives defied the Governor last weekend by adopting a strict anti-abortion plank at the state convention. Like President Bush, Mr. Wilson often appears trapped between the moderate and the extreme right in the Republican camp.
"Wilson is in the same position as Bush," said Bruce Cain, associate director of the Institute of Governmental Studies at the University of California at Berkeley. "If the conservatives stay home in the next election he is in trouble. He has got to keep them in his camp, but he can't let them define him." Mr. Cain added that "the balancing act between losing the right and keeping the people in the middle" can be a dizzying one, likely to produce clumsy "lurches" from one end of the political spectrum to the other.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
New orders for durable goods fell in August, the third drop in four months. The unexpected decline of one-tenth of 1 percent raised fresh doubts about economic recovery. Also, the National Association of Realtors said that sales of existing homes slipped 3.2 percent, despite the lowest mortgage rates in 20 years. [Page 33.]
Personal income slumped one-half of 1 percent in August to a seasonally adjusted rate of $5.03 trillion, the worst drop in 19 months, as the effects of Hurricane Andrew more than offset what would otherwise have been a rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent. [38.]
The Senate voted overwhelmingly against President Bush's proposal to permit taxpayers to earmark up to 10 percent of their income tax payment to reducing the national debt. [33.]
 
 International
The Japanese yen is emerging as perhaps the world's strongest major currency, at roughly 120 to the dollar, which could hurt Japan's already weakened automobile and electronics giants. [33.]
France and Germany appeared to have won their battle against currency speculators, at least for now, maintaining the franc's value and salvaging Europe's monetary system. [33.]
 
Markets
The Dow industrials plunged 37.55 points, or 1.1 percent, to 3,250.32 on renewed concerns that economic weakness would hurt third-quarter earnings. For the week, the Dow was down 76.73. [41.]
Treasury bond prices rose sharply as the durable-goods and personal-income reports led some traders to conclude the Federal Reserve might push interest rates down further. [41.]
Lawmakers are rushing to get a compromise futures markets bill onto the floor before Congress adjourns next week. [42.]
Natural gas futures prices rose modestly after a day of seesaw trading at the end of a wild week. [42.]
 
Companies
The U.A.W. struck G.M. in Lansing, Mich., where the popular Pontiac Grand Am and other models are built, complaining that laborers are overworked. But G.M. takes 39 hours to make a car, compared with 22 for Ford, an analyst said. [33.]
Lechters hopes to become the Gap of housewares by selling at lower prices than specialty chains like Williams-Sonoma. The Harrison, N.J.-based chain has 455 stores in 37 states and is expanding aggressively in the New York City area. [34.]
GlenFed is fighting for its life. The owner of Glendale Federal, the nation's fifth-largest savings and loan association, is trying to wring profits out of its 200-plus branches by cutting costs and making less risky mortgage loans, while bargaining with regulators for enough time to put its house in order. [34.]
Bell Sports has its eye on Europe's bare-headed cyclists. The leading American maker of bicycle helmets estimates that only 5 percent of Europe's 105 million riders wear helmets, compared with 20 percent of America's 93 million riders. [34.]
 
Today's Columns
Employee stock ownership plans can solve several problems at once for privately owned businesses, while minimizing taxes for the families who own them, Deborah P. Baker, a Chemical Bank vice president says. Jan M. Rosen: Your Money. [35.]
Tiny bubbles of hardened gelatin that can store delicate proteins, viruses and even living cells without destroying them could ease administering many new drugs, say a team of university scientists who invented them. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [35.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Clinton Says He's Not Leaning Left but Taking a New 'Third Way'

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Seeking to counter this week's Republican offensive portraying him as a leftist, tax-mad, big-government liberal, Bill Clinton today began an effort to once more position himself as a "third way" Democrat, neither of the left nor the right.
At the same time, the Democratic Presidential nominee sought to turn President Bush's attack against him, depicting his opponent as a "do-nothing" President who is "out of touch, out of ideas and out of time," and who clings to the "stale, failed rhetoric of the past." 
 Mr. Clinton introduced his new defense in a noontime address that was almost preachily earnest to a small crowd of invited guests at the University of Connecticut at Hartford, in West Hartford. He echoed it, in a looser fashion, before a passionate, mostly young crowd of more than 10,000 people packed shoulder-to-shoulder near the historic Faneuil Hall here.
 
'A Can-Do Country'
 "You cannot permit this election to be about false choices from America's past, about the same old categories, the same old boxes we try to put people in," Mr. Clinton said in West Hartford. "We are living in a new world, at the end of the cold war, and we have new challenges and new opportunities and we had better seize them, and we had better be willing to park all this aimless hot-air rhetoric at the door and deal with the people's problems and the people's agenda.
"I think this is a can-do country," he continued. "This should not be an election about the stale, failed political rhetoric of the past. If we let this be about tax and spend and trickle-down, we ought to be ashamed of ourselves. This is about whether we have the courage to face up to the realities of modern life."
In truth, Mr. Clinton evinces no shame in discussing the Republicans' theory of trickle-down economics, which he mocks in most speeches. But his distaste for the words "tax and spend" is both profound and well-founded; the charge of liberalism, if it sticks, can be fatal to a Democrat seeking the White House.
Ever since the lesson of his first, and last, gubernatorial defeat Mr. Clinton has positioned himself as a centrist, and the idea of third-way politics is at the heart of his vision of himself and of a resurgent Democratic Party. For years, the Arkansas Governor has been an active player in the somewhat vaguely defined school of policy and politics that seeks to escape the left-right boundaries formed 60 years ago.
But, since winning his party's Presidential nomination, Mr. Clinton has often slighted discussion of this aspect of himself in favor of more direct and more traditional appeals to Democratic core groups. The candidate's public persona remains vague, and his true beliefs are not clearly understood by many voters.
Now Mr. Bush is seeking to take advantage of this with a negative campaign designed to portray Mr. Clinton as liberal to the point of vaguely socialistic radicalism and as a fiend for tax increases.
Clinton campaign officials said they decided it was imperative that the candidate directly and forcefully address Mr. Bush's attacks, and he did, in a speech that top operatives worked on over several days, only to have Mr. Clinton rewrite it this morning.
"George Bush says there is a Grand Canyon between us, and in that he is certainly right," the Governor said. "There is a gap between his economic policies and mine, between his philosophy and mine, and in fairness there is also a gap between his rhetoric and reality, most importantly the reality of what I have advocated as opposed to what he says I have advocated."
Mr. Clinton, who often but subtly plays generational politics, repeatedly spoke of Mr. Bush in terms that suggested the President was old and tired and that his view of the world belonged to an era that was over.
On the central issues of taxing and spending, Mr. Clinton -- who has, in fact, proposed government programs that would entail increases in both spending and taxes -- took pains to distance himself from that aspect of his party's reputation. "I know the Democratic Party in Washington has been in the past too identified with tax and spend, big government," he said. "But I have worked hard to be a different kind of Democrat and to give the people a different kind of Democratic Party."
