HEADLINE: Senate Rejects Bush's Plan On Debt-Reduction Checkoff

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
After a debate colored by Presidential politics, the Senate voted overwhelmingly today to kill a campaign proposal offered by President Bush to permit taxpayers to earmark up to 10 percent of their income tax payment to reducing the national debt.
The measure, introduced by Senator Bob Smith, Republican of New Hampshire, was one of a medley of amendments offered today to a $31 billion tax bill moving through the Senate. The Smith amendment would have mandated that Federal spending be slashed by the same amount as the total debt payments designated by taxpayers. 
 The amendment was defeated in a procedural vote of 58 to 36, largely along party lines.
In a second defeat for the Administration, the Senate killed a Republican amendment striking a provision from the package that would have permanently extended two tax increases for wealthy taxpayers established in the 1990 budget agreement. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said the President would now be forced to veto the tax package unless his proposal was accepted by a Senate-House conference.
Through the day, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, and other Democratic leaders worked hard to limit additions to the tax package. The Senate bill would expand the deductibility of individual retirement accounts, slash luxury taxes on expensive goods, provide a tax credit to first-time home buyers, offer a write-off for intangible assets acquired in company takeovers, and create enterprise zones, where business people would receive tax incentives to invest in poor neighborhoods.
The tax bill was originally intended to respond to the kind of urban decay that led to rioting in Los Angeles in April, but it has since gotten bogged down by Presidential politics. President Bush has said he would like to sign the bill if it does not raise taxes.
The White House asked Mr. Smith to introduce the tax-form write-off proposal, which Mr. Bush offered at the Republican National Convention in an acceptance speech that was intended to project a vision of the economic policy he would pursue if re-elected. The vote demonstrated that Mr. Bush will need a Republican Congress to pass his economic program in a second term, a prospect that even Republican strategists say is remote, at best.
In a speech laden with criticism of the Democratic ticket headed by Gov. Bill Clinton, Mr. Smith said today, "The American people deserve a chance to show that they are willing to make the sacrifices necessary."
He added: "I would just say to Mr. Clinton, 'Why don't you let the American people decide whether or not the plan will work?' "
Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, said the amendment would empower taxpayers who are demanding that Washington cut the deficit. "That's why we have Ross Perot," he added.
In a response punctuated by tragic tales from Greek mythology and dripping with sarcasm, Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, said: "This amendment sounds like a silver bullet, but it's really a poison pill. In reality, its a potion that will taste like honey, but it's a trick. There is no magic herb to guard against its bewitching powers."
He said the permanent spending cuts required by the amendment might eliminate the national debt in 17 years, but would create "massive hemorrhaging" in vital services.
"There would be no spending left," he added. "There would be no Army, no Navy, no Air Force. There would be no law enforcement. All Federal prisoners would have to be let out."
The Internal Revenue Service had said the proposal offered no major administrative difficulties, but earlier this year a Treasury official testified before a House committee that proposals for tax-form checkoffs would have little effect on the debt.
The future of the bill is much in doubt, in large part because it has become enmeshed in the campaign debate on taxes. Mr. Bush's admission that he was mistaken in agreeing to raise taxes in the 1990 budget agreement has hardened Republican opposition to the permanent extension of two tax increases for upper-income taxpayers. The increases were established in that compromise.
Mr. Dole proposed an amendment to strike from the tax package provisions limiting itemized deductions and gradually discontinuing personal exemptions for the wealthy, as well as a provision decreasing the number of proposed enterprise zones to 30, from 125. The measure was defeated by a vote of 59 to 34.
Mr. Bentsen, the principal proponent of the tax package, said the tax extensions were required to finance the re-establishment of tax deductibility of I.R.A.'s for higher-income taxpayers, and other expansions of the accounts. Those changes would cost the Treasury $6.2 billion over the next five years. Mr. Bentsen accused Mr. Dole and the Administration of seeking a tax cut for the wealthiest 3 percent of taxpayers.
"This is a way to show your constituents that you're against tax increases," Mr. Dole said. "As is often the case with taxes, once they've got them, the Democrats are loath to let them go."
Senators Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, tried to highlight the needs of cities by presenting an amendment to provide $500 million in additional financing for Head Start and other law enforcement, employment and health programs, 60 percent of which would be aimed at areas designated for special investment-tax breaks.
"We're talking about making these enterprise zones strong enough so they can really turn things around," Mr. Riegle said. The measure was approved by voice vote.
The House has passed a far more modest tax bill, providing fewer enterprise zones and modest capital gains tax breaks that are not included in the Senate version. Congressional aides express growing doubts that the Senate can pass its bill, work out a compromise in a House-Senate Conference Committee, and send a final version acceptable to President Bush by the first week in October, the time the lawmakers hope to adjourn.

HEADLINE: A Strained Relationship: Congress and the Capital

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
On Thursday evening, Congress voted to force the District of Columbia to hold a citywide referendum on the death penalty.
Six hours earlier, the lawmakers defeated a measure to provide financing for a District law that would enable unmarried city workers, including homosexual couples, to obtain health insurance covering their partners. 
 For some members of Congress and District officials, the two actions are a sign of a deterioration in the volatile relationship between Congress and the District. Some members of Congress argue that Congress has a paternalistic attitude tinged with racism toward a city with a black majority, and that it minimizes the competence of the District's government.
Eleanor Holmes Norton, the District's nonvoting delegate in Congress, who strongly opposed both Congressional moves, said there was a strain between Capitol Hill and the District government "caused essentially by one factor: the homicide rate." She noted that other cities have high homicide rates, but "they are not the cities where the members of Congress live."
 
Some Signs of Warmth
 But others, on both sides of the issue, said the election last year of Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly to succeed Marion Barry led to a rapprochement between the district and the Congress, and the first increase in Federal funds in five years. And Southern politicians no longer headed the crucial Congressional committees, which no longer review every jot and tittle of the district's budget. Indeed, the key House chairman, Julian Dixon, a Democrat of Los Angeles, is a former chairman of the Congressional black caucus.
"The District of Columbia had a setback this week, but I think that the Mayor still has good relationships with Congress," said Mr. Dixon, chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee for the district. "I don't look for any lasting damage in the relationship."
But Thursday's vote on the death penalty indicated increased tensions between Congress and the district as members of Congress have become increasingly concerned about the high incidence of crime in the neighborhood around Capitol Hill.
Their aides have been robbed and some murdered going to and from their jobs, and their homes have been burglarized. The death penalty measure was introduced by Senator Richard Shelby, Alabama Democrat, whose aide Tom Barnes was among the murder victims. "Tom's death was the catalyst for my involvement in trying to find solutions to the violent crime that plagues our city," he said.
District officials themselves were in the process of putting it on the ballot in November, and the sponsors of the measure believe that it will be adopted.
The members also were caught up in election year concerns that their opponents could portray them as soft on crime and family values. "We could visualize those 30-second television spots," said Representative Leon E. Panetta, who has strongly supported home rule for the District of Columbia but who voted for the measure.
Representative Dean A. Gallo, New Jersey Republican and sponsor of the death penalty measure, said, "We're dealing with something that touches more than the district," Mr. Gallo said. "There are 435 House members, who are touched by this problem."
To combat crime on Capitol Hill, Ms. Norton sponsored a bill to expand the jurisdiction of the Capitol Police to include more of the neighborhood around the Capitol. That measure also was approved Thursday.
As for the unmarried couples bill, she said: "That was exclusively an election-year problem. That had come up in the House three times, and passed each time."
The vote on the death penalty posed a special problem for Mr. Panetta. "I really think the District of Columbia ought to handle its own affairs," he said in an interview. "But crime continues to be a very serious problem in the district. Part of it is the urban crisis that is part of every city's social and economic problems. But I don't get the sense that the district has a strong commitment to confront this issue.
"There was a period of increasing hope that the district could manage its own affairs. But the travails of Marion Barry and the deterioration of services have added to concerns about the ability of the city to respond."
Mayor Kelly pointed the finger directly at Congress. She noted that Congress, responding to the White House's directive, had reneged on a $26 million payment that had been earmarked to fight crime. "At the same time the Congress postures about crime and attempts to force feed the District a death penalty, it removes the prevention funds and programs from our budget designed to effectively combat the problem," she said.
Representative Ronald V. Dellums, a liberal Democrat from Oakland, Calif., called Congressional intervention in the district's affairs "the ultimate act of cowardice."
Representative Maxine Waters, a liberal Democrat of Los Angeles, discerned racism in Congress's treatment of the district. "Congress really has an attitude about the District of Columbia that lingers despite the fact that they have very competent members of their City Council," she said. "Congress has little respect for people of color."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly of Washington speaking at a rally yesterday to protest Congress's interference in the District. (Lisa Berg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall 37.55 on Economic Fears

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Stock prices tumbled yesterday on renewed concerns that continued economic weakness would hurt third-quarter earnings.
On the New York Stock Exchange, the 30 issues that make up the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average fell by 37.55 points, or 1.1 percent, to 3,250.32. For the week, the Dow was down 76.73. 
 Broader indexes also posted big declines. The Standard & Poor's 500 fell by 4.12, to 414.35, while the Russell 2,000 index dropped by 2.03, to 190.90. Volume on the Big Board was a moderately heavy 213.7 million shares, up from 188 million on Thursday.
Prices on the American and Nasdaq markets also fell.
Fears about the economy were underscored by weaker-than-expected reports on durable goods orders and consumption, both released before the market opened.
 
Worries on Economy
 The reports "increase the likelihood the Federal Reserve will ease monetary policy again," said Robert Wallburg, a stock market analyst at MMS International, "but the market chose to look on them as saying we may not be coming out of recession."
Aside from worries about the economy and earnings, stock traders and analysts said uncertainties surrounding the Presidential election continued to prey on investors.
"A month ago, the market wasn't sure that Clinton would really win," said Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist at the Kemper Securities Group. "Now it looks like we may have a new President with a new agenda. And the fact that Perot may get back in the race adds another element of uncertainty."
Mr. Wallburg added that while "Perot has no chance of winning, until we can tell who his entry favors that is another reason for investors to move to the sidelines."
 
A 33-Point Plunge
 Pharmaceutical and health care stocks were pounded, pushed lower initially after Medical Care America said it did not expect any growth in third-quarter earnings because of restructuring and merger costs, an announcement that ultimately pushed down the price of the company's shares by more than 50 percent. The stock closed at 25, down 33 points on the day.
Medical Care America was created two weeks ago when Medical Care International and Critical Care America merged.
Recent newspaper articles highlighting economic and policy pressures in the drug and health care businesses also helped push prices lower.
Among other drug and health care stocks, United Healthcare fell by 3 7/8, to 47 7/8. Johnson & Johnson slipped by 2 7/8, to 47 5/8. And Merck's stock fell by 1 7/8, to 43 3/4.
Cyclical issues like automotive stocks and conglomerates also took a beating. Ford Motor closed at 38 3/4, down 1 5/8, while General Motors shares fell by 1 1/8, to 32. Allied-Signal closed at 53 1/8, down 1 3/8, while United Technologies dipped by 3/8, to 48 1/8.
Chubb posted the session's biggest gain, as its stock rose by 3 1/4, to 82 1/2. Other big gainers included Loews, up 2 3/4, to 120 1/4, and FMC, whose stock closed at 44 5/8, up 1 5/8.

HEADLINE: Rising Yen: Japan's Mixed Blessing

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Amid the commotion in the European foreign exchange markets, the Japanese yen has staged a rally and is emerging as perhaps the strongest major currency right now, a development that could hurt Japan's already weakened automobile and electronics giants.
The yen closed here on Thursday at 120.25 yen to the dollar, a high for Tokyo after rising as high as 119.83 earlier in the day. Today the yen weakened a bit, closing at 120.85, Just last week the yen was as low as 125 against the dollar and at the beginning of August was down to 128. 
 [In New York trading Friday the dollar was quoted at 120.75 yen, up from 120.55 yen late Thursday. On Wednesday, the dollar plunged as low as 119.55 yen before recovering a bit.]
The yen has been gaining in the last few weeks even against the German mark, whose strength has caused a crisis for the British pound, the French franc and other European currencies. At the beginning of the month, the mark was worth 89 yen; now it is worth 80.
 
'Full-Court Press'
 "It's full-court-press, yen strength against all currencies," said Paul A. Summerville, senior economist for Jardine Fleming Securities in Tokyo.
The strength of its currency is likely to prove a mixed blessing for Japan. It could alleviate some of the pressure on Japan's beleaguered banks and make it less expensive for Japan to import the oil and other raw materials it depends on. Politically, a strong yen could help mitigate a soaring trade surplus by making Japanese exports seem more expensive to the world and foreign products cheaper to the Japanese.
But for automobile and electronics companies that depend heavily on exports, the high yen could deal another blow at a time when the companies are already suffering heavily from a slump in Japan's domestic market. The net overall impact of a higher yen could be to prolong the nation's recession, some economists say, even in the face of the Government's $86 billion stimulative spending plan.
Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and other top officials have said in the last two days that the Government would consider intervening in the market if the yen experiences too sharp a rise, but that this did not appear to be the case yet. The prospect of intervention has helped keep the yen from rising further, analysts said.
 
Gradual Change Sought
 But Japanese officials actually appear to be more interested in making sure exchange rate changes are gradual, not in keeping the yen from rising. Indeed officials of the Finance Ministry and Bank of Japan have generally been in favor of a rise in the yen and Yasushi Mieno, governor of the Bank of Japan, reiterated Thursday that he still favored a firming of the yen over the long term, according to press reports here.
Still, investors in the Tokyo stock market interpreted the developments favorably. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks rose 327.23 points on Thursday but then fell back by 215.19 today to close at 18,394.76.
With Japan's own economy in a steep slump and interest rates low, the yen hardly appears to be a candidate for a strong rally. Many executives and economists think the yen looks good only by default, as investors seek to escape the turmoil in Europe and because prospects for the American economy are uncertain.
"The main reason for the sharp rise of the yen doesn't exist in the yen itself," said Akira Satate, deputy general manager of foreign exchange at the Bank of Tokyo.
 
Strength Seen Fleeting
 Some executives said the current strength of the yen would be only transitory. But others say the same factors that have brought the yen to its current position will drive it even higher. In addition, some people are hoping the economy here will recover because of the Government's stimulatory package announced last month.
"The yen is now a safe-haven currency," said Robert Alan Feldman, director of economics and market analysis for Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd., who thinks the yen will rise to 115 to the dollar or even higher. Despite its poor economy and its political scandals, Japan has a more certain political and economic outlook than the United States and many European countries, he said. Japan's strong trade and current account surpluses are also helping keep the yen strong, he said.
The prospect of a higher yen is sending chills through the board rooms of Japan's electronics and automobile companies, which are already facing periods of extremely low profits or even losses.
Takashi Matsuda, managing director and chief financial officer of the Honda Motor Company, said in a statement that if the yen stayed at its current level or gained strength it would have unfavorable effects both on Honda's export profits and on the Japanese economy. The company, which gets nearly half its revenues from sales in North America, has been basing its financial projections on the assumption of 130 yen to the dollar.
In part because of the gradual strengthening of the yen since last year, Japanese auto makers have already been raising auto prices in the United States more than their American competitors, and have lost some market share.
"The move in the currency right now is the best thing that's happened to Detroit in a long time," said Stephen Usher, an analyst with Kleinwort Benson International in Tokyo.
For Casio, the Japanese manufacturer of calculators, watches and other electronic gadgets, each 1-yen rise in the exchange rate translates into a reduction in pretax profit of 1 billion yen, or more than $8 million, said Toshio Isobe, a spokesman for the company. But raising prices right now would be difficult, he said, given the weak economies throughout the world.
Japanese banks could also get a break in meeting new requirements for the capital they must have relative to their assets. The sharp fall in stock prices in the last two and a half years has already put some banks in danger of not being able to meet those requirements because some gains on stocks are counted in the capital calculations.
Mr. Summerville of Jardine Fleming said that about 25 percent of the asset of the major Japanese banks were in dollars, such as loans for real estate in the United States. With the yen strengthening, less capital, as measured in yen, is needed to cover those assets. "This is good for Japan because it gives the banks more breathing room," he said.
Japan has managed to adjust to a much bigger gain in the yen that was caused by the 1985 Plaza Accord, in which major nations agreed to strengthen the yen in an attempt to slow Japan's export machine. By early 1988 the yen had risen to almost 120 to the dollar -- a record passed only this week -- from about 250 yen to the dollar in 1985.
The sharp change in the currency caused an economic slump here, but one from which Japan recovered with dazzling speed.
To make up for tougher export markets, Japan stimulated its own economy with fiscal measures, leading to a domestic boom. Manufacturing companies invested heavily in automation to improve efficiency and moved some operations offshore so they could remain competitive in world markets. And with its currency strong, Japanese companies became major buyers of downtown skyscrapers, Hollywood studios, oceanside golf courses and other American property.
The Japanese will not be able to rely on the domestic market for help this time. However, with banks nursing bad loans and companies in weak condition, the new strength of the yen is not expected to set off a new shopping spree for foreign properties.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Home State;
Suddenly Arkansas's Being Noticed, But a First Glance Can Be Misleading

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIL, Ark.

 BODY:
Forget George Bush's campaign fly-around this week aimed at depicting Arkansas as a sluggish economic backwater. What really gets Ray Lewis is what he hears from his relatives in Mississippi.
"As backwards as Mississippi is, they go around telling Arkansas jokes," grumbled Mr. Lewis, who farms in this picturesque mountain hamlet. "I don't know who they think they are to be telling jokes about us." 
 Long touchy about its image, accustomed to obscurity and resigned to being the butt of jokes, Bill Clinton's home state is being poked and prodded these days to a degree unmatched since its last extended brush with fame, the Little Rock school desegregation riots of 1957.
For both parties, part of the definition of Bill Clinton will come down to a definition of his home state, right down to the antic banjo music in Mr. Bush's attack ad on Mr. Clinton's tax record. But a few days of meandering through Arkansas' backroads produces a picture far more interesting than either the Republican view of Arkansas as a left-in-the ditch backwater or Mr. Clinton's portrayal of Arkansas as plucky, emergent Sun Belt growth state.
 
Utterly Unpretentious Orbits
 What emerges on the surface is a distinctive, utterly unpretentious place that from Little Rock to Peckerwood Lake and Hot Springs to Marmaduke reflects a culture dominated by small cities and small towns still traveling largely in their own refreshing orbit. But beneath the surface is a place that is more familiar than it might appear, whose appeal and whose challenges say much about a nation drawn south and west and wrestling with problems of race and poverty.
An intriguing mix of geography and culture -- Southern, Western and Midwestern at the same time -- Arkansas can seem like an extension of Texas at Texarkana and of Mississippi at Helena. But it's dominated by two rich slices of Americana, the spectacular mountain scenery of the Ozarks and the astoundingly fertile, kitchen-table-flat farmland of the Mississippi Delta.
That diversity, and particularly the populist mountain influence, has helped produce some of the most progressive and independent politicians in the South, like former Senator J. W. Fulbright, the current Senators Dale Bumpers and David Pryor, and Mr. Clinton.
If Arkansas seems different, it is because it always has been.
Viewed in its early years as the last stretch of desolate frontier before the Indian territory of Oklahoma, Arkansas grew up in the land left over between Missouri and Louisiana in the Louisiana Purchase.
"Arkansas had a reputation in the 19th century as being a place of renegades that was so dangerous and crazy no self-respecting person would move there," said a University of Arkansas history professor, Jeannie Whayne.
Unlike Texas to the West and Mississippi to the east, which came to symbolize mythic elements of their region, Arkansas could not even get its own ragged mythology right.
Its national image was first shaped by the tale of the Arkansas Traveler, depicted in folk tales, fiddle tunes and quilts and prints. The original story had to do with a group of Arkansas gentlemen, including a gubernatorial candidate, on horseback, engaged in a comic battle of wits and eventually playing a fiddle tune with an Ozark Mountain squatter.
As it came down through history, it evolved into a tale of a lordly Easterner looking down on a backwoods rube. For better or worse that image has stuck.
The state joined the Confederacy, but few battles of any consequence were fought there; residents in the mountain northwest fought for the Union, and Arkansas has retained little of the Lost Cause fervor common to the Deep South.
"Arkansas had a secessionist convention that met in Little Rock to decide whether to secede, and interestingly most counties sent their delegates down there with orders to stay in the union," said Bill Penix, a lawyer in Jonesboro. "Sure enough, they got all drunked up and seceded."
Even the state's racial history is misunderstood. Arkansas is still tarred with the image of the turmoil that followed Gov. Orval Faubus's refusal to integrate Central High School in Little Rock in 1957.
But Arkansas, where blacks make up about 16 percent of the population, was chosen as a test case for integration because it was believed to be moderate on race. And Governor Faubus's defiance has always been viewed as a political ploy on his part rather than an expression of a deep racial chasm.
"Arkansas was actually jerked out of its natural orbit by Orval Faubus," said Harry Ashmore, the author and former editor of The Arkansas Gazette. "The truth is Arkansas probably has as good race relations as anywhere else in the country and always did have."
More people now live in areas designated as urban than rural. But with 2.4 million people, about the population of Metropolitan Atlanta, spread out over 53,000 square miles, and its largest city, Little Rock, having a population of only 175,000, Arkansas is still a state with a sense of limitless space.
Once the planter wealth of the Delta produced the state's aristocracy and the mountains were the preserve of hopeless poverty. Now the situation is reversed. In the Delta, where increasingly mechanized farm work does not provide nearly the number of jobs it once did, all the problems of the rural South stand out in sharp relief.
In the small town of Hughes, about 15 miles from the Mississippi border, the early evening air is moist and heavy and a thunderstorm of great dark clouds is moving across the cotton and soybean fields of the Delta.
 
A Town 'Beyond Dead'
 But for the crowds of poor blacks congregating on front porches, for people like James Toney, a farm worker sitting on a street corner, or David White, who has a salvage business, this is a town stuck in an era whose time has passed.
"If I had a job offer somewhere else, I'd leave Hughes in a minute and never come back," Mr. White said.
Many whites share the pessimism.
"This town isn't dead," said Vester Steele, who owns the small S & S Grocery Store. "It's beyond dead."
But it is the mountains that have most shaped Arkansas's culture, and they now dominate the economy as well. Northwest Arkansas now is home to Tyson Foods Inc., the world's largest poultry producer, Wal-Mart, and booming new retirement communities around Fayetteville, Bentonville, Rogers and Springdale that have turned Arkansas into one of the nation's most popular retirement states.
Amid endless stretches of mountain highway, it is possible to find some people who fit the old mountain stereotypes.
At the gas station and convenience store that is the only business in Nail, Richard Brown, who sports a grizzled stubble and floppy hat, drives up in a pickup truck loaded with wood.
"Twenty years ago, you could make a living in Arkansas," said Mr. Brown, who has raised 13 children by hauling wood and farming with four mules. "Now, between the taxes and the environmentalists closing down some of these mills, it gets worse and worse."
 
Feel of Endless Yard Sale
 But, in a state that has the feel of an endless yard sale, with roadside stands and flea markets everywhere selling everything from and crystals to peaches to quilts, the hillbilly past has more to do with tourism than reality. In Hardy, the weathered looking craftsmen making leather belts and holsters turns out to be Ken Mullin, a certified nuclear welder, who moved there from Los Angeles a few years back.
And at places like Hillbilly Bill's Gift Shop and Putt-A-Way in Mountain Home or the Booger Hollow Trading Post north of Dover, which push hillbilly calendars, recipe books, joke books and T-shirts, the mountain image lives on only because it's good for business.
"Some of the people at the Chamber of Commerce don't like it, but this is what draws people here," said Bill Arthur, whose business card lists him as the head of Hillbilly Ventures Company rather than Hillbilly Bill.
Indeed for most Americans, Arkansas is not just like home, unless home includes businesses like Count Razorback's Liar's Headquarters, Gas Station and Bait Shoppe in the Ouachita Mountains. It is still a place where a sheriff in Forrest City a few years back proudly displayed in his office the severed testicles of a rape suspect, and where Arkansas caviar means the eggs of the long-snouted paddlefish, a prehistoric fish found only in the Mississippi Valley whose eggs are sold as a caviar substitute.
It is still far poorer, 47th in per capita income in 1990, than the rest of the country and more rural, where a factory job is likely to be in a chicken processing plant.
But from the satellite dishes dotting the mountains, to the retirees from Chicago flocking to the Ozarks, the state is a reminder that nearly all of America exists within the reach of the worlds of Wheel of Fortune, People Magazine and MTV.
 
Contradictory as Any State
 Still remembered by many for Mr. Faubus, Arkansas can be as contradictory on race as the rest of the nation. It is home to both the Ku Klux Klan leader Tom Robb's Klan retreat near Zinc and strong black officials like Joycelyn Elders, Mr. Clinton's outspoken health director.
Like the nation, its challenge on race now has more to do with economics than civil rights, as it tries to bring prosperity to the poor, largely black Delta as it has to the overwhelmingly white northwest. While the income gap between whites and blacks narrowed slightly in the nation during the 1980's, it widened slightly in Arkansas.
And even though Arkansas chic may still seem an oxymoron, the state's changing fortunes, like the prospect of two young Southerners making up the Democratic ticket, reflect the nation's demographic shift.
Twenty-five years ago Eureka Springs was an eccentric resort town of Victorian cottages and limestone buildings little known outside the Ozarks. Now it is like a booming, madcap, Southern theme park, with the original downtown ringed by attractions ranging from the Anita Bryant Show, to the Swanee River Boys Country Revue to the seven-story-tall Christ of the Ozarks Statue, passion play and New Holy Land exhibit.
"I moved from Chicago, to Kansas City, to Eureka Springs, which tells you something, I guess," said Katie Austin, who works as a chef on a tourists' dinner train. "I just couldn't take the dog-eat-dog life up there. Arkansas may be a late bloomer, but it's because people don't know what's down here."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Twenty-five years ago Eureka Springs, Ark., was an eccentric resort town. Now it is like a Southern theme park. Arkansas' mountain image lives on at Hillbilly Bill's Gift Shop in Mountain Home in calendars, recipe books and T-shirts. "Some of the people at the Chamber of Commerce don't like it, but this is what draws people here," said Bill Arthur, of Hillbilly Ventures Company. With him was his wife, Alice. Chart: "Arkansas at at Glance"
 
People
 Arkansas's population in 1990 was 2,421,000, an increase of 2.8 percent from 1980. Population growth from 1970 to 1980 was 18.9 percent.
 In 1990, whites were 82.7 percent of the population, blacks 15.9 percent and others, 1.4 percent.
 
Business
 Manufacturing, agriculture, forestry and tourism are the state's principal industrites.
 Tourists spent $2.3 billion in Arkansas in 1990. The Ozark and Ouachita Mountain regions are popular recreational areas.
 Arkansas is the nation's largest producer of poultry (951.2 million birds in 1990) and of rice (three million tons in 1990).
 Four Fortune 500 companies have headquarters in Arkansas; Tyson Foods, Riceland Foods, Murphy Oil and Hudson Foods.
 
Money
 In 1990, per capita personal income was $14.188. The national average was $18,691.
 Average hourly earnings for manufacturing workers were $8.07 in 1990. The national average was $10.84.
 
Higher Education
 The state has 20 state and private four-year colleges and universities, 12 two-year colleges, 6 vocational-technical schools, 5 technical institutes and 13 technical colleges.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Dual Effort To Survive By GlenFed

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
GlenFed Inc., owner of Glendale Federal Bank in Glendale, Calif., the nation's fifth-largest savings and loan association, is fighting for its life.
Confronted by a California economy on the ropes and Federal regulators embarrassed by their failure to prevent widespread collapses in the savings industry, GlenFed is battling on two fronts. 
 On one side, it is wringing profits out of its 200-plus branches by cutting costs and making new mortgage loans that are less likely to go into default than the riskier loans it made in the late 1980's. On the other, it is dickering with regulators for enough time to put its house in order without the specter of failure scaring away its senior officers.
 
A Shrunken Industry
 It is the kind of struggle that has overcome many savings and loans, and reduced the industry to 2,100 companies from 3,200 at the end of 1987.
Investors and traders have decided that GlenFed's future is risky; yesterday's closing price on the New York Stock Exchange, $2.375 a share, was near the 12-month low.
But apart from the standard cures of cutting costs, concentrating on the most profitable kinds of business and working to correct delinquent loans, GlenFed is looking to the Federal courts for relief.
Stephen J. Trafton, GlenFed's 45-year-old chairman, said on Thursday that he planned to offer to settle for $500 million a lawsuit the company is pursuing against the Federal Government. That money would give GlenFed the capital it needs "and would be a lot less than the $3 billion it could cost the Government if they were to close us," Mr. Trafton said.
Mr. Trafton is seeking to settle a lawsuit GlenFed filed in 1990 asking the United States Claims Court to find that enactment of a 1989 law overhauling the savings industry amounted to the Government's breaking a contract. The 1989 law prohibited Federal regulators from counting as capital the good will that GlenFed and other savings and loans entered on their books when they bought insolvent institutions in the early 1980's.
Good will is the amount by which an acquired institition's liabilities exceeded its assets. The ability to count the good will as capital was one factor in making acquisitions of failed institutions attractive to companies like GlenFed.
GlenFed had $700 million of good will resulting from its regulator-approved purchase of a failed savings and loan in Florida. Eliminating that amount from its capital caused GlenFed to fall below the minimum capital levels set in the 1989 law and subjected the company to criticism from regulators. As a result, Mr. Trafton said, the company has had a more difficult time attracting capital.
In July, Judge Loren Smith of the Claims Court agreed with GlenFed that the 1989 law broke a contract entered into by Federal regulators and that it caused financial harm to GlenFed. Federal regulators are appealing that decision.
 
Analyst Advises Patience

 
 Peter Treadway, a savings and loan analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said investors should not look forward to any quick windfall from the court decision. "But a contract is a contract," he said, "and I expect that eventually the company will get something."
Mr. Treadway noted that Mr. Trafton had been highly successful in improving the company's business, but had been stuck with bad loans. "As a manager who inherited a lot of problems, I think he walks on water," Mr. Treadway said. But he noted that Mr. Trafton, who is an Arctic explorer, might yet find that "the ice melts faster in Southern California."
"I think GlenFed will survive in an undercapitalized, wounded state," Mr. Treadway said. "But it is a very risky situation."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 41; Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 493 words

HEADLINE: Weak Economic Data Lift Bonds Sharply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose sharply yesterday as new reports on durable goods and personal income reflected extended weakness in the economy. Short-term government securities posted sharp gains.
The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond rose 21/32 point, or $6.56 per $1,000 in face amount, causing its yield to tumble to 7.35 percent, from 7.41 percent late Thursday. 
 The economic reports turned traders' sights away from Europe's currency crisis, which has preoccupied the market for weeks, and back to the United States economy. A weak economy increases the chances the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates, which would increase bond prices.
 
Three Critical Declines
 The Commerce Department said new orders to factories for durable goods in August fell for the third time in four months. The decline of one-tenth of 1 percent was slight, but it was unexpected, coming on top of a 2.7 percent drop in July.
The Commerce agency said personal income fell five-tenths of 1 percent last month, but the overall decline was more than accounted for by a drop at an annual rate of $60 billion caused by Hurricane Andrew.
Also, the National Association of Realtors said sales of previously owned homes fell 3.2 percent in August. Despite the lowest mortgage rates in 19 years, sales slumped in every region except the West.
Also helping the market was a belief that next week's report on September employment would be weak. The employment report is one of the most significant economic indicators, and economists say a weak report could force the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates again.
"That's the key number," said Ray Stone of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton N.J., adding that if the employment data are indeed poor, the Fed could ease rates when its Open Market Committee meets Oct. 6.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, short-term maturities rose 3/16 point to 17/32 point and intermediate maturities gained 7/16 point to 15/32 point, the Telerate financial information service reported.
The movement of a point equals a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all Treasury issues outstanding with maturities of a year or longer, rose 4.86, to 1,278.84.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills sank to 2.85 percent as the discount lost 9 basis points, to 2.80 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 2.9 percent as the discount fell 10 basis points, to 2.83 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 3.04 percent as the discount lost 10 basis points, to 2.94 percent.
A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, paid at maturity.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was quoted at 3 percent.

HEADLINE: Archdiocese of New York Imposes a Salary Freeze

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
The Archdiocese of New York, struggling to control rising costs, has frozen the salaries of 1,600 lay employees and the monthly stipends of 1,500 priests.
The salary freeze is the archdiocese's latest step to curb spending, said Joseph G. Zwilling, a spokesman for the archdiocese. Over the last two years, the archdiocese has closed 10 schools; merged 6 schools into 3; reduced the work force of Catholic Charities from 410 to 263, and put together a task force of corporations to study its finances. 
 The archdiocese has also proposed a one-year wage freeze for 4,325 teachers in Catholic schools, who are now working without a contract. The union is resisting such a move.
 
Paying the Bills
 Mr. Zwilling said that parishioners have continued to give more money, but that the expenses of the archdiocese have risen even more rapidly, particularly for health care and insurance.
"We have to pay the same sort of bills everybody else does," Mr. Zwilling said. "We're not immune to the economy we're living in."
He said he did not have figures for the overall costs, expenses or budget of the archdiocese. "I really can't put that figure together because there are so many different elements," he said.
The hospitals, schools, parishes and affiliated agencies all have their own budgets, he said.
Last year, officials said the archdiocese had an operating budget of $370 million.
 
Salary Freeze
 The salary freeze took effect on Sept. 1. Lay employees, including secretaries, administrators and cafeteria workers, will have to forgo cost-of-living increases and merit raises of 3.5 percent.
And priests who work in archdiocesan parishes will receive no increase for the third year in a row. They are paid a monthly stipend of $500 to $600, depending on how long they have been ordained, though many earn extra income teaching or lecturing. Housing costs are covered for those who live in rectories.
"Archdiocese employees have accepted it very well," said Mr. Zwilling. "They understand the financial situation. It's been a big topic."
The Archdiocese of New York covers Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island, Westchester and six counties north of the city, and serves two million Catholics in 412 parishes.
The neighboring Diocese of Brooklyn is also facing "difficult economic times" and is cutting costs wherever possible, said a spokesman, Frank DeRosa, but he said the diocese had not instituted any kind of salary freeze for workers.
The archdiocese's salary freeze was first reported in the Sept. 24 issue of Catholic New York, the weekly newspaper of the archdiocese. The New York Post reported it yesterday.
The archdiocese started two fund-raising campaigns in 1991 that have had mixed success. The drive to raise $100 million for the parishes surpassed its goal by $15 million. "This is the most raised by any diocese in the country ever," Mr. Zwilling said.
But a campaign to raise an equal amount for 140 inner-city schools, primarily from corporate givers, has fallen far short. Only about $27 million in donations and pledges has been collected so far. "We seem to have reached a plateau," Mr. Zwilling said.
The archdiocese is facing long-term difficulties in continuing to support the schools, which have provided a good education for thousands of children living in inner-city neighborhoods and which in recent years have increasingly served poor black and Hispanic children. From fiscal year 1991 to 1992, the archdiocese cut its subsidy to the schools from $29 million to $23 million.
 
10 Schools Closed
 It closed 10 schools over the last two years, six of them in poor neighborhoods. Other inner-city parochial schools face possible closing because of shrinking enrollments, rising costs and the cuts in the archdiocesan subsidies.
The 298 parochial schools in the archdiocese, attended by about 106,000 students, rely primarily on tuition and the local parish churches for financial support.
The archdiocese's contract with the two unions representing the teachers in its schools expired Aug. 31. The archdiocese has asked the unions to go into mediation, but so far they have rejected that proposal, Mr. Zwilling said.
Officials with the Federation of Catholic Teachers, which represents 4,000 teachers, did not return calls yesterday. Officials with the Lay Faculty Association, which represents 325 teachers, could not be reached for comment.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
In Their Own Words

 BODY:

PRESIDENT BUSH -- In an interview yesterday on WBBM-AM radio in Chicago
"It's not a question of family values. I have long favored family leave, but I don't believe in burdening the economy further and burdening the employers. I mean, we want more jobs for women, and I have very good proposals. They've had that bill sitting around for eight or nine months, and they send it down just two weeks before -- one week before they adjourn and just before an election, trying to make political hay out of it. HEADLINE: New Terminal Announced for Newark Airport

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Sept. 25

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey plans to build a new passenger terminal at Newark International Airport and renovate other buildings there to handle soaring numbers of international travelers.
The $110 million project will almost triple the number of international passengers the airport can handle per hour, to 3,000 from 1,100, said the Port Authority chairman, Richard C. Leone. 
 "I think no one anticipated that there would be this kind of demand," he said. "This is our first attempt to fully expand to meet the unprecedented growth."
Overseas travel through the Newark airport has increased by 133 percent over the last four years, from 1.2 million passengers in 1988 to 2.8 million in 1991, making it the fastest growing airport in the region. The Port Authority estimates that the current figure will increase by at least 40 percent by the turn of the century.
Port Authority officials say the new terminal, which is expected to open in 1995, solidifies the stature of the Newark airport, now among the top 10 international airports in the country.
But the growth in Newark has not come at the expense of Kennedy and La Guardia airports in New York, said Stanley Brezenoff, the authority's executive director.
"That's a sort of persistent concern that is expressed," Mr. Brezenoff said. "The fact is that the Port Authority is investing billions of dollars in all three airports."
The growth at Newark has come from a growing number of new airlines looking to compete in an international market under deregulation, Mr. Leone said. In the last three years, 20 airlines have introduced international service at the airport. Kennedy International Airport and La Guardia Airport did not have space to accommodate new flights, Mr. Leone added, while the movement of affluent homeowners and corporations to Northern New Jersey in the last decade has made the airport an attractive alternative to New York.
 
Immigration and Customs Space
 Total passengers at Newark from January to May 1992 increased by 8.8 percent from the same period in 1991. At Kennedy , volume increased by 4.8 percent during the same period, while La Guardia's volume fell by 1.7 percent.
Newark's expansion project was approved Thursday at a meeting of the authority's board. In addition to a new building, to be built between two concourses of Terminal B, it includes more space for United States Customs and the Immigration and Naturalization Service, a new baggage claim and inspection area and a more efficient use of gates and ramps.
The airport is already building a $378 million monorail that will link the airport's long-term parking lots, its car-rental area and its three terminals. The monorail is expected to open in late 1994 or early 1995.
Major projects are going on at the two New York airports, too. At La Guardia, Mr. Brezenoff said, in addition to a USAir terminal that opened last week, the authority is renovating the main terminal and planning road work, all totaling $300 million in Port Authority funds and $250 million in airline funds.
 
Tighter Focus at Kennedy
 And at Kennedy, where an ambitious plan to rebuild the airport as the nation's premier gateway was scrapped after the agency had already spent $100 million, a refocused project is already under way, he said. Instead of a new central terminal, the plans focus on renovating and rebuilding the nine existing terminals, adding a cargo terminal, rebuilding roadways and adding monorail links.
The plans also include a new passenger terminal, financed by five international airlines, that will be the first new terminal in the airport since the 1960's, he said. The project will cost $1.8 billion in Port Authority funds and another $2 billion in airline and other private funds.
Mr. Brezenoff added that steps had been taken to insure that money would not be wasted at Kennedy. "We've submitted a risk analysis that lays down all of our assumptions, what milestones there are, projections, what things might go wrong," he said. "We will periodically revisit those as the projects continue."
And Donald Plavin, the agency's director of aviation, added that the ill-fated project had more to do with the recession and the weakness of the two airlines most involved in the plans. "Half of the whole airport was carried by T.W.A. and Pan Am," he said. "Those carriers would not have been able to finance the project. We had to step back and regroup."
At Newark, where about half the international service is provided by Continental Airlines, the agency expects the volume of passengers to continue to grow, Mr. Plavin said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Where Impulse Buying Hasn't Died

 BODY:
Lechters Inc. hopes to become the Gap of the housewares market by selling everything from measuring spoons to color-coordinated bathroom sets at affordable prices, cheaper than those of chains like Williams-Sonoma and Crate and Barrel.
The chain, based in Harrison, N.J., now has 455 stores in malls, strip centers and cities in 37 states, up from 234 in 1988; it hopes to be at 535 by the end of the year. 
 The New York City area is the latest target for expansion by Lechters, in part because the company says more business is generated there than in other parts of the country, with space-hungry city dwellers spending more on storage and closet items. Fifteen of the 18 stores in New York have been opened since 1990, with the most recent at 85th Street and Third Avenue. Another Manhattan store is scheduled to open early next month at 111th Street and Broadway.
 
A Profitable Stock

 
 Lechters seems to have plenty of fans on Wall Street. Its stock closed yesterday in over-the-counter trading at $18.125, a gain of 12.5 cents for the day. The stock was priced at $10.25, adjusted for a 2-for-1 split, when Lechters began offering shares in July 1989.
"I like the Lechters story, they are doing everything right and everything they need to do to succeed," said Dana Telsey, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence in New York.
The housewares chain does seem to have retailing, demographic and economic trends on its side. The rapid expansion of Lechters comes at a time when department stores have scaled down their "home shops." The company is virtually alone in stocking almost endless assortments of kitchen utensils, tabletop items and basic housewares -- most costing less than $10.
And the biggest population segment -- the baby boomers -- are in a nesting mood. "The baby boomers' years of consumption are gone," said Michael Anthony, vice president and general merchandising manager of the chain. "Now they have families and children in college and need to save money. The 90's, not like the 80's, will focus on the home."
Even the recession has played somewhat into Lechters' hands. People seem to be eating more meals at home, and while they may not be buying dishwashers, they seem willing to buy dish towels.
"The recession works for Lechters because people are trying to stay at home to conserve money," said George Rosenbaum, chief executive of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a Chicago-based marketing research firm. "When you go into a Lechters you are not going to get into trouble because the items on the shelves are not very expensive."
A study conducted by the Shapiro firm for Lechters found that of every 100 customers who enter a Lechters, 80 end up buying something. Mr. Rosenbaum said that for a chain that survives on discretionary items, this rate is high. About the only retailers with higher purchase rates are grocery stores and fast-food chains. "Basically Lechters will do very well if it is in a high traffic area," Mr. Rosenbaum said.
Indeed, in a period when other retailers watched sales decline, sales at Lechters stores open at least a year grew 2 percent last year and overall sales increased 25 percent, to $234.3 million. For the first half of 1992 sales were up 28 percent, to $112.6 million, and net income rose 18 percent to $1.1 million.
Donald Jonas, the chairman and chief executive of Lechters, is no newcomer to retailing. His father owned a discount department store in the 1940's called Jonas at 14th Street and the Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan. At the age of 23, after attending the University of Richmond, Mr. Jonas opened his first store, a leased women's apparel department in discount shops.
The venture was subsequently expanded into a chain, called Barbara Lynn, after Mr. Jonas's wife. But he gradually left the women's wear field because it was too competitive.
Housewares was less so. "We made a lot of mistakes in the beginning but there was no one else in the business," he said. The first Lechters store opened in 1975 in a shopping mall in Rockaway, N.J.
 
Raising Cash
 The rapid expansion of Lechters started in July 1989 when the company went public, raising $20 million, most of which was used to repay bank loans. Last year the company raised $15 million from senior notes and $28 million from the secondary offering of common stock. In August of last year the company raised $51 million in a bond issue. All these deals have left the company with $84 million in long-term debt to be paid in the next 10 years.
The chain prides itself on being "category killers" in certain products by offering numerous variations. Take the garlic press. Lechters sells eight models varying in sizes, handles, color and quality, with prices from $4.99 to $13.99.
Gadgets like a pickle grabber and an ergonomically correct vegetable peeler are also something of a Lechters trademark.
"We would like people to think of us as the store that has everything, the problem-solving store and a fun place to shop," Mr. Jonas said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The chain of Lechters housewares stores has been expanding rapidly in New York City, helped in part by space-hungry city dwellers' need for storage and closet items. Donald Jonas, the chairman and chief executive of Lechters, stood at the company's store on Broadway and West 57th Street in Manhattan. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Jersey City Is the Victor In Relocation

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
In a battle illustrating how desperate real-estate companies are for tenants and governments are for jobs, New York City and New York State have accepted the loss of 1,000 jobs in Manhattan after calculating that it would cost them more than $50,000 a job to retain them.
The winner in the contest was Jersey City, which succeeded in persuading a subsidiary of the First Chicago Corporation, a bank holding company, to relocate its administrative and back-office operations to Newport Center, a sprawling office, retail and residential complex along the Hudson River. 
 Newport Center was conceived in the heady growth days of the 1980's. Its developers, the Lefrak Organization of New York and Melvin Simon & Associates of Indianapolis, gambled that financial-services companies and other corporations fed up with soaring Manhattan rents would flock to the complex.
 
Tenants Staying Put
 But in the aftermath of the 1987 stock market crash and the onset of the recession in 1989, which ravaged the financial-services sector, rents in Manhattan have plunged and the complex has found it difficult to woo new tenants. About 37 percent of Newport Center's nearly 1.5 million square feet of office space and 90 percent of its 1.2 million square feet of retail space are leased; 93 percent of its 2,000 apartments are occupied.
Underlining the importance that New Jersey placed on snaring First Chicago, the company's decision to move was announced yesterday at a news conference presided over by Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey. "This is the first major corporate location to the Hudson 'Gold Coast' in four years," he said. New Jersey is offering inducements worth at least $5 million.
Paul Weisbrod, president of New York City's Economic Development Corporation, said the city and New York State would have had to pay more than $50,000 in tax benefits and energy discounts for each of the 1,000 jobs to keep them. That is more than twice what the city has previously been willing to spend.
"Certainly $50,000 is far, far in excess of what we have ever provided or offered," he said, "and we decided we shouldn't do it." By comparison, the city and state agreed in August to grant benefits worth about $106.2 million, or more than $20,000 a job, to persuade Prudential Securities Inc. to keep 5,000 jobs in the city for 20 years.
Asked whether the package offered by New Jersey represented a sharp escalation in the battle between the states for jobs, Mr. Weisbrod was reluctant to attack New Jersey. "It has always been fairly intense," he said of the competition. "I think over the past three years or so New Jersey has not been very successful in luring companies from New York."
He added: "Our neighbors and we should be working together to improve the competiveness of the region rather than spending public money to shift jobs from one part of the region to another. We have tried very hard here to have our neighbors realize this as we do."
 
Nonaggression Pact
 Last year, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut signed a nonaggression pact, promising not to use negative advertising against one another in the battle to keep or attract jobs. They also committed themselves to cooperate on economic issues.
Describing the agreement as limited in scope, Mr. Weisbrod said he did not feel that New Jersey broke it in the First Chicago contest. "It has been part of an ongoing competition, and it's a competition where -- at least certainly for the last several years -- we have been exceptionally successful."
Mr. Weisbrod tried to play down the importance of keeping First Chicago, saying that such back-office jobs were not a growth area because technology was reducing the need for them.
"It's not a positive, but it's not hugely negative," Enda Bracken, an assistant vice president at Laudauer Associates Inc., a real- estate consulting company, said of the First Chicago move. "There's no cause for alarm at this stage. The flow of companies to New Jersey has slowed down substantially over the last few years. The reason is New York rents have become substantially more competitive."
 
Moving by Mid-1993
 The subsidiary that is to move, First Chicago Trust Company, has signed a lease for 240,000 square feet in Newport Tower and plans to move by mid-1993. A 36-story office building with one million square feet that overlooks the Hudson River, the tower was completed in April and was bought from its developers by the Limited Inc., the apparel chain based in Columbus, Ohio.
The First Chicago unit, which performs shareholder services for corporate customers -- mailing dividends, annual reports and proxy material and answering shareholder questions -- will keep 100 jobs in lower Manhattan.
In addition to the 1,000 jobs going to Jersey City, First Chicago is moving 100 jobs from Manhattan on Nov. 1 to a new mailing and computer-printing center in Edison, N.J.
First Chicago Corporation now employs 2,300 people in the metropolitan area, including 1,500 in Manhattan at the trust subsidiary, in corporate banking and in mailing and printing operations; 700 at a credit-card-processing operation in Uniondale, L.I., and 100 at a receivables-mailing operation in Secaucus, N.J.
First Chicago Trust's president, Lorne H. Price, said Newport Tower's technological abilities, including fiber optics and satellite communications systems and backup electrical systems, combined with the price of the space, heavily influenced the company's decision. He also noted that the complex is a short ride on PATH from Manhattan.
 
New Jersey's Inducements
 In an interview, Anthony R. Coscia, chairman of the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, said the state had provided benefits worth $5 million to $6 million to First Chicago. These included a capital investment in the building and an equity stake that the state was taking in the building.
A New Jersey official who insisted on anonymity said the stake would be less than 5 percent. He said First Chicago's base rent was about $10 a square foot, which he said was about half what First Chicago would have had to pay for comparable space in Manhattan.
In addition, Mr. Coscia said, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company had offered First Chicago "a very competitive rate." Because Jersey City is in an urban enterprise zone, First Chicago will have to pay only a 3 percent state sales tax, half the normal rate.
He denied that the state had been excessive in wooing First Chicago. He said the state, for example, had spent much more to keep a General Electric Company aerospace operation and its 2,000 jobs in New Jersey. "We're building them a building," he said.
The move must be an especially bitter pill for Barry F. Sullivan, New York's Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. He is the former chairman of the First Chicago Corporation. Jennifer Kimball, a spokeswoman for Mr. Sullivan, said he had not been personally involved in the negotiations. Mr. Sullivan is still a consultant to First Chicago and has made a policy of not involving himself in any city business with the bank.
The subsidiary is now situated at 30 West Broadway in lower Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Storm Slashed Incomes in U.S.

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Hurricane Andrew hurt Americans' total personal income in August, wiping out what would have been a healthy increase, the Commerce Department said today.
Personal income plunged five-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted rate of $5.03 trillion, the worst drop in 19 months. If not for the storm, income would have increased seven-tenths of 1 percent, the best in six months. 
 The agency said August's overall income decline was more than accounted for by a storm-caused drop at an annual rate of $60 billion.
Andrew's demolition of property in southern Florida and south-central Louisiana reduced rental and business owners' income. Work interruptions cut salaries, and crop destruction hurt farm income.
The storm also depressed personal consumption spending. It fell one-tenth of 1 percent, to $3.32 trillion, the worst showing in 10 months. In later months, the storm will probably lift both income and spending as people get cleanup jobs and start buying lumber and other building supplies, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Accord on Aid to Ex-Soviets

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
House and Senate negotiators have agreed on a bill authorizing $460 million next year for wide-ranging aid programs to help the former Soviet Union make the transition to democracy and free markets.
The bill, a compromise of measures the two chambers passed earlier, authorizes a $12.3 billion increase in the American contribution to the International Monetary Fund, which is helping Russia overhaul its economy. It also supports a contribution of as much as $3 billion for currency stabilization funds for the Commonwealth of Independent States. 
 The bill, which the negotiators cleared on Thursday, is expected to get final House and Senate approval before Congress adjourns for the year at the end of next week. A separate foreign-aid-appropriations bill that includes aid for Russia and other former Soviet states is making its way through Congress.
President Bush said on April 1 that the United States would participate in a $24 billion international aid initiative for the former Soviet states and had hoped the legislation would pass before President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russian visited Washington in June. Mr. Yeltsin made a strong pitch for the aid in an address to Congress.
The bill softens the conditions on Russian aid that the Senate version had linked to a pullout of troops from the Baltic states. The new language would require progress on withdrawal and allow the President to waive the aid restrictions.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Bonds Is, Of Course, A Key to Victory

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25

 BODY:
It is 5:40 P.M. at Three Rivers Stadium. Barry Bonds stands at the plate, crashing baseball after baseball into the multiple decks in right field. It's a sight the National League has seen too much of and too little of in 1992.
Clubs have crafted entire game plans to prevent Bonds from beating them. He has had the bat taken out of his hands again and again. His 31 intentional walks this season are the most in the majors. His 123 walks are 31 more than anyone else in the National League. 
 "I don't know how he's got the numbers he does," said Don Slaught, the veteran catcher for the Pirates. "It ain't like they are giving him r.b.i. In fact, their doing their damnedest not to. The guy gets to swing the bat about once a game."
It has often been enough. Tonight, Bonds swung his bat and collected another hit. He walked again, too, and not surprisingly, the Pirates won, 3-2, from the Mets. The triumph reduced Pittsburgh's clinching number for third straight title to 2.
 
Numbers of a Star
 Bonds has 31 home runs and has driven in 97 runs. His 71 extra-base hits are tops in the league. His .621 slugging percentage is 36 percentage points higher than the next man, Gary Sheffield of the Padres. No one else has scored more than Bonds's 104 runs.
"He's the m.v.p.," said Pirates Manager Jim Leyland. "There's no doubt in my mind. He's the best left fielder in the game, and he's playing on a first-place club. What do you have to do? If he doesn't win, I don't understand how it all works."
It doesn't work on the field any more explosively or extravagantly than it has for Bonds in September. With the Pirates getting constant pressure from Montreal, Bonds has ruled. He is forever on base, forever a threat, forever crippling one more pitch.
He has hit .452 over the last 14 games as the Pirates have applied what appears to be the knockout punch to the Expos. He has reached base safely 64 times in his last 110 plate appearances. He has walked 26 times in that span, and scored 25 runs in the 24 games.
"A lot of things I've done this season, I've had to say, whoa," said Bonds. "I've had to almost say that's not right, that's impossible."
 
Empty Bandwagon in April
 Before the season, more than a couple of observers termed Pittsburgh's shot at a third consecutive division title impossible. Bobby Bonilla was with the Mets as a free agent, John Smiley had been traded to Minnesota in a deal driven by economics, and Bonds was destined for free agency and perhaps a season of distracting speculation.
But Andy Van Slyke has hit .324. Jay Bell has been an anchor at shortstop and even mounted the N.L.'s longest hitting streak -- 22 consecutive games. Tim Wakefield has come out of obscurity and flung knuckleball after knuckleball and turned in inning after inning for a beleaguered starting rotation. Jose Lind has vacuumed everything hit near him at second. And Doug Drabek has put together yet one more clutch second half of stranglehold pitching.
"It's not a great team by any means," said Leyland. "But it's a damn good ball club day in and day out."
It's a club consequently headed for another run at the World Series, and after that likely another round of rupturing rearrangement. Bonds, the league's most valuable player in 1990, is the most attractive free agent to come on the market in a decade.
 
'To Find His Pot of Gold'
 "I want Barry to chase the rainbow, to find his pot of gold and to understand that his pot of gold isn't only made up of money," said Leyland. "But I'm not going to try and sell him on staying with this club or to try and sell him on me or this city. I don't have that right. I don't want that right. That's the system, and more power to the players."
With all that power, Bonds understands he has no control over whether he wins another m.v.p. award, terming it a result wrought by "statistics and sportswriters." So he has tried to keep a handle on his emotions.
"I don't want to set myself up for disappointment," he said. "To win the N.L. East again this season has probably been the best one of the three. There were a lot of reasons for us to fall or fail."
Barry Bonds, with a bat in his hands or taken out of his hands, is the central reason why the Pirates have not.
 
INSIDE PITCH
 SID FERNANDEZ, who gave up a leadoff homer to GARY REDUS, took the loss for the Mets, and his record fell to 13-11. RANDY TOMLIN got the victory for the Pirates to improve his career mark against the Mets to 8-0. . . . The Mets are 2-11 against the Pirates.

HEADLINE: Is the Novel Dying? Hope and Despair From Eight Who Should Know

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
The novel is alive and well, but subject to occasional spells of depression about its future. That, more or less, was the majority opinion among eight practitioners of the art, who discussed "The Death of the Novel, the Life of the Novel" on Thursday evening at Town Hall in midtown Manhattan.
The event, organized by the Lannan Foundation, a private arts organization based in Los Angeles, brought together Harold Brodkey, Michael Cunningham, Oscar Hijuelos, Norman Mailer, Paule Marshall, Norman Rush, Mona Simpson and Barbara Probst Solomon. They submitted to almost painfully sensitive and complex questioning by Michael Silver blatt, the host of "Bookworm," a weekly interview program on radio in southern California. 
 Mr. Silverblatt announced early that he had read 220 novels in the last year and might have read many more if Mr. Brodkey and Mr. Mailer had not published two epic-length books, "The Runaway Soul' and "Harlot's Ghost," respectively. The evening might have finished much earlier if he had read, say, 25 or 30.
As the speakers took their places onstage one by one, Mr. Silverblatt hit each of them with a personally tailored question requiring about a week's worth of thought to answer. Mr. Brodkey, first out, had barely found his chair before he was wrestling with, "Why do we need a theory of the novel?"
Most of the panelists sweated through these exam questions. Mr. Mailer jumped at his: "What is the novel?"
"That's easy," he said. "An attack upon reality." He then proposed a supplementary definition, calling it "all those perceptions for which there is no room in other forms," and warned that it is in danger of dying not for lack of vitality, but for lack of an audience.
 
Liberators Versus Gatekeepers
 Like most of the other panelists, Mr. Rush, the author of "Mating," which won the National Book Award for Fiction last year, criticized the cultural forces, notably television, that worked to the detriment of literature, and the dead hand of academia, but he expressed a basic faith in the novel's power to endure. The source of this power, he said, is "ethical anxiety," which he located in "a recognition that we are all limited in our ability to comprehend the world." The novel, he said, "offers us the chance to be something other than we are, and it is therefore a mighty engine of liberation."
Unfortunately, Mr. Rush said, in America a novel lives by being placed on the syllabus of college English courses. Mr. Brodkey took sharp exception, arguing throughout the evening that writers do not live or die based on the decisions of what Mr. Rush called "the gatekeepers" of academia. "Librarians probably have more effect," Mr. Brodkey said, "and we never talk about the politics of librarians."
Mr. Brodkey also found himself at odds with Ms. Marshall, the author of "Brown Girl, Brownstones" and "Daughters," when he argued that novelists and serious readers of fiction constituted a kind of subversive elite in American culture, which he described as essentially political and economic rather than literary.
Ms. Marshall, whose novels describe the life of West Indians in Brooklyn, bristled at the word elite. She cited the small reading groups of black women whom she encountered in cities across the country on a recent book tour as evidence of a more popular audience for serious fiction than one might suppose.
 
How Close to Reality?
 One of the evening's more bizarre episodes came when a member of the audience asked the panelists what short books they might recommend to the homeless residents of a shelter that he managed. Mr. Brodkey, thinking aloud, said that perhaps something close to the residents' actual experience might be the ticket, and he was halfway into recommending "One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich" before he thought better of it and suggested George Orwell's "Down and Out in Paris and London," a book that he said had helped him when he was young and penniless. Mr. Rush recommended Kafka and the short stories of Chekhov and Isaac Babel, "works that deal with the extremities of the human condition." Ms. Simpson suggested the works of Primo Levi.
The menace of television and film, lurking at every turn, inspired several impassioned defenses of the novel. Ms. Simpson, author of "The Lost Father," argued that not even the best film could ever create truly memorable characters in the way "Middlemarch" or "War and Peace" do, characters that enter one's life in the way members of one's family do, and become part of one's moral reasoning. "A great novel is worth 1,000 films," said Mr. Hijuelos, the author of "The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love." His remark drew hisses from several audience members. Perhaps they had seen the movie based on his book.
The question of audience and the novelist's role was an undercurrent throughout the evening. Mr. Mailer and Mr. Brodkey described writing as an intensely personal quest, and the novelist as being, in crucial respects, a voluntary exile from American culture. Mr. Cunningham, the author of "A Home at the End of the World," and Ms. Marshall argued for a more socially engaged fiction, pointing to the work of younger black, Asian and gay writers as the best hope for the vitality of the form.
"One of the great strengths of the novel is that it is probably doing more to give a voice to the disenfranchised than any other form," said Mr. Cunningham, whose work addresses gay issues. "Hollywood is not doing it, television is hardly doing it, and I'm thrilled with it."
Mr. Mailer, who is often thought of as one of the heftiest egos ever to hit the printed page, described the work of the novelist as a radical surrender of self. "Serious novelists conduct reconnaissance into moral reaches that are not under their command," he said, and his remark seemed to amplify a point he had made earlier about the essential humility of the writer's craft. "The art of the novel," he said, "is to arrive at that artless point when your characters become more real than yourself."
By the end of the evening, the American novel seemed to be holding its own, bloodied but unbowed, certainly far from dead. True, Mr. Silverblatt bemoaned what he called "a time of national disgrace for the novel" and delivered a tongue-lashing to the critics who failed to rally around "Harlot's Ghost" and "The Runaway Soul."
Ms. Simpson showed more heart. Rejecting the talk of gloom and doom, she said, "The best thing I can think of is to quote my old writing teacher, Richard Price, who told us, 'I think the novel will be at your funeral.' "
