HEADLINE: Review/Film Festival;
Of an Earl, an Old Love and Roger

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
Three superb short films by Mike Leigh of England, Denys Arcand of Canada and Michael Moore of the United States make up the program titled "Taking the Pulse," which will be shown at the New York Film Festival today at 4 P.M. and midnight. Because they probably won't be presented anywhere else in this same combination, you may want to check if there are any seats left for the program. The films don't have much in common, but seeing three such decisively idiosyncratic works together has a way of raising the spirits.
Mr. Moore's 23-minute contribution, "Pets or Meat: The Return to Flint," is a sort of "Roger and Me 2." It's an engagingly tatterdemalion sequel to his 1989 hit documentary in which he examined the sad state of Flint, Mich., after mass layoffs by General Motors, and some of the ways in which private citizens and public boosters were coping. 
 Since Mr. Moore last visited Flint with a camera crew, things have continued to change, meaning that they've gotten worse, even for Roger Smith, the G.M. chairman whom the film maker unsuccessfully tried to interview earlier. Mr. Moore says that Mr. Smith, after resigning from G.M., had his pension package reduced by $100,000.
From time to time throughout "Pets or Meat," the folksy film maker toys with the idea of sending the former executive a check to make up the difference. He could afford it: his profits from "Roger and Me" reportedly allowed him to set up a $250,000 foundation to help independent film makers and social action groups. According to the new film, Mr. Moore also paid two years' rent to each person shown being evicted in "Roger and Me." Now and then social satire pays off.
"Pets or Meat" takes its title from the sign outside the house of Rhonda Britton, the woman who was selling rabbits in "Roger and Me." She is now bankrupt but unbowed. She works at K-Mart and has expanded her in-home business by adding a line of rats and mice, sold as food for pet snakes. One not-great shot: a python engorging a rabbit the size of a small dog.
Other characters make return visits, including Fred Ross, the deputy seen evicting destitute tenants in the earlier film. Now Mr. Ross also works as a repo man, that is, as a repossessor of automobiles. Not all business in Flint is down. Employment is up at the unemployment office. Sales of home security systems and guns have risen because of the increase in crime.
Wearing his G.M. cap squarely on his head, looking quizzical and never surprised, Mr. Moore wanders through this landscape like Tocqueville disguised as a late 20th-century Middle American hayseed. For those who can't get to Lincoln Center today, PBS television stations are scheduled to show both "Pets or Meat" and "Roger and Me" on Monday night.
Mr. Arcand's 25-minute "Seen From Elsewhere" is a segment from a new Canadian anthology feature titled "Montreal Vu Par. . ." Whatever the rest of the film is like, Mr. Arcand's contribution is delicious, an older woman's ecstatic, alarmingly frank recollection of a love affair she had many years ago in Montreal.
Attending a boring diplomatic reception in a Latin American capital, where each succeeding guest has a worse horror story to tell about the provincial manners and morals of French Canadians, the woman is prompted to recall Montreal as the scene of the great love affair of her life. Her surprised husband stands by as she delights the women around her with the explicit details of an escapade conducted during a World Health Organization conference, amid a very snowy weekend and exploding mailboxes, among other things.
The film, beautifully written by Paule Baillargeon, who also appears in a small role, recalls the wit and elan of Mr. Arcand's "Decline of American Civilization" (1986).
The high point of the program is Mike Leigh's "Sense of History," a one-character film that is not, strictly speaking, a Mike Leigh film at all. Mr. Leigh did not write the script, as he usually does. Instead, he sort of presides over it, seeing that all goes well. The true auteur of "A Sense of History" is Jim Broadbent, the 40-ish English actor and wizard, who conceived and wrote the screenplay and plays the portly, 70-ish 23d Earl of Leete.
In the course of a 25-minute monologue, the Earl takes his unseen interviewer on a tour of the 900-year-old Leete estate, chatting all the while about his family, his politics, his marriages and the skeletons in his closet. It's a merciless and sometimes hilarious portrait of the aristocracy, though the Earl is far from being a twit. He's a bigoted, arrogant, lethal weapon of privilege. Yet for all of his faults he is almost likable. He's certainly credible.
The performance of Mr. Broadbent is as remarkably rich as his screenplay, a capsule history of Britain from the landing of William the Conqueror through World War II and beyond. The Earl tells the interviewer that he could not, in all good conscience, take up arms against Hitler, though that doesn't mean he approved of everything Hitler stood for. The Earl believes in land, class, civil order and, as he says with a sweeping gesture, "keeping the bastards out."
Mr. Broadbent will be remembered for his performance as the husband in Mr. Leigh's "Life Is Sweet." To appreciate his extraordinary physical transformation for "A Sense of History," you might want to see him in Neil Jordan's "Crying Game," also being shown at the festival today. In that film he plays a character about 30 years younger and 40 pounds lighter than the garrulous old Earl.
"A Sense of History" is an exemplary work.
 
 
 
TAKING THE PULSE
 PETS OR MEAT: THE RETURN TO FLINT, directed by Michael Moore; edited by Jay Freund; produced by Mr. Moore and Lydia Dean Pilcher. Running time: 24 minutes. This film has no rating. These films are at Alice Tully Hall, as part of the 30th New York Film Festival.

HEADLINE: EUROPE: FALL AND WINTER;
In the West End, the Stage Is a Whirl

BYLINE: By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE; BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE is the chief theater critic for The Times of London.

 BODY:
ENGLAND may be in recession. London and the southeast may be particularly hard hit. Tourists from America, put off by the weakness of the dollar against the pound, may be fewer than hoped. Nevertheless, two of London's more important theaters are reopening this fall, each with its innards expensively retooled.
For the last four years, the most central of all West End theaters, the Criterion, has been just a hole beneath Piccadilly Circus. Theatergoers have been deprived of not only the stage that gave the English-speaking world "Waiting for Godot" and many other major plays, but also a Louis XVI-style auditorium that had, sadly, become tacky and decayed. But by Oct. 21, after the expenditure of a million dollars, the theater is to be restored sufficiently to present a new play by James Saunders, "Making It Better," which was well received during a tryout at the Hempstead Theater in February. 
 Jane Asher is to stay on in the role of a BBC producer who finds 1989 an emotionally as well as a politically taxing year. She takes two Czechoslovak lovers after her husband has made his own particular defection, by coming out of the sexual closet.
Betrayal of all kinds is in the air, and it is handled with the same wry, dry wit that Mr. Saunders, one of Britain's most underrated dramatists, brought to "Bodies" and "Next Time I'll Sing to You." "His best play to date," wrote Irving Wardle in The Independent on Sunday.
The other expensively refurbished theater is the Donmar Warehouse in Covent Garden. Regular playgoers may have suffered the cramped, bumpy seats, but most of them still had special places in their hearts for the theater. The Royal Shakespeare Company used the Donmar Warehouse for years, mounting many of its finest productions on the theater's broken boards. Pam Gem's "Piaf" (in which Jane Lapotaire won a Tony for the title role on Broadway) opened in the Donmar Warehouse, as did works by Edward Bond, Stephen Poliakoff and Howard Brenton, as well as Willy Russell's "Educating Rita."
The evening should be easier on the derriere if not the mind when Stephen Sondheim's "Assassins" reopens the theater on Oct. 29. The show, which celebrates an all-American bestiary of Presidential assassins, had a bumpy ride when it appeared at Playwrights Horizons in Manhattan early last year. It won some admiration and respect, but failed to make the leap from Off Broadway to Broadway. Will new orchestration and the guiding hand of Britain's hottest young director, Sam Mendes, change the fortunes of one of Mr. Sondheim's most daringly original librettos?
Christmas is the time classical audiences want some R & R, and this year the holiday brings another major musical revival to the National Theater in London. Will Nicholas Hytner, the director of "Miss Saigon," succeed in doing for "Carousel" what Richard Eyre did for "Guys and Dolls" 10 years ago? That question will be answered on Dec. 10, the opening night for the tune-packed Rodgers and Hammerstein show.
But nearly two months before that, on Oct. 20, the West End sees a more talked-about musical arrival. Indeed, no coming show is drawing as much hype as Hal Prince's production of the John Kander and Fred Ebb version of "Kiss of the Spider Woman." The show, which reportedly faltered in workshops in New York, opened in Toronto this summer and received some rapturous reviews. Robert Cushman, a former theater critic of The London Observer who lives in Canada, wrote that it should join "Porgy and Bess," "Sweeney Todd" and "Camelot" as one of the four American musicals of truly tragic dimensions.
But how can Manuel Puig's novel-turned-play-turned-film make that leap? How can even Prince inflate a jail-house tale involving just two characters into a major musical? The answer appears to lie largely with Chita Rivera, who is coming to London to play some of the prisoners' dream women, primarily the menacing arachnoid of the title. Expect her and the show to make a prompt move to Broadway if and when it lives up to its advance billing at the Shaftesbury Theater.
Everybody complains about the dearth of new plays at mainstream London theaters, although such sightings are more frequent there than on Broadway, where they alight about as often as swallows in Antarctica. Two of Britain's less prolific dramatists have important openings, at the National Theater and the Royal Shakespeare Company's smaller London house, the Pit. And coincidentally -- or is it something in the air? -- each play has a similar theme.
Peter Shaffer, the author of "Amadeus" and "Equus," has produced nothing since "Lettice and Lovage" opened in London in 1987 and moved to New York soon after. His as yet untitled new play opens on Dec. 16 at the Pit, is directed by Peter Hall, and brings Judi Dench and Michael Pennington to the stage in a portrait of a troubled marriage. Specifically, a wife looks back on her life with a turbulent playwright, examining their love and estrangement, and what Mr. Shaffer tantalizingly calls "the dilemmas of revenge and retribution."
"Stages," by David Storey, who at the age of 59 is 7 years younger than Mr. Shaffer, also has a somewhat ruminative, introspective sound. Alan Bates plays a writer-painter performing an emotional post-mortem on himself, his loves and the work that, it seems, drove him to madness.
With Lindsay Anderson directing, as he did Mr. Storey's wonderful "Home" and "The Contractor" in the 1970's, this could be the play that regalvanizes a playwriting career that has been somewhat becalmed of late. Opening night at the National Theater: Nov. 18.
Harold Pinter, surely the greatest living British playwright, does not pen much for the theater these days. He started his professional career as an actor, has very occasionally appeared on the stage since he became a dramatist, and returns to it on Nov. 2 in his own "No Man's Land." The theater where the play is being revived is the Almeida in London's Islington section, and the event is sure to draw cognoscenti and Pinter scholars into its tiny, shabby auditorium.
What makes this doubly exciting is that "No Man's Land" is the least known of Pinter's full-length plays. It had a modest success at the National Theater in 1975, with Ralph Richardson as an alcoholic recluse and John Gielgud as the down-at-the-heels poet who assaults his name and his memories; but it has not had a major showing since then.
Will Mr. Pinter and Paul Eddington, respectively following in those actors' large footsteps, succeed in rehabilitating the play? There is no more fascinating question being posed by the London theater this fall.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE STORMS: THREE REPORTS;
Miami

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR; STEVE LOHR, a financial reporter for The Times, has covered Hurricane Andrew's effects on Florida's economy.

 BODY:
FOUR days after Hurricane Andrew cut its swath of destruction through south Florida on Aug. 24, Miami's top tourism officials met here with a group of their counterparts from Charleston, S.C., where Hurricane Hugo came ashore in 1989. One message from the South Carolina hurricane veterans: don't be misled by the surge of hotel bookings in the storm's aftermath as relief workers, insurance adjusters, construction crews and soldiers descend on the area.
Indeed, hotels rooms are scarce now in the Miami area, with occupancy rates averaging 80 percent, well above the 65 percent or so that is typical for the sluggish months before the peak winter season. "But the problem is that the influx of people because of the cleanup and rebuilding displaces the normal fall tourism business," said Helen Stansell, executive director of the Charleston Convention and Visitors Bureau. "And we found that you've got to work real hard to get people back." 
 Miami's tourism revival campaign began almost as soon as the storm passed. State and local tourist agencies have run newspaper and television ads, set up an 800 phone number for updated information and dispatched representatives abroad to allay the concerns of travel agents in key foreign markets. Their message is that the hurricane's undeniable devastation, and its eerie scenes of crumpled buildings and toppled trees, was largely confined to the southern part of Dade County.
The most populated areas and best-known tourist sites escaped severe damage. The Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau reports that 110 of its 115 member hotels are were open by last week. The Art Deco district along Ocean Drive, downtown Miami, Miami Beach and Bal Harbour suffered minor wind damage, and little more. The port facilities in Miami and Fort Lauderdale, jumping-off stations for Caribbean cruises, were spared.
Key Biscayne was hit harder. The Sonesta Beach Hotel and the Sheraton Royal Biscayne Beach Resort remain closed, though both are trying to reopen as soon as possible, perhaps before Christmas. The Silver Sands Motel, an endearing landmark and watering hole, was almost totally destroyed and its future remains in doubt.
Farther south, in the Kendall area, the 290-acre Metrozoo, which was home to 1,200 animals and an attraction for more than 700,000 visitors annually, was devastated. "It looked like a war zone when I walked in the first morning," recalled Ron Magill, the zoo's assistant curator. The storm had toppled concrete walls and picked up trucks, tossing them hundreds of yards like children's toys. During the rebuilding, expected to take a year and cost more than $20 million, one third of the animals have become refugees, sent to zoos from San Diego to the Bronx, including three koalas Mr. Magill took as passengers in a five-seat airplane to Busch Gardens in Tampa.
Still, Miami's tourist business remains remarkably intact, entirely capable of handling the 8.4 million visitors the area last year. But will they come to Miami's sun-and-fun playground knowing that the hurricane-ravaged areas and tent cities are just 25 miles or so to the south?
The answers from travel agents and cruise-line operators are mixed and inconclusive. Brian Robb, vice president of marketing for the Carlson Travel Group in Minneapolis said a scarcity of hotel rooms in Miami, not canceled tourist trips, seemed to be the big problem caused by the hurricane so far. Tim Gallagher of Carnival Cruise Lines said hurricanes were always followed by a falloff in cruise business, but added that it was too early to gauge Andrew's impact. A "nonevent," said Jane Weiller, president of Hartsdale Travel Agency in Hartsdale, N.Y., who has not seen a single cancellation in Miami travel plans after the hurricane. A "drastic effect," asserted Paul Williams of Linden Travel in Manhattan, noting that the few people the agency booked for Miami in this off-season tended to switch plans and go elsewhere, places like Bermuda.
A closer look at the high Miami-area hotel occupancy rates suggests a falloff in tourist travel. Mayco Villafana of the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau gives a rough estimate that perhaps half of the 80 percent occupancy in local hotels is normal travel, while the rest is storm-related traffic. Given the usual early-fall occupancy rate of 65 percent, that indicates a tourist and business travel shortfall of as much as 25 percent. And relief workers, cleanup crews and insurance adjusters don't spend their money on many leisure pursuits.
The leaders of Miami's tourism industry recognize that they face a challenge. "There will be a dip," said Tony Goldman, owner of the Park Central, the Imperial and the Heathcote, three adjacent hotels in the Art Deco district. "But the message we need to get across is that the devastation was 25 miles south of here, things are operating now as they did before the hurricane, and that people have nothing to feel guilty about by coming." "If they don't come," added Mr. Goldman, who is also an executive board member of the Miami visitors bureau, "then that could really shake the economics of area and inhibit the comeback of the region."
The 8.4 million tourists who visited the Miami area last year spent $7.2 billion. And nearly one-third of the region's work force, more than 250,000 people, is dependent on the tourism business. Many of these service workers live in the hurricane-battered areas of south Dade County. "If we don't have a healthy tourism industry, we'd not only have people homeless but also jobless," said Mr. Villafana of the vistors bureau.
The message that tourism is back in business is the central theme of the post-hurricane ad campaigns by the state ("Florida: We're Still Open") and Miami ("Miami's tempo is as upbeat as usual"). Spending for the Miami campaign is set at $200,000 for September through November. Getting that message out and repeating it is crucial in post-disaster situations to counteract the steady stream of television, newspaper and magazine images of destruction that people saw right after the hurricane, according to Charles Goeldner, a professor at the University of Colorado business school and editor of The Journal of Travel Research. "The biggest problem is overcoming the intial perception," Mr. Goeldner said.
TRAVEL business bounces back at different rates after natural disasters depending on how much damage was done and how deftly the local people handle the recovery. Three months after the San Francisco earthquake in 1989, the hotel occupancy rates were still 25 percent below normal and retail traffic in Fisherman's Wharf was off 50 percent, according to Economics Research Associates, a travel consultancy in San Francisco. One problem was that the San Francisco earthquake, unlike the Florida hurricane, knocked out vital traffic arteries. Yet within a year, San Francisco's tourism business had recovered fully.
More damaging to tourism is civil unrest like the riots in Los Angeles. Many Japanese tourists have shunned Los Angeles in recent months, according to Economics Research Associates. And the company's studies of tourism in Hong Kong, a staging post for China travel, after Tiananmen Square and social unrest elsewhere found that international travel to those destinations fell off sharply for two years. "Tourists are far more forgiving of acts of nature than of acts of man," said Steve Spickard, vice president of the consultancy.
For Miami, the international image is particularly important because 55 percent of its visitors come from abroad, mainly from Europe and Latin America. The evidence seems to be that foreign travelers are coming back. Dermot Cairns, a tour operator from Belfast, Northern Ireland, who sends a jetful of 360 tourists to Florida each week, reported that in the first two weeks after Andrew 75 percent of his clients canceled their trips, even though they fly into Orlando and many then go on to Miami.
But as word got out that tourist operations in Florida were working as usual, the qualms of Irish travelers soon vanished. "The business came back remarkably quickly," Mr. Cairns said.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2371 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Behind the Masks of a Moralist

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
As the dawn lightens, the first entrance of the Greek chorus shocks an audience into realizing just how astonishing Ariane Mnouchkine's Theatre du Soleil really is. The double door at the distant rear swings open and in they surge -- 15 red-clad women (though some are really men), stamping and swaying with a gleeful joy that is very close to barbaric fury.
There is little scenery in the modern sense, but the look is still riveting: faces covered with chalk-white makeup, like masks; headpieces, and costumes with full skirts, vests and glittering ornaments that are an ingenious hybrid of the ethnic cultures stretching from southern Italy through the Middle East to southern India. 
 Miss Mnouchkine's Theatre du Soleil (Theater of the Sun), an institution in Europe for nearly 30 years, is quintessentially French and inherently cosmopolitan. A nearly lifelong Parisian, Miss Mnouchkine has created a unique style that blends world theatrical cultures in the service of Western classics and contemporary epics.
Outwardly similar to the work of another Paris-based theatrical internationalist, Peter Brook, Theatre du Soleil's stylistic fusion is more diverse and organic, its enunciation of the French language more elegant and its dance and music closer to Pina Bausch and other European choreographers. Although Miss Mnouchkine has her detractors, she has won critical admiration and audience enthusiasm that is close to adulation.
Despite her fame abroad, her company has visited the United States only once, presenting Shakespeare in French at the 1984 Olympic Arts Festival in Los Angeles. Now, finally, the company will make its New York debut, with three cycles of its current four-part project, called "Les Atrides," or "The House of Atreus." The performances will take place over an 11-day period starting Thursday at the specially refitted Park Slope Armory in Brooklyn, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
Americans are hardly used to hearing theater in foreign languages; in Brooklyn, incomprehensibility will be alleviated by the familiarity of the plays and by translation through earphones. But more than language separates Theatre du Soleil from conventional Anglo-American theater. In addition to its synthesis of theatrical traditions, the company is a commune, a radical popular theater born of leftist idealism that speaks to theater lovers all across the political spectrum. When three of its four parts were staged in Paris last June, the conservative American monthly New Criterion called "Les Atrides" the "most exciting and innovative theatrical experience on earth."
Miss Mnouchkine is a cheerful woman with a handsome face, a winning grin and Brillo-like gray hair, given to baggy yet comfortably stylish clothes. She combines the images of fierce theatrical moralist, bubbling happy child, nurturing mother and forbidding French intellectual. (It was she who branded Euro Disney a "cultural Chernobyl.")
Although she was born in Paris in 1939, the daughter of Russian immigrants, Miss Mnouchkine's first connection to theater was at Oxford. "I went there to study psychology," she said, during a break from tour performances in Montpellier, not far from Marseilles. "But then I joined the Oxford University Drama Society, and one day I said, 'Of course, this is what I want to do.' "
In the early 60's, she embarked on a year's journey to Asia, then founded Theatre du Soleil in 1964. From the first, it was a visionary enterprise, a band of leftist romantics convinced that they could change the world. And although the personnel has turned over completely, the vision remains consistent.
"Theatre du Soleil is the dream of living, working, being happy and searching for beauty and for goodness," Miss Mnouchkine said. "It's trying to live for higher purposes, not for richness. It's very simple, really."
The theater got its name through a similarly openhearted idealism. "At the time theaters were named for their directors, but I could not imagine calling it Le Theatre Ariane Mnouchkine," she said. "We were looking for life, light, heat, beauty, strength, fertility . . ."
In 1970 the ensemble took possession of what has remained its home ever since -- three airy warehouses in the Cartoucherie (or weapons depot, which is what it was up to the 19th century), in the Bois de Vincennes just east of Paris. Today, the first of the warehouses is a huge lobby space, the second a transitional area, and the third, the 1,200-seat theater: sharply raked bleachers and a huge square performing area bereft of wings or flies or changeable scenery. It is this theater that Miss Mnouchkine insists be replicated whenever her company tours. But touring performances cannot duplicate the all-embracing mood in Paris, the sense of having entered, willingly, into another world.
The company spent the 1970's exploring France -- "telling our history in order to make it advance," as she once put it. In 1979 she shifted gears, with her own adaptation of Klaus Mann's novel "Mephisto." Then, in the early 80's, came Shakespeare: "Richard II" (the company's first comprehensive employment of Asian masks and costumes), "Twelfth Night" and "Henry IV, Part I."
The success of the Shakespeare productions brought yet another change of direction: two nearly daylong epic pageants about contemporary Cambodia and India by the French feminist intellectual Helene Cixous (see-zou). The next project was to have been another Cixous blockbuster, this time on the controversial topic of the Vichy regime.
"Helene Cixous was ready, but I was not," Miss Mnouchkine said. "It so difficult to imagine such a close period in time and space. Before, when we talked about France, it was a long time ago, and when we talked about now, it was far away. The Resistance images are still with us, from photographs and films. I felt my dreams were not free, not theatrical: they were still realistic."
Instead, Miss Mnouchkine plunged back into the classics. It was her idea, for "Les Atrides," to preface Aeschylus' "Oresteia" trilogy with Euripides' "Iphigenia in Aulis," written more than 50 years later and more sympathetic to Clytemnestra; her grief at the sacrifice of her daughter makes her murder of her husband more understandable. It's better theater and better feminism.
Beyond sheer spectacle, "Les Atrides" is striking for the power of its choruses, the omnipresence of the music and the doubling and redoubling of the principal parts. The chorus changes from fiercely joyful women in "Iphigenia" to soldiers overcome by the horror of war in "Agamemnon" to black-clad, vulturelike harridans in "The Libation Bearers." In "The Eumenides" they become terrifying mythic beasts, no longer dancing but growling and snarling, led by three harpies straight from a Brechtian proletarian netherworld and standing as eternal threats to human benevolence.
The ever-present background music is provided by Jean-Jacques Lemetre, who has been with the troupe for 14 years. When actors are speaking, he leaps among his battery of exotic instruments, a megalomaniacally inflated one-man band, although for the chorus dances he falls back on recorded ensemble music. He says his music is so intimately wedded to speech rhythms that having other musicians accompany him would be nearly impossible, and a live dance ensemble would be too expensive.
More unusual still is the casting of a few actors in most of the major roles. The most dramatic case is that of Simon Abkarian, a French-born Armenian raised in Lebanon who spent many years in Southern California -- as a cabaret dancer, he says. Mr. Abkarian plays Agamemnon, Achilles, a chorus leader, a messenger, Orestes and, to cap this tour de force, Orestes' nurse.
The Brazilian Juliana Carneiro da Cunha, a dancer trained in the school of Maurice Bejart, does both Clytemnestra and Athena in "The Eumenides"; the Indian Nirupama Nityanandan is Cassandra, a chorus leader, and Iphigenia, a role in which her 20 years of training as a Bharata Natyam dancer in Madras can be seen to especially beguiling effect. Brontis Jodorowsky, born in Mexico of a Chilean father and a French mother, plays a host of secondary parts.
Artistic decisions are described as simple deductions from unassailable "evidence"; that doubling parts may make dramatic sense is dismissed as coincidence. "What I call theatrical evidence just emerges," Miss Mnouchkine said. "It's not discussed. We discuss when something goes wrong, when for two or three days we are stuck. When the work is going, we don't discuss, we work."
The actors concede, however, that Miss Mnouchkine makes the final decisions. Mr. Jodorowsky sees her as almost like a Zen master: "She directs not by adding things but by taking things away, down to the more and more simple, the more essential."
Dismissive of most acting today, with its uninflected imitation of life, Miss Mnouchkine prefers a broadly emotive style that recalls what we know of early Western theater and that still exists in the non-Western world. Not for her, despite her own academic background, the psychological identification of the typical modern Western actor. "We flee daily life," she said in an interview in The Drama Review. "We do not talk of psychology but rather of the characters' souls. The theater is not supposed to represent psychology but passions."
Miss Mnouchkine believes that masks (or masklike makeup) liberate acting from pale realism. In "Les Atrides," the masks and makeup become simpler as the plays approach modernity. Yet, Miss Mnouchkine says, the mask is always there -- "the mask of character."
She categorically rejects the idea that she has poached on exotic cultures. "What we do derives completely from the action of the characters," she said. "Iphigenia is not using the real steps and mudras of India, which would mean nothing to us. She's just showing her feelings. She's not using the codes; she's using what is inward.
"IMPERIALISM IS NOT MY problem; it is your problem," she said, speaking of Americans. "Cultural imperialism is the opposite of what we do. It is the repressing of other cultures. It's what we suffer from in France, with the film and television products of the United States."
Economically, Theatre du Soleil is still a commune, although its members live in their own apartments with whomever they please. It is legally organized to share income -- at present, 60 people (including Miss Mnouchkine and the 26 actors as well as backstage personnel) receive 9,000 francs ($1,800) each per month. "It's a small salary," Miss Mnouchkine said, "but it's not worse than many other theaters."
The company is given $1.4 million annually by the French Ministry of Culture, the figure having been doubled in 1981 when the Socialists took power. The rest of its income (roughly twice the subsidy in an average year, according to Nathalie Pousset, a company administrator) derives from the box office and fees from tour hosts. Miss Mnouchkine rejects corporate sponsorship, but the New York debut was insured by French corporate support from Air France and Elf Aquitaine.
Right now, the troupe is a young one, with the veteran actors having only six or seven years of tenure. "When we started, we were there for all our lives," Miss Mnouchkine recalled wistfully. "But of course it's a mistake to think that."
Miss Mnouchkine holds annual workshops, usually 10 days long, and although she says they are not auditions, she gets most of her actors from them. By all evidence this is a happy group, full of people who really like one another. Miss Carneiro da Cunha, for one, speaks lyrically of her new friendship with Miss Mnouchkine, how they left a late show in Toulouse and rode through the streets on their bicycles as the sun came up.
Still, there is the potential for estrangement between the director and her actors. "People who come here may be nervous at first," Miss Carneiro da Cunha said. "They know Ariane as somebody very famous. But after a while they just see Ariane. And they're famous, too, collectively. What is difficult is the question of age. I've aged and they have not."
Although the company remains true to its Utopian ideals from the 60's, the Utopia seems now to be expressed in religious terms -- the theater as a sacred space and art as an avenue to the divine.
"That is all very personal, very intimate," Miss Mnouchkine said. "We never go on stage thoughtlessly, without saluting it, some little sign, just putting a hand on the stage. For some it's religious, for others superstitious, for others just a habit. Our actors never step on the stage without realizing that it relates to spirit and the progress of the mind."
 
 
 
ASSEMBLING THE PARTS
 "Les Atrides" will be presented under the auspices of the Brooklyn Academy of Music at the Park Slope Armory, Eighth Avenue and 15th Street. The four plays will be performed in three four-part series: the first is this Thursday and Friday and Oct. 8 and Oct. 9 at 8 P.M.; the second, Saturday at 3:30 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 1:30 and 6 P.M.; the third, Oct. 10 at 3:30 and 8 P.M. and Oct. 11 at 1:30 and 6 P.M. Each performance runs approximately two and a half hours, without intermission.
Series tickets are sold out, but seats remain for individual performances. Tickets are $40 and can be purchased through Ticketmaster and at the BAM ticket office (but not at the armory). Information: (718) 636-4100.
Seating is reserved by section only; there are no reserved seats and latecomers will not be seated. Doors open one hour prior to curtain time, and the audience is invited to secure seats and then visit the dressing area beneath the armory bleachers to watch the troupe put on costumes and makeup.
For simultaneous translations of performances, which are in French, headsets can be rented for $5.
Picnic meals are available prior to curtain time and between performances on weekends.
To reach the armory by subway, take the F train to the Prospect Park-15th Street stop and walk two blocks north. A free shuttle bus goes to the armory from BAM, 30 Lafayette Avenue, 90 minutes before each performance and returns to BAM up to an hour afterward.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Letting Your Computer Be Your Guide

BYLINE: By L. R. SHANNON; L. R. SHANNON writes the Peripherals column for The Times.

 BODY:
PERSONAL-COMPUTER owners will soon have access to travel information drawn from the Zagat Survey guides to hotels and restaurants, which compile customers' opinions of the establishments.
The software, one of three noteworthy programs for travelers, brings together the Zagat information with mapping data, right down to street addresses, licensed from Etak, of Menlo Park, Calif., in a versatile and easy-to-use program developed by Axxis Electronic Publishing, of Haverford, Pa. The product, Zagat-Axxis Cityguide, should be available in retail outlets starting Thursday. The first three guides will be for New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, and will cost about $99 each, or all three for $249. 
 Maps are at the heart of the Cityguides, both overall maps of the selected cities or more detailed representations of neighborhoods of interest. Underlying the maps are the data, which can be searched in many ways. For instance, you could ask for all the French restaurants with a Zagat food rating of at least 18 within a specified distance from your hotel. (Zagat ratings run from 0 to 30.)
The computer then would produce a capsule review of one or more restaurants -- there are 1,063 in the New York version -- with address, phone number, price and other information. Of course, you can find all that in a book. But the computer also displays a map, pinpointing the location of the restaurant, and will show the best route for getting there, as a line on the map or in plain prose, which a user can print out and take along. You can even specify areas you would like the route to avoid or places you want to include on the way. The hotel information, for 79 establishments in New York City, is handled similarly.
Although there is no reason that a Cityguide couldn't be used on a desktop computer, it is really aimed at travelers who carry a portable computer. The search for a place to have dinner can become so absorbing, indeed, that there is a danger you will never leave the room.
For people who tend to such absorption, the program offers plenty of toys, or rather tools, for edification. You can zoom in and out for closer or more general views, measure distances, draw on the map or split the screen to see two neighborhoods at once. The map can even be folded, electronically, much like a printed version.
The computer requirements are well up in the high end, particularly for a portable. The machine must be capable of running Microsoft Windows 3.0 or 3.1, preferably in color, with at least two megabytes of working memory (four megabytes is recommended, though) and, depending on the city, five to nine megabytes of hard-disk space. Additional cities should come on line before the end of the year, more than 30 in the United States, as well as versions for the Apple Macintosh and Powerbook, and for a variety of handheld computers. More information: Zagat Survey at (800) 333-3421 or (212) 977-6000.
 
Campground Directory
 Finding the right campground or recreational-vehicle park couldn't be easier when a computer does the dirty work. Microcamp Campground Directory, Western U.S.A., a program from Corinthian Concepts of Fair Oaks, Calif., makes that possible.
Let us say we are planning to drive a 35-foot recreational vehicle to South Lake Tahoe, Calif., in September. The first step is to pick the state, California, followed by the geographic region, the northeast. Then we select the nearby town, in this case South Lake Tahoe, from a long list. Next we fill in an on-screen form with the features we want in a campground: the minimum area in acres; the maximum elevation in feet; the month open; the minimum number of tent and R.V. sites; the maximum R.V. length the camp can handle; R.V. hookups and waste-disposal stations; boating; drinking water; flush toilets; trails; swimming; fishing; showers, and whether the camp is public or private.
It is necessary only to specify the requirements we insist on; the rest can be left to fall as they may. For instance, gregarious travelers might prefer a camp with a fairly high minimum number of sites, so there are more people to meet, or dedicated walkers will want trails to explore. In this example, the crucial factors are the month, September; the R.V. length, 35 feet, and, come to think of it, a shower after a couple of days on the road. So we fill in those blanks and press a key. (By the way, almost no typing is involved. Selections are made from a series of lists.)
In an instant, the names of three campgrounds appear: K.O.A. Kampground Tahoe Paradise, Richardson's Resort and Tahoe Valley Campground. We're familiar with K.O.A.'s, so we'll look at that one first. Another key is pressed.
In addition to the information we already knew, because we specified it, there are driving directions from South Lake Tahoe, the phone number and address, reservations policy, the number of tent and R.V. sites, and much else, including whether pets are allowed.
Instead of seeking a camp by state, region and nearby town, you can look for one in a particular recreation area -- the Kenai Peninsula in Alaska, say, or Bighorn Canyon in Montana. The program is limited to 12 states: Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington and Wyoming.
When you have made your choice, you can print out the information and take it along. In fact, if you travel with a computer, you can take the whole program along.
Hardware requirements are fairly modest: a computer with any kind of monitor, 512 kilobytes of internal memory, DOS 2.0 or later and a hard disk with at least two megabytes of free space. The suggested retail price is $99.95, and if Microcamp is not available at a software shop it can be ordered from Corinthian Concepts by phoning (916) 863-1475.
 
Cities on CD-ROM
 CD-ROM technology -- Compact Disk-Read Only Memory -- might have been invented for travel guidebooks. These little platters, essentially the same as the more familiar music CD's, can hold enormous numbers of words, as well as striking illustrations and even sounds. Great Cities of the World, volumes one and two, bring all of these capabilities to a home or office personal computer, assuming it is a rather powerful one.
Volume one covers Bombay, Cairo, London, Los Angeles, Moscow, New York, Paris, Rio de Janeiro, Sydney and Tokyo; volume two covers Berlin, Buenos Aires, Chicago, Jerusalem, Johannesburg, Rome, San Francisco, Seoul, Singapore and Toronto.
For each city, there is information in the following categories: fast facts, such things as climate and currency; culture; sights; transportation; shopping; entertainment; recreation; restaurants, and hotels, divided into deluxe, moderate, economy and ones near the airport. There are maps galore. In volume two, parts of the maps can be selected for a more detailed look, although the mapping options are rudimentary compared with those in the Zagat-Axxis packages.
So-called slide shows put color photographs of attractions in the selected cities on the screen, complete with narration and music. There are essays by Jan Morris, Pico Iyer and Simon Winchester.
To run the Great Cities programs, one of the following systems is required: an A.T.-class machine running DOS 3.1 or later, with 640 kilobytes of memory, V.G.A. graphics, hard disk, mouse, CD-ROM drive and headphones or speakers; a Multimedia-equipped A.T. running DOS 3.1 or later, two megabytes of memory, Super V.G.A., audio card, hard disk, mouse, CD-ROM drive and headphones or speakers; a Macintosh LC or II-series computer, System 6.0.7 or later, four megabytes of memory, a 13-inch color monitor, hard disk and CD-ROM player.
Each of the two volumes of Great Cities of the World has a suggested retail price of $79.95. They are available at major software shops, or directly from the publisher, Interoptica Publishing, 300 Montgomery Street, second floor, San Francisco, Calif. 94104; (415) 788-8788.

LENGTH: 1751 words

HEADLINE: AFTER THE STORMS: THREE REPORTS;
Bahamas

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL; EDWIN McDOWELL covers the travel industry for The Times.

 BODY:
ONLY hours before Hurricane Andrew smashed into the United States mainland late last month the storm barreled into the Bahamas, the string of islands stretching 600 miles southeastward into the Atlantic Ocean from just off the coast of Florida. While the destruction in the Bahamas does not compare with the devastation in south Florida, the hurricane -- the worst to hit the islands in more than 60 years -- killed four people and left some 1,700 of the 250,000 residents of the Bahamas homeless. It also wiped out roads, bridges and resort hotels.
But almost all major damage was confined to the northern part of Eleuthera, Harbour Island, Spanish Wells, Cat Cay, Bimini and part of the Berry Islands -- that is, to several of the sparsely populated Family Islands. Nassau and Freeport were untouched, except for minor damage from high winds and rain, as were the Abacos, Cat Island, Andros Island, the Exumas, San Salvador and various other of the Bahamas's 40 inhabited islands. 
 Prime Minister Hubert A. Ingraham said there was $250 million in damage, with $100 million of it on Cat Cay. In a separate, earlier interview Baltron Bethel, the Bahamas director general of tourism said "the physical devastation affected about 2 percent of our rooms, cottages and apartments."
Instead of a modest increase in tourism this year, officials now expect a 10 to 20 percent drop -- despite their reassurances to travel agents in North America and an extensive advertising campaign designed to assure the public that 98 percent of the Bahamas was untouched by the hurricane. Still, even though damage was so limited the Bahamian economy was affected more than Florida's. The island nation earns almost 60 percent of its gross domestic product from tourism, and the jobs of 7 out of 10 Bahamians are dependent on the industry.
The restoration and repair of property already underway on most of the damaged islands is impressive, but it may take years to recover from the loss of wildlife and the uprooting of tens of thousands of trees, plants and flowers. While most tourists visit the Bahamas to swim, shop and gamble, the loss of some of the islands' natural beauty could hurt the new Bahamian Government's efforts to emphasize tourism for nature lovers and environmentalists.
Looking forlornly across eight acres that until recently had been graced by stately coconut palm trees, Roger Becht, the owner of the 10-room Runaway Hill Club on Harbour Island, one and a half miles long, lamented three weeks after the hurricane, "With its beautiful beaches and reefs, this island can't help but come back. But for most of us, it just won't have the same look." While the rooms themselves suffered only minor
 flooding and boken windows, Runaway Hill's landscape and vegetation are no longer lush.
Several hundred yards down the pink-tinged beach, on 16 landscaped acres that had been a bird sanctuary, the Pink Sands resort is a tangle of uprooted palm trees and rotting vegetation heaped so high that in some places it obscures the windows blown out of the 29 abandoned cottages.
But the Pink Sands is an exception; most of the half-dozen other resorts on Harbour Island, which traditionally close from Labor Day to about mid-November, already look as though they will be ready to greet guests on schedule. For example, the 10-room Ocean View Beach Club, high atop a cliff overlooking the ocean, lost the railing on its deck and sustained other minor damage. "But we were planning to close for renovations in October anyhow," said Ithalia Johnson, the assistant manager, "so when we reopen you won't even know a storm passed through here -- except for the missing vegetation."
OCEAN VIEW plans to reopen Nov. 1, as does the 14-acre beachfront Coral Sands Hotel and the Rock House, a seven-room hotel facing the bay. The 38-room Romora Bay Club, once a private estate, expects to reopen by November.
The residents of Harbour Island still hope to restore some of its natural beauty. "We're trying to import 15- to-20 foot palm trees" to preserve the island's character, said Clayton Johnston, a Canadian-born schoolteacher, who has lived there five years. As he spoke, members of the Bahamian defense force and construction crews from the United States Navy were swarming atop the island's elementary school, putting the finishing repairs on the roof damaged by the hurricane.
Andrew also hit nearby Spanish Wells, which now has only one of its two hotels remaining, and the northern end of Eleuthera, the narrow, 110-mile long island less than 10 minutes by ferry from Harbour Island and Spanish Wells. The hurricane destroyed the 18-room Current Club Beach Resort and Marina in northern Eleuthera and damaged at least four other hotels and resorts in the area. It caused structural damage Club Med Eleuthera's restaurant and water-sports complex, closing the 300-room resort 10 miles from Governor's Harbour Airport. But the club plans to reopen Nov. 14. Veering westward, the storm also battered the Berry Islands, Cat Cay and Bimini.
Though sparsely populated, those islands struck by Andrew are among the brightest jewels in the crown that the new Government -- elected to office only four days before the hurricane hit -- was planning to use as its lure for environmentally oriented travelers.
The hurricane damage would have been far worse had not Andrew mostly just huffed and puffed at Nassau (New Providence) and Freeport (Grand Bahamas), briefly interrupting power and telephones, toppling trees, breaking windows and flooding roads. Not only are those the most populous cities, but their attractions and gambling casinos lure most of the 3.6 million annual visitors, who last year spent $1.2 billion.
"We canceled some shows, and we taped our windows and put sandbags against the exits," said Peter F. Major II, executive assistant manager of the 867-room Carnival's Crystal Palace on Nassau's Cable Beach. "Then we held a hurricane party for guests in a ballroom, but luckily the worst we got were high winds and rain."
Despite Government fears, many visitors appear unfazed. Hunter Turnage, a Cablevision salesman from Raleigh, N.C., arrived in Nassau earlier this month on a four-day package tour. "I checked with my travel agent to be sure the hurricane didn't affect Nassau," he said, "and when they said there was no problem I didn't give it a second thought."
Also there were many Japanese tourists, part of the growing number of visitors from that country to the Bahamas. "We have a group arrive every day, 99 percent of them honeymooners," said Tomoko Mitamura, resident representative for ANA Hallo Tours, who added that only a few groups delayed their arrival because of the hurricane.
Three young women from Tokyo, who attended high school and college together, stood in Parliament Square recently listening to the Salvation Army band, the sun glistening off the musician's brass instruments and white uniforms. "We came to swim and win lots of money gambling," said one of them, to a chorus of laughter from her friends.
Despite the impressive pace of repairs on the damaged islands, some hotels there may never come back. "If this is rebuilt it won't be by us, because we're selling it," said Crystal Newbold, the wife of one of four owners of the Spanish Wells Beach Resort, a 30-room landmark on Spanish Wells island. Mrs. Newbold spoke amid the rubble left after the hurricane sheared off the resort's entire second floor, shattered windows and uprooted trees. A few blocks away, Lester Roberts, the manager of the Spanish Wells Yacht Haven, with five apartments, was busy arranging repairs for the dock and replacement windows for the office.
The hurricane destroyed the Chub Cay Club, a hotel and 90-slip marina at the south end of Berry Island, according to Mr. Bethel. According to Prime Minister Ingraham, Andrew also destroyed the Cat Cay Club and its 110-slip marina on Cat Cay, a three-mile-long luxury hideaway about 50 miles from Florida.
"Almost everything there is completely shattered," said Paddy O'Leary, a pilot for Chalk's International Airlines, who flew several post-hurricane charter flights to Cat Cay. After taking off from Bimini recently he flew his 17-passenger seaplane low over Cat Cay, enabling passengers to view the widespread wreckage alongside million-dollar estates and to see the hundreds of palm trees uprooted or broken in two by wind gusts that residents estimate exceeded 200 miles an hour.
Winds hurtling up Bimini Harbor blew off part of the roof at 24-room Brown's hotel, then continued up the beach where it destroyed the dock and flooded several of the 49 guest rooms at the Bimini Big Game Fishing Club and Hotel, owned by Bacardi. It also smashed windows and downed trees at the 32-slip Blue Water Resort, which is host of the Hemingway billfish tournament in March. Both operations are back in business, but without many of the trees, hibiscus and bougainvillea that formerly graced their beachfront properties.
THE COMPLEAT ANGLER, the bar, restaurant and 12-room hotel in Bimini, suffered some flooding and the same power and telephone failure that afflicted most of the Family Islands. But the storm left virtually untouched the ground-floor Hemingway Museum, which is filled with photographs, sketches and other memorabilia of the writer, who often held forth in the bar in the 1930's.
Up the hill, between harbor and ocean, the 13-room Anchorage Restaurant and Hotel lost nine coconut trees, a half-dozen windows and much of its vegetation. "I'm 53, and I lived through a lot of storms, but nothing like this," said Ivan Banks Thompson, its longtime bartender. "But everybody pitched in to help, and the storm actually brought all the people back together who had been divided by the election."
Mr. Thompson was referring to the bitterly contested election Aug. 19, in which the Free National Movement toppled the Progressive Liberal Party, which had ruled the Bahamas for 25 consecutive years.
The new administration plans to sell the seven Government-owned hotels -- three on Grand Bahama Island, two on Nassua and two on Andros -- and four casinos (two each on Nassau and Freeport) to private developers. It envisions developing and promoting the Family Islands as separate and distinctive destinations not only for the scuba diving for which they are now renowned but also for nature walks, bird watching and quiet getaways at small, family-owned-and-operated clubs and lodges.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1466 words

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Water and Sewer Charges;
The Orange Light on Meter-Based Billing

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
RICHARD MEYERS is a prudent man. When New York City installed a new water meter at the 37-unit building he manages at 1780 Eastburn Avenue near the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, he called in a consultant. How could the building conserve on water use, he asked.
The consultant told him to put aerators on the bathroom faucets. Change the kitchen faucets. Replace the valves in the toilets. Buy new shower heads. If the correct products are chosen, low-flow devices can save 10 to 30 percent in water use, the consultant said, at a cost of only $40 to $60 an apartment. 
 Mr. Meyers did all that. But he has yet to tell the Department of Environmental Protection's Bureau of Water and Energy Conservation to start billing him on a consumption basis -- the purpose of the new meters that are gradually being installed citywide. Thanks to a moratorium on mandatory billing by usage in multifamily buildings (unless they have been built or rehabilitated since 1985), he will still be billed by the traditional method, based on building frontage and other property characteristics.
"I might change my mind," he said. "It depends on whether I get better control than I have now."
Regardless of the billing system used, it is becoming clear that rapidly rising water and sewer charges will be a key issue in multifamily housing operations in the 90's. The question is whether the city and state will respond to the issue.
They won't be goaded to action by aroused tenants, most likely. Renters don't feel surges in operating costs as a pocketbook issue. Co-op dwellers, however, may notice their maintenances costs rising. For homeowners, consumption billing has usually moderated the effect of rate increases.
The water agency itself is restudying the billing question. A one-year moratorium on mandatory use-based billing in city-metered apartment buildings was announced in May 1991. It was extended for another year last May. Owners have been told that if they install a meter voluntarily they can have frontage billing for two years thereafter. They can have it for three years if they also install 1.6-gallon-a-flush toilets.
Meanwhile, the city is systematically installing meters at a rate of 7,000 to 10,000 a year toward a 1998 completion date. About 2,500 multifamily properties have metered billing already because they are of post-1985 construction, and 2,000 more have it because of voluntary installation. There are about 80,000 multifamily properties in all.
Most owners are "sitting on their hands," as one spokesman put it, hoping for a change in a pricing system in which, in the name of conservation, they are held accountable for their tenants' usage habits.
The pricing system is in fact under review as sharply rising bills in metered higher-density moderate-income and low-income properties spread alarm in housing circles. While rates rise rapidly, consumption-based billing has put the greatest burden on the housing that is least able to afford it -- low-income, often overoccupied, buildings.
"Much of our problem has been to meet the city's mandated sewer-treatment capacity," said Steven F. Ostrega, deputy environmental commissioner in charge of the water bureau. "If we don't curb demand we'll have to expand sewer treatment plants. We can't have business as usual. We meter to change behavior." He said he expects a 17 percentage drop in usage in one- to three-family houses, and 7 1/2 percent systemwide in multifamily housing.
BUT he also said the agency was considering combining a uniform base charge with a consumption-based charge, which many utilities across the country do. That might help even out the disparity between low-occupancy and high-occupancy buildings without losing the incentive to conserve on water use.
"The city went from one extreme to the other in 1988, but the optimum is somewhere in the middle," said Frank R. Lichtenberg, professor of finance and economics at the Columbia Business School.
On the conservation side, incentives for installing low-flow equipment are conceivable. City housing officials say they want to revise the regulations on J-51 tax abatements to reclassify toilet replacements as a major capital improvement. A $350 abatement would then be available even if the replacement was not part of a larger-scale upgrading. Legislative action is needed in Albany.
Under state Division of Housing and Community Renewal rules, owners of rent-regulated buildings must install three fixtures -- sink, bathtub or shower, and toilet -- to get reimbursement through a major capital improvement allowance. In a 50-unit building, toilet replacement for low-water-use equipment might cost $15,000, said Lewis M. Kwit, a consultant. But to get the allowance an owner must spend $50,000. Owners have asked the division to consider a change.
Even without consumption-based billing, customers have been feeling the rising rates. Property owners now pay $1.01 for 100 cubic feet of water (748 gallons), and their sewer sharge for that much use is $1.61. The $2.62 total is double the charge five years ago.
Ten years ago the city's sewer rate was a third of its water charge. This year the sewer rate is 59 percent above the water charge. Normal water use for three-person apartment households is 200 to 400 gallons a day. At the present $2.62 charge for 100 cubic feet, the cost attributable to an apartment using 40 cubic feet (299.2 gallons) of water a day for a 31-day month is $32.48. The actual range of use in New York City buildings is much wider and depends on population density, mechanical efficiency and whether there are leaks and how long they persist.
At Manhattan Plaza, a 1,680-unit development at 42d Street and Ninth Avenue, average daily use is only 210 gallons per apartment, said Alan Rothschild, president of the Vantage Group, a consulting firm in North Brunswick, N.J. And the building can do 10 or 20 percent better, he said. In buildings with average densities of four or five people per apartment, 400 to 600 gallons a day is the likely average. "But I've seen averages of over 1,000 gallons a day," Mr. Rothschild said. Leaks or waste are the culprits when high density is not.
Many tenants don't know how much water is used in normal living. A five-minute shower with a high-flow shower head uses 25 to 35 gallons (15 to 20 gallons with a low-flow device), Mr. Rothschild said. Older tank toilets with older flushometers use five to seven gallons a flush. Running a faucet without an aerator for five minutes might use 15 to 20 gallons.
The effect of the rate increases and metered billing on lower-income apartments is illustrated by data from the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, or LISC. The corporation-backed nonprofit company will have financed 3,000 units of low-income rehabilitations in the city by the end of the year.
It studied 11 projects with 972 apartments, most of them two-bedrooms, that have had water meters for two years. The average water and sewer cost per apartment last year was $249. When the rent levels were set in 1988, the projected cost was only $90.
Now, for new projects, LISC is following the approach of the Community Preservation Corporation, a major source of financing for moderate-income housing. It is planning for costs of $400 per apartment a year -- or 11 percent of total operating costs.
"This flawed approach is having a truly serious impact on the long-term viability of housing," said Marc Jahr, LISC's New York City program director of consumption-based billing. The Community Preservation Corporation also has warned that the new level of cost is a threat to moderate-income housing.
At the water board, Mr. Ostrega said that city capital funds were needed to cover 86 percent of the cost of federally mandated sewer improvements in fiscal 1992, or $534 million. Five years ago the city paid 50 percent, or $204 million.
"There can be a 20 to 40 percent saving in water use without changing tenant habits," Mr. Rothschild said. But owners have to pick the right products from among hundreds on the market. Billing based on use provides the incentive, he said. But he also favors some degree of cost passthrough to tenants.
"There must be enough of a passthrough so people will report leaks," said Dan Margulies, executive director of Community Housing Improvement Program, an owner group concerned with building operations.
Owners are generally skeptical of how much tenants can be expected to cooperate by reporting equipment malfunctions, practicing restraint in use and permitting prompt repairs. Since conservation provides no economic reward to renters, and waste carries no penalty, it may be naive to expect widespread cooperation.
"Education will work in some buildings but not in others," Mr. Margulies said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

INDUSTRY: SIC5141 GENERAL LINE GROCERIES (53%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (97%);

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Shopping Malls;
Luring Crowds -- and Buyers -- With Fun and Games

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
LAST April, Newport Center, the 1.2 million-square-foot, two-story mall developed by Melvin Simon & Associates in Jersey City, leased space to a carousel. Since then, sales at the street-level stores nearest to the ride are up almost 27 percent over the same period last year and sales at second-floor stores are up 10.4 percent.
"I can't prove it, but I'm pretty certain the carousel made the difference," said Kenneth L. Volk, the center's marketing director. 
 The owners of the CambridgeSide Galleria, a mixed-use complex on the Charles River in Cambridge, Mass., insists that the stores in its three-story, million-square-foot mall already are doing well. Still, they expect that a sports museum and a sports-oriented gaming arcade scheduled to open early next year will increase traffic, and thus sales, even more.
"They'll bring people to the mall on weekday mornings, say, or other hours when malls generally don't do a lot of business," said Stephen R. Karp, chairman of New England Development of Newton, Mass., the mall's owner.
Gone are the days when shopping centers relied only on a good mix of stores and a decent location to thrive. The overbuilding of malls in the 70's, the continuing entry of women into the workforce and the stubborn recession have created a situation where a glut of malls is competing for a dearth of shoppers.
As a result, malls increasingly are wooing game rooms, rides, museums, even stores that double as entertainment centers, all in the hope that they will bring more shoppers in to play, perchance to buy.
"Developers have learned that good clean amusements not only turn vacant spaces into income-producing areas, but also serve as gathering places that attract shoppers," said Deborah Kops, a partner with Arthur Andersen Real Estate Services in Dallas.
Data on sales per square foot are difficult to come by. But Keith J. Foxe, a spokesman for the International Council of Shopping Centers in Manhattan, says he's certain that sales have dropped in the last couple of years.
And developers, while not offering hard numbers, acknowledge the problem.
"Time spent in shopping malls has been declining steadily, because your typical shopper has neither the time nor the money to spend," said M. Leanne Lachman, a managing director of Schroder Center Management of Dallas, which manages 10 malls in the South and West and has put game rooms in most of them.
Big-league developers like Melvin Simon, based in Indianapolis, and the Rouse Company, based in Columbia, Md., and smaller, regional developers like Schroder are inviting amusement tenants to open new facilities or expand old ones in some of their malls. Among those being wooed are Edison Brothers, of St. Louis, which operates virtual-reality parlors, which immerse players in a computer-generated mock environment, or Nickels and Dimes Incorporated in Dallas, which operates gaming arcades,
They are also talking to hybrid amusement/selling operations like Oshman's, based in Houston, which lets customers play a variety of sports as well as buy sporting equipment, and Glamour Shops, based in Oklahoma City, which takes, and sells, photos of customers in amusing poses.
For the amusement tenants themselves, a result has been not only good lease terms, but also access to locations that might have spurned them in the past. Susan E. Mosedale, a spokeswoman for the International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions in Alexandria, Va., says that calls from mall developers are so frequent that her association now takes exhibit space at the International Shopping Center Show. And developers and game room operators alike report little, if any, difficulty getting zoning variances needed to be in shopping centers.
"We used to be a pariah," said Ronald M. Kostelny, president of Nickels and Dimes, which operates more than 200 arcade-like operations at malls. "Now we're being invited in, at real low rents."
Indeed, amusement tenants can solve a multitude of problems for malls. They can keep shoppers at the mall longer, provide amusement for children or nonshopping spouses and, in rural malls where space is ample, turn open areas into income-producing property -- say, by putting in miniature golf courses.
In more cramped malls, scaled-down amusements often fit in secondary space that is otherwise hard to rent.
IN a sense, the gap between the amusement industry and the shopping center industry has narrowed. Many of the Rouse-owned centers, like South Street, Boston's Faneuil Hall and the like are as much amusement malls as they are shopping areas. And shopping center-cum-fantasyland malls woo as many tourists hankering for fun as shoppers clamoring for goods.
Among them are Melvin Simon's new 4.2-million-square-foot Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn.; the 11-year old West Edmonton Mall in Alberta, Canada, and the new Forum Shops, next to Caesar's Palace in Las Vegas, which sports moving sculptures and other attractions.
For its part, the amusement industry has grown far more sophisticated. Virtual reality, laser tag and other high-tech attractions have never developed the beer-drugs-and-cigarette stigma that pool halls and pinball arcades once had. And, consultants say, parents have less trouble with the idea that their children are hanging out at an arcade next to Macy's than with their being at one next to a bar or adult book store.
"There's more respectability to amusements at a mall than at a downtown area," said Charles A. Shorter, a real estate specialist at Arthur Andersen in New York.
Still, not all malls have the space or the inclination to put in a full-scale amusement parlor. For them, the answer to spicing up the shopping experience is often to woo stores that do double duty as amusement centers, like Oshman's Sporting Goods. These stores, sprinkled across the country, not only sell sporting goods, but also serve as sporting places in their own right: Visitors can play basketball or golf, rollerblade, whack tennis balls -- and, of course, buy all the attendant paraphernalia.
"WE'RE now getting the kind of great deals on leases that only full-service department stores used to get," crows Alvin N. Lubetkin, president of Oshman's, whose stores generally run upward of 55,000 square feet.
Schroder, for one, is wooing Oshman's to many of its malls, on the theory that a miniature golf course, say, can attract visitors but that a small in-store golfing area next to golf-related merchandise is going to attract visitors and buyers.
"They attract men who come in with their kids, and their sales per square foot are terrific," said Ms. Lachman.
Still, the rush to amusement tenants has not yet hit New York City. Melvin Simon, for one, emphatically spurns amusements for A. & S. Plaza, its vertical mall in Manhattan.
"Mall of America draws families, who come to spend the day," said Donald E. Boelke, executive vice president of Melvin Simon. "A. & S. Plaza targets commuters and transients and it commands rents that no arcade could pay."
Similarly, the South Street Seaport, in lower Manhattan, is just getting a toe wet in the amusement pool, and even that it is doing reluctuantly. The huge festival mall has let Edison Brothers put in a tiny, 50-square-foot virtual-reality game room on the second floor of the Fulton Market Building, a vertical food court crammed with fresh food shops and restaurants. If that turns out to be popular and problem-free, the Seaport may put in a full-scale virtual-reality room or some other form of amusement.
But Larry M. Wolf, a senior vice president of the Rouse Company, which owns South Street, is more resigned than ecstatic over the prospect.
"Entertainment tenants are not high rent payers, and they don't generate high sales per square foot," he said, "and you're certainly not going to put them in spaces that you can rent to an Ann Taylor store, or even in space right next to an Ann Taylor store."
But, he added, "They are still a lot better than nonproductive space."

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
A Small Menu Mostly From the Grill

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BROOKS

 BODY:
RIDING the crest of the trend for grilled dishes is Chop Chop American Grill in Westport. The word grill in a restaurant's name suggests not only fresh foods simply prepared but also telegraphs casual and informal, which suggests economical dining as well -- a suggestion not always borne out in the pricing.
Chop Chop American Grill is in a free-standing building that has housed several other restaurants in recent years (most recently Checkers). A fence-enclosed outside dining area has been added in front, which is very pleasant as long as the weather remains cooperative. Inside the rather dark, medium-small main dining area (there's a second dining room upstairs) the decor is simple, with creamy-tone stucco walls, velveteen cafe curtains, matching wall hangings and area separators, appliqued with patches of patterned fabric suggesting stylized cows. We're not sure whether this free association is valid, though steaks are on the menu. 
 A small menu, such as this one, usually augurs well, suggesting that the chef has set parameters. In addition to two steak choices, the menu also lists several other grilled red meat entrees -- lamb chops and filet mignon -- along with several grilled seafood dishes.
Chop Chop is open for dinner only. We began one evening with Maryland crab cakes with chive beurre blanc sauce. The two medium-size crisp, deeply browned, tightly packed cakes were pepped up by the addition of red pepper flakes.
Another worthwhile starter was grilled scaloppine of swordfish: thin escalopes in a perky mustard tarragon sauce, accented by a julienne of summer squash, zucchini and carrots (the same julienne that accompanied the entrees).
Less appealing was an order of grilled sliced eggplant, portobello mushrooms and roasted red peppers in a bath of olive oil and balsamic vinegar. The problem was the star of the show: chunks of eggplant had been skinned before grilling, thus all the rich smokiness that usually accrues to the skin was lost. What remained was chewy, tasteless and boring.
Two salads sounded terrific but came up short. We ordered the mixed green salad because of its promise of endive and Gorgonzola but though the greens were diverse and crisp, the endive consisted of a few pieces chopped fine and the Gorgonzola had gone AWOL. A bibb lettuce, tomato and watercress salad had a sparkling raspberry dressing, but deserved better olives than the tired canned black ones.
Among the entrees, Angus won: the boneless Angus shell steak grilled, served in a shallot-peppercorn sauce, and sliced black Angus steak, served with caramelized onions and red peppers in a resonant roasted garlic sauce. Both steaks were medium rare (as so ordered by our guests), firm and with fine flavor.
The seared swordfish steak was also well prepared, moist and flavorful, even though the menu-specified ginger broth had evaporated.
Less satisfying was a special of grilled tuna. Ordered rare, the tuna steak arrived well-done and case-hardened, unredeemed even by a fresh tomato and caper-rich sauce or the combination accompaniment of wild rice, white rice and toasted pignoli.
Desserts are served in generous portions. A strawberry shortcake was mammoth, with an abundance of fresh whole berries even though the shortcake was a square of yellow cake. Best choice was the chocolate pecan terrine, a thick slice of pecan-rich fudgy chocolate topped with whipped cream, served in a pool of raspberry puree. The berry-filled almond cookie shell, resting in a sweet raspberry puree, held an abundance of delicious fresh blueberries, raspberries and strawberries, but the cookie shell was over-browned, overbaked, overglazed and tough.
A three-course dinner for two came to $47 before tax, tip and beverages. Several of the right ingredients are already in place at Chop Chop American Grill -- a welcoming staff and a quiet, casual atmosphere. With time, fewer short-cuts in ingredients used, and more attention to culinary matters, this new place could find a loyal clientele among Westport's dining establishments.
 
Chop Chop American Grill
