HEADLINE: A Surge Expected in Homeless Population

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
JIMMY McLAWRIN pushed a shopping cart filled with cardboard across the plaza of the Journal Square PATH station in Jersey City. In the night shadows near the shops that line the plaza, men and women lay sleeping on the concrete.
A chill breeze was blowing as Mr. McLawrin approached one after another of the sleepers, extracting a length of cardboard from his cart, gently covering each person in turn. Then he found a vacant space nearby, unloaded the rest of the cardboard and built a shelter for himself. 
 As winter approaches, officials of social service agencies across the state are predicting a dramatic rise in the number of people who will be forced onto the streets. After Dec. 31, municipal welfare benefits will be abruptly terminated for thousands of men and women in New Jersey; estimates run as high as 14,000. At that point, officials said, many people who have never before been homeless, who have lived close to the edge but have always managed to scrape together money for the rent or the mortgage, will find themselves in a shelter or on the street.
Together with the continuing recession and lingering high unemployment, the welfare action could swell the ranks of the homeless beyond the ability of social agencies and shelters to cope with them, officials said.
"I think there is a disaster coming," said Linda Flores, director of the Elizabeth Coalition to House the Homeless, an advocacy group in Union County. "The whole system is bursting."
In past years, the coalition would typically provide assistance to about 30 new families during the month of August, she said, adding: "This August was as bad as February. We had 96 new families."
Though the families aided by the coalition are nearly always provided with some form of shelter, Ms. Flores said, the rise in their numbers probably reflects the rise in the number of hard-core homeless. "They're the ones who live under the railroad trestles and under the turnpike," she said. "They're the ones nobody talks about."
Up-to-date data on New Jersey's homeless are hard to find. Advocates for the homeless estimate that there are 29,000 people who do not have permanent lodging. Most of the homeless population consists of women and children who are on some form of public assistance and who are living in shelters or temporary housing.
Data from the state Department of Community Affairs indicate that the number of families that received some form of public emergency housing assistance in fiscal year 1991 totaled almost 26,000 people -- a 67 percent increase over 1989.
But the hard-core homeless, the men and women who live on the streets of cities like Jersey City, Newark, Camden and Atlantic City, are generally not in those figures since they have little or no contact with the agencies that do the counting. .
Bobi N. Ruffin, director of Health and Human Services for the City of Newark, calls them the "hidden homeless." How many are there? "I really couldn't venture a guess," she said.
What many advocates for the homeless are sure of is that the numbers of homeless, hidden or otherwise, will substantially increase after Dec. 31. "We are very worried," said Mary Wells, chairwoman of the state Human Services Advisory Commission, which advises the Commissioner of the Department of Human Services on issues and policies.
In response to the state's budget crunch, state officials determined that single employable adults who were on general assistance -- municipal welfare -- as of July 1 would lose their benefits after they had been on assistance for six months.
As a result, those who were on municipal welfare on July 1 will be removed from the rolls after Dec. 31.
"These are people who are already on the brink," Ms. Wells said. "They might be employable from a doctor's perspective, but they are the least employable people around from an employer's perspective." When their welfare benefits end, she said, such people are likely to end up on the streets.
Statistics from the state Division of Human Services indicate that the number of people currently on general assistance is 30,939, and that 19,672 of them are classified as employable. Nearly all are individual adults.
Mariano Vega, chief of social services for Hudson County, estimates that between 10,000 and 14,000 of them, statewide, will have their assistance terminated after Dec. 31.
"They'll be hitting the homeless ranks in much larger numbers," he said. "And what safety net is there? The people on the front lines are expecting this to be their worst year."
Alan Zalkind, director of the Essex County Department of Citizen Services, said that Essex County has about 10,000 general assistance recipients. About 7,500 of them are in Newark.
 
Payment of $140 a Month
 "We're seeing a large number of individuals with no recourse, no safety net and no place to go," Mr. Zalkind said.
The typical payment that an individual on general assistance receives, he said, is about $140 a month. More important than the money itself, he said, is the fact that the welfare recipients are eligible for medical benefits and shelter assistance. In fact, most shelters for the homeless only admit people who are actually on the municipal or county welfare rolls.
Once those people are off the rolls, Mr. Zalkind said, they are no longer eligible for emergency assistance or medical benefits.
"You literally have an adult with no place to go," he said. "And we have seen absolutely no plans to date that attempt to address the potentially disastrous consequences."
There is no central state clearinghouse for dealing with the problems of homelessness. Some aspects are managed by the Department of Community Affairs, which provides about $2 million in state funds and $500,000 it receives from the Federal Government for the Shelter Support Program. That program provides financing to improve existing shelters and create new ones.
 
$4.6 Million for Help
 Another program that the department administers is the Homelessness Prevention Program, which provides $4.6 million in temporary assistance for people with unexpected monetary problems that could cause them to lose their homes. Participants must prove that they will be able to get back on their feet within a relatively short time, usually a couple of months.
In the Division of Human Services, about $7 million is earmarked for food and shelter for families that are not not receiving other homeless assistance.
 
102 Emergency Shelters
 And families on welfare who are in immediate danger of becoming homeless can receive temporary rental assistance -- up to $250 a month for up to a year -- to keep them in their homes.
What happens after the year is over?
"That's the $64,000 question," said Andy Rauer, assistant Administrative Supervisor of Social Services in Camden County. "In two months they end up with another eviction notice."
The day-to-day responsibility for sheltering those immediately in need of a roof over their head falls upon 102 licensed emergency shelters scattered throughout the state. Currently, 74 of those shelters are inspected by the state's Bureau of Rooming and Boarding House Standards to insure that they provide acceptable shelter. The remaining 28 shelters are inspected by the various municipalities in which they are situated.
Many of those who run the shelters say they have already noticed a large increase in the number of people seeking help and they fear that as the cold weather sets in and people are dropped from the welfare rolls, shelters could be overwhelmed.
Ms. Flores, of the Elizabeth Coalition, said there were not nearly enough emergency beds in that area. "There are already hundreds of people on the streets," she said. "What's going to happen when a couple of hundred more are added to that?"
Mr. Vega said he expected this winter to be significantly worse than previous years.
 
A Magnet for the Homeless
 "Jersey City tends to become a magnet for homeless folks who tend to travel," he said, pointing to the easy access provided by PATH trains to New York and Newark.
Mr. Vega said that in a study his office conducted in 1990, one out of five Hudson County families was homeless or at risk of becoming homeless. "At risk meant that they were one paycheck away from not being able to afford their rents," he said.
The number of shelters has not significantly increased since then, he said, but, "We are now at an all-time high of unemployment." And the shelters were already at or near capacity in 1990.
The Rev. Marvin W. Krieger, who runs the Hoboken Shelter for the Homeless, a 20-bed shelter that is also a soup kitchen, said he expected to be turning away a dozen people a night when winter sets in, even if he used his "emergency capacity" limit of 30 beds.
"I figure if being homeless isn't an emergency, then what is?" he said.
Not all of the homeless, however, will even bother to seek help at a shelter, no matter what the weather.
"If I can sleep out here at 13 below, I can sleep out here anytime," said 39-year-old Mr. McLawrin, as he stood in front of his cardboard shelter in Journal Square, remembering a particularly cold night he had spent out on the streets, alone.
 
Homelessness Hits Suburbs
 Officials of social service agencies say that a significant change is taking place in the demographics of homelessness. "It's absolutely hitting the suburbs," said Mary Wells, chairwoman of the state's Human Services Advisory Council. "People are losing houses, they are going up for foreclosure," she said. "And these people are going to be homeless, too."
Ms. Wells, who also runs a private, nonprofit social services agency in Burlington County, said that among the people seeking emergency housing assistance are increasing numbers of "newly non-affluent" former members of the middle class.
Many two-income couples overextended themselves financially when the economy was thriving and now find themselves "in a tremendous financial bind," she said, if one of the partners loses a job.
Such people, she said, are loathe to ask for help. "One agency had a client family living in a Mercedes Benz," Ms. Wells said. The family, she said, had not sought immediate shelter because "they were mortified and overcome by the embarrassment of it."
Linda Flores, director of The Elizabeth Coalition to House the Homeless, said her organization provided housing assistance to more than 3,000 people each year. "About 18 percent of our new clients are coming from the suburbs," she said.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Q & A: Dr. Jay R. Brandinger;
Translating Research into New Products

BYLINE: By HELEN PIKE

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
DR. Jay R. Brandinger has a resume that spans high-technology history, from the transmission of the first, pre-satellite, television signals between England and the United States to the creation of RCA's first video-disk players. Last year, he turned 64 years of age, but he had no intention of either giving up flying -- he owns a Cessna Turbo 210 -- or retiring.
"I was, in fact, looking around," he said. What he landed was the job of executive director of the state's Commission on Science and Technology. His salary is $83,000. 
 The commission is devoted to fostering research through its advanced technology centers at the state's five research universities and transferring the results of that research out of the labs and onto production lines.
The commission has an office in Washington to help entrepreneurs obtain grants that will allow them to develop new business in New Jersey. It also works with state officials in improving the teaching of technology in New Jersey schools and in the training of workers to operate high-technology equipment.
In a recent interview, Dr. Brandinger said the commission had brokered a number of new business ventures, including companies producing ultrasonic medical equipment and advanced laser systems, and had obtained more than $231 million in commercial and government funds, and $13 million worth of Federal small business grants to New Jersey enterprises.
Dr. Brandinger, an avid ham radio operator, holds a Bachelor of Science degree in electrical engineering from Cooper Union and a Ph.D. in education from Rutgers University. He and his wife, Alice, an educator, live in Pennington Borough.
Q. Why does New Jersey need a state-supported science agency?
A. The main objective is to create an environment which is conducive to rapid technologically driven economic growth, so it's not just a science agency. Yes, we do science at one end. But we also are concerned with the development of new products at the other end.
For example, we didn't have much focus at our universities in biotechnology back in 1984, when the commission started. We looked around and said: "Biotechnology is going to be the thing of the future. Health care is going to be important. The graying of America in the year 2000 is an important aspect. Health costs are going to rise. How are we going to do this more effectively and efficiently?' "
Since then, we have, on the average, put 40 percent of our budget into biotechnology. We've also put in capital equipment investments through two bond issues. Now New Jersey is No. 2 to California in the number of biotechnology companies.
Q. Why is that so important?
A. The fact is, we've lost more than 100,000 manufacturing jobs, mostly in the blue-collar labor area, and clearly, with a 9 percent unemployment rate, we are very concerned.
These jobs will be replaced in the future with jobs that grow out of new biotechnology pharmaceuticals and biotechnology devices and systems, and then beyond that, in the 21st century, with jobs from electronics, computers, communications and high-definition television.
Right now, the high-tech manufacturing and the research and development which is done within the state represent something between 5 and 10 percent of the state's total gross product. But even if we continue in the high growth rate that we're in, we won't seriously impact unemployment in the short-term. We think it takes time.
Q. How much time?
A. Probably about five to 10 years.
Q. What is the commission's budget for this fiscal year?
A. The total is $20 million.
Q. Is it down again from last year?
A. That is correct. We were cut more than 10 percent. But 25 percent of our budget is not available for grants. It is used to repay loans on equipment. So our total budget available for grants is something just under $15 million.
Q. Does that jeopardize any of the advanced technology centers?
A. The budget passed by the Legislature left unfunded two of our centers, one in plastics recycling and the other in the investigational cancer therapy area.
Q. Are you going to make up that financing through private partnerships?
A. Those centers are strongly encouraged to find alternate sources of funding. Given the current state of things, New Jersey is not in a position to provide funds.
Q. Why hasn't New Jersey done more to turn its patents into manufactured products?
A. During the 1960's and 70's, the U.S. Government issued a series of consent decrees that made the technologies patented by A.T.& T. and RCA available to their competitors. The business focus then shifted to how to make products in a cheaper fashion. Ultimately, this led to moving factories to more competitive labor markets west, south and overseas. Tax breaks for setting up factories in Puerto Rico also led the pharmaceutical industry to move a lot of their manufacturing out-of-state.
But the research and development for both these industries is still primarily here in New Jersey. In fact, 85 percent of all pharmaceutical research done in the United States is done here in the state.
Q. How do you reconcile the state's image as a premier research center with its status as one of the more heavily polluted states in the country?
A. We are the most densely populated state. When I checked to see where the pollution was coming from, about 20 percent was really from the manufacturing side. The majority of the pollution is a result of transportation, both commercial and private. Automobiles that traverse our roads. Trucks and buses traveling in New Jersey and through New Jersey. These are the major sources of air pollution.
Even if you cleaned up all the factories, you still wouldn't be out of problems with respect to air pollution. You need to deal with the issue of the combustion engine, for example, or the diesel engines, which are polluting.
We believe that we are leaders of how to restore sites in where we have damaged the environment. We think the products which will be made here in New Jersey will help do that, and that the technology will be sought out worldwide, and this will be a major and important business.
But restoration is not the long-term answer. We believe if you do it right in the first place, if you manufacture products in a clean environment, and the products are clean and can be disposed of in a clean way, that will be less expensive. And we will all have a better place in which to live.
Q. What is the commission doing about the stringent environmental regulations that seem to hamper business?
A. One way the commission offers help is through one of the advanced technology centers, the Hazardous Substance Management Research Center at the New Jersey Institute of Technology. This center offers technical advice to the State Department of Environmental Protection and Energy that helps interpret the regulations or that helps write, modify or implement them.
For example, there's no recognition of the difference between the land that's used for manufacturing and the land that's used for building single-family homes. The requirements are somewhat different if you look at them in terms of the question of how much of the site has to be restored and to what levels.
A very important thing the Governor has proposed is a change in the way those laws would be dealt with. What he has done is make a very strong suggestion, and hopefully it will be passed by the Legislature, that will change the laws to recognize differences in the uses of the land.
Q .Why did you leave the Sarnoff Research Center in Princeton to come to work in Trenton?
A. I'm working on retirement. I've retired from RCA Laboratories. I've retired from General Electric. I've retired from the Sarnoff Research Center. I'm now in the state, and am looking for my fourth retirement. I'm going to keep looking to retire until I get it right. But that's not really the answer.
I'm here because I want the state to be the kind of a place where I want to live. It really occurred that I was at a point in my career where I might be able to help. I am a citizen of New Jersey. I've been here a long time. I got most of my advanced education here. I think I have a lot of background and knowledge and can do some things that would be appropriate.

HEADLINE: For Women, Fewer M.B.A.'s

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
MARILYN C. COOPER is the kind of woman who could someday put business schools out of business. An idealistic honors student at Wellesley College, she is precisely the sort of young go-getter whom many business schools would love to go get -- but can't.
Trouble is, she has no interest in business school. "There's just so much out there about glass ceilings in business and the limits that are there," said Ms. Cooper, who hopes instead to pursue a career in higher education. 
 She is also put off by the growing expectation of many graduate business programs that students delay their education until their late 20's, so that they can apply their real-life experiences in the classroom. "That would definitely be a big drawback," said Ms. Cooper, who is 22. "I'd like to think that by 27, I'll be starting to have children, not starting an M.B.A."
Typical? You bet. Much to the consternation of the nation's leading business schools, more and more young women who could easily join the next generation of business leaders are turning off to high-powered careers in business, the kind that often call for a name-brand graduate-school education as a prerequisite.
What these women seem to be turning to instead are careers in law, science, government and the nonprofit sector, professions that might be less lucrative but potentially more satisfying. Or they are simply setting their sights on less demanding jobs in the business world that might allow them to better fuse their work and family lives.
Though many business schools are also experiencing a drop in male applicants because of the economy and a growing feeling that the schools have failed to teach the right skills, a greater proportion of women seem to be reaching the conclusion that the M.B.A. is not worth it. The decline is seen both in the number of applications and in the number of entering students.
Indeed, recession has made pricey business schools a dubious luxury, especially for women who have to worry that their earnings after graduation will trail those of their equally-educated male counterparts. At the same time, sexual harassment in the work place and the risk of being shunted onto a slow-moving mommy track during one's childbearing years have painted a grim picture of corporate life.
After years of being able to sit back and admit students as fast as they could open their mail and process the applications, business school administrators admit that the problem is a vexing one. "It does concern us," said
 A BITTERSWEET MOOD
The women who led the way into the highest levels of American business worry that few will follow. Page 27.
Rod R. Garcia, the acting director of admissions at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management.
His school has seen the number of female applicants decline 11 percent since 1987, versus a 24 percent rise in male applicants for the same period. To turn that around, M.I.T. is joining nine other leading business schools next Thursday in Boston in a panel discussion and reception for 250 bright young women to sell them on business school.
ONE reason why these ordinarily competitive schools seem willing to cooperate is because they see it as so critical to their survival as the talent scouts for the nation's top corporations.
"We talk increasingly about the need for future managers to understand and develop skills to deal with labor and consumer markets that are much more diverse than they used to be," said Charles W. Hickman, director of projects and services for the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business, which accredits some 250 American business schools. "If you have a business school that is all-white or all-male, that becomes an increasingly hollow exercise."
Business schools also cannot afford to ignore the trend because of the clear impact it could have on their bottom lines. Twenty years ago, women made up 4 percent of all business school graduates. In 1990, the last year for which government figures are available, women got 34 percent of the 77,203 M.B.A.'s awarded.
At that rate, the math becomes quite compelling. Even more than with other minority groups, a slight percentage drop in women applicants can cause a big dip in the reservoir of talent that schools draw on.
"The Harvards and the Columbias of the world may get 2 or 3 applicants for every opening instead of 5 or 6," said Mr. Hickman. "But if you follow that through to all the other schools, some won't get enough. That has real dollar implications."
Certainly, the explosive growth in the number of foreign students accounts for part of the gender imbalance in the pool of applicants. Bowing to criticism that their graduates were ill-equipped to deal with the complexities of a global marketplace, many business schools have been setting aside one out of every three seats for foreign students to broaden the class perspective. Many of these recruits tend to be sponsored by their employers and nearly all are men.
But even allowing for that wrinkle in the statistics, schools are detecting a decline in interest from women.
What makes the decline more puzzling is that of the people who take a widely used admissions test for business school each year, the percentage of women has remained fairly constant, at about 38 to 40 percent, according to William Broesamle, president of the Graduate Management Admission Council in Los Angeles, the organization that designs the test.
HE suspects that women are therefore either seeking out part-time programs near their homes that might allow them to keep working while in school or simply staying put at their current jobs for economic reasons and skipping graduate school altogether. The attrition theory is consistent with what Stephen Christakos has observed as the admissions director of Northwestern University's Kellogg School. "Harvard and Stanford were my two top competitors last year," he said. "The work force was No. 3." And he believes that women are more vulnerable to economic pressures than men.
"It's harder for us to close the sale" with women applicants, said Mr. Christakos. He suspects that women have a harder time than men justifying the $130,000 that a top-quality business education can cost between tuition, expenses and forgone wages, citing differences in income expectations and in the number of years women can expect to work before family issues interrupt. "As a cost-benefit decision, it may be harder for women to decide to go to school than for men," he said.
JACE SCHINDERMAN, an associate dean at Columbia University's Graduate School of Business, suspects, too, that the advancing age of entering classes may also be "colliding with women wanting to have children earlier." For that reason, Columbia says it is considering relaxing its admission rules and admitting promising younger women with less work experience.
That sort of flexibility would appeal to Amy C. Hoffer, a 21-year-old senior in Northwestern's industrial engineering department who is considering business school sometime down the road. "Several of my friends really think a lot about what trade-offs are involved when you doggedly pursue a business career."
Administrators are also studying ways that their programs may be subtly turning off women, ranging from the shortage of women faculty to possible differences in the way professors grade men and women on classroom participation.
In an effort to make their programs more hospitable to women, many schools are featuring more women in their brochures and at their annual dinners, realigning admissions departments and faculty ranks to include more women, and reexamining their curriculums.
As Debra A. Felix, the assistant dean in charge of admissions at Columbia's business school, sees it, business schools have not always been as hospitable to women as they could be.
Back when she was earning her own M.B.A. at Columbia, she remembers being annoyed that her grade in introductory marketing depended heavily on two exams, one on golf balls and the other on men's toiletries. "I got an honors grade, so I guess I figured it out," said Ms. Felix, whose complaints that year at least insured that the following year's class got to write about a more neutral test topic: pens.
 
 
Two Schools Reach Out
 TWO business schools that are among those working the hardest to woo more women are Columbia and Northwestern.
Columbia has mounted an ambitious research project to canvass students, alumni, faculty and recruiters to identify reasons for the decline in applications from women.
In the meantime, the school plans to hold more luncheons for promising young women and conduct a phone campaign to reach out to women who have requested applications. It is also looking to create fellowships or scholarships just for women.
In addition, Debra A. Felix, the school's admissions director, has spoken bluntly with a number of Japanese companies that pay for their employees to attend top-ranked American schools, since they sponsor male candidates almost exclusively. "I'm asked every year by Japanese companies, 'How can we get our people in?' " said Ms. Felix, who said she initially limited her advice to the usual remarks about grades and test scores.
"Finally, I said, 'Send women,' and they freaked. And the next year, they finally did," she said triumphantly.
At Northwestern in Evanston, Ill., the school features more women in its brochure in lieu of the usual "two-guys-with-a-rugby-ball kinds of shots," as Stephen Christakos, the school's admissions director, put it. The brochure also touts the school's grassy, suburban campus -- a big draw for safety-conscious women.
Northwestern is one of the few schools that has its own students read all incoming applications. This year, it is hoping to find enough women among its current students to fill 17 to 18 of the 37 reading slots, up from 13 last year.
"We hope that just by having more women as the first reader, we'll even the playing field," said Mr. Christakos.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY;
Two Old Foes Battle for Unity And to Support the Franc

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
It was a heroic fight. Against the forces of profiteers in the $1 trillion-a-day foreign exchange market, Germany and France battled to preserve the value of the French franc. They did it by digging deep into their currency reserves to buy francs on the open market. But success is not guaranteed since government resources are small compared with those of the world's currency traders. Yet defending the franc was more important than money; it was a show of unity after France's lukewarm endorsement of the Maastricht treaty. Europe "is facing tests of strength that will be decisive for its common future," Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said. President Francois Mitterrand of France echoed the sentiments. The joint actions put "all Franco-German irritations to bed," said Stephan-Gotz Richter, president of Trans Atlantic Futures, a consultant in Washington.
 
Fleshing Out Health Care
Appearing before a group of employees at Merck & Company, the big pharmaceutical manufacturer in Rahway, N.J., Gov. Bill Clinton put a little flesh and blood on his health care plan. He told the group that if elected he would require private employers with more than 50 workers to provide health- care insurance for employees and would have the Federal Government supplement health care coverage for the unemployed. Mr. Clinton also said he would call for price controls on drugs. His plan would "drastically simplify the administrative costs of the American health care system" and save about $700 billion by the end of the decade, Mr. Clinton said. The plan would also provide incentives for small companies to band together to pool coverage and reduce costs, something President Bush has also proposed. The Bush campaign criticized Mr. Clinton's proposals, saying price controls on drugs would reduce private funding for research.
Time was when most of mahogany row went Republican. But last week Governor Clinton garnered endorsements from 400 of America's corporate titans. Among the endorsers were Paul Allaire, chairman of Xerox; Robert Haas, chairman of Levi Strauss; Reuben Mark, chairman of Colgate Palmolive; Sumner Redstone, chairman of Viacom, and the taste maker Martha Stewart.
 
Paid to Do the Right Thing
While Mr. Clinton talked health care, President Bush was homing in on the nation's small business owners. He began by vetoing a family-leave bill that would require companies to grant at least 12 weeks of unpaid leave to any employee with a family emergency. The bill was opposed by many small-business owners who said it was too costly. "I have always supported employer policies to give time off for a child's birth, adoption or for family illness," Mr. Bush said in his veto message. Instead of the bill, he proposed tax credits for employers who give workers time off. Later, in Greensboro N.C., Mr. Bush proposed $20 billion in tax cuts for small businesses.
 
Durable Goods Decline
Orders for durable goods, those big-ticket items that are supposed to last three years , fell 0.1 percent in August, the third monthly decline in four months. The report was "Weak, weak, weak," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago.
 
In Need of an Economic Miracle
Dogging the Presidential race is the sluggish economy. It grew by 1.5 percent in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said. "The calendar is running out for George Bush,"said Robert G. Dederick, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
 
Daring to Offend China
Time was when President Bush couldn't do enough for China. He supported its most-favored-nation trade status against and fought Congressional pressure to put sanctions on it after the crackdown in Tiananmen Square. But with the election looming, old loyalties have been called into question. Last month, Mr. Bush authorized the sale of 150 F-16's to Taiwan, China's longtime foe. Last week, he agreed to sell 12 SH-2F "Lamp" helicopters to Taiwan for $161 million. The helicopters, which can detect and attack submerged submarines, are made by the Kaman Corporation in Bloomfield, Conn. Connecticut -- whose eight electoral votes are considered up for grabs -- has been severely hurt by cutbacks in Pentagon spending.
 
Japan's Bank Won't Budge
In Japan, they are calling it a recession even though growth has so far not turned negative. Japan's gross domestic product expanded by a meek 0.2 percent in the second quarter, the Ministry of Finance said last week.
 
Pleading for Fewer Rubles
Russia is learning about democracy the hard way. Yegor T. Gaidar, the acting Prime Minister , is dedicated to establishing a market system, but he must contend with a Parliament still dominated by proponents of central planning. And while Mr. Gaidar has been trying to keep money growth slow, Parliament appointed Viktor Gerashenko as head of Russia's central bank. Mr. Gerashenko likes to keep those printing presses running. As a result, since last month, the value of the ruble has lost 49 percent of its value. Last week Mr. Gaidar pleaded with Parliament, saying that unless the money supply was tightened, the Russian monetary system would collapse.
 
Agency Hopping at Olds?
Leo Burnett U.S.A., the advertising agency, has been selling Oldsmobiles since 1967. A few years ago it came up with the "This is not your father's Oldsmobile" theme. But the campaign alienated the car company's older customers without bringing in new ones. Oldsmobile's sales are sluggish, to say the least. Last week, the General Motors Corporation put the Oldsmobile account up for review. Although it did not announce which agencies would be allowed to compete for the account, which is worth $100 million to $110 million, it said Leo Burnett would be in the running. "We are confident we can retain the Oldsmobile business," said Jim Oates, Burnett's chairman. Perhaps it will. The last time G.M. dismissed an agency was in 1958.
 G.M. has been working hard to keep the labor peace. But last month, after announcing plans to close plants, lay off workers and buy parts from outside suppliers, workers at its Lordstown, Ohio, struck. And last week, 4,200 members of the United Automobile Workers union went on strike at a body stamping plant in Lansing, Mich., for the same reasons.
 
Cracks in the Rock of Gibraltar
The Prudential Insurance Company may like to portray itself as solid as the rock of Gibraltar, but according to an independent nonprofit research agency, its losses from Hurricane Andrew so far total $1.2 billion -- four times what executives predicted. Those losses could use up 10 percent of Prudential's capital. The estimates caused alarm among analysts at Standard & Poor's, the credit-rating agency, placed it on credit watch with the possibility of downgrading Prudential from AAA, the highest rating. "We have always felt that Prudential was stretched on capital relative to the rating," said Mark Puccia, a senior vice president at Standard & Poor's. Earlier this year, Moody's Investors Service downgraded the nation's No. 1 insurer from Aaa, for exceptional , to Aa1, for excellent.
 
The Pseudo-Sodas
With the fizz going out of the Coca-Cola Company's sales, its third-quarter financial forecasts were, well, flat. One of Coke's answers is to go New Age. Following a host of competitors, Coca-Cola will bring out a new drink in the fast-growing "clear" category, to be called Nordic Mist. The new drink, a flavored sparkling water, will follow Pepsi Cola's H2oH! and Pepsi Crystal and the Seagrams entry, Quest. But while Nordic Mist will be clear, it won't be a health food. It will derive its sweet taste (not to mention 112 calories) from high-fructose corn syrup. "It's soft drinks in disguise," said Jack Trout of Trout & Ries, a marketing firm in Greenwich, Conn.
 
Shoring Up Travelers
The Primerica Corporation, the big financial services and insurance company, said last week that it would invest $722.5 million in the struggling Travelers Corporation in return for a 27 percent stake in the company. Primerica's chairman, Sanford I. Weill, said he would work with Travelers to direct its operations. More than a third of its $13 billion in outstanding mortgages are in trouble.
 
Behind the Scenes at 'Tonight'
The way Ken Kragen tells it -- he's a Hollywood artists' manager -- Helen Kushnick plays too rough. Ms. Kushnick was Jay Leno's manager, and when he became host of the "The Tonight Show" earlier this year, became executive producer. Mr. Kragen said Ms. Kushnick kept one of his clients, the country singer Travis Tritt, off "The Tonight Show" after learning that Mr. Tritt was also appearing on the rival "Arsenio" show. What was even worse, Mr. Kragen said, was that for no reason other than vindictiveness, Ms. Kushnick canceled a scheduled appearance on "The Tonight Show" by Trisha Yearwood, another country singer whom Mr. Kragen represents. Ms. Kushnick denied Mr. Kragen's assertions about her motivations. That denial was not enough for NBC. Last week the network dismissed Ms. Kushnick.

HEADLINE: An Energy Prophet Who Guessed Right

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif.

 BODY:
In a way, S. David Freeman is a prophet coming into his own. As head of the Ford Foundation's energy project in the early 1970's, he correctly predicted that improved energy efficiency would be cheaper than continued expansion of power plants, and he predicted that American energy use, then galloping ahead, would reach a plateau by the late 1980's. At the time, oil companies and utilities said his idea was radical and wrong, but in fact it was not radical enough. When the plateau was reached, it was 15 percent lower than what Mr. Freeman had predicted.
For the last two years Mr. Freeman has been general manager of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District (SMUD), which is scrambling to replace the power from the Rancho Seco nuclear plant, which the voters closed three years ago. But Mr. Freeman is still a radical prophet. And in an interview earlier this month, he backs new technologies for electricity production to replace nuclear power. 
 Question: You have a toe in the water in every form of conservation and alternative generation. Why?

 Answer: We're going to end up by the year 2000 not only with a very much cleaner power system, but one where the price of electricity for the people of Sacramento County is going to be very reasonable and stable.
If over the next 10 years, through our rebates and education and financing, we can displace the energy-consuming devices with much more efficient ones and reduce the per-capita consumption of electricity 10 or 20 percent, even if we raise the rates 5 percent, I've got happy customers.
We're replacing the nuclear plant with cogeneration, using natural gas, plus a large chunk of advanced and renewable technologies that we're working to improve, so that when we have to commit to them, they can be fairly cost effective, especially if you pay any dues at all to the environmental costs.

 Q: Is this as if you set out to sea and lost sight of land and are going to innovate your way to the other shore?

 A: On the contrary. It's the people who feel that we're going to produce our way out of this problem with nuclear power and carbon-rich coal who are at sea. We have learned the one lesson that needs to be learned from the last 20 years, that nuclear power has proven to be an economic failure in the United States of America, that we can't afford it. The planet cannot afford the continued or increased production of coal or oil.
Now we start off with the advantage of having some hydropower in our system, and some geothermal. We're taking care of all of our growth with efficiency improvements. And we're adding the windpower and a big block of renewables, and we have some geothermal. Add the whole thing up, we're going to be predominantly a clean utility.

 Q: SMUD wants to plant 50,000 trees a year. Why?

 A: When I came to Sacramento a little over two years ago, I bought a home in Arden Park, and some wise person, 20 or 25 years ago, had planted some Modesto ash trees that form a canopy. It was in June, and I'd just come from Austin, Tex. What I had was not a tree but an air-conditioner. It had the wonderful impact of getting better every year, not rusting.
I asked the guys to come up with some numbers. The numbers were that in year 10, we had sizable savings. It was worth giving the trees away; they were saving electricity at less than 4 cents a kilowatt-hour, which was our economic screening device. It sounds like we're just a bunch of do-gooders, greenies, but this is a hard-headed, cost-effective part of our efficiency program.

 Q: Is SMUD's experience a guide for anybody else?

 A: I think so. No one that I know of has put down the simple number of what has nuclear power generated in cost per kilowatt-hour. But if you take all of the plants that were abandoned, plus the ones that were built, I would guess that that number is very close to 20 cents per kilowatt hour. Though you have the emotional believers in nuclear power making fun of solar enery and wind energy, their product hasn't cut it in the marketplace even though it's highly subsidized.

 Q: Can renewable energy sources compete economically?

 A: We may very well end up with less renewables and more efficiency. But that's a wonderful contest to have on your hands. I've got my energy-efficiency people now competing with the guys who develop the solar technologies. Whichever one wins, we're going to be a winner.
We take these issues seriously. We think that's the foundation for our credibility in electrifying our transportation system. The electric system will reduce carbon tremendously because the electric motor is 98 percent efficient, and you don't run the car when it's idling. It not only cuts out local air pollution but it reduces the carbon emissions, not to mention ameliorating the problem of going to war [to secure the oil needed] to get to work.

GRAPHIC: Photo: S. David Freeman (Matthew L. Wald/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Currency Wars: Central Banks May Yet Prevail

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
CALL it the great bank bailout, 1990's style.
That is one way to look at the currency follies of the past several weeks, in which European central banks lost billions of dollars, or marks, or pounds, in defending absurd exchange rates. 
 Those losses are someone else's gain. And while the profits were spread around, there is no doubt that commercial banks, being among the biggest and best-capitalized currency traders, were also among the biggest beneficiaries.
Of course, profits made from currency trading can be lost in the same way. And so the big question in Europe now is whether France and Germany will be able to keep the franc from plunging. If they do and if calm eventually returns to markets, then the central banks will make back some of their losses.
The currency game has its unfair elements. It is the Bundesbank, the much-reviled German central bank, that is spending the most money buying French francs. And it is the Bundesbank that could decide to change course by significantly lowering German interest rates, thus taking pressure off the franc and locking in big profits for the Bundesbank. In the currency markets, insider trading is perfectly legal.
Most German interest rates remain high, but the Bundesbank did manipulate the rate on money lent overnight, dropping it almost to nothing. Meanwhile, the French overnight rate soared. That makes it expensive to bet that the franc will fall, a fact the central banks hope will discourage speculators.
To win, the central banks must be believed when they vow to maintain existing exchange rates. Of course, that's what they said before the pound plunged. But perhaps this time the central banks really mean it.
There are, in both Germany and France, people who are quite happy with the idea of a "small Europe," composed of a group of northern European countries whose distinguishing feature would be that they kept within the Exchange Rate Mechanism when the going got rough. "We may," said Yves Lyon-Caen, the chairman of Credit National, the big French bank, "have to create a Europe with Britain out of it." Such a Europe, he said, could move rapidly toward monetary union.
Meanwhile, Europe shows signs of stagnation. Mr. Lyon-Caen thinks that France will post real growth of a puny 1.5 percent next year but that Germany's figure will be only 1 percent. His hope is that the weak German economy will persuade the Bundesbank to push down interest rates.
For big banks, the idea of a weak Europe and a stumbling American economy raises the question of more loan losses, and Mr. Lyon-Caen says German banks are muttering privately about deteriorating loan portfolios. The banks may end up needing all of those currency profits.
Whether they will keep them will probably be known soon. But it may take much longer to get good news about economic growth, on either side of the Atlantic.

HEADLINE: At Work;
A Corporate Collaboration for Care

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
FRAN SUSSNER RODGERS has been in the work-family business or more than 20 years, so she knows how to keep faith in a project over a long time. So it is surprising to hear that she fretted a bit over what would eventually become the American Business Collaboration for Quality Dependent Care. That landmark $25.4 million initiative, concluded earlier this month by 137 businesses and organizations, will provide their employees with a broad range of family services. The announcement included a statement signed by the chief executives of 11 spearhead corporations.
Ms. Rodgers, head of Work/Family Directions Inc., the Boston-based consulting firm that provided expertise, can now pass out tangible evidence of the fruits of collaboration: an 11-page list of infant, child, youth and elder-care projects in 25 states being created or enhanced by the corporations. The list, she says, represents the taming of chaos. "In retrospect, it seems systematic," she said. "Personally, at the beginning, I had doubts." 
 The doubts did not derive from any skepticism about the need for more attention to the pulls between family and jobs many American workers feel. President Bush may not be convinced of the need for a Family Leave Act. And there may be entire sectors of the economy that pay little attention to family issues -- typically the sectors that employ women in small numbers. But the ones that do pay attention pay a lot of attention. Long before the collaboration was a twinkle of potential entropy in Fran Rodgers's eye, corporations like I.B.M., Xerox and A.T.& T. were keeping track of demographic trends that forecast the need for the services a family may need as it passes through the life cycle, all of which are included in the state-of-the-art buzz phrase "dependent care."
It was precisely because some companies already had dependent care partnerships in the pipeline that the collaboration survived an 18-month process to become the relatively pristine headless entity its early sponsors envisioned. The International Business Machines Corporation, for example, a catalyst, brought lessons learned in three projects to the initiative's first meeting, in April 1991, at a hotel in Greenwich, Conn.
"It planted the seed that maybe this concept had merit and could be developed on a larger scale," said J. T. Childs Jr., director of work-force diversity programs at I.B.M., who called the first meeting and is widely credited as a conceptual force behind the initiative, though he portrays himself more as a willing instrument of destiny than an innovator. The Greenwich meeting, he said, "started the engine, but it didn't start the race."
THE race was in reality a collective shedding of corporate ego, a process especially difficult for business, which typically blanches in unison at the notion that the highest form of charity is anonymously given. A crucial step in the collaboration was the decision not to disclose the amount of money each company contributed, which would have allowed the rankings-by-donation so dear to the corporate communications office. The final list includes only totals for each of the 44 communities that are home to the projects.
That crucial step made others possible, including a kind of feedback loop between corporate headquarters, employees in need of services, providers in local communities and Work/Family Directions and its resources. "The grass-roots piece of it is important and appealing," said Deborah Stahl, director of the family care development fund at A.T.& T. "Programs are delivered on a community level." She added: "You can't just plop down a model of a child-care center everywhere. You have to figure out ways to address different needs."
According to Mr. Childs, "The idea was to think global but act local. We wanted to facilitate services where the need was. It helps the local economy by creating a collision between employee needs and service providers." Perhaps it was utter incongruity of a Big Blue bigwig speaking in the language of New Age politics that softened Ms. Rodgers's early worries. By the third or fourth month of meetings, she had moved her likelihood-of-success index up to "maybe"; by six months, she was positively serene.
"Crunch time," as she calls it, starts now, as implementation begins. The group's slogan is "Doing together what none of us can afford to do alone," and Ms. Rodgers hopes that in 10 years people can look back for an object lesson: companies, she said, "should not dismiss solutions simply because they aren't within their own resources."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fran Sussner Rodgers, standing, leading a meeting at the offices of Work/Family Directions in Boston. (Joe Wrinn for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
. . .And a Forecast for the Future

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
As fuel economy and recycling become increasingly important, more and more lightweight -- and different -- materials will find their way into the cars of the future, according to a recent survey by the University of Michigan's Transportation Research Institute.
The study, based on responses from domestic auto manufacturers and suppliers, as well as scholars and consultants, showed that to achieve a corporate average fuel economy (CAFE) of 35 miles per gallon by the year 2000, nearly 200 pounds would need to be shaved from today's cars. 
 To do that, according to David E. Cole, director of the university's office for the study of automotive transportation, car makers will need to use more expensive and exotic materials such as ceramics, magnesium, powdered metals and composites, although steel will remain dominant.
"Although the value of CAFE regulation is intensely debated," Cole said, "its influence will steer product strategies, engineering direction and sourcing decisions."
Further, he said, recycling of old cars has emerged as a significant issue for the international auto industry in recent years and is expected to have a much heavier impact on design over the next decade. Exterior body parts in particular will use more nontraditional materials, with about 35 percent of the doors and fenders of domestic cars made of plastics and polymers.
The report concludes that "although material trends appear to be reasonably stable, they still represent a significant change from the composition of components today. This suggests rather strongly that we are on the threshold of a revolution in automotive materials."

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Happy Hoofbeats Out of the Past . . .

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
THERE are people like me in Detroit! Or at Ford's headquarters in Dearborn, at least. If I was unsure before, I know it now that I have put in some time at the wheel of a new Mustang convertible, the one with the big 5-liter V8 and the huge tires and ...
Ah. And the eye-popping red body with the pristine white roof and the white leather upholstery and the white wheels with the chrome horses in their hubs. This car is not only properly old-fashioned, it is dressed up like a tart on the town. And I love it. 
 For some time now, I have been complaining that the domestic manufacturers are failing to give us cars that we want, that are exciting. That come with hues that are more than a monotone. That can be opened properly to the wind, either as convertibles or as hardtop coupes.
O.K., Ford said quietly. Take that!
Well, that is this year's incarnation of the street racer that gave pony-cars their name, a Mustang LX with the optional 225-horsepower engine driving the rear wheels through a four-speed automatic transmission. It is fast and it looks that way. I worry about getting arrested just sitting at the light.
There is the sound, for one thing, the burbling through the dual exhausts that makes the little Ford sound like a cabin cruiser. Love it. And there is the smooth flood of torque when you put your foot into the gas. When you drive all these fours and sixes, you do forget.
Of course, there are other things that you forget about the older and "more exciting" designs, too. For instance, the lovely pleated buckets -- comfortable as they are -- are fairly flat and offer little support. There is a tooth-loosening ride that only a periodontist could love. And you have to be a pretty good driver to throw the car into a curve at speed.
But, shucks, you don't have to drive fast. You get the good sound at any speed, and the gearing makes the car want to cruise at a nice license-preserving 60 on the highway. That also helps save the fuel, providing average economy of about 19 miles per gallon. And with a tank that holds only 15.4 gallons, fill-ups come with dismaying regularity in any case.
That is a factor of more than just the big engine, though. Part of it happens because of the convertible's weight, which at a ton and a half is 220 pounds more than the already heavy Mustang coupe. The added averdupois attests to the stiffening that is needed to take the place of the car's normal steel roof, but even with that stiffening there is a lot of shake on rough highways and potholed city streets.
An all-new Mustang will be coming in 1994, and lighter materials can be expected in its design. But, for now, Ford is saving weight (and cost) by leaving out such things as counterbalancing hinges for the hood. I mention that, because all you have to do to realize the heft of current components is to lift that giant piece of steel and prop it up on its rod.
The hinges at the other end of the car are worth mentioning, too. As in days of yore, they are exposed and incorporated as small styling touches on the lid of the trunk, which opens to reveal a shallow compartment fit mainly for soft luggage. The car may be heavy, but its occupants will travel light.
Inside, there is an air bag for the driver and a full array of instruments, including a 140 m.p.h. speedometer. The lined, well-fitted top goes up and down with the push of a toggle on the right side of the black instrument pod, and most of the other controls are equally easy to use.
The radio is an exception. It is low in the center of the dash and has buttons rather than knobs for tuning. You have to take your eyes off the road and fumble a lot.
Getting into the back seat also is difficult, since the would-be occupants must do battle with the front seatbelts, anchored in the rear and blocking the entry. Once ensconced, though, there is a surprising amount of legroom back there.
One of the best features of the car, it should be said, is its price. Ford's Mustang has always been one of the better bargains around, and you can actually own one of the plain-vanilla versions for about $11,000. Step your way through all the permutations and you get to the convertible, which lists for $19,644 and goes out the door at about $22,000.
That's still a steal, and if you're like me, you'll be grinning all the way home from the bank.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The '92 Mustang convertible: Bright paint, big tires, a rumbling exhaust and a reasonable price. (Ford Motor Company)

HEADLINE: The Strangelove Economics of 1992

BYLINE: By Warren B. Rudman; Warren B. Rudman is a Republican Senator from New Hampshire.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Recently, many politicians and economists have launched a new approach to the exploding U.S. deficit: Don't worry, be happy.
Tired of wrestling with how to untie our fiscal Gordian knot, these folks now suggest we simply learn to live with our red ink. They advise us to indulge our urge to spend our children's money, advocating Strangelove Economics ("How I learned to stop worrying and love the deficit"). 
 Candidates this year have treated the deficit like the skunk at the garden party. They advocate "investment" (spending) and "tax cuts." But they seem to be choking on "deficit reduction," offering only minimal measures in that direction.
The problem is that the winner of the race will have no mandate for change with a $4 trillion debt hanging over his head. Unless Federal borrowing is decreased, thus reducing interest payments, there will be no money to pay for campaign promises. Perhaps Ross Perot's expected re-entry into the Presidential race tomorrow will finally incite discussion.
Don't misunderstand me. Deficit reduction is not a panacea for all our economic problems. But it will re-establish fiscal equilibrium and avert economic turmoil in the years ahead. Even those who preach against reductions now must recognize that it is the weight of huge deficits amassed in the last 20 years that has mired us in the current recession. The debt and attendant $200 billion annual interest prevent us from deploying traditional countercyclical measures -- cutting taxes and raising spending -- as we have done in every past recession.
The Federal red ink has crippled growth by reducing national savings and capital formation. In 1979, when the gross national product was $2.5 trillion, savings in the U.S. totaled $109 billion. But a run of huge deficits over the next 13 years devoured savings and dramatically reduced the capital for investment. By 1992, the G.N.P. stood at $5.7 trillion but savings totaled only $22 billion.
Moreover, we continue to accumulate debt. The Government's liabilities should terrify everyone under 21 (or those who have kids that age). Adults today will receive $14 trillion more in benefits than they pay in taxes. This translates into a $150,000 gap for every household.
Between 1993 and 1997 the Government will collect $657 billion in payroll taxes and premiums for Medicare, but it expects to pay out $913 billion in benefits. It's estimated that by 2020, Social Security and Medicare taxes will increase to between 29 percent and 37 percent of payroll deductions. Today, 70 percent of American families pay more in Social Security taxes than they do in income taxes. Almost 50 percent of Federal spending goes for mandatory entitlements, and the amount is rising rapidly.
Cutting the deficit will involve tough decisions and hurt some people in the short run. But it is far preferable to the calamity that will result if we refuse. That's why former Senator Paul Tsongas and I have formed the Concord Coalition, a nonpartisan, grass-roots group that hopes to break the gridlock, reduce the debt and build a future for our kids, not hand them the bill.
The time has come to put up or shut up. A freeze on Federal programs is acceptable. Reasonable military cuts are warranted. New revenues must be considered. And ballooning entitlement programs must be reformed.
America has always held the promise of a better tomorrow. Not now. And not if we succumb to the siren call for the feel-good, quick-fix policies advanced by Dr. Strangelove economists and politicians. Unless we change course -- reduce our debt, save more, invest more -- our children and grandchildren will be the first generation of Americans to have fewer opportunities and a lower standard of living than their parents.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Elkton, Md.;
R & D Center Sets Up Shop

BYLINE: By Maureen Milford

 BODY:
A $29 MILLION research and development center that sprouted from a former farmstead is an out-of-the-way example of the emerging world market that is breaking down boundary lines.
Himont Inc., the world's leading producer of polypropylene resins, with headquarters in Wilmington, Del., considered 17 sites in Delaware and Pennsylvania for its North American research and development operation, looking for the best deal. 
 It chose 200 acres in this historic Cecil County town -- known for its quick marriages of eloping couples -- because the state offered $2.475 million and the county $650,000 in low-interest loans and funds to train new employees and because fast approvals let Himont complete the building at 15 percent less than it would have laid out elsewhere, company officials said. Moreover, the site is just 20 miles from its headquarters.
Himont, created in 1983 as a joint venture of Montedison S.p.A. of Milan and Hercules Inc. of Wilmington, was taken over by the Italian manufacturer in 1990, but not before the center here was in the pipeline. Himont's only other research and development operation is in Ferrara, Italy.
Ballinger, the Philadelphia architectural firm that designed the project, was asked to style the building here after others the company owns in Europe.
The boxy, two-story, sand-colored-brick building housing 165 researchers and supporting personnel is trimmed in bright red, green, blue and yellow. Much of the steel is exposed on the interior and painted in primary colors. An atrium offers researchers windows and natural light in their offices, across the corridor from the laboratories.
The 145,000-square-foot building is the first of what the company expects to be several on its Oakmont campus here to accommodate perhaps 2,000 employees within the next 15 years. Its diverse mixture of scientists hail from all over the world, from Nigeria to China.
The town of about 9,000 residents, incorporated in 1787, has become a rest stop on the way to the Chesapeake Bay. Discount liquor marts, truck stops for drivers turning off Interstate 95, shopping centers and fast-food restaurants have become important to the local economy.
Preliminary plans by the state's Highway Administration to build a road that would bypass Cecil County's largest town to get on I-95 have not been well received by local businesses and officials.
As neighboring New Castle County in Delaware has become more restrictive on development and land prices have risen, many builders have been moving housing projects here so they can offer a more affordable product.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Cooking Up Some Ideas For Negative Campaigns

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"EVER notice Bill Clinton when he runs?" asked Sean Fitzpatrick, an advertising executive who recently parted with the Bush campaign's ad team. "He looks like a duck."
Mr. Fitzpatrick turned that concept into a proposal for a television commercial: a waddling mechanical duck dissolves into images of the hefty Arkansas Governor jogging. The announcer says Mr. Clinton claims he is "not like those Democrats in Congress who like to tax and spend, tax and spend." Then, after the duck has quacked, he says: "We say, if it talks like a duck, walks like a duck, it must be a Democrat." 
 Though that spot has not been made, the season of the attack ad has arrived. Last week, the Clinton and Bush campaigns officially began using paid-for airtime to fling mud.
The Clinton camp fired first; its commercial interspersed clips of President Bush making predictions of a recovery with black-and-white frames showing rising jobless figures.
The Bush campaign tried humor; it used hick music and fast-forward video in an ad that portrays Mr. Clinton as a Governor of a small, backward state who did little but raise taxes.
It will only get nastier, and the toughest ads can be expected to come from the Republicans as long as Mr. Bush is stuck in second place in the polls.
"The resistance to Bush is akin to the resistance that mosquitoes have developed to DDT -- people are resisting any and all advances from him," said Douglas Watts, the advertising director for the 1984 Reagan campaign who is now in public relations. "The only way to truly overcome that is to start beating up the other guy."
Killer commercials have inherent risks, but they are often the only way candidates can break through to voters whose only exposure to political discourse is on "Murphy Brown," not the evening news.
The most important decision facing the Republicans in coming weeks is not whether to attack but how hard and on what issues: If Mr. Bush jumps from family values to the draft to pollution in Arkansas, he risks confusing voters and undermining his own credibility.
Most analysts agree that reviving tales of womanizing would only cast the Republicans as purveyors of sleaze. And while the Bush campaign has prepared advertising implying that Mr. Clinton evaded the draft, many Republican strategists questioned whether that issue "has legs" because of the public's ambiguity about the Vietnam War.
 
Pick One Bull's Eye
 "They have to throw darts at one bull's eye," said Don Sipple, an advertising consultant in Mr. Bush's campaign earlier this year. "It has to be Clinton's credibility. I would deal with it very explicitly. Just frame it there at the top of the commercial: How much can we really trust Bill Clinton?"
As long as the criticisms are accurate, Mr. Sipple has no qualms about nasty ads. "You're going to take the hit for going negative," he said, "so you might as well land the blow."
But officials in both the Bush and Clinton camps are nervous because it is getting harder to dodge media "truth squads" -- greater efforts by reporters to look into the claims made in the advertisements. They also know some voters have grown sophisticated about commercials and may not want to elect someone they think is too vicious.
Mr. Bush is still accused of race-baiting with the Willie Horton ad in 1988. A reminder of the danger to the messenger is Elizabeth Holtzman's attacks on Geraldine A. Ferraro in New York's Democratic Senate primary. The ads may have cost Ms. Ferraro the race, but Ms. Holtzman came in fourth, and many voters disliked the tone of her campaign.
The Bush campaign's use of humor and the Clinton campaign's attempts to hang the President using only his own words and numbers from his own Bureau of Labor Statistics may have been attempts to avoid sharing Ms. Holtzman's predicament.
Republicans say their television assault will move into higher gear this week, and the Clinton campaign is not known for shrinking from a brawl. Neither camp will disclose what it has in the works, but several political consultants were asked what they would do under the circumstances. Mr. Fitzpatrick's answer was the duck ad.
Tony Schwartz, a Democratic consultant, said he would reprise his 1968 "A Heartbeat Away" commercial that sought to make voters nervous about Spiro Agnew, Richard M. Nixon's running mate. "The ad should say, 'Which of these two men do you want a heartbeat away from the Presidency: Quayle or Gore?' " Mr. Schwartz said. "It is very meaningful when you talk about how many of the last Vice Presidents became President."
Joseph Napolitan, who also helps Democratic candidates, says they should exploit the idea that Mr. Bush is out of touch with ordinary Americans.
A script he dreamed up opens with scenes from the Depression, cuts to a preppie emerging from a limousine with his school books, and then to Mr. Bush emerging from Air Force One and into a limousine. The announcer says "Some people never come into contact with the realities of life," recalls that young George Bush was chauffeured to school in Greenwich, Conn., and says he still doesn't understand poverty, hunger or unemployment.
Mr. Napolitan, who has been in the business for decades, counsels subtlety to his younger peers. "We tried to sneak in with a stiletto," he said. "Today, they're hitting with a sledgehammer."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Perot: What's Changed And What Hasn't

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
HE set out to rescue a weary America last winter: a bantamweight billionaire Texan with a get-it-done zeal, a puggishness for television talk shows, a populist's drawling scorn for Washington politics and, not least, the support of an army of devoted, mostly middle-class volunteers. The early polls looked rosy for Ross Perot.
But by midsummer, the enterprise had soured. The press had raised a host of questions about the Perot background and character. His promises of programs to fix the ailing economy, the deficit, unemployment had largely gone unfulfilled. His campaign was in disarray. He was nosediving in the polls. 
 And on July 16, he abandoned his undeclared Presidential bid. Many followers called it a betrayal and Democratic and Republican leaders breathed easier, no longer facing the tortuous uncertainties of a three-way race. Mr. Perot all but vanished from public view.
But his more dedicated zealots carried on, quietly getting his name on ballots in all 50 states. And Mr. Perot in late July released a far-reaching economic plan that proposed to eliminate the budget deficit in five years by raising some taxes, cutting health costs and military budgets and taking other painful steps. Oddly, Mr. Perot seemed to be doing better after giving up his campaign.
And last week, he said his decision to quit had been a mistake. He scheduled television time, including an appearance tomorrow night on "Larry King Live," and there was much anticipation that he might well resume his quest for the White House, at least nominally.
But political experts said it was no longer the same game as last February. Too many things had gone wrong and would not be forgotten, they said. The February-to-July campaign, among other things, uncovered for many Americans a dark side of the Perot character: an autocratic, secretive, thin-skinned man who could be mean-spirited, domineering yet fragile.
 
Resenting the Press
 Though almost unknown to most voters when his campaign began, he resisted appeals by his advisers to publish advertisements that would help define him, and aides said he resented the news media for exploring his background and character, for exposing his business practices and his penchant for snooping on competitors, political foes, even friends and family members.
The New York Times in early July reported that Mr. Perot, convinced he had been cheated out of a lucrative state contract in the 1980's, had a private detective undertake an unrestrained investigation of a rival company executive in the computing business. The detective, the report said, gathered evidence against the company and the executive and tried to get officials to investigate him and prosecute one of his aides.
Mr. Perot also was reported to have ordered an investigation of a 1982 land deal involving the chairman of Pennzoil, who had been a friend and business partner of George Bush. Other reports said he had investigated Mr. Bush's children and had his own children shadowed. He denied the allegations, which he called dirty tricks by Republicans, or provided justifications but no detailed explanations.
Throughout his campaign, Mr. Perot resisted making appearances at forums other than those packed with his enthusiastic supporters. He made only one true campaign appearance, on July 11 before a convention of the National Association or the Advancement of Colored People in Nashville. Though the bulk of his address was an appeal for racial harmony, it was marred by some ill-chosen words that left the impression that he lacked an appreciation of black sensibilities. His remarks were sprinkled with references to "you people" and "your people," words that have traditionally offended many blacks.He later apologized for any unintended slight, but his appearance left a sense of ill-will.
Earlier in the campaign, Mr. Perot had said he would not appoint homosexuals to cabinet positions because, "I don't want anybody there that will be a point of controversy with the American people." Aides said his comment was taken out of context, but groups representing homosexuals were incensed. He later met with gay rights groups; in July, he reversed course on the issue of appointing gays to cabinet positions and said he favored an end to the Government policy that bans homosexuals from serving in the military, though if elected he said he would not promise to directly order the Secretary of Defense to end the policy.
While known for organizing skills and his ability to get things done, Mr. Perot seemed unable to cope with internal dissension and turmoil in his own campaign. There were two factions. One, headed by professional political consultants like Edward J. Rollins and Hamilton Jordan, co-managers of the campaign, felt he had to follow traditional practice and define himself more clearly for the public because he was slipping in the polls and allowing the press and Republican critics to define him.
Another faction, including James Squires, his press spokesman, recognized that Mr. Perot had to do some conventional things, like taking polls, but they also felt that his strength was in being a nontraditional candidate with a broad grass-roots support, and they were inclined to let the campaign lean more heavily on the volunteers.
Mr. Perot, who wrote his own speeches and preferred one-page memos on issues rather than studies in depth, rejected the advice for an ad campaign to define himself, prompting Mr. Rollins's resignation on July 15, the day before Mr. Perot's own withdrawal.
Mr. Perot spoke of fixing national problems, like a good mechanic under the hood, tinkering with the economy, the deficit, health care and unemployment. He promised a complete platform, and even went into a retreat to get it done. But by midsummer, he had not issued it, and in the end he could not even fix his own discombobulated campaign.
But in a race that for many had been an emotional roller-coaster, Mr. Perot may have lost heaviest -- the loyalty of some of his most devoted followers -- with his decision to abandon the campaign itself. Fury, bitter disappointment, crushed hopes: these are a legacy not easily overcome, even by the Perot magic.
