HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Middle East Lets Itself Consider Peace

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
NEARLY a year after Arabs and Israelis sat down at the peace table in Madrid, Arabs in a number of countries and Israelis seem to agree they have a real opportunity to firmly establish a habit of negotiation that might, step by step, lead to peace.
It is a mood that contrasts vividly with that of the spring and early summer of 1990, just before Iraq invaded Kuwait, when many people in Israel and the Arab world clearly saw the region sliding toward war. It also contrasts with the mood 11 months ago, when both sides seemed content to come to the bargaining table primarily to please the United States, with little real hope of making progress. 
 Now, many people on both sides say that while reliance on military force for nearly half a century has established basic facts of life in the region, it has failed to settle the Arab-Israeli conflict in any durable way. So there is a general belief that the peace process begun by the United States will continue and perhaps achieve small breakthroughs, even though the latest round of talks in Washington proved inconclusive and recent exchanges between Israel and Syria have proceeded only fitfully.
In conversations with Arab and Israeli scholars, newspaper columnists and politicians in Jerusalem, Tel Aviv, Cairo, Amman, Algiers, Tunis and Kuwait over 10 weeks, there has been a consensus on several points: that Arabs and Israelis have no way to go but toward making peace in whatever form is possible; that both sides seem willing to advance toward a settlement, albeit warily; that Arabs and Israelis have more to fear from Iran in the immediate future than from each other, and that Arab rejectionists hold few cards if any (although that could change if Israel insists on humiliating terms.)
 
Reluctant Pragmatism
 "No one in the Arab world has got any interest in doubting the peaceful intentions of the new Israeli Government," Usama al-Baaz, chief foreign policy adviser to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, told the press in Cairo last week. But Adli Sadek, a commentator, wrote less sanguinely yesterday in Al Quds al-Arabi, a Palestinian daily in London. "It is true that no one has a credible substitute to a settlement," he said, but he also wrote: "It is forbidden to the negotiator, in fact it is impossible, to give up any of our beliefs."
This reluctant pragmatism has been sustained now for 11 months by a palpable relaxation of tensions and a number of confidence-building measures on both sides. American Jewish leaders were invited to visit Saudi Arabia this year. Israelis have quietly relaxed military patrolling in the West bank. Syria and Yemen have moved to allow their tiny Jewish communities to leave.
It is true that much of this progress is the product of a lack of alternatives. Still, it is creating a momentum for peace that may be difficult to reverse.
Above all, every Mideast country has been sobered by how close Iraq came to manufacturing atomic weapons, along with its missiles and chemical weapons. Now Israel and several Arab countries have arrived separately at two additional conclusions: they can be more certain of each other's limits, and all must prepare to face a new and unpredictable danger, Iran.
They know the Government in Teheran is rearming and they have little doubt it is working to export its revolutionary ideas -- to Palestinians as well as other Arabs. Their fears have been underlined by reports that Iran will soon take delivery of three submarines from Russia, and by Iranian moves to take over a tiny Persian Gulf island it shared with the United Arab Emirates.
Much of the change in how Arabs view Israel began with the humiliation of Iraq in the gulf crisis, which itself was played out against the loss of the Soviet Union as an ally against Israel and the West. This allowed for the rise of the liberating notion that being pro-Western need not be a stigma. Pro-Western regimes like those in Egypt and Saudi Arabia took the lead in making decisions in the Arab world, and even Syria became willing to converse with Israel.
Optimism that the postwar peace talks might, indeed, go somewhere was sealed with the election in June of Yitzhak Rabin and his Israeli Labor Party coalition, which accepts the principle of trading land for peace. Many Israelis now express confidence in Labor's fundamental proposition that the last two years have wrought enough changes to afford Israel time to try a new approach toward its neighbors. There also appears to be a widespread appreciation that while Israel has contained the uprising of Palestinians against occupation, it cannot forever suppress all Palestinian aspirations.
From Tel Aviv to Riyadh, there is, as well, a vivid appreciation of the cost of armaments. Egypt is struggling to rebuild its economy after four wars in 40 years, and Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, which spent well over $120 billion on the gulf war, now run yearly budget deficits.
In Israel, whose economy has long been hostage to its defense budget and the cost of building settlements in occupied territory, there is now also difficulty with absorbing Jews who left the Soviet Union. And its friend the United States is proving to be a giant with economic feet of clay.
"Rabin understands that we have a chance to make peace and consolidate this lack of threats because he understands that on the horizon new and more serious threats are emerging and they are existential threats because of who is on the horizon," Zeev Schiff, a commentator on military and political affairs for the daily Haaretz, said in a conversation in Tel Aviv. He spoke of "an unbelievable change" in the position of Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, and he also said, pointing to Iran, that the profile of Israel's enemies is changing.
For their part, many Palestinians have begun to say that time is against them in their effort to wrest land from Israel as the basis for a settlement. The other day, Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, said that Saddam Hussein had misled Palestinians "under the illusion that his missiles were to liberate them from Israeli occupation." It was just a passing remark in a radio interview, nearly obscured by other comments in his usual vitriolic style. But it spoke volumes.

LENGTH: 1290 words

HEADLINE: A Time for Statesmen. Or for a Pause.

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: BONN

 BODY:
THE names of Jean Monnet, Konrad Adenauer, Alcide de Gasperi and Charles de Gaulle were being invoked last week by their successors, to recall the high ideals and aspirations that underlay the foundation of the European Community but that lately seem to have been lost in bickering.
Many Europeans were asking themselves whether their current leaders are up to the task of bringing Europe closer to unity, or even of preventing the loss of what has already been achieved. Much of the monetary and political chaos of the last few weeks has been an object lesson in inept political leadership and in the narrow national vision that the Community's original architects sought to transcend. 
 "There will be no peace in Europe if states just realign themselves on the basis of national sovereignty and the resultant politics of prestige and economic protectionism," Monnet, the great French political thinker who never held elective office, wrote before World War II ended. Chancellor Helmut Kohl recalled his words in a speech to the German Parliament Friday: "Europe must be united, and not only by cooperation, but by a voluntary surrender of sovereignty by the European nations to a kind of central union, a union that has the power to reduce tariffs, to create a broader European market and to prevent the revival of nationalism."
Starting next January, Europeans will have a tariff-free single market, but the trouble is that not all of them are sure they want political union, or even a single currency. Pulled in different directions by the pressures of a global recession, left to their own devices by Americans preoccupied with their very different internal economic and social problems, Europeans seem to be asking themselves whether they should stop where they are for a while.
The Community has come a long way toward achieving the dream articulated by Monnet. But De Gaulle and Adenauer and the other founders in the 1950's and 1960's glossed over a basic contradiction that has always lain at the heart of the community. Should it tend toward a collection of loosely cooperating nation-states, or a true United States of Europe? They never really decided.
Instead of bringing all of Europe closer together, the end of the cold war intensified the contradiction. The countries of eastern Europe and the old Soviet Union fiercely insisted on reviving national and ethnic distinctions that Communism had suppressed. Civil wars to the east have all but killed the dream of bringing the new democracies there quickly into the European Community fold, and have made all Europeans think more than they used to about what makes them different from one another, instead of about what they all have in common.
 
A Call for Vision
 "We need statesmen," complained Jacques Delors, president of the community's Executive Commission, at a conference in Brussels last week. "A statesman is a man who sees far and wide, in spite of internal problems." But by wavering in the face of public doubts about the unification process, rather than arguing persuasively for going forward, he seemed to be saying, many were not up to the task.
Mr. Delors has many critics, who would say he should hardly be the first to throw stones on the question of leadership. But in recent years, critics of Europe's unification process have often cast bigger shadows than its supporters. Margaret Thatcher of Britain, when she was Prime Minister, left no doubt where she stood: Britain would not surrender its sovereignty to the bureaucrats in Brussels; European states should be content with the joys of the completely free-trade zone they will have starting next year.
Mr. Kohl and President Francois Mitterrand of France have both made clear that they believe Europe should advance more quickly toward unity, in a real federation.
But at the moment these are not strong leaders, either at home or abroad. Both have been in office for the past decade. Mr. Kohl's authority as the Chancellor of German unification has slumped badly because of the unexpectedly high costs of unification and the social and economic turmoil they brought.
Mr. Mitterrand's popularity was sagging before he called a referendum for last Sunday on the treaty on European political and economic union that was signed in Maastricht, the Netherlands, last December. Uncertainty about whether the treaty would survive the referendum (and it barely did, with just short of 51 percent of France's voters approving it) brought monetary strains within the Community to a head, and have shaken it to its foundations -- needlessly, in the view of some of the French President's critics. Mr. Mitterrand himself looks exhausted, and he was recently diagnosed with cancer of the prostate.
Italy has been in a state of political uncertainty ever since last spring's elections. And Mrs. Thatcher's successor, Prime Minister John Major, now faces a growing rebellion by members of his own party who wonder whether the Iron Lady may have been right after all about staying aloof from Europe.
European integration has always advanced in fits and starts, great creative initiatives being succeeded by periods of consolidation and doubt. But forward movement has almost always coincided with periods of strong national leadership in the key countries. In addition, it has also usually had enthusiastic support from the United States.
But Americans' attention now seems consumed by their own election, and by their economic problems. And when the European leaders signed the Maastricht treaty last year, outlining the way to a common currency as early as 1997, it appears that they may have overreached themselves.
Now there is no way for the treaty to go into effect as scheduled next January, even with the narrow endorsement given in France. Denmark, which rejected the treaty in a referendum June 2, said it would not try again until next year. As for Britain, Mr. Major made clear that he would not put the treaty before Parliament before Denmark resolves its problems. Given all the difficulties, there was talk last week that France and Germany could try to go ahead with monetary union on their own, probably together with Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.
 
French-German Solidarity
 German solidarity with France in the money markets was much more evident last week than it had been with Britain or Italy the week before. Mr. Kohl said Germany's Government and central bank believed the franc was at the right level against the mark. With their support, the franc steadied at the end of the week. Without it, the pound had been forced the week before to float free.
Mr. Major, who holds the rotating presidency of the 12-member European Community now, called an emergency summit meeting in Birmingham Oct. 16, when the leaders will discuss the way forward.
One thing they all agree on is that if the Maastricht treaty is to be saved, all national leaders will have to do a better job of explaining to their citizens how it would work. Crucially, the current generation of leaders has not been able to reassure nervous people who think of themselves first of all as British, French, German, Danish or Dutch that surrendering more national sovereignty to European institutions does not mean losing national identity to a faceless bureaucracy in Brussels.
In the end, some of Europe's nations may decide, as the Danes seemed to do in June, that they just don't want to risk that at all. In that case, perhaps France and Germany will indeed go ahead and build a "small Europe." It would be a far cry from the "Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals" that De Gaulle used to speak of. But smaller visions seem to have succeeded grand ones all over the world.

HEADLINE: U.S. Uncommonly Inactive In World Economic Arena

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
President Bush's new world order, which assigns leadership to the United States as the surviving superpower, clearly did not apply this week to the European currency turmoil. While the United States Government stood by, Germany marched Europe to the German agenda.
Similarly, Mr. Bush's call last spring for rapid approval of foreign loans for Russia was not repeated by the Administration this week at the semiannual gathering of the world's finance ministers and central bank presidents -- a meeting that is frequently a platform from which to push America's foreign economic goals. The White House was silent on Russia. 
 Behind the American reticence is the diminishing power of the United States to shape Europe's economies, a loss of influence made more explicit than ever by the European currency turmoil. That turmoil suggests a world dividing into spheres, with Germany the superpower in Western Europe, the United States in the Western Hemisphere and Japan in Asia and the Pacific. Russia has so far resisted any superpower's strong hand.
 
'They Do Not Listen to Us'
 "The Germans did not inject themselves into the negotiations with Mexico and Canada for a free-trade agreement, and they do not listen to us in Europe," said Jeffrey Garten, a managing director of the Blackstone Group and the author of the recently published "A Cold Peace: America, Japan, Germany and the Struggle for Supremacy."
Confirming that assessment, a senior Treasury Department official who asked for anonymity said the Germans simply rejected or ignored American proposals in recent months that were intended to avoid the currency crisis that finally developed. The turmoil of the past two weeks disrupted the mechanism that had kept European currencies within a fixed range of Germany's mark. The steady mark has slowly replaced the dollar as the measure other Europeans use to value their currencies.
"The Germans believed they could control the currency market, and we believed they could not," the Treasury official said.
 
'A Domestic Agenda'
 But once the currency markets got out of control, American officials abstained from their usual vocal backseat views of how Europe should proceed. And they have not participated in any of the backroom negotiations to resolve the crisis, the Treasury official said. Those talks started in Europe, moved here this week during the meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, and then migrated back to Europe.
"It is up to the Europeans how to put their system back together, not us," the official said. "First they have to stabilize the situation, and then we might play a role in the future."
Several other reasons help explain the low-key American presence at the meetings here. The main one was the presidential election. With Mr. Bush concentrating his campaign rhetoric on solutions for the domestic economic crisis, his strategists have apparently decided not to draw public attention to foreign problems -- particularly problems that have not responded to American pressure.
"The Administration is obviously involved in a domestic agenda," a senior Administration official said, suggesting that at least until Nov. 3, Bush officials are likely to say little about foreign economic issues. The election strategy has soft-pedaled references to the new world order that President Bush proclaimed during the Persian Gulf crisis.
In that spirit, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and David C. Mulford, Under Secretary for International Affairs, had publicly badgered the Germans to lower interest rates, with Mr. Mulford even getting into a squabble with German officials last spring.
The Americans argued, in effect, that only after the Germans, with their increasingly dominant economy, lowered rates could other European nations lower theirs. The American goal was to get Europeans to stimulate their economies, making them more prosperous so that Europe would purchase more American goods and help the United States out of its hard times. But the Germans refused, fearing that lower rates and too much borrowing would raise Germany's inflation rate and weaken the mark.
And the Germans also noted that the United States was in no position to criticize the rising German budget deficit when the American deficit is so high, and rising.
 
A Charitable Reaction
 In the end, the mark proved too strong for the currencies of Britain, Italy and Spain, with their sluggish economies, and these currencies were sharply devalued, destroying the European exchange rate mechanism in the process.
The crisis came on the eve of the meeting here, and the Bush Administration, with its election strategy in mind, responded with mild generalities about stronger worldwide economic growth. The one American attempt to upstage the discussions among Europeans over the proper values of their currencies was a proposal from President Bush that would in effect peg currency values to an index of commodity prices, reducing in the process the mark's power in Europe.
"The Administration was trying to show some leadership and imagination and to provide a sophisticated justification for lower German interest rates," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, offering a more charitable reaction than the Europeans, who ignored the proposal.
The Bush Administration similarly refrained from inserting itself into the growing conflict in Russia -- a conflict that America seems powerless to control. The Russians are divided between those who want to qualify for Western loans by cutting Government spending, closing inefficient companies and laying off workers, and those who want a go-slow policy to save jobs -- even if that means little foreign funding.
The Bush Administration, at the April I.M.F. and World Bank meeting, had declared that a historic moment had arrived and the West should quickly channel funds to the former Soviet Union -- and Russia, in particular -- to save it from falling back into Communism. The assumption was that President Boris N. Yeltsin's Russian Government would soon take the steps to qualify for the foreign loans, an assumption that no longer holds.
 
Avoiding the Wrong Words
 The Administration's policy has not changed, but the timetable for implementing it certainly has, Administration officials said. And Congress has not yet voted approval of a $12 billion contribution to the I.M.F. that America is required to make to help finance aid to Russia. Unable to act, American officials remained silent on the subject this week. So did the Germans and the Japanese, two other contenders for influence in the Commonwealth of Independent States.
Given the European currency turmoil, no one particularly noticed. The American silence on Russia seemed less striking than the image of America sidelined in the currency crisis. Aside from the priorities of the election campaign, another view offered for the reticence was concern that the wrong words from American officials might worsen the currency turmoil.
This concern recalls that in mid-October 1987, James A. Baker 3d, then the Treasury Secretary, now White House chief of staff, demanded that West Germany lower interest rates and the value of the mark. His angry public criticism of German economic policy made a small contribution to the stock market crash a few days later, on Oct. 19, 1987.
And finally, the weak economic growth in the United States at a moment when the German Government is spending billions to rebuild East Germany has eroded American influence in Western Europe. The reunification program means Europe is buying more products from Europe at the same time that the United States is buying fewer European goods.
"If the United States economy were only stronger," said David D. Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, "we could have some influence in resolving this crisis."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
A Tense Uncertainty Grows in the Campaign

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Five weeks before Election Day, it is a tense time for Gov. Bill Clinton, but an alarming one for President Bush.
Behind the happy, Trumanesque imagery of Mr. Bush's whistle-stop tour through the Midwest this weekend are some hard political facts: a formidable deficit in the national polls, an unfriendly electoral map and now, the possible re-entry of his most tormenting critic, Ross Perot. 
 Mr. Perot's re-emergence at this late stage of the campaign would be, in many ways, a major headache for both parties; before the Texas billionaire bolted from the race last July, he showed strength among voters who form the bases for both major candidates, and the prospect of his re-entry has sent both campaigns back to an anxious reassessment of the states.
Mr. Clinton, as the front-runner in national polls, but a very nervous one, obviously has the greatest interest in maintaining the status quo in the race. As James Carville, his top strategist, put it, "If the election were held today, I would be happy."
Some analysts suggest that Mr. Bush is so stalled now that he could profit from a scrambled race that forced voters to think anew, and perhaps splintered anti-Bush sentiment.
But Democrats argue, with some evidence in state-by-state polling, that Mr. Clinton can afford to take more of a blow from a new rival than Mr. Bush can. And some analysts say that Perot II could turn out to be another dance with television cameras that produces protest voting, but only marginal electoral impact.
 
Powerful Forces at Work
 Some political professionals are beginning to wonder whether the economic and political forces now working against Mr. Bush are largely beyond the influence of strategy, tactics and strange turns in the campaign plot like the re-entry of Mr. Perot.
"This election is being driven by the continuing pessimism about the economy and a rejection of George Bush as leader," said Thomas Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution, the research center in Washington.
Representative Vin Weber, a Minnesota Republican who is a co-chairman of the Bush campaign, said: "It's still clearly uphill. I think the campaign has gotten its act together over the past few weeks in terms of getting out a consistent economic message, but we still have a heavy burden of proof in a change-oriented environment."
Mr. Bush's team has become painfully aware of the clock. James A. Baker 3d, viewed this summer as the savior just off stage, has been in the White House for a month. His team has honed Mr. Bush's economic message, mounted a new attack on his rival and tried, repeatedly, to seize control of this race. But Mr. Bush has made little if any progress in the polls in recent weeks.
A poll made public today by Time magazine and CNN showed Mr. Clinton with 49 percent of the likely voters and Mr. Bush with 37 percent, a Democratic lead that had grown from 6 percentage points a month ago. In a three-way race, Mr. Clinton would draw 43 percent, Mr. Bush 32 percent and Mr. Perot 17 percent.
Those figures would change if Mr. Perot formally entered the contest, as would those of another new one by Newsweek that showed Mr. Clinton leading by 10 points in a two-way race and a nine points in a three-way race.
Still, while Washington is a city quick to draw conclusions and hang crepe on the basis of polling, Peter Hart, the Democratic poll taker, notes that this Presidential election has transformed itself in 40 days before: Patrick J. Buchanan rose and fell, Mr. Clinton went from a bleeding nominee to a formidable front-runner and Mr. Perot soared, crashed and burned in about the same time. "I think the idea that we've seen the last card played is very misleading," Mr. Hart said.
This week, the Bush camp clearly entered what politicians delicately describe as "the hard contrast" phase of its campaign: it intensified its assault on Mr. Clinton's record and character with a new television commercial attacking him as a taxer and spender, and with biting new speeches from the President himself.
Some Republicans grumbled, privately, that the Baker team had waited too long to pull the trigger, but campaign officials said Mr. Bush first needed to make a positive case for his re-election. Charles Black, a senior adviser to the Bush camp, indicated that the campaign had high hopes for its new round of advertising.
"About everything there is to know about Bush is known, in terms of bad things for people to know about him," Mr. Black said. "But people don't know much about Clinton." Asked if Mr. Clinton's draft history would be featured in the new advertising, Mr. Black replied that he would not be surprised if it did.
 
Bush's Strategy on Debates
 Until Bush strategists see some movement in poll results, they are expected to take a hard line on debates; top strategists are said to believe that agreeing to debates would simply freeze the race, while the debate itself could allow Mr. Clinton to "close the sale" with the voters.
The Clinton campaign, meanwhile, is cheered by national and state polls that show him in powerful position to gain the 270 electoral votes he needs to win.
In California, a primary anchor for a Democratic majority this year, Mr. Clinton retains a double-digit poll lead, and a Los Angeles Times survey indicates the margin would be unaffected if Mr. Perot runs. Mr. Clinton holds solid leads across much of the Northeast, according to polls conducted this month and compiled by The Hotline, a political newsletter.
Those polls also show that Mr. Clinton holds significant edges in such traditional swing states as Missouri and Illinois, and is running competitively with Mr. Bush in much of the South, including Florida and Texas.
Clinton aides argue that while Mr. Perot may cut into their margins in many of these states, he would not do so enough to change the outcome. These analysts say Mr. Perot actually helps them in some Southern states, notably North Carolina and Georgia.
Still, Clinton forces are aware that much of their support is soft and subject to erosion from advertising aimed at Mr. Clinton's trustworthiness. This is widely expected to be the primary use of the draft issue against Mr. Clinton, an issue raised anew today by a Los Angeles Times report that a meeting was arranged for him with the head of Selective Service in Arkansas in an attempt to avoid the draft.
The Clinton campaign plans to keep emphasizing the economy and Mr. Bush's record in dealing with it. If Mr. Perot does re-enter the race, Mr. Clinton is expected again to avoid direct attacks on the Texas billionaire, on the ground that Mr. Clinton is the natural inheritor of Mr. Perot's supporters.
The Bush forces attacked Mr. Perot vigorously last spring, and the strategy was widely seen as backfiring. Mr. Clinton is also expected to talk more, in the coming days, about reducing the Federal budget deficit, which was an important issue to Mr. Perot.
"The important thing is that we maintain our focus, that we understand this is not a race about Ross Perot; it's a race about the economy and about change," Mr. Carville said.
Whether either campaign will be able to maintain its focus with a revived Perot campaign is another question. Strategists in both parties throw up their hands when it comes to calculating the Texan's impact.
Political professionals say they expect a Perot campaign, at least initially, to get intensive news coverage, and suggest he could help drive the campaign dialogue. For example, he could make it harder for the Bush campaign to focus its fire on Mr. Clinton. In the past, Mr. Perot has delighted in chiding his rivals for focusing on attacks rather than issues, and he seems to take special delight in chiding Mr. Bush. Mr. Perot could also make it hard for Mr. Bush to continue to resist the bipartisan commission's plan for debates.
But he could also point out the flaws in Mr. Clinton's economics, and muddy Mr. Clinton's claim to be the voice of change and economic responsibility.
Still, a revived Perot campaign would be essentially a symbolic effort, many analysts. As a result, it is unclear how many actual votes it would produce, particularly since the level of enmity seems so high toward him in the aftermath of his on-again, off-again campaign this year. The Time-CNN Poll, for example, found him viewed unfavorably by 46 percent of respondents and favorably by 25 percent.
Mr. Perot is widely expected to have his greatest electoral impact in Texas, a state that Mr. Bush must win.
For now, the two campaigns are simply, warily, waiting for Mr. Perot's announcement of his plans. Until then, one Administration official argued this week, the polls are meaningless, "because you just don't know what people's reactions are going to be."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Clinton Again Faces Draft Issue As He Returns to New Hampshire

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 26

 BODY:
Seven months after a second-place showing in this state's Democratic primary saved him from political destruction, Gov. Bill Clinton returned today, triumphant but still dogged by the same questions that nearly destroyed him in February.
As Mr. Clinton hopscotched through campaign appearances in three New England states today, reporters peppered the Democratic Presidential nominee with questions about how he managed to avoid being inducted by the military during the Vietnam War. 
 The questions that first arose as a campaign issue days before the February primary here and have periodically resurfaced, came up again today in the aftermath of a published account asserting that in the summer of 1969 Mr. Clinton's Army induction notice was canceled after a lobbying effort directed at the head of the Arkansas Selective Service.
But Mr. Clinton stayed at least as much on the offensive as on the defensive today, hitting his opponent hard in speeches in New Hampshire, Vermont and Maine and in remarks to reporters.
 
Sharp Attack on Bush
 Responding to charges by President Bush today that Mr. Clinton's economic plan would entail higher taxes for millions of middle-class people and not simply the rich Americans whom Mr. Clinton has said he intends to tax, the Democrat responded sharply.
"He has no credibility on taxes, and he can't even count," Mr. Clinton said. "Everything he says is wrong. He raised taxes on everybody. It's just bull. My plan is out there. It's clear: we ran it with Congressional Budget Office numbers."
The question of Mr. Clinton's draft status arose anew today in an article in The Los Angeles Times that said he had benefited from efforts by a Republican friend seeking to arrange a meeting between him and Col. Willard A. Hawkins, who had been appointed by a Republican governor and was director of the Arkansas Selective Service in 1969.
In the past Mr. Clinton has acknowledged that he cast a wide net in the summer of 1969 looking for a way to escape induction, but he has always said he did not do anything improper or receive any special treatment, aside from what might be expected to be given a Rhodes scholar from small-town Arkansas.
Today, he acknowledged that he might have met with Mr. Hawkins, as The Los Angeles Times article suggested, but that any such meeting, if it did occur, would have been part of routine procedure, suggested to him by the local draft board in Hot Springs.
"They told me what procedures to follow, and I followed their procedures," Mr. Clinton told reporters after a speech here.
He said he had no recollection of meeting with the director of the Arkansas Selective Service, but he added: "That doesn't mean it didn't occur. I mean it could have happened by letter or meeting. I can't say one way or the other, because I don't know for sure."
Whatever he did, Mr. Clinton said repeatedly today, had been at the suggestion of the Hot Springs draft board and was strictly "normal procedure."
The draft questions did not appear to mar the Governor's mood, which was notably upbeat as he spent the day in that most pleasant of political activities, running ahead in places where he had been expected to be behind.
Neither New Hampshire, where Mr. Clinton spoke first, nor Vermont, where he spoke next, had voted for a Democratic Presidential nominee since Lyndon B. Johnson's landslide victory in 1964. Maine, the third stop on the New England tour, has not gone Democratic since 1968.
This year, Clinton campaign officials say their polls in all three states show their candidate ahead of Mr. Bush.
Perhaps with these figures in mind, Mr. Clinton struck a note of thanks and expectant victory in speeches today.

HEADLINE: Angola to Vote, Unsure About West's Democracy

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUANDA, Angola, Sept. 26

 BODY:
After nearly three decades of war, economic hardship and political strife, Angolans will go to the polls next week to elect a government freely for the first time. While the election could be viewed as a triumph of democracy, cynicism is widespread.
Many Angolans are not convinced that Western-style democracy can work here. Their doubts have not been lessened by sporadic incidents of violence, much of it stemming from a mix of ethnic differences and old vendettas. 
 The backdrop to the voting is the legacy of a long and brutal civil war in which rebel groups first fought Portuguese rulers and then each other on a cold-war battleground. More than 500,000 Angolans died during a generation of bloodshed, two-thirds of them children, leaving virtually no family untouched. An additional million people, fleeing the fighting, Government confiscations, rebel incursions and the military draft, have simply left the country, much of which is devastated.
 
Luanda in Decay
 The cost of the war is especially conspicuous here in Luanda, a seaside capital once called the Rio of Africa. Signs of decay are everywhere: ruined roads, the stench of uncollected garbage, formerly stately apartment houses and villas sinking into squalor, wretched shanty towns with a deadly lack of sanitation. On many streets, men, women and children maimed in the war can be seen hopping on homemade crutches.
The decision now facing Angolan voters is who should bear the blame for such misery, a judgment that has overshadowed debate about future policies.
Does the fault lie with the governing party, the once avowedly Marxist-Leninist Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, which was sustained for years by Soviet arms and Cuban soldiers? Even party officials admit that its economic stewardship has been disastrous since the country gained independence from Portugal in 1975.
Or should the blame fall on its main rival, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, and its leader, Jonas Savimbi? With military and financial support from the United States and South Africa, the group, known as Unita, fought a war that ravaged this country yet, arguably, never seriously challenged the Government's hold on power. With the end of the cold war, Mr. Savimbi signed a peace accord last year with President Jose Eduardo dos Santos, paving the way for next week's elections.
Mr. Savimbi, who favors a free-market economy and ties to the West, and Mr. dos Santos, who advocates a largely state-controlled economy, are the most prominent of 13 presidential candidates. If no one receives a majority in the voting Tuesday and Wednesday, in which more than 223 seats in Parliament will also be filled, a runoff election will be held.
Although 400 United Nations monitors will supervise the vote, concerns aroused during the campaign persist.
 
'An Abstract Concept'
 "The average man on the street doesn't know anything about democracy; it's just an abstract concept," said Holden Roberto, a presidential candidate who led the old National Front for the Liberation of Angola, which fought the Portuguese and then the M.P.L.A. with Unita.
"All he knows is what he sees everyday, and that is that the cease-fire hasn't stopped the violence and things are getting worse as the election approaches," he added.
His comments were echoed by Paulinho Fernandes Madeca, the Roman Catholic bishop of Cabinda, Angola's oil-producing enclave.
"The people are full of fear, and a lot of them are leaving their villages because they don't know what will happen during the elections," he said.
Still, if Western-style democracy endures and flourishes, the reward for Angola's 10 million people could be enormous. With such resources as oil, coffee, iron ore, cotton, sisal and diamonds, Angola has exceptional potential. Western experts say that with political stability, the country could become one of the few on the continent to break away from the economic decline seen elsewhere.
 
Reticence on Outcome
 There is a profound uncertainty about the outcome of the elections. Most voters are reluctant to discuss their views, and even the best-informed specialists and experienced diplomats say they are at a loss to forecast the results.
Reports in the Government-controlled news media have made much of the violence that has disrupted some rallies, with rocks, bottles, and, in some cases, bullets aimed at some candidates and their supporters. But the attention given to such incidents tends to overshadow the peace that has prevailed at most of the scores of rallies held since the campaign began in earnest in late August.
Before the cease-fire accords were signed in May 1991, conventional wisdom in Luanda suggested that Unita would be an easy winner against the increasingly divided and dispirited governing party. Pointing to the disciplined Unita organization, toughened by years of guerrilla warfare, diplomats and other foreign experts had spoken almost as if a Savimbi victory was inevitable.
Although nearly 20 mostly centrist parties have emerged, they have largely failed to capture the public's imagination as alternatives to either Unita or the M.P.L.A.
Many political commentators here predict that the most potent element in the elections will be the enduring power of regional and ethnic loyalties. In theory, Mr. Savimbi has a slight edge in this area because his political base, the mostly rural and agrarian central highlands, dominated by his ethnic group the Ovimbundu, forms nearly 40 percent of the population.
 
Support Far From Solid
 The governing party, by contrast, was said to draw most of its support from the much smaller group of mixed-raced Angolans, called mesticos in Portuguese, and to a lesser extent from the Kimbundu people of Luanda and the nearby Cuanza Valley.
But reporters and diplomats who have devoted extensive time and effort to interviewing voters throughout the country have found Mr. Savimbi's support among the Ovimbundu far from solid. And doubts about his candidacy appear to have grown as the election campaign has progressed.
In most instances, the sentiment appears to be directed not so much in favor of the M.P.L.A. or Mr. dos Santos, its longtime leader, but rather against Mr. Savimbi.
Part of Mr. Savimbi's troubles stem from the fact that the Ovimbundu were often victims of Unita's guerrilla tactics, although in most cases unintentionally. Tens of thousands of Ovimbundus, for example, are believed to have been killed or maimed by land mines laid by Unita soldiers. The rebels, however, contend that Government troops and their Cuban allies used mines to punish villages sympathetic to the guerrillas.
 
Accusations on 2 Deaths
 Furthermore, the image that Mr. Savimbi carefully cultivated in some western countries as Angola's great democratic hope has also been tarnished by recent accusations that two popular men who had once been his proteges were put to death last year at his group's headquarters in southeastern Angola. Mr. Savimbi has denied involvement in their deaths while accepting responsibility for whatever abuses may have occurred in the war.
The governing party has been plagued by accusations of financial misconduct by its leaders, a continuing theme in the campaign. It is widely said that while party leaders mouthed slogans about equality and socialism they abused their positions.
Even relatively junior party officials could get tax-free imports, preferential housing and special rights to travel. And while corruption is not thought to have reached the level of plunder attributed to, say, President Mobutu Sese Seko of neighboring Zaire, it has been a liability for Mr. dos Santos.
The subject is so sensitive that even some opposition politicians tend not to make much of the issue in public out of fear of inviting swift retaliation by the authorities. But analysts here say that graft and corruption in this country is believed to have increased sharply in recent months.
While some aides have always been engaged in petty corruption to make ends meet, high-level officials dealing with foreign executives are said to be routinely demanding bribes, buying foreign property and sending money abroad. A piece of graffiti found on walls throughout the city reads:
"The M.P.L.A. steals, Unita kills."

HEADLINE: Prospects Looking Up For 7 Southern Senators

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 26

 BODY:
In the Republican high tide after the Persian Gulf war, all roads to a Republican takeover of the Senate seemed to run through Dixie, where seven Democrats were up for re-election in what looked like a strong Republican year.
Now, the Democrats have a shot at winning them all. 
 The South remains the Republicans' best hope for picking up seats in the Senate, and Democratic Senators in Georgia, North Carolina and South Carolina are all viewed as vulnerable in a year when anti-incumbent sentiments may prove as potent as the war once seemed.
But one of the most telling signs of how much has changed in the last year and how much has not changed in 12 years of Republican Presidents is the political landscape of the South, where the conservative gains nationally did not produce the Republican gains in the South that many had anticipated.
Back when President Bush's approval ratings were hovering around 90 percent and the war seemed certain to be a dominant issue, Republicans were anticipating dramatic gains.
 
Five Freshmen Senators
 Up for re-election are four Democratic Senators who voted to continue economic sanctions against Iraq rather than authorize force in the Persian Gulf: Terry Sanford of North Carolina, Wyche Fowler Jr. of Georgia, Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina and Dale Bumpers of Arkansas. Five of the seven up for re-election -- Mr. Fowler, Mr. Sanford, Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, John Breaux of Louisiana and Bob Graham of Florida -- are freshman.
At the minimum, Mr. Sanford, Mr. Fowler and Mr. Hollings seemed likely losers. "They all looked like dead meat," said Harrison Hickman, a Democratic consultant now working for Mr. Sanford.
At most, all seven, perhaps with the exception of Mr. Breaux, were thought to be possible targets for the right challenger.
Since then, Mr. Bush's popularity has plummeted. The war has receded as an issue and been replaced by the economy. The Democratic ticket of Southerners, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, has left Southern Democrats more energized than in any race since 1980.
And the Republicans repeatedly failed to get their strongest candidates, like Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, Gov. James G. Martin of North Carolina and a former Georgia candidate for governor, Johnny Isakson, to run. Nothing came of the Republican hope of getting the Gulf war hero, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, to run against the popular Mr. Graham in Florida.
The Democrats are now considered safe in Arkansas, Louisiana, Florida and Alabama. But political analysts say the races in Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina could all be highly competitive.
In some ways, the dynamic is similar in each race: an incumbent with some clear vulnerabilities fighting an anti-incumbent tide.
"In almost all the state races I can think of this year, if it was close, the incumbents lost," Mr. Campbell said.
Recent independent polls in the three races show the incumbents leading, but within reach. The most endangered may be Mr. Sanford, who is now a 75-year-old freshman Senator.
With the Gulf war vote no longer a prominent issue, Mr. Sanford's experience as a World War II paratrooper may balance out his vote. But his relatively liberal voting record and what is viewed as an uneven first term make him vulnerable.
Mr. Sanford fought off health problems over the summer. And he may be the only one of the three incumbents to be outspent by his rival, Lauch (pronounced lock) Faircloth, a former Democrat who is backed by the potent conservation organization, the National Congressional Club, allied with Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina.
 
Ticket Helps Democrats
 On the other hand, Mr. Faircloth, who ran unsuccessfully for Governor in 1984, does not have nearly the heft as a candidate that Governor Martin would have had. And for the first time since 1976, Democrats could actually be helped by the top of the ticket rather than dragged down by it the way they were in 1980.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas recently campaigned in South Carolina and proclaimed the state the Republicans' best chance to beat an incumbent. And Mr. Hollings, a prickly 26-year incumbent, may be just the kind of candidate whom voters may turn on this year, particularly in perhaps the most Republican state in the South.
But Mr. Hollings has strong ties to the usually Republican textile belt around Greenville, a big fund-raising edge and an opponent, Tommy Hartnett, who is a veteran politician without much outsider appeal. He lost his last race, a bid for lieutenant governor.
The nastiest race may come in Georgia, where Paul Coverdell, a Republican, is already trying to make an issue of whether Mr. Fowler overdrew his account at the now-defunct House bank when he was in Congress. Mr. Fowler's camp is likely to make an issue of Mr. Coverdell's tenure as head of the Peace Corps, where he was accused of using the office to plot his political future in Georgia.
Mr. Fowler's relatively liberal voting record makes him a target. But it is not yet clear if Mr. Coverdell will raise the money needed to stay competitive. And some Republicans fear that Mr. Coverdell simply does not have the personal presence to make the case against Mr. Fowler.
In fact, though Mr. Sanford, Mr. Hollings and Mr. Fowler could end up falling to an anti-incumbent mood, the Democratic incumbents may also symbolize the success of the Democrats in holding off the Republican tide in a decade when the Democrats won only one state, Georgia, in a Presidential election from 1980 to 1988.
Merle Black, a professor of politics and government at Emory University, said that despite the conservative politics of the region, the Democrats have prospered by fielding savvy, pragmatic political moderates while the Republicans have tended toward ideologues like the four Senate Republican victors in 1980: Mack Mattingly in Georgia, Jeremiah Denton in Alabama, John East in North Carolina and Paula Hawkins in Florida.
Many observers think at least one of the incumbents is likely to lose, but absent an effective negative campaign by the Republicans, said Mr. Black, the traditional Democratic strengths could work this year for Mr. Sanford, Mr. Fowler and Mr. Hollings.
"The Democrats have usually positioned themselves as moderates blending liberal and conservative positions in a way that can attract white swing voters and put together a majority, while the Republicans get only the white conservatives, and that's not enough," Mr. Black said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Georgians Illustrate Why What Worked for Bush in '88 Doesn't Work in '92

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTELL, Ga., Sept. 25

 BODY:
Frank Ellis is the kind of voter who could short out a political consultant's computer programs: a conservative, anti-abortion, 53-year-old white Southerner who has voted for the Republican candidates Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan and the Democrats Jimmy Carter and Michael S. Dukakis.
This year, though he likes what the Republicans say about family values and is uneasy with Bill Clinton's draft record, he is firmly in the Clinton camp. 
 "I'm opposed to abortion, and I agree with Quayle on Murphy Brown, but that's not what the election's about," he said over lunch at Dolly's Farmhouse Restaurant here. "I think people are a little bit more sophisticated than they used to be. They care about the economy. They don't go for all that other junk anymore."
 
Contrast With '88 Race
 Voters like Mr. Ellis may go a long way toward explaining why, despite several weeks of the kind of harsh, value-laden attacks on Mr. Clinton that dismantled Mr. Dukakis four years ago, President Bush remains stalled well behind Mr. Clinton in the polls.
There are any number of differences between 1988 and 1992, from the dismal economy to the chasm in political savvy between Mr. Dukakis and Mr. Clinton. And it is unclear how issues like Mr. Clinton's draft history will play out in the campaign's remaining five weeks. But interviews with dozens of voters in suburban south and southwest Cobb County, just outside Atlanta, an area that leans Republican but is also home to many of the Reagan Democrats both sides are courting, bring out two major reasons why what worked in 1988 is not working now.
The first is the degree to which the economy dominates the race. The second is the way an electorate that is in parts more jaded, more sophisticated and more cynical about politics seems far more resistant to the kind of emotion-laden political gambits that have worked for Republicans in the past.
"I think that in February or March of last year, something clicked in with the American public, where they said, we're sick of the scandal of the week, that unless it's something of cataclysmic proportions, we don't give a damn about it," said Matt Towery, a Republican running unopposed for state representative whose district includes part of South Cobb County. "They're just concerned about the economy."
The interviews also elicited the widespread sense of unhappiness with both candidates that has pervaded the political year and that offers the potential for Ross Perot to play a significant role if he gets back in the race. Less clear is which candidate he would hurt.
As a second alternative for change, he could take votes from Mr. Clinton. But, here at least, it may be just as likely that he could take votes from Mr. Bush by providing an option for voters who want action on the economy but do not trust the Democrats to provide it.
It is clear that one reason the Republican strategy has not worked is that in its rawest form, like the speeches of Patrick J. Buchanan and the Rev. Pat Robertson at the Republican Convention, it may not have been as much in touch with the values of the electorate as Republicans thought.
But in this conservative area, where the bumper stickers on mini-vans in mall parking lots tend toward things like "Life is Fragile: Handle with Prayer," it is not hard to find people who like what they hear from the Republicans and do not like what they know about Bill Clinton and the draft.
"It's a moral issue," said Mary Hernandez, a retired civil servant. "I think Bush has higher morals than the other one. The problem is sinners are more popular than Christians."
But almost everyone who mentioned family values and the draft issue as reasons for voting for Mr. Bush planned to vote Republican anyway.
Frances Zieman, 43, a legal secretary who plans to vote for Mr. Clinton, said: "You think of the flag thing four years ago; what kind of issue is that? It's a different world than it was four years ago. I don't think those things work anymore."
Family values has fallen out of the Republican playbook, but the draft issue clearly carries weight with many voters.
"If someone didn't want to fight for his country, how is he going to lead it?" asked Glenn Neumann, 47, a shop foreman from nearby Powder Springs. But he says he will probably vote for Ross Perot if he runs. If Mr. Perot does not, he will vote for Mr. Clinton. "I can't vote for Bush," he said. "He's been in there for 12 years and hasn't done anything."
On the other hand, the draft seems to have limited appeal to women and to many younger voters.
"I couldn't care less about it," said Tom Foster, a 29-year-old sales manager who says he is undecided.
In fact, if there is a value question that really sticks with many of these suburban voters, it is the economic abilities of the Democratic Party.
"I don't see how any intelligent person who cares about his job can vote for a Democrat for President," said Franklin Burton, 36, a contractor.
It is clear that even if the particulars are not critical, the combination of doubts about the Democrats and the questions raised about Mr. Clinton work together to turn off many voters who do not want to vote for Mr. Bush.
Still, some wonder where voters will go if Mr. Perot enters the race. The Texan will surely siphon off some Clinton votes as an alternative for people who want change. But he also appeals to conservative voters focused on the economy, like Maria Perrucci, 39, who owns a yogurt shop here, and Jill Buhler, 34, a homemaker from nearby Marietta, who would otherwise vote for Mr. Bush.
"I want a businessman in there," Mrs. Buhler said. "I don't care for Clinton's ideas, and I don't think Bush has any."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Says Clinton's Plan to Tax the Rich Will Be Costly for the Middle Class

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Ohio, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Striving to win back disgruntled middle-class voters, President Bush said today that Gov. Bill Clinton's economic proposals would hurt the middle-class taxpayers that the Democratic challenger has pledged to help.
White House officials produced new economic estimates that they said demonstrate that Mr. Clinton's plan to raise the taxes of the top 2 percent of the nation's earners would actually cost a couple with a gross income of $85,000 about $2,800 a year in higher taxes. 
 "That is the big secret of this campaign," Mr. Bush said, standing on the bunting-draped rear platform of a train that stopped in four Ohio towns today. "To capture all the revenue that he wants to raise, to pay for all these promises, Bill Clinton will have to go after the middle class. I am not going to let him do that, and neither are you."
President Bush offered his harsh, new critique as he began a two-day train trip through Ohio and Michigan, two states that have been hit hard by the recession and that will be crucial to his re-election hopes in November.
The 19-passenger car train traveled along rivers and past harvested corn fields, followed a path through some of the most solidly Republican counties in the state, where unemployment rates are generally low.
The Bush campaign estimated that Mr. Clinton's tax-increase plan would affect about nine million people, or 8 percent of all taxpayers.
 
Budget Office Calculations
 Mr. Bush argued vigorously that Mr. Clinton was reaching into the pockets of the middle class to earn $150 billion in new revenues. But an official who briefed reporters on the train about the estimates provided by the Office of Management and Budget would not say whether they considered these high earners to be part of the middle class.
Gene Sperling, the Clinton campaign's economics adviser, said the Bush campaign was distorting the Democrat's plan. The 2 percent figure, he said, was shorthand for what Mr. Clinton really intends, which is to raise taxes only on those people who earn $200,000 or more a year.
And the tax burden on the middle class, he said, would still be eased by allowing taxpayers to choose between increasing the deductions they are allowed for children and across-the-board tax relief.
In Washington, an economist with Congress' Joint Committee on Taxation noted that it was difficult to pin down the top 2 percent, but said the figure fell between Mr. Clinton's and Mr. Bush's notions, at about $155,000. This figure was based on report by the Internal Revenue Service this spring.
Mr. Clinton's plan, the President said, also overestimates the money it would save from proposals like taxing foreign companies. One such company, Honda, has an automotive assembly plant that employs 10,000 people in Marysville, Ohio, Mr. Bush's first stop of the day.
"Now, you slap a tax on Honda, and they'll take the jobs and go somewhere else," Mr. Bush said.
Mr. Sperling responded that forcing foreign companies to pay corporate income taxes on all their earnings in the United States would only help keep American jobs. "We believe that good foreign companies pay their fair share of taxes," he said.
The Bush campaign also said that Mr. Clinton's proposal was too optimistic in the growth it projects for the American economy and the programs it promises to create.
The Administration official who briefed reporters said that each time Arkansas ran short of money, Governor Clinton had tapped the middle class, "because that's where the money is."
Energized by the new line of attack and warming to his appeal to average Americans, Mr. Bush used a variation on a line from a country music song that Mr. Clinton has often used to accuse the President of being out of touch.
"We've heard that song before," he said. "Jimmy Carter sang it. Walter Mondale sang it. Michael Dukakis sang it, and they're going after the rich, but the middle class always gets up singing the blues. Big government gets the gold and you get the shaft."
 
Recurring Complaint
 Mr. Bush also renewed a recurring complaint about Mr. Clinton's economic plan, asserting that the plan proposed programs without explaining how they would be financed. The budget cuts that Mr. Clinton has suggested to help reduce the deficit, the President said, are not realistic and represent $242 billion in spending cuts that cannot be achieved.
Mr. Bush criticized Mr. Clinton and his proposals at every stop along the train tour today.
"We must not take a risk about this economy," he said, stating that Mr. Clinton raised taxes in Arkansas and comparing him to a former Governor of another Southern state. "Our economy could slide into a disaster if we go back to the misery days of Jimmy Carter, if we make the wrong choice."
The White House said the trip was patterned after a similar journey made by President Reagan from Dayton to Perrysburg, Ohio, in 1984. But Mr. Bush, who was accompanied by his wife, Barbara, also backhandedly acknowledged the success of the Democrats' bus tours.
"For four months another candidate for President has been tearing down the United States of America, running the country down," Mr. Bush said in Columbus. "Maybe he's inhaling too many of those bus fumes. I think he did inhale them.
"Well let's get that bus off the side of the road. Because on this train trip we're going to blow the whistle on Governor Clinton. I am tired of his lousy record in Arkansas."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A crowd gathered yesterday on Main Street in Marysville, Ohio, for President Bush's address from the rear platform of the "Spirit of America" train, upper right. The two-day train trip goes through Ohio and Michigan. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Top Police Ranks Reach Labor Accord

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration has reached a new labor agreement with representatives of the 8,500 captains, lieutenants, sergeants and detectives in the New York City Police Department who had been working without a contract for more than two years, the city announced yesterday.
The agreement, which still has to be approved by the membership of the Superior Officers Council, covers the next 15 months and is retroactive to June 3, 1990, when the last contract expired. The agreement provides for an immediate 3.5 percent increase in salary and a 1 percent increase at the end of the first year, as well as a welfare fund increase of $100 and other benefits. 
 The contract mirrors a settlement reached last year with the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. A statement released by Mayor David N. Dinkins's office said the agreement was "consistent with those reached with other uniform and civilian employees."
The contract will be financed through city funds set aside for it, the Mayor's office said.
The Superior Officers Council is a coalition of four bargaining units. Joseph V. Toal, president of the Sergeants' Benevolent Association, said that with the "difficult economy," he was happy with the agreement.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ross Perot;
Perot's Summer Followers Stir Again, Warily

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Sept. 26

 BODY:
If Ross Perot does as he has hinted and re-enters the Presidential race, the breadth of his influence will depend on whether he can win back the supporters who lost faith in him when he dropped out in July.
Some are undoubtedly lost forever. Others, like 35-year-old Nancy Wilder of Chicago, say they will listen to him again, but with much more skepticism. 
 Ms. Wilder, a lawyer in the Cook County Prosecutor's Office, said she had previously considered voting for Mr. Perot because she believed that the other candidates were not addressing the problems of the inner cities. And while she now said she would be willing to take another look at him, her view is colored by Mr. Perot's earlier defection.
 
High Negative Rating
 "I was disappointed when he dropped out and curious as to why he did it," Ms. Wilder said. "But I never got an answer that satisfied me. If he couldn't explain dropping out, how does he explain coming back in?"
Recent polls and interviews with former Perot supporters around the country show that the Texan's abrupt withdrawal on July 16 shattered the bond of trust he had built with voters dissatisfied with the candidates of the two major parties. For the billionaire to again be a serious contender for the White House, he must reforge that link.
A poll by CBS News this week illustrates the scope of Mr. Perot's challenge. The national telephone survey of 1,757 registered voters found that 47 percent had an unfavorable opinion of Mr. Perot, a higher number than the unfavorable rating for either President Bush or Gov. Bill Clinton. The poll was conducted Tuesday through Thursday, just after Mr. Perot said in a television interview that his decision to quit the campaign was a "mistake." The margin of error was plus or minus three percentage points.
In a campaign year when the question of trust has been an overarching theme, Mr. Perot's abandonment of his crusade this summer could greatly hinder his ability to play a role in the Presidential race, as a candidate, kingmaker or pacesetter on the economic debate. The grass-roots effort that put his name on 25 state ballots before he left the race was built as much around his personality as it was fueled by dissatisfaction with the current crop of politicians. As a flawed prophet, Mr. Perot now seems to have mostly alienation to power his movement.
In recent interviews even those who said they would still vote for Mr. Perot added that their enthusiasm for him had been diminished by his defection. Mr. Perot had been a refreshing breeze, a man of candor who was a sharp contrast to the typical dissembling candidate, they said. Now, he seemed just another politician.
"As a Republican I believed Bush when he said, 'Read my lips, no new taxes,' " said Diane Rees, a 53-year-old Boulder, Colo., lobbyist was spokeswoman for the Perot Petition Committee in her state. "Then subsequently I believed Perot's pledge that if we got him on the ballot in all 50 states he would run a first-class campaign. Then I believed him when he said was getting out. Although I feel I'm politically sophisticated, my ability to be fooled is undiminished."
To be sure, there is a strong desire for Mr. Perot's return among some who still cannot stomach either Mr. Bush or Mr. Clinton. That Mr. Perot's resolve seemed to have wilted under partisan criticism and press scrutiny matters less to these backers than their displeasure with the major-party candidates and the Presidential campaign's level of discourse.
"My opinion of him dropped considerably," said William Flower, the 36-year-old owner of a steel-processing business in Athens, Ala. "It's kind of an easy thing for him do. He can drop in and drop out whenever he wants to. But I would still vote for him, even though I still question his electability."
Timothy Murphy, 41, a Fargo, N.D., businessman who was his state's coordinator for the Perot campaign, agreed, saying: "I think he is a half-pint vessel. But I am so tired of Murphy Brown and Bill Clinton's draft record. I cannot believe the level this campaign has fallen to."
 
Feeling Like a Jilted Lover
 But other former Perot backers said they would never reconsider him. Jennifer Laszlo, 28, a Democratic political consultant who worked on the Presidential campaigns of Boris Yeltsin in Russia and Vaclav Havel in Czechoslovakia, saw Mr. Perot as a bold reformer, challenging a tired and ineffective government, but not any more.
"I think he's lost credibility," said Ms. Laszlo, a Washington resident who for a short time trained volunteers in the Dallas headquarters of Mr. Perot's petition committee. "I think the people who really cared about him and got excited about politics, maybe for the first time, were disappointed. They're like a jilted lover."
Donna Willard, 41, of New Britain, Pa., did not sign a petition for Mr. Perot, but said she would have if someone had asked. Ms. Willard, who works out of her home selling hand-painted light-switch plates and splash boards for sinks, said she would still consider him for President, though with a more critical eye.
"I really try to think of myself as an open-minded person, so I would like to hear what he has to say and have others dispute him and give their reasons why," she said. "But it's not a great thing for a President to say, 'It's not real good. I'm out of here."

HEADLINE: TEACHERS REACH PACT IN DETROIT

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Administrators and teachers reached agreement this afternoon on a two-year contract, signaling the end of a strike that has closed the nation's seventh-largest school system for 26 days. But the contract carries bitter medicine: layoffs and budget cuts are necessary to offset a wage increase, and that is likely to fuel more anger among parents and students.
The contract, which appeared to settle the largest of several teacher strikes across the country this fall, will be voted on next week by the 10,500-member Detroit Federation of Teachers. The teachers are expected to vote Sunday to go back to work, paving the way for them to return Monday and for the city's 168,000 students to start classes on Tuesday. 
 The agreement calls for a raise of 4 percent in the first year and 3 percent in the second year; more textbooks for grades one through five, and a management team to study class reduction over the next year.
As the strike dragged on this month, teachers and school officials came under biting criticism from students and working parents, many of whom scrambled to find alternatives. "I'm mad at the teachers," said Venus McCrary, a single unemployed mother of two daughters in elementary school, whom she took with her on job interviews and to night school classes. "Why couldn't they take care of this in the summer?"
 
Grim Relations All Over
 Experts say the Detroit strike is indicative of the grim relations between teachers and school boards in many places. While the number of teacher strikes this fall is lower than in past years, the number of teachers working without contracts is higher.
School boards have been taking a harder line with teachers, partly because of economic constraints and partly because the public is demanding that school officials hold teachers to higher standards. Both undercurrents have been played out in Detroit.
If approved as written, the contract will require the school district to make cuts in its $1 billion budget to offset the pay increases. It is likely to force the layoffs of up to 250 members of the teachers' union, which also includes nonteaching personnel.
"We always said a contract with a more than 2 percent pay increase would require cuts," said Deborah M. McGriff, the Superintendent of Schools. "People shouldn't be surprised."
The teachers had wanted a 6 percent increase, while the 11-member Board of Education proposed 2 percent. Detroit teachers earn an average of $42,000 a year, as against $36,650 for teachers in other large urban districts. The United States average is $33,015.
The union also demanded that classes be reduced by an average of one student every year for the next decade, from the current averages of 34 in the lower grades and 35 in grades 5 through 12. That would involve hiring 90 to 115 new teachers a year, the union said, but administrators said the proposal would be too expensive. The parties compromised with an agreement to study the issue.
Ms. McGriff said a committee would be appointed to study where to make budget cuts. This is not likely to please parents or students already dismayed by the disruptions caused by the monthlong strike.
"Teachers are messing up our last year," said Yevrah Billingsley, 16 years old, a senior at Finney High School, adding that "I don't know where to go" to take the college entrance exams and find college financial aid information.
 
Lessons by Phone
 During part of the strike, the school system agreed to open six schools throughout the district. The schools, staffed by volunteers and retired teachers, served 600 to 700 students, according to the district. For its part, the teachers' union initiated a "Learning Line," on which students could dial a phone number to hear an abbreviated lesson. A lesson on Friday, for example, was about autumn and why leaves turn colors.
But most students and parents found themselves with few options. "I have been trying to think of things for my kids to do," said Ms. McCrary. She said she was occupying her daughters, 8-year-old Yolanda and 6-year-old Deandrea, with arts and crafts activities, but worried that Yolanda would fall behind in classes.
"The strike," she said with a sigh, "has been too much on parents."
Yolanda added: "I wish I was in school. I'm ready to go."
Some parents even tried to enroll their children illegally in suburban districts by lying about their addresses. Dr. Ken Siver, a spokesman for the nearby Southfield Public Schools, said 10 to 20 students were trying to enroll each week.
"Some had an angle," said Dr. Siver: they would tell school officials they had just moved into the district and didn't yet have documentation of their residence. "But some were honest about what they were doing," he went on, "and we had to turn them away."
