HEADLINE: Republicans May Be Losing Hold On Suburbs in New York Region

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 24

 BODY:
For more than 20 years and through five Presidential elections, national Republican candidates have cinched up New York City's suburbs in New Jersey and Connecticut as securely as any state in the South or the West -- a sort of miniature electoral lock in the heart of the supposedly liberal Northeast.
In places like this community in southern Fairfield County, Connecticut, and in the affluent commuter suburbs in Bergen and parts of other northern New Jersey counties, Republican voters provided the margin of victory, and the financial contributions that helped to cancel out large areas in the two states where Democrats still did well. 
 But in 1992, political experts and members of both parties say, the Republican grip in the region surrounding the nation's largest city has been loosened, mainly by a recession that has battered the white-collar suburbs as never before. As a result, President Bush could find himself in trouble in two states that have been in the Republican column since the election of Richard M. Nixon.
It is not, the experts say, that Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic challenger, could actually expect to win in places like Darien, where even Franklin D. Roosevelt at the height of his popularity lost badly, but rather that Mr. Bush simply might not do quite as well as he did in 1988 in the places where he must do very well.
Although the Electoral College vote in Connecticut and New Jersey -- 23 -- is a small slice of the 270 needed to win, the battle for the suburbs surrounding New York City is likely to be reflected in similar places throughout the country -- from the suburbs of Chicago to the sprawling counties outside Atlanta. In regions like these, voters for the last two decades formed a major part of the coalition that Republicans forged to tap middle-class resentment against the programs of President Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society.
Ross Perot in 1992 has been able to tap resentment toward the Bush Administration's handling of the recession and the Federal budget deficit, and when he dropped out, Mr. Clinton appeared to benefit as the remaining challenger. The signs by Mr. Perot that he might re-enter the Presidential race could complicate matters for both parties.
Driven by these new realities, Mr. Bush has been to New Jersey three times just since the Republican Convention, and campaign officials promise at least three or four more campaign trips there before Election Day. Mr. Clinton hit the suburbs twice this week alone. He chose New Jersey for a major speech on health care on Thursday and Hartford for an address on economics on Friday.
"Bush will win here -- the relevant question is how big he'll win," said State Representative Reginald L. Jones, a Republican who represents Darien in the Connecticut General Assembly. "A loss of support for Bush in the more affluent suburbs of Fairfield County could be enough to give Governor Clinton our eight electoral votes."
All across the region, local Republican leaders speak in similar tones.
"To deliver New Jersey, Bush has to deliver Bergen County -- and he will," said John A. Schepisi, the county's Republican Party chairman, who conceded that some voters had been lost. Noting that Mr. Bush had visited the county during the summer, he said, "One more visit by Bush, which I am anticipating, will solidify Bergen County as a Republican bloc vote for the President. I have personally written to the President advising him that it is necessary."
People in both parties say Mr. Clinton has a commanding lead in New York State, while public-opinion polls show closer margins elsewhere in the region. A poll released this week by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University showed Mr. Clinton with a 13 percent lead in New Jersey. The University of Connecticut's latest poll, earlier this month, showed the race as essentially a dead heat in this state.
 
A Different World
 What has happened across this region since 1988 is that the Republican prosperity is simply gone -- erased by a recession that has swept away more than 140,000 white-collar service-producing jobs in New Jersey alone, with three-quarters of those losses concentrated in the northern part of the state, according to state and Federal figures.
Also cutting into Mr. Bush's support is the defection of Republicans who are mostly moderate on social issues. They have deserted the President following recent Supreme Court decisions supporting state laws that restricted access to abortions and in response to what they felt was a strident emphasis on narrowly defined family values at the party's convention.
And party identifications have continued to weaken as well, or have been turned upside down entirely. Here in Darien, for example, the race for the state legislature is between two Republicans: one candidate, Sally Bolster, has repudiated Mr. Bush and is running on the Democratic line and as the endorsed representative of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker's new third party, called A Connecticut Party. The other candidate is Mr. Jones, who supports the President.
But political scientists say that a deeper and sometimes hidden aspect of the suburban collective psyche has not come into play. In 1988, the Republicans portrayed the Democratic candidate, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, as a candidate whose natural constituencies were in the very urban centers that many in the suburbs have moved to get away from, according to Cliff Zukin, a professor of political science at Rutgers University.
That deep -- and in some cases racially influenced -- fear that some suburbanites feel about New York City as a symbol of blight and liberal programs run amok provided a wealth of Republican votes.
This year, in campaigning in New Jersey and around the country, Professor Zukin said, Mr. Clinton has avoided being pinned down as "urban" by using a few set phrases near the top of most of his speeches -- that he is against handouts and wants to foster self-sufficiency.
Yet there clearly have been some fundamental changes in the New York City region since the last Presidential cycle that go beyond perception. Since February 1989, about 10 percent of all the jobs in Nassau and Suffolk Counties in New York simply disappeared, according to figures from the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. New Jersey lost 319,000 jobs; Connecticut lost more than 180,000 jobs as banks and insurance companies and real-estate companies contracted or collapsed. While the jobs are gone, many of the people who held them remain, and remain angry at the Administration.
Until last year, for instance, here in Darien, Tami Green and her husband, Bob, always disagreed over politics. She's a Democrat, he's a Republican. Then he lost his job as a vice president at Equitable Life Assurance Society in Manhattan. After a year he has still not found a new job. He's voting for Mr. Clinton.
"It's a whole new world," said Ms. Bolster, the Republican running here as a Democrat. "White-collar unemployment is a phenomenon this country has never experienced before."
But the race is clearly by no means over. To the extent that the Bush campaign can convince Republicans who remain faithful here and in New Jersey that the gap can be closed with Mr. Clinton, local politicians say, Bush supporters will be inspired to turn out in larger numbers.
The administration has also recently announced several long-delayed major military contracts and development plans that would benefit communities or companies in the two states. Earlier this week, Mr. Bush suggested turning Fort Dix in central New Jersey -- which at one point was scheduled for closing -- into a training camp for United Nations peacekeeping forces. In Connecticut, Pratt & Whitney, the jet-engine maker, got a $740 million contract for jet engines, and Sikorsky Aircraft, a helicopter maker near Bridgeport, was told to begin negotiating for a sale of helicopters to Turkey.
And political experts also generally agree that since Mr. Clinton got the largest share of new support when Ross Perot dropped out of the race during the summer, he would conversely be expected to lose more than Mr. Bush would of the people who might go back to Mr. Perot, who will be on the ballot in both states.
"If he enters the race -- Zoom! I'm getting involved again and supporting him," said Jim Maser, a resident of Milford, Conn., who said he likes Mr. Perot "because he's a strong man, and he's got new ideas."
But Mr. Maser's comments, offered at an interview at Olympic Donuts, drew an immediate response from a friend across the table, Burt Monroe. "I just couldn't vote for Perot after he dropped out. So I'll have to go with Clinton," Mr. Monroe said. "The economy is killing the people around here -- we need someone new."

HEADLINE: Small Airports: Convenience and Limits

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW WINDSOR, N.Y.

 BODY:
Joseph and Molly Malak were tired of driving from Cleveland to visit their son in Hyde Park. But they hate to fly into La Guardia or Newark International, which they say are "too hectic and too congested." So on a recent trip they flew here to Stewart International Airport, the New York metropolitan region's newest commercial airport and one of a half-dozen suburban and exurban airports attracting passengers from Kennedy International, La Guardia and Newark International Airports.
While the New York region's three major airports have reached the saturation point, with a combined total of nearly 70 million passengers and a million flights a year, midsized "reliever airports," like Stewart, Long Island-MacArthur in Islip, L.I., and Westchester County in White Plains, continue to grow. And smaller airports like Atlantic City's and Bridgeport's are expanding also. 
 With the smaller airports offering daily flights to most East Coast cities and hub airports for virtually all major airlines, suburbanites are discovering that -- instead of two hours in traffic, $15 a day for parking and interminable runway delays -- they can fly without ever going to New York City or Newark.
The smaller airports offer convenient location but limited commercial service compared to the bigger airports. The smaller airports usually are served by a few smaller jets like 737's, and most of the commercial flights are on turboprops seating about 30 to 50 passengers. Most of the flights at these airports still involve corporate and private planes.
 
'Lot More Civilized'
 "In the past, I'd always fly out of Kennedy, but it would take two hours just to get there," said Lisa Savino, of Brewster, N.Y., who flew to California from Stewart on a United Airlines flight. "This is half an hour from where I live and it's a lot more civilized."
Mariette Reed, who has used smaller airports like Mercer County near her home in Princeton, N.J., said: "It's lovely. Everyone is pleasant and it's amazing to be able to walk comfortably from long-term parking to the terminal."
The rate of growth at the smaller airports is evident in such incongruous scenes as 737's sidling up to the Quonset hut-style terminal at Westchester County Airport, whose tiny waiting area is a solid mass of people during the morning and evening rush.
The increase in use has been particularly striking at MacArthur, where 1.2 million passengers departed last year, up from 257,500 in 1982, said Lee Rosche, the airport's assistant manager. Two years ago, two new concourses were added and jet bridges were introduced, allowing passengers to board without walking across the tarmac, signaled the airport's coming of age.
Among the airlines serving MacArthur are American and USAir, as well as regional commuter carriers owned by major airlines like Delta's Business Express, United Express, Northwest Airlink and Continental Express. A new carrier, Carnival Airlines, is to begin flights to Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach, Fla., in December.
The boom is, in part, a ripple effect of airline deregulation in 1978, which led to a doubling of passenger travel in the early 1980's, clogging most major airports. But it is also a function of population growth and the changing character of suburban and exurban areas like Suffolk County.
"Suffolk's growth has been phenomenal in the last decade, but like much of Long Island, it's no longer a bedroom community for New York," Mr. Rosche said. This is reflected in the airport's many business travelers, who use it to fly to places like Chicago, Washington, Boston and Raleigh-Durham.
Stewart has had even more striking growth since the former Air Force base opened for commercial use in 1990. Starting with 12 daily flights, the airport's service has expanded to 80 daily flights, which may push its total passenger count to nearly 1 million this year, said Judy Eurich, an airport spokeswoman. A sleek new terminal, which has seven airline counters and car-rental desks, is to be supplemented by a $6 million terminal, with construction to begin next spring.
At Atlantic City International Airport, the number of passengers has tripled, to 740,000, in the last six years. And United Express and TWA Express began flights to Washington and New York this summer. With a $2.5 million refurbishing completed in 1989 and plans under way to expand the terminal and to build a parking garage, the airport has begun to attract more than just gamblers.
"As service has increased, we see more local people from South Jersey who might have gone to Newark or Philadelphia before," said Kevin Willis, the airport's manager. The lure, he added, is not only free parking but also flights by USAir -- which began jet service at Atlantic City in 1988 -- and United to their hubs, which have made it easy for passengers to fly to distant destinations.
And Sikorsky Memorial Airport in Bridgeport has had more traffic, as Business Express, USAir and Continental Express offer 27 daily flights to places like Washington, Philadelphia, Boston and Newark.
But, while deregulation, demographics and the appeal of convenience and civility have led to growth, that growth has led to complaints of noise from people who live near those once-sleepy airfields. This has been especially true of Westchester County Airport, where the number of annual passengers increased to 750,000 last year from 400,000 in 1985.
"In the 1980's, the surrounding community's awareness of the noise increased considerably," said Roland Reisley, of Pleasantville, N.Y. "Now, if you open your doors on a slightly overcast Friday evening when they fly low, you hear them thundering past, one after the other."
Richard Aarons, the editor in chief of Business & Commercial Aviation magazine, expressed the fundamental ambivalence of those who are both airport neighbors and potential users: "People don't like airports in their backyard any more than they like landfills. Yet, everyone wants to live within 20 minutes of an airport."
Perhaps the greatest frustration is at Danbury Municipal Airport, where $13 million has been spent over the last decade to upgrade the runways and terminal, and where about 900 private planes take off on Saturdays, but which has no airline service.
"It's a little tiring, hearing the airlines' excuses why they don't come," said Paul Estefan, the airport's administrator. "They say our runways are too short, the weather conditions aren't good or that they've already published their new schedules and can't add us."
But if the recession ever ends, even Danbury may be in luck.
"When the economy picks up, there will be a strong demand for these Northeastern airports because the big airports are landlocked and can't expand," said Paul Bollinger, a senior vice president of the Airports Association Council International, a trade association representing some 700 airports. "If there's demand for increased air traffic, airlines will have to look to other facilities."

LENGTH: 1567 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Welcome to the Major Leagues, Bud Selig Presiding

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25

 BODY:
"Your chancellorship, how are you?" an old friend asked Allan H. (Bud) Selig, the slight, bespectacled and blue-blazered fellow standing in bas-relief in front of a big, bright abstract painting in the Milwaukee art museum.
"Hello, Ed," said Selig, with a faint smile. Selig, the owner of the Milwaukee Brewers baseball team, had recently been given a new title in baseball. But "chancellorship" it was not. 
 "Mr. Selig," said another man, another old friend. "I guess I may call you that now."
"You certainly may," said Selig. Then, to a companion at his side: "Oh, the rips a guy's gotta endure."
Selig has been portrayed recently as more ripper than ripped in the wake of the de facto firing of Fay Vincent as commissioner. "Some writers called it a beer-hall putsch," said Selig. "And some said I was the ringleader. It was nothing of the sort. I had talked with Fay for hours and hours about our dissatisfactions. So it was no sudden thing. And I was just one of the group, even though I probably made more phone calls than anyone else."
"Buddy," said a smartly dressed woman named Bonnie, who came by with a tray of hors d'oeuvres in her role as museum volunteer, "are they paying you to be the new commissioner of baseball?"
"I'm not the commissioner," he answered. "I just have an interim position. It's called chairman of the executive council. And no, the question of salary never came up."
"Nice not to need $650,000."
"Is it," someone wondered, "a charitable contribution?"
"Call it whatever you want," said Selig.
These exchanges took place recently in the late afternoon at a viewing of paintings and other art objects that would be auctioned the following day.
In a few hours, he would be in his box for the game against the Angels in County Stadium, rooting knowledgeably and passionately for the team he fought to bring from Seattle to Milwaukee 23 years ago. "Isn't it amazing?" he said. "We're still in the pennant race. No one expected this." He mentioned Phil Garner, his rookie manager. "He's done a great job. A great job. Better than great."
In between such civic and familial duties, Selig must also find time to function as this quasi-chancellor of baseball, this czar of sorts, this chairman, a position his peers elected him to with a unanimous vote after Vincent resigned.
"There is only one powerful owner in baseball, and that's Bud Selig," said Selig's good friend, Jerry Reinsdorf, the owner of the Chicago White Sox. "He's the only one who can get votes out of the other owners. It's because he's such a nice guy, and he works at staying in touch with the rest of us."
Others, like Don Fehr, the executive director of the Major League Players Association, wonders if in fact Reinsdorf is the great power among the owners. "Possibly the puppeteer," Fehr has said.
But without question, Selig has been one of the most industrious of owners, and one of the few whose major income comes from baseball. And he is always on the phone. "I probably talk with every owner at least once a week, and some many times more than that," said Selig.
 
Redefining the Job
 One of the issues they are talking about now is finding a new commissioner, a position, he says, that needs not only to be filled, but must also be redefined. "We should look at it not in terms of 1920, when the commissioner's role was first defined, with Judge Landis," he said, "but in the realities of 1992."
It would seem, however, that a redefinition of "commissioner" would leave out the broad powers that Kenesaw Mountain Landis had, and that some of his successors, like Vincent, at least thought they had. But, in the end, they didn't have it. After all, Vincent had stated just weeks before he was ousted that he would never resign.
"I don't make any unilateral decisions," said Selig. "I operate by consensus. If there is a problem of any sort, I get in touch with the executive council. Immediately! And we go from there. We'd probably take a vote and consensus rules."
One of the first issues to arise in his interim reign was whether to proceed with the realignment of the National League that Vincent announced, and that the Chicago Cubs sued over. Last week, Selig and the other owners rescinded the realignment. "It leaves the next commissioner with a clear path to proceed in any way he wants," said Selig.
It seems to be clear, however, that the owners will not endure a new commissioner stepping on any of their toes. And so what person of substance would want such a job in which, at this point, he would seem more a figurehead than a decision-maker?
"Plenty would," said Selig. "People asked the same question after Bowie Kuhn was told he would not be re-elected, in 1984. You wouldn't believe the stature of the people who applied for the job. And remember, the man who accepted the job, Peter Ueberroth, was golden boy of the day, the hero of the Olympics and on the cover of Time Magazine as their Man of the Year."
In fact," he said, smiling now, "we've already gotten a lot of applicants. One of the first was from a butcher in San Mateo. He had some pretty good ideas, too. But I think we have to go in another direction from him."
"We need a strong commissioner, and we expect to have our man within two to four months," Selig continued. "There's a lot that an imaginative man can do. Look at the tremendous job David Stern has done with the N.B.A. We've got to improve our game to make it more appealing. Sure, attendance records have been broken regularly in the last decade or so. But network television ratings of games is down, and more than half the teams are losing money. And the major problem is the huge salaries the players are getting."
The economic situation of the teams is now being studied by a committee combining the owners and the players' union, and Selig is co-chairman of it. The union is more than skeptical about the number of teams losing money. Fehr sees Selig as a "traditionalist" who "would like baseball to be like it was in the 1950's."
"His view is the players are doing better than they should be doing," Fehr said.
One of the major considerations must be a restructuring of compensation for teams that lose free agents, Selig said. According to him, teams that are suffering financially, particularly those in the smaller markets, need relief. These teams include the Brewers, whose revenue from local television broadcasts is among the lowest in baseball.
Fehr contends, however, that the owners should help themselves and not ask the players for aid. And television revenue-sharing for local markets, which exists for the teams in the National Football League, for instance, is unknown in major league baseball.
Selig's argument to this is both circular and "traditional." He admits that "the owners have been somewhat responsible for the high salaries paid" -- and after all, who pays those salaries? But he contends that if things continue at this pace, in which the average major league salary has risen to more than $1 million, the small-market teams might be driven out of the game.
"We need a strong commissioner to lead, like Bart," said Selig. While A. Bartlett Giamatti served only nine months as commissioner before he died, he maintained an impressive and extraordinarily eloquent stature. Selig said he considered Giamatti one of his best friends. "Bart said, 'My job is to lead by suasion.' He understood that there were 26 owners with sometimes 26 different agendas. It was up to the commissioner to bring us together."
The feeling left by Selig was that Vincent was unable to do this; that Vincent's heart was in the right place, but his politicking abilities were not; that he appeared to believe he was the Judge Landis of the 1990's. "That just doesn't go anymore," said Selig.
Selig mentions that if negotiations with the union fail then a "work stoppage" or "lockout" is possible.
Selig, who has lived his whole life in Milwaukee, headed a group that purchased the Brewers for $10.8 million in 1970. He is only 58, but among baseball's owners only the Dodgers' O'Malley family, Gene Autry of the Angels and Ewing Kauffman of the Royals have owned teams longer. The Brewers, he concedes, now have an estimated value of $105 million. A new, $140 million stadium that will soon be constructed could add further value to the ball club.
 
Try the Soup
 Meanwhile, the search for a new commissioner continues. Selig is part of the search committee. He discussed this in a wooden booth in Jake's Deli on 17th Street on Milwaukee's North Side, in the heart of the inner city. Selig is part owner of the small restaurant, and proud of it, recommending especially its chicken-noodle soup and lean corned-beef sandwiches.
He himself ordered a hot dog, on which he spread ketchup. "I know you're supposed to put mustard on a hot dog," said Selig, "but ketchup is my weakness. You see, I'm not that much of a traditionalist."
As for a new commissioner, he noted that such names as former Secretary of State James Baker and the Democratic National Committee chairman, Ron Brown, had been mentioned.
What about Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf?
"No," he said, "I haven't heard his name."
Or Arnold Schwarzenegger?
"Not his either," said Selig, laughing. "But I have no doubt that we'll find someone excellent."
Then Bud Selig, His Chancellorship, bit seriously into his ketchup-laden hot dog.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We need a strong commissioner to lead, like Bart," said Bud Selig, Brewers owner and chairman of owners' executive council. (Joe Piccioto for The New York Times)

By the same logic, each of us could give a boost to the gross domestic product by going out and smashing up the family car. But will someone assure us that what is good for the G.D.P. is good for America?

HEADLINE: The Success of Lean Auto Manufacturing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Andrew Pollack's article "A Lower Gear For Japan's Auto Makers" (Aug. 30) contains many insights into the current gloomy state of affairs in the Japanese automobile industry. Yet, although Mr. Pollack does not say so explicitly, the article leaves the impression that a key reason for the recent decline is the failure of the Toyota production system. I believe the opposite is the case.
In fact the Toyota production system has done exactly what it is supposed to do -- namely, give companies competitive advantage in markets where success depends on high quality, low cost and rapid introduction of new products. 
 If anything, the system has worked too well. Domestically, it has forced other Japanese auto manufacturers to adopt similar methods. Internationally, because of the system's demonstrated effectiveness, American and European auto manufacturers have begun to implement it, and the gaps in quality and cost are closing. Some countries have resorted to negotiating away or legislating away the system's advantages, by forcing quotas or local content rules (which require the manufacturer to deal with unfamiliar suppliers) onto Japanese auto makers. One might say that the Toyota production system, rather than being a failure, is actually a victim of its own success.
The Japanese economy is in a downturn that fundamentally has nothing to do with the auto industry. If American auto manufacturers were to abandon lean manufacturing in the belief that the system has outlived its usefulness, they would be committing a serious error that would undermine the considerable gains they have made in quality, cost and manufacturing flexibility.
 
EDWARD J. HAY
Lexington, Mass., Sept. 3
 
Mr. Hay is a senior vice president at Rath & Strong Inc. and is the author of "The Just-in-Time Breakthrough: Implementing The New Manufacturing Basics."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGES;
Another Step Forward for Yale's Sharkey

 BODY:
CATHERINE SHARKEY had one of those ho-hum Yale careers, grinding out a 3.9 grade-point average while majoring in economics, serving four years as starting lacrosse goalkeeper, tutoring high school students and doing volunteer work at the New Haven Juvenile Detention Center before graduating summa cum laude and becoming a Rhodes Scholar. Now she has a new distraction.
She is one of 10 finalists for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's second annual Woman of the Year Award. Sponsored by Champion, the award, which will be announced in November, gives equal weight to academic achievement, athletic accomplishment, community service and leadership. 
 Other finalists include JENNIFER COBB of Cornell (neurobiology, track and field); LISA KAY AREL of M.I.T. (biology, gymnastics); JULIA BURDICK of Washington University in St. Louis (religion, track and field); CATHERINE BYRNE of Tennessee (kinesiology, swimming), and LORI DETWEILER of Arizona (occupational safety/health, diving). The others are JANET LOUISE KRAUSE of Nebraska (biology, volleyball); BARB PRANGER of Kansas (exercise science, swimming); NICOLE SCHERR of South Dakota State (English, track and field) and PENNY TOLLEFSON of Hamline in St. Paul (psychology, swimming).

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 906 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER

 BODY:
FREEDOM. Volume One: Freedom in the Making of Western Culture, by Orlando Patterson. (Basic Books, $15.) This analysis of freedom as a peculiarly Western ideal won the 1991 National Book Award for nonfiction. It is an irony of history, Orlando Patterson contends, that the institution of slavery in ancient societies was a prerequisite for the growing valuation of personal liberty. "It is a tribute to Mr. Patterson that as one reads his interesting book one wants to ask and try to answer . . . difficult and even painful questions," Mary Lefkowitz said here last year.
THE RISE OF LIFE ON EARTH, by Joyce Carol Oates. (New Directions, $8.95.) In this brief novel, Joyce Carol Oates explores the mind of Kathleen Hennessy, a severely abused child who becomes, seemingly ineluctably, an adult capable of murder. "Like Bach with his musical sense, Joyce Carol Oates is practiced with her narrative tools; she writes scenes of unrivaled vigor and conviction that precisely express her vision," our reviewer, Jane Smiley, said last year. Also available in paperback is HEAT: And Other Stories (William Abrahams/Plume, $12), which focuses on typical Oates themes of familial and social violence. The most successful stories are those in which the menace is understated, the injury purely emotional, Wendy Lesser said here last year: "We get normality in all its terrifying nakedness." And Ontario Review Press has brought back into print Ms. Oates's 1971 novel, WONDERLAND ($12.95), the story of a man whose entire family was killed during his childhood in a murder-suicide. It includes the revised ending the author wrote for the book's first paperback edition, as well as a new afterword. It is "in effect, if not intention, an old-fashioned horror story," said our reviewer, Geoffrey Wolff. 
 THE GOOD SOCIETY, by Robert N. Bellah, Richard Madsen, William M. Sullivan, Ann Swidler and Steven M. Tipton. (Vintage, $13.) This sequel to "Habits of the Heart: Individualism and Commitment in American Life" stresses that democracy begins at home. By emphasizing responsibility in private life, the authors argue, Americans can improve public institutions. "The moral vision of the authors is commendable, their motives noble, their analysis subtle," Cornel West said here last year.
TALES OF THE MASTER RACE, by Marcie Hershman. (Harper Perennial, $10.) Marcie Hershman's characters, citizens of a fictional German town during World War II, aid the Nazi cause not through direct participation but through naivete and neglect. Last year The New York Times's Michiko Kakutani called this first novel "a searing portrait of the consequences of moral laziness and self-absorption."
J. EDGAR HOOVER: The Man and the Secrets, by Curt Gentry. (Plume, $15.) To Hoover, the director of the F.B.I. for almost 50 years, information was power; as this thick biography demonstrates, he collected it whether or not he knew it to be true. "Mr. Gentry shrewdly compares him to the 'embezzling bank clerk' who could never take a vacation because he feared his crimes would be discovered while he was away," David M. Oshinsky said in The Book Review last year.
IN MY FATHER'S HOUSE, by Ernest J. Gaines. (Vintage Contemporaries, $10.) This 1978 novel by the author of "A Gathering of Old Men" and "The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman" concerns a black clergyman in rural Louisiana who is suddenly confronted with the legacy of his profligate past. "It is the force of Mr. Gaines's character and intelligence, operating through [his] deceptively quiet style, that makes his fiction compelling," Larry McMurtry said here.
CHILDHOOD'S FUTURE, by Richard Louv. (Anchor/ Doubleday, $11.) The author, a newspaper columnist, points out that ours is the only industrialized Western nation in which work and family are viewed as completely separate. He encourages parental leave policies and flexible work schedules to help Americans sustain their emotional as well as economic lives. "His book is useful because it reminds us that childhood's present does not have to be childhood's future," our reviewer, Lisbeth B. Schorr, said last year.
THE DEADLIEST OPTION, by Annette Meyers. (Bantam, $4.99.) This murder mystery gives a whole new meaning to making a killing in the stock market. The heroines, Xenia Smith and Leslie Wetzon, are, like the author, Wall Street executive placement consultants. "Ms. Meyers clearly knows whereof she rips to shreds," Marilyn Stasio said here last year.
THE HAPPIEST MAN ALIVE: A Biography of Henry Miller, by Mary V. Dearborn. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $13.) One man's genius is another man's pornographer, and few embodied that contradiction more readily than Henry Miller. This biography provides a detailed overview of the influences that made him the man and the writer he was. "Ms. Dearborn's perspective on Miller's childhood is especially rich," Perry Meisel said in The Book Review last year, "since it is a feminist and mildly psychoanalytic one."
THE MIND OF THE TRAVELER: From Gilgamesh to Global Tourism, by Eric J. Leed. (Basic Books, $15.) Eric J. Leed delves into the philosophical and spiritual aspects of travel, beginning with what may have been the first journey -- Adam and Eve's expulsion from Eden -- and continuing through conquests and crusades to contemporary tours. Last year our reviewer, Helen Bevington, called his book "a historian's account, wonderfully rich in material."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
The Facts Are Elusive in the Jobs Debate

SERIES: Issues -- First article of a series: Creating Jobs

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The goal of his economic policies, George Bush has said for years, is "jobs, jobs, jobs."
Yet fewer new jobs have been created in his Presidency than in any other Presidential term in the last half century. Actually, fewer people are on private payrolls today than when Mr. Bush took office. 
 Those facts give Gov. Bill Clinton a leg up in this year's campaign for the Presidency, where, both candidates say, job creation is the top issue. But neither Mr. Clinton nor Mr. Bush is sticking to the facts. Both use questionable statistics to bolster their positions.
 
Tossing Out Numbers
 Mr. Bush says Congress is at fault for the poor jobs record in his Administration. Accepting the Republican Presidential nomination in Houston last month, he said that if lawmakers had approved the tax cuts and other economic measures he proposed in January 500,000 more Americans would now be at work.
That number was apparently derived from a misreading of his own budget.
So much for the past. Now, the Bush campaign is arguing that Mr. Clinton's proposed policies would cost the country 2.6 million jobs. Outside experts say that assertion is probably nonsense and certainly unprovable.
Mr. Clinton's declarations on job creation are in the same vein. The President's plans on medical care, Mr. Clinton says, would result in the loss of nearly two million jobs. That number comes from a college professor in North Carolina who concedes it is a "guesstimate" based on the shaky assumption that Mr. Clinton would control the rising cost of health care and Mr. Bush would not.
Mr. Clinton says his own policies would create eight million jobs in the next four years, a sum that sounds ambitious but that actually would barely keep pace with the expected growth in the number of people seeking work. A Clinton staff assistant said the figure was arrived at more or less arbitrarily.
 
Same Words, Different Ways
 Impartial economists suggest that voters simply ignore the candidates' specific claims and charges about job creation and job losses.
Janet L. Norwood, the Federal Commissioner of Labor Statistics from 1979, in the Carter Administration, until last year and as politically neutral an expert as exists on such matters, put it this way: "In a campaign, there are a lot of numbers that come out about jobs, but I don't think there's any way really to determine how many jobs would be created or lost by different policies."
Still, both Presidential candidates say job creation is the foremost issue in the campaign, and they say so in strikingly similar words.
"Creating jobs is the No. 1 issue," Mr. Bush declared when he kicked off his campaign in Gulfport, Miss., the day after the Republican National Convention ended last month.
Not to be outdone, Mr. Clinton said in a television interview over Labor Day weekend that "the No. 1 thing" he would do as President would be to provide "a jobs program."
The candidates differ significantly in their approaches to job creation. Mr. Bush believes the best way is to give tax breaks to businesses and investors. Mr. Clinton would have the Government spend billions of dollars more on public works like highways, bridges, railroads and communications systems.
Both candidates talk at length about training workers. Mr. Bush would give people grants of up to $3,000 each to help them pay for job training. Mr. Clinton would require companies to spend 1.5 percent of their payrolls on worker training or pay a comparable amount into a Government fund that would finance training.
 
Economy's Crucial Role
 Economists say Government spending probably creates marginally more jobs than tax cuts, since some of the money that people and companies get from tax reductions would be saved, not spent. On the other hand, tax cuts probably have a more immediate impact on the economy than spending on public works because those projects require time for design and planning.
In the end, the overriding factor in job creation is how well the economy does. With times as slack as they are now, each percentage point of annual growth in economic output should create about a million new jobs, said Laurence H. Meyer, a economist who runs a St. Louis forecasting concern that bears his name. As the economy improves, Mr. Meyer said, the amount of growth needed to generate a million jobs will increase somewhat.
Both candidates have offered plans for improving the economy, but deciding who has the better plan is a matter of politics and ideology, not fact. Those who believe that the Government should basically keep its hands off the economy and let the free market run its course favor Mr. Bush's plan. Those who think that the Government should play a lead role in driving the economy favor Mr. Clinton's approach.
 
Gaps in Explanation
 But two other factors that bear on job creation have not been fully addressed by either candidate.
The first is the budget deficit, a topic that neither man seems eager to discuss. To the extent that Mr. Bush's proposed tax cuts are offset by lower Government spending and to the degree that Mr. Clinton's increased spending on public works is offset by higher taxes or lower spending elsewhere, the effect of the next President's policies on new jobs will be reduced. On the other hand, if he simply allows the deficit to grow, private investment will presumably be lower and interest rates higher, and that, too, would hurt the job market.
The second factor is mushrooming medical costs. Increasingly, companies facing the high cost of medical insurance are paying existing employees overtime rather than hiring new workers. But neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Clinton has presented a fully developed plan to keep medical costs down.
Mr. Bush is at a disadvantage in the debate over jobs because his Administration's record on the matter has been so poor. He promised in the 1988 campaign to create 30 million jobs in eight years, but so far, as Mr. Clinton keeps pointing out, the President is 29 million jobs short. According to the latest data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, 117,737,000 people were at work nationwide last month, as against 116,708,000 when Mr. Bush became President in January 1989.
The increase of less than 1 percent is by far the worst record in any Presidential term since World War II. By contrast, the number of jobs in the country increased by 11.2 percent in Jimmy Carter's Administration, by 6.3 percent in Ronald Reagan's first term and by 9.8 percent in Mr. Reagan's second term.
The number of nongovernment jobs has actually fallen by 28,000 during the Bush Presidency.
 
Impact of Military Budget
 At the Republican convention, Mr. Bush said Congress was partly to blame. "On Jan. 28," he declared, "I put before Congress a plan to create jobs. And if it had been passed back then, 500,000 more Americans would be at work right now."
Asked this week how the President had arrived at that figure, a campaign staff member referred to a passage on page 1-37 in the budget that Mr. Bush submitted last January. The passage states that Mr. Bush's proposals "should create an additional half a million jobs during the next four years," not in seven months.
The Bush campaign's charge that Mr. Clinton's proposals would cost the country 2.6 million jobs is based in large part on the calculation that the military budget cuts proposed by Mr. Clinton would result in a loss of one million jobs. That may be the case, but it is hardly more jobs than Mr. Bush's own plans for the Pentagon would cost.
The Defense Budget Project, a private organization whose analyses of the military budget are regarded as authoritative, has calculated that Mr. Bush's plans for cutting military spending by $1.42 trillion over the next five years would result in a loss of about 900,000 military and civilian jobs over the period and that Mr. Clinton's cuts of about $60 billion more than that would mean a loss of perhaps an additional 100,000 to 150,000 jobs.
Mr. Clinton promises that all the money saved from military cuts would be spent on job-producing public programs, a promise that may not square with his pledge to hold down the budget deficit. Mr. Bush says only that he would promote retraining for displaced workers from military industries.
The Bush campaign also argues that 1.6 million jobs would be lost under Mr. Clinton's proposals because of the burdens imposed on business by medical insurance and training requirements, automobile mileage standards and corporate tax increases. The figures were compiled by the Republican staffs of the Senate Budget Committee and the Congressional Joint Economic Committee.
The Democratic staff of the Joint Economic Committee published a rejoinder attributing the Republican calculations to fabrications and erroneous statistics that were based on biased computer models and that ignored relevant academic research.
 
The Art of Estimating
 Mr. Clinton maintains that Mr. Bush's plan to limit spending on Medicare and Medicaid would cost 1.8 million jobs, a figure that is just as unprovable as Mr. Bush's claims about the Clinton agenda. The source of the figure, Kenneth E. Thorpe, an associate professor of public health at the University of North Carolina, said in an interview that his estimate was based on his view that Mr. Clinton would save businesses money by keeping the rise in medical costs under control and that Mr. Bush would not.
Mr. Clinton's promise to create eight million jobs during the next four years would mean that the economy was not performing particularly well. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the number of people seeking work is expected to rise naturally by about 7.5 million people during that period, meaning that by his own estimate Mr. Clinton would hardly put a dent in the unemployment rate.
Many economists are simply put off by the numbers that the candidates are bandying about. Lawrence Chimerine, a senior economist at DRI-McGraw Hill, an economic consulting concern in Lexington, Mass., said, "This whole process of trying to quantify things is designed to make people think there's more precision and credibility than there is."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 2, 1992, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about the Presidential candidates' stands on job creation misstated their plans for military spending. President Bush proposes spending a total of $1.42 trillion on the military during the next five years. Gov. Bill Clinton favors spending about $60 billion less than Mr. Bush has proposed over that period.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "CANDIDATES ON THE ISSUES: Two Points of View On Creating New Jobs"
 
The current unemployment rate is the highest in eight years. Hundreds of thousands of Americans will lose their jobs in the next four years as the military and related industries shrink because of the end of the cold war. Countless other workers in manufacturing will find themselves out of work as factories move overseas or become more mechanized. Many of those who will be looking for work will need training for the modern workplace. President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton agree that creating new jobs is one of the most important issues in the Presidential campaign and that the best way to guarantee new jobs is to strengthen the economy. What they disagree on is how to do it.
 
THE RECORDS
 
During the Bush Presidency, the number of jobs in the United States has grown by less than 1 percent, the lowest rate of growth in any Presidential term since World War II. The number of nongovernment jobs has fallen by 28,000. As of last month, the unemployment rate had risen to 7.6 percent from 5.6 percent the month Mr. Bush took office.
 
Overall employment in Mr. Clinton's home state has increased. From January 1989 to July 1992, the last month for which statistics are available, the number of jobs in Arkansas grew by 11.8 percent. The unemployment rate fell during that period to 7.1 percent from 7.6 percent.
 
THE PHILOSOPHIES
 
Mr. Bush holds that the best way to create new jobs is to give tax breaks across the board to home buyers, businesses and investors.
 
Mr. Clinton argues that the Government should become actively involved in job creation by financing public works projects and giving specific tax breaks for the kind of investments that are most likely to result in new jobs.
 
TRAINING
 
Mr. Bush would allocate an additional $10 billion over five years for skill training, including grants to individuals of up to $3,000 to help defray the cost of training and counseling and job referral assistance. All workers would be eligible, but emphasis would be placed on helping workers who lost jobs because of trade agreements and lower military spending.
 
Mr. Clinton would require employers to spend 1.5 percent of their payrolls on training, or they would have to pay a comparable amount into a Government fund that would finance job training. Apprenticeship programs would be developed in which high school students and recent graduates could learn skills.
 
SCORECARD
 
Mr. Bush is at a serious disadvantage on this issue because his record on job creation has been so poor. He maintains that if Congress had approved all his economic proposals this year, 500,000 more Americans would be at work, and he says the Clinton policies would cost 2.6 million jobs. Those claims are at best unprovable.
 
Mr. Clinton says his proposals will create eight million new jobs over the next four years, but that is basically a back-of-the-envelope calculation that would reflect job growth if the economy improves modestly. He contends that the Bush health-care plan would result in the loss of 1.8 million jobs, but the claim cannot be documented.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
A New Landscape for Global Bonds

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
THE crisis in European currency markets has taken a harsh toll on mutual fund investors whose funds own foreign bonds and notes. These funds lost more than 2 percent of their value on average in two weeks that ended last Thursday, according to Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J.
This devaluation of mutual fund shares caught many investors by surprise, especially those in short-term global income funds. But obstacles in creating monetary union in Europe may actually be good news for holders of long-term global bonds who are able to ride out short-run price moves. 
 Still, investors in the United States should not underestimate the chaos roiling Europe. "We've seen a breakdown of the European monetary system equal to the 1987 stock market crash in the United States," said David R. Kenerson Jr., who manages the Van Eck World Income Fund in Manhattan.
The pandemonium in European financial markets has helped to discredit the idea that short-term global income funds are suitable substitutes for money market funds. The short-term global funds, which were introduced a few years ago and already hold more than $22.5 billion, aim for share price stability using a complicated hedging technique that relies heavily on the premise that European currencies will fluctuate within a narrow range. That premise no longer holds.
But for investors holding shares in short-term global funds, "there's no reason to sell if you understand that some currency risk means moderate risk to principal," said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc., a mutual fund research group in Chicago. Investors who found the recent turbulence too much should move their cash back into domestic money funds, he said.
While some of the world's attention in recent weeks has been focused on drastic moves in foreign-exchange rates, it is interest rates that move bond prices first, noted A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical. And so, he said, investors should be considering the opportunities rates are offering. Many fund managers say a fall is inevitable for European interest rates, which are unusually high, but they disagree on when this will happen. As interest rates fall, bond prices rise, producing capital gains for bondholders.
Most global bond fund investors were hurt in recent weeks as foreign-currency bonds were sold and the proceeds were moved to the relative safety of dollar-based investments. In the week that ended on Sept. 17, the Benham, Franklin and MFS funds declined more than 4 percent each. But looking forward, managers say that European bonds represent the best value of debt securities anywhere in the world.
Fiona Biggs manages the top-ranked Dreyfus Strategic World Investing Fund, a fund with wide latitude to invest in either stocks or bonds. Right now, her bond exposure is greater, and she owns bond futures to gain leverage because "the European economy will be so much worse than people expect." She added, "The European economic cycle is a few years behind the United States' ."
The best reason to buy shares in European bond funds is for diversification that provides a hedge to investments in dollars for times when United States markets are reeling, said Mr. Kenerson at the Van Eck World Income Fund. And the best time to invest is after a crash, he said. He predicts continuing volatility in the short term, but as the volatility subsides, there should be "improvement in bond prices and currency generally."
Indeed, while investors have been expecting rates to decline in Europe, "the currency breakdown has accelerated the natural process," said Steven Ilott, with Rowe Price Fleming in London, which manages the T. Rowe Price global bond funds.
Unlike the Dreyfus fund and several others, the T. Rowe Price International Bond Fund makes limited use of hedging, which protects against currency swings. Hedging limits losses, but it also reduces gains.
European bonds have not yet rallied, and there is a very good chance that interest rates will decline and create capital gains, said Nimrod Fachler, who manages the Paine Webber Global Income Fund. His strategy at this point is to invest in long-term bonds in Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and France -- the countries with the strongest currencies.
Over all, the outlook for investors who already hold European bonds is good, said Steve Bartow, chief investment officer for Putnam's global fixed-income group. Britain cut its interest rates last week, and Italy is expected to do so soon. But public opinion polls indicate that most Germans do not favor giving up the mark in favor of a single European currency, he said, and this sentiment "doesn't get us out of the soup in terms of ongoing volatility."
Investors hoping to profit from Europe's crisis must look at how heavily a fund is invested there. For those who expect European bonds to rise, the more a fund has in Europe, the better its prospects. The high-ranked IDS Global Bond Fund, for example, has relatively little invested in Europe. It normally keeps only 20 percent of its portfolio in Europe and owns even less today, said Ray Goodner, its manager.

LENGTH: 1591 words

HEADLINE: Individualist-Idealist Breaks the Rules

BYLINE: By CAROL STRICKLAND

 BODY:
WHEN civic leaders of Rock Hill, S.C., envisioned an entrance for their new industrial park, they had in mind a redwood sign saying, "Tech Park." What Audrey Flack, the sculptor from East Hampton, gave them were four 22-foot-tall gilded goddesses.
Departing from expectations is hardly new to the 61-year-old Ms. Flack. Her 40-year career is the subject of a retrospective opening on Sept. 29 at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington.
The exhibition and a monograph published by Harry N. Abrams Inc. are entitled "Breaking the Rules." From Ms. Flack's celebrated Photorealist paintings of the 1970's to her sculptured deities of the 80's and now a proposed 10-story high monument in Queens, breaking the rules has been Ms. Flack's major rule. 
 Ms. Flack's work is in the permanent collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Whitney Museum of American Art, Museum of Modern Art and Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.
"In the last 40 years Flack has become one of the best-known contemporary women artists," the administrative director of the National Museum of Women in the Arts, Rebecca P. Abbott, said.
"Audrey Flack is an exciting, varied artist and a fine craftsman," said Elaine Benson, who directs her gallery in Bridgehampton.
Although Ms. Flack's work is popular with the public and collectors, critical opinion is divided. Ms. Flack's New York dealer, Louis K. Meisel, still winces at past reviews. He recalled how John Russell used the phrase "irredeemably hideous" in connection with Ms. Flack's Photorealist paintings in The New York Times in 1983. "Audrey has always been 20 years ahead of the pack," Mr. Meisel said. "Her work has nothing to do with the avant-garde. It's better."
What makes Ms. Flack's work controversial is her tendency to infuse tacky pop imagery, executed in gaudy colors, with religious significance. In her well-known Photorealist paintings she portrayed images ranging from Buddha to Marilyn Monroe, from Buchenwald survivors to strawberry tarts.
She fused Old and New Worlds, using the Photorealist airbrush method to paint over a projected photographic slide. Modern technology aside, her compositions are 17th-century "vanitas" still lifes, complete with symbolic trappings like hourglasses, skulls, ripe fruit and dewy flowers suggesting the brevity of life.
Similarly her statues of pagan goddesses have Classical costumes, but assertive poses and the lithe bodies of Olympic athletes.
 
'It's Postpostmodern'
 "I do go back to the ancients and to Neoclassicism, but my work is very contemporary," Ms. Flack said in an interview. "It's postpostmodern."
Ms. Flack's passionate concern with spiritual and emotional subjects runs counter to the cool theoretical bent of art-world trends. "Critics can't deal with her work because it goes too much against what contemporary art is about," the curator of the retrospective, Thalia Gouma-Peterson, said. "Audrey goes out on a limb and does her own thing. The work is right on the edge, but because of its tremendous power never becomes sentimental or kitschy."
Ms. Flack's sculptures for Rock Hill illustrate her belief that art can heal social ills. Rock Hill (population 42,000) had fallen on hard times before it gambled on the goddesses to change its destiny. A 100-year-old decaying mill town near the North Carolina border with 20 percent unemployment, the town was almost bust after 13 of its 14 textile mills had closed. "We had to rediversify the whole economy," Mayor Elizabeth Rhea said.
To attract international business, Ms. Rhea commissioned Ms. Flack to create "heroic sculpture of the Michelangelo type."
Called "Gateway," the collaboration between Ms. Flack and an architect, Michael A. Gallis, was conceived "not just as a gateway to the city, but to the city's future," Mr. Gallis said.
 
'An Immediate Visualization'
 Although critics demanded that the money be spent on roads and schools, Mr. Gallis, an urban planner, maintained that civic sculpture would prove a better investment. "Public art exerts a powerful effect on the psyche of a city," he said. " 'Gateway' became an immediate visualization that change would happen."
Two years after unveiling the statues, the industrial park is fully occupied by companies from England, France, Switzerland and Germany. The influx brought $150 million in investment and created nearly 2,000 jobs. "The sculptures have absolutely been a drawing card for us, a tremendous boost," Ms. Rhea said.
The art also transformed Rock Hill's image from blue collar to black tie. It went from being considered an esthetic void, lacking even a statue of a Confederate general astride a horse, to the apex of culture in the region. Even booming cities like nearby Charlotte have eyed the statues enviously and are planning their own.
"Thank you for putting those sculptures in Rock Hill," a waitress told Ms. Rhea. "I'll never get to Europe, but I ride by those statues every day. I really feel I've been somewhere special."
"Art is for the people," said Ms. Flack, who hopes her next big project will reinvigorate Queens. The Friends of Queen Catherine have chosen her to design in collaboration with Mr. Gallis a monument to Catherine of Braganza (1638-1705), Princess of Portugal and Queen of England, after whom the borough is named.
Situated on the East River in the Queens West development to be built at Hunters Point, opposite the United Nations, the statue, second in size in New York only to the Statue of Liberty, would "bring business to Queens and give the borough a slice of New York's tourism," said Manuel A. Sousa, president of the friends group, which formed three years ago to build the monument.
Catherine is a symbol of internationalism, said Mr. Sousa, an official of the Portuguese Trade Commission. The monument represents "the ethnic variety in the borough, where 150 different languages and dialects are spoken," he added.
For Janet M. Schneider, head of the friends' art committee, which selected Ms. Flack's design, the monument would promote Queens as "a place with a history attached to significant world events." The monument would cost $2 million, to be raised privately. If the Queens West office and residential complex proceeds on schedule, the monument would be completed by 1995.
For Mr. Gallis, the monument "announces Queens as not just this low flat suburban outer zone, but an important component of New York."
For Ms. Flack the 36-foot-tall bronze sculpture on a 54-foot-high base symbolizes "a new millennium."
"She's a healthy image to give us hope," Ms. Flack said. "No fat frumpy queen." Her design is "an image of movement."
"Her robes are flowing in the breeze," Ms. Flack said. "She's bringing in change with the wind. This will give New Yorkers a different feeling about themselves. She is the essence of what we need now."
And how does a bejeweled corseted 17th-century monarch holding a globe in her hand relate to modern needs rather than past glory? Thalia Gouma-Peterson, a professor of art history at the College of Wooster in Ohio, said Ms. Flack's heroic female sculptures were very "now" in spirit. "One would never mistake them for antique figures," Professor Gouma-Peterson said. "There is tremendous power in those figures. They're self-assured, marching out to conquer the world."
Embodying female strength is Ms. Flack's goal. "Audrey is a staunch supporter of women and women's imagery," said Louis K. Meisel, who directs a gallery with his name in SoHo.
"Audrey's art is not feminist propaganda," said Dorchen Leidholdt, a lawyer and founder of the New York Coalition to End Violence against Women. "But her feminism is inextricable from her art."
Ms. Flack proudly practices activist art and recently addressed a rally to defend battered women. To a crowd of 8,000, Ms. Flack recounted the myth of Medusa, the subject of two of her sculptures. In the reinterpretation Medusa was not grotesque and vicious, but an innocent victim of male violence.
"Here's this woman who was raped, then punished and then beheaded," Ms. Flack said. "I felt very strongly I had to give this important woman a voice. Men see violence against women as macho and glamorous. We have to change that sensibility."
"Audrey is messianic in a way," the director of the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, Trudy Kramer, said. "She makes an effort to convey her ideas and participate in social issues. She's very interested in her work being democratic."
Ms. Flack has a home in Manhattan but is an integral part of the East End art scene. In the 1950's she caught the Abstract Expressionist fever, living in Springs, near Jackson Pollock, "around the corner from Bill de Kooning," she said.
Ms. Flack and her husband, Robert Marcus, an executive, have owned a house and studio in East Hampton for nearly 20 years. "Long Island is a very special place in the world," Ms. Flack said. "This is sacred territory." Her nearly lifesize bronze sculpture "Islandia: Goddess of the Healing Waters" symbolizes Long Island for Ms. Flack. The winged goddess was displayed last summer outside the Parrish and is now at the New York City Technical College in Brooklyn.
"There's a reason artists come to the Island to work, something about the air, the space and the light," she added. "There's an energy here that's freeing."
"Audrey has taken a lot of risks with her work, which has allowed her to grow in important ways," Ms. Kramer said. "She has a lot of courage as an artist."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: RICHARD H. STRAUSS;
Improving Business at the State's Airports

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
THE future of Connecticut's six airports is the topic of a series of hearings being conducted around the state by Richard H. Strauss, Deputy Commissioner of the State Department of Transportation.
The commissioner is meeting with pilots and passengers to gather comments on the Transportation Department's new five-year capital improvement program for the airports. At Bradley International, for instance, more than $30 million in improvements are planned. Currently, Mr. Strauss is responsible for state ports and airports in Hartford, Windsor Locks, Oxford, Windham, Danielson and Groton, as well as 138 associated aviation businesses, including municipal airports like Tweed-New Haven and Sikorsky Airport in Stratford. 
 In a recent interview at Windham Airport, Mr. Strauss discussed Connecticut's airports, as well as the issue that is on many aviators' minds as he conducts the hearings: how taxes pose a serious threat to efforts to build a strong aviation base in the state. Following are excerpts from that conversation:
Q: What is the tax problem for aircraft in Connecticut?
A: Connecticut towns tax the aircraft as property. In many states there is a registration fee. I expect that's going to be an issue everywhere we go.
Q: Is there any estimate of the number of aircraft that might be moved into the state if planes are subject to a registration fee instead of a tax?
A: I think that's speculative. But if you look at the number of aircraft in, say, Groton, and what has happened there over the last several years. You've seen the aircraft move, to a large degree, because of the tax, across the border into Westerly. There are about a dozen or 15 aircraft based there, and a few years ago the number of aircraft there was in the 50's or 60's. You see that taking place across Connecticut.
Q: How much would the change from a tax to a registration fee save the average aircraft owners?
A: Obviously, it depends on the registration fee that is ultimately imposed. We're talking about in excess of $2 million in property tax revenues with the system now, and I think the registration system would collect approximately $500,000, so the average aircraft owner would save about 75 percent.
Q: Why do you want to make it easier to own a plane in Connecticut?
A: First of all, the businesses at the airports provide service to pilots and aircraft owners, and having additional aircraft will help their businesses. If you have a very small airport like a Danielson Airport, with a limited number of aircraft based there, it becomes very difficult to have an operator there full time to provide the services that are needed. Having more aircraft makes those airport-based businesses more profitable, so that's a direct benefit.
The indirect benefit to those businesses and to the state is that through the additional aircraft based here, you create new jobs to work on those aircraft, and you have the potential to attract new companies that want to locate their businesses near airports, or entice existing businesses to base their aircraft in the state. That can provide spinoff benefits in terms of sales tax revenues, more jobs and taxes on petroleum products. We will sell more fuel if we have more aircraft. We will create more jobs if we have more aircraft.
Q: Aircraft owners say you are the first Deputy Commissioner to give the tax issue a lot of attention. How did that happen?
A: It came up shortly after I started in June 1991, and it was clear that this was a major concern among aircraft owners. We had a team of people working on it last year. We introduced it this year, but there were many issues on the table. I'm hoping we can make a strong case for it next year. It's clear that this is something that could have a significant impact, and we're committed to trying to get it through again, probably with a hold-harmless clause for the communities that are getting aircraft property tax payments now, so they don't lose money.
Q: The state lost a few private airports in the 1970's and 1980's to real estate speculators. Could that happen again if the market heats up?
A: We have an airport system plan that identifies all the airports in the state and the role they play in general aviation. There's no question that the property tax, as it stands today, has a great impact on aviation in the State of Connecticut. If the property tax isn't changed, you will probably see an erosion of air transportation facilities. If it is changed, you will see benefits from higher utilization of existing airports to economic development.
Q: How much is the state proposing to spend on capital improvements?
A: At Bradley International, the five-year plan exceeds $30 million. At the five general aviation state airports, we're looking for $7 million in Federal funds and $2 million in state funds per year. Then we also participate in funding of improvements at municipal airports, in Danbury, New Haven, Bridgeport. We pay 25 percent of the non-Federal share, which means we pay 2.5 percent and the city pays 7.5 percent of the cost.
Q: There are three airports along the shore, in Stratford, New Haven and Groton, that provide commercial service. Why are they not used more heavily?
A: You really only have jet service at one of those airports, Tweed. The frequency of flights are also important to people's decision as to where they are going to fly out of. Groton, Tweed and Sikorsky might meet the need of some passengers, but many people prefer the airport with a higher level of service, terminal facilities, jetways, and those types of amenities. And as the highway systems improve throughout the state, Bradley becomes that much closer to Fairfield County and southeastern Connecticut.
We're looking forward to the day when the transportation network will be very much improved, and put us in a much more competitive situation with Boston and New York airports. That's good because those airports have significant congestion. It's also more of a reliable airport because we don't have coastal fog, which can close down Boston and New York.
Q: How close to capacity is Bradley?
A: We're doing our master plan now which will identify that, but the air side is at about 60 percent of capacity, and the terminal, its expected capacity is about 8 million embarkments a year, and we're at about 4.8 million. This year is up from last year.
Q: You've recorded increases of well over 10 percent many months this year. What's driving that?
A: The fares. There are a lot of people who have decided "Hey, with these fares, I'm going to go on vacation." Pricing moves people, and the rates have been good, so more people are flying.
Q: Much of what the capital plan contains is renovation and maintenance. Are there any plans for expansion of the air transportation network in Connecticut?
A: We have a lot of work to do regarding simply rehabilitation. At this airport in Windham, for instance, we're not necessarily expanding, but we're looking at safety enhancements, with the creation of a new taxiway. To a large degree the limited funding we have available allows us to look at rehabilitation, and not expansion.
Q: Your plan calls for finding a private operator for Danielson Airport, and possibly for Windham and Oxford later. Why is the state considering getting out of the operation of small airports?
A: We're looking all through our operations and continually analyzing our expenditures to find better ways to do what we do. And if we do it differently, what level of service are we going to provide for the customer, which is the aircraft owner or traveler. In order to do that, we have to test the market. So we do requests for proposals and see whether private businesses can work with us to operate and maintain facilities in such a way that will allow us to reallocate our limited resources to their maximum efficiency. You have to ask, is there another way to do it? For some facilities it may work, for others it might not be the way to go.
Q: Do environmental concerns  about things like de-icing chemicals, fuel and habitat destruction prevent you from doing some of the things you want to at airports?
A: Whether you're running a service in the public sector or the private sector you need to be sensitive to environmental issues. Glycol is an environmental issue at major airports that needs to be addressed from two directions.
One is the safety of the flying public, that the plane be properly prepared to take off in a way that is safe.
On the other hand, you have to deal with the issue of glycol's infiltration into the groundwater. That happens to be one that is very much in the public eye right now. There's no question, though, that if you're building a new facility, the environment is another issue you need to deal with. That's the reality. We work closely with the Department of Environmental Protection, and identify those areas we need to work on.
Q: Is noise becoming more of a concern as suburbanization creeps out to some of the state's once-rural airports?
A: We're fortunate that modern aircraft have become much more quiet. There is a significant difference between a Stage 2 aircraft and Stage 3 aircraft, in terms of noise. Those large airports with commercial air service, we've seen continued improvement in the noise levels people are faced with.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard H. Strauss, Deputy Commissioner of the State Department of Transportation. (Ernie Hearion for The New York Times)
