HEADLINE: New Campaign Against PCB's in the Hudson

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
DESPITE regular warnings from the state, most Hudson River fishermen continue to eat PCB-contaminated fish, because they are either unaware of the risks or they do not care about them, a Poughkeepsie-based environmental organization reported last week.
"The bottom line, of course, is that we have to clean up the PCB's, but short of that, we somehow have to get the word out about the dangers of ingesting the chemicals," said Bridget Barclay, environmental director of Hudson River Sloop Clearwater, a 13,000-member nonprofit group that is compiling results from a yearlong study of fishermen's habits. 
 In interviews that began in the spring of 1991 with 340 anglers from Fort Edward (a Hudson River town about 40 miles north of Albany), south to Brooklyn and Staten Island, the environmental group found that 43 percent of fishermen along the river ate their catch at least twice a week, a rate the state considers unsafe.
The Clearwater organization's findings follow an updated health advisory last spring that was issued jointly by the State Department of Health and the State Department of Environmental Conservation. The advisory warns about the hazards associated with eating fish from the state's fresh waters, the Hudson River estuary and the New York Harbor area.
Although the newest advisory eases some previous Health Department restrictions on consumption, it still recommends limits on how often different kinds of fish can be safely eaten. For example, the advisory suggests that people eat no more than one meal a month of striped bass caught in the river south of the Tappan Zee Bridge. It also warns against eating any striped bass caught north of the bridge, where PCB concentrations are higher.
In the past, the Health Department has warned against eating any fish from the Hudson River.
But many of the anglers interviewed by Hudson River Sloop Clearwater said that even though they have known about the advisories, they have disregarded them.
"People tell us, 'You're going to die anyway,' and 'I've been eating the fish for years and nothing has happened,' " Ms. Barclay said.
In addition to recommending how often it is safe to eat fish spawned in the Hudson River, the state's 1992-93 advisory says that women of childbearing age, infants and children younger than 15 are probably more vulnerable to the effects of PCB's and should not consume any fish from the river.
Nevertheless, many Hudson River anglers are sharing their fish with family and friends, according to the Clearwater's findings. About 76 percent of those who told interviewers they ate the fish also said they shared their catch with at least one child younger than 15 or with a woman of childbearing age.
Laboratory studies have linked some types of polychlorinated biphenyls to cancer in animals. Also, there is a growing body of evidence that suggests that exposure to PCB's could cause nervous-system disorders, headaches and fatigue in all humans, along with reproductive problems in women and developmental delays in children.
During a 30-year period ending in 1977, it is estimated that about 1.1 million pounds of PCB's were discharged legally into the Hudson River from two General Electric Company plants that were manufacturing capacitors in Fort Edward and nearby Hudson Falls. The PCB's were a fire-retardant coolant used in the capacitors.
Although levels of the chemical found in the sediment at the bottom of the river and in fish dropped sharply after General Electric quit discharging PCB's into the river and have continued to decline -- albeit at a slower rate since 1980 -- samplings of fish show that those levels remain above the two parts per million allowed by the Federal Food and Drug Administration for commercial fisheries, said Ronald J. Sloan, a research scientist for the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
Another study of 11,000 people fishing in Lake Ontario also showed that anglers have not changed their eating habits despite the state's health advisories. A study conducted last year at the State University of New York at Buffalo reported that people with fewer years of education and lower household income consumed fish from the heavily polluted lake more often than others, said Dr. John E. Vena, an author of the study and an associate professor of social and preventive medicine at the school.
Similarly, preliminary results from the Clearwater study suggest that social and economic factors may be influencing people's fish-consumption habits, although those data have not been fully analyzed, Ms. Barclay said.
"A question we have is how many people are subsistence fishing," she said. "Is this their main source of food?"
"But whatever the reason they are still eating the fish is the word about the dangers is not getting out there, and that is a big concern to us," she said.
 
No Licenses Required
 The Clearwater study -- which cost $22,000 and was financed in part by the Hudson River Foundation for Science and Environmental Research in New York City and the W. Alton Jones Foundation in Charlottesville, Va. -- showed that only 46 percent of the fishermen were aware of the state's health advisories.
Part of the reason that fishermen along 150 miles of the lower Hudson may not be aware of the health risks, Ms. Barclay suggested, is that the advisories are issued along with fishing licenses, but south of Troy on the river no licenses are required. North of the Troy Dam, fishing is prohibited.
Historically, licenses have not been required for the lower Hudson River, part of which is a marine district not subject to regulation, said Langdon Marsh, executive deputy commissioner for the state's Department of Environmental Conservation. Although the state has recently considered fishing licenses for that part of the river as a vehicle for disseminating information and as a source of revenue, it has become what Mr. Marsh called a "politically contentious" issue.
Licensing has been opposed by recreational fishermen, who do not want restrictions on their activities and who also do not want to pay fees.
 
A Corps of Rangers Sought
 Instead, the state is seeking Federal financing for "urban fishing rangers who would go around and talk to anglers" who may not be aware of the health hazards, Mr. Marsh said.
Hudson River Sloop Clearwater is particularly concerned about the section of the river along the Westchester and New York City coastline because of the density of the population in that area and the large number of recreational fishermen, Ms. Barclay said. In addition to fishing rangers, signs posted along the riverbanks may also be an effective way to alert anglers.
The advisories are being distributed to bait and tackle dealers, and information is being disseminated by agents of the Cornell Cooperative Extension and by special-interest groups, like the Sierra Club, said Anthony Forti, a research scientist with the State Department of Health.
Christopher Letts, an educator with the Hudson River Foundation, runs shad and crab festivals along the river and shows people ways to cook the fish to reduce the health risks from PCB contamination. A crab festival will be held at Croton Point Park in Croton-on-Hudson next Sunday.
 
'This Is Not the A.&P.'
 "There's a danger of being too conservative when it comes to deciding whether or not to eat the fish," Mr. Letts said. "And you can tell people not to, but they are going to do it anyway. So you might as well show them the safest way to do it."
"There is something magical about people being able to take sustenance from the environment. It gives you a link," he said. "This is not the A.&P."
While the state and environmental organizations try to teach fishermen about the risks of consuming fish from the river, the problem of counteracting the PCB contamination -- which could cost $280 million to $750 million -- awaits completion of a study by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.
 
Federal Study Due in 1994
 At the request of the State Department of Environmental Conservation, the Federal Government is reevaluating the interim no-action policy it adopted in 1984. Options include continuing the no-action policy, keeping PCB's in place with sand or gravel in areas that could be stirred up by storms or ice, using biological methods to reduce contamination or dredging the river bottom, treating the chemicals and then depositing them in landfills.
The results of the Federal study will not be available until 1994, and they will be subject to public review before action is taken, said Douglas J. Tomchuk, an environmental engineer for the Federal agency.
Under the Federal Superfund Act, General Electric could be held responsible for the cost of cleaning up the river.
 
 
 
 
Warnings and Preparation
 IN a 1992-93 health advisory, the State Department of Health and the State Department of Environmental Conservation recommends limits on eating sport fish because many fish contain potentially harmful levels of chemical contaminants.
Specifically, long-term exposure to PCB's has been linked to cancer and nervous-system disorders. In general, the advisory says, it is recommended that a person eat no more than a half-pound of fish a week caught by recreational fishermen from the Hudson River. Infants, children younger than under 15 and women of childbearing age should not eat any fish from the Hudson River.
The following are some recommendations from the health advisory:
People should not eat any American eel, white perch, carp, goldfish or white catfish taken from the Hudson River from Troy Dam south to and including Lower New York Harbor. They should also not eat any hepatopancreas (the mustard, liver or tomalley of crabs) or any of the cooking liquid from crabs taken from the same part of the river.
The advisory also says not to eat any striped bass taken from the Hudson from Troy Dam South to the Tappan Zee Bridge.
Adults are advised to have no more than one meal a month consisting of walleye, rainbow smelt, largemouth bass, smallmouth bass, Atlantic needlefish, bluefish, northern pike or tiger muskellunge taken from the Hudson from Troy Dam south to and including Lower New York Harbor and to have no more than six blue crabs a month from the same part of the river.
The rule of only one meal a month also applies to striped bass taken from the Hudson from the Tappan Zee Bridge south to and including Lower New York Harbor.
None of the above recommendations apply to commercially caught fish.
As for preparing and cooking fish, the Health Department issued the following recommendations:
*Choose small fish. Older and larger fish may be more contaminated because they have had more time to accumulate contaminants in their bodies.
*Use a method of filleting fish that will reduce the skin, fatty material and dark meat, because those parts contain many of the contaminants.
*Cooking methods like broiling, poaching, boiling and baking, which allow contaminants from the fatty parts of the fish to drain out, are preferable. Pan frying is not recommended. Cooking liquids from fish should be avoided.
*For shellfish, do not eat the soft green substance found in the body section. These parts, known as the tomalley or liver, contain high levels of PCB's.
Additional information on the health advisory can be obtained by calling the State Health Department at (800) 458-1158.

HEADLINE: Don't Think for Yourself Unless You Can

BYLINE: By Alan Ryan; Alan Ryan teaches politics at Princeton University. He is the author of "Bertrand Russell: A Political Life."

 BODY:

THE ETHICS OF AUTHENTICITY
By Charles Taylor.
142 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press.
$17.95. 
 CHARLES TAYLOR is a philosopher of broad reach and many talents, but his most striking talent is a gift for interpreting different traditions, cultures and philosophies to one another. He is a Canadian who has taught at both McGill University and the Universite de Montreal; he is an admirer of Pope John Paul II, but he is a liberal and evangelical Roman Catholic whose instincts are more congregationalist than hierarchical.
When he was a professor in Oxford in the 1970's, he walked across the lawns of All Souls College like a man more at ease with a canoe upon his shoulder; yet his alliances to European intellectual life were closer and stronger than those of almost all his colleagues. He has been active in Canadian politics all his adult life, as an ardent defender of a maximum of decentralization and an equally ardent opponent of Quebec separatism.
If you did not know this, you might guess it from "The Ethics of Authenticity." Mr. Taylor writes about the agonies of the existentialist tradition in the down-to-earth idiom of Anglo-Saxon analytical philosophy; he ties what many critics have thought of as the crisis of the modern mind that began in the 16th and 17th centuries to the politics of the present Presidential campaign; and he comes across, if one dare say so, sounding much like that great North American mediator John Dewey.
This is less surprising than it sounds. Three years ago, Mr. Taylor published "Sources of the Self," significantly subtitled "The Making of the Modern Identity." There as here he drew on ideas that he spelled out more than a dozen years ago in his "Hegel," ideas that Dewey applied 50 and 60 years ago to just the same anxieties. One difference between them will be welcomed by his readers. If Mr. Taylor is no more stylish a writer than Dewey was, he is much brisker. He is also tougher-minded, and less willing than Dewey was to believe that the modern world is sure to live up to its better self. Much of "The Ethics of Authenticity" urges us to think more subtle thoughts; but the final chapter urges us into the polling booths, and into our town meetings. If the modern world is to live up to its potential, we the citizenry will have to work at it.
Mr. Taylor starts from a familiar place: we -- modern, affluent, secular North American we -- set an overwhelmingly high value on self-fulfillment, on the idea that each of us should find some way of life that satisfies us and is authentically our own. Yet this quest for self-fulfillment has backfired. Mr. Taylor takes three large complaints against modernity -- ones that, he says, "are discussed, bemoaned, challenged and argued against all the time in all sorts of media." The first complaint is that the rise of individualism has wrenched us loose from all the settings that gave meaning to the lives of our forebears; we have been thrown back on our inner resources, but when we look inside ourselves, we find emptiness because we have been cut adrift from everything that once supplied the resources we are seeking.
This is bound up with the second complaint -- what Mr. Taylor summarizes as "the primacy of instrumental reason." Our only understanding of what it is reasonable to do is based on efficiency and "cost-benefit" calculation. We are quite good at working out the best ways to make things happen, but less good at knowing whether we should be making those things happen in the first place. The way medical technique has made dying even more alarming than it used to be is a case in point; we have become very clever at keeping the dying body alive a little longer, but have forgotten how to care for the patient. We have lost the sense of the meaning of life and death that might -- to use Mr. Taylor's rather unlovely term -- "enframe" technique.
The last charge is political. We suffer under something that Herbert Marcuse was not the first observer to describe as the despotism of the system. A hundred years before, de Tocqueville feared that Americans might become "enclosed in their own hearts," that they would retreat to the security of their homes, abandon politics and therefore lose political control over their destiny. They would not suffer the terror of the police state; they might even live comfortable lives, but it would be the "pitiable comfort" threatened by Nie tzsche that they enjoyed, and existence would lack human dignity. Put the three charges together and we face "a loss of meaning . . . the eclipse of ends . . . [and] a loss of freedom."
Mr. Taylor's formidable skills of allusion and exegesis allow him to pack in an astonishing number of reference points -- to "The Closing of the American Mind," by Allan Bloom, and its obsession with relativism and subjectivism; to "The Cultural Contradictions of Capitalism," by Daniel Bell, and its fear that capitalist affluence promotes hedonism, selfishness and amoralism; and beyond these to Heidegger's fears about technology, Max Weber's fears about the "iron cage" of the modern bureaucratic state, and a great deal more. Still, even Mr. Taylor has to concentrate his forces; the reconstruction of the modern moral consciousness is hardly to be achieved in 142 pages.
Wisely, he concentrates on the first charge, the complaint that individualism rots moral commitment, that when we think for ourselves we turn the world into a meaningless desert. This is wise because it is the fundamental issue. If there are forms of moral individualism that give the world meaning, that sustain community rather than eroding it, the other complaints are easier to deal with. If, to take one of Mr. Taylor's own examples, we learn to understand the natural world as having its own voice and its own meaning -- if not in the way our medieval predecessors saw it, as one of the texts by which God communicated with us, perhaps in the way Wordsworth or Emerson saw it -- we are already halfway to knowing where to draw the line over the exploitation of natural resources. If we see ourselves as already deeply implicated in the common life of our society, we ought to find it easier to reanimate our democratic faith.
The problem, Mr. Taylor says, is that individualism's supporters and critics have alike misunderstood it. Mr. Bloom's complaint that individualism produces the shallow relativism expressed by "everyone's entitled to his own views" is only a half-truth; the truer ethics of authenticity demand that each of us believes not whatever we feel like but only what we are genuinely persuaded of. This needs more than individual honesty. We need other people to set intellectual standards for us; we need other people to recognize our successes and failures. We need "horizons of significance." And in fact they exist, though they are underexplored. In other words, Mr. Taylor is culturally anxious, but he deplores cultural pessimism. Nostalgia will not do; everyone knows it is hopeless merely to try to turn the clock back. We have left the medieval world behind for good reasons. We have our own resources, and it is these we must explore.
THIS will not simplify life, but we know that. The incoherence of simple views is familiar. "Right-wing American-style conservatives speak as advocates of traditional communities when they attack abortion on demand and pornography," Mr. Taylor says; "but in their economic policies they advocate an untamed form of capitalist enterprise, which more than anything else has helped to dissolve historical communities, has fostered atomism, which knows no frontiers or loyalties, and is ready to close down a mining town or savage a forest habitat at the drop of a balance sheet."
Incoherence is not the exclusive property of the right: "On the other side, we find supporters of an attentive, reverential stance to nature, who would go to the wall to defend the forest habitat, demonstrating in favor of abortion on demand, on the grounds that a woman's body belongs exclusively to her. Some adversaries of savage capitalism carry possessive individualism farther than its most untroubled defenders."
That is well taken, if not novel. It is harder to come to grips with the underlying philosophical position. If we share Mr. Taylor's view that we can take our ethics seriously only when we tie them to a view of the "meaning" of nature and human existence, how do we know whether existence means what we suppose? The conventionally religious have an obvious advantage in answering such a question because they think they are playing a part in a script written by God; but what about the unconventionally religious and the agnostic others?
Mr. Taylor's short book is so full of good things that one cannot decently complain about what it leaves out. Still, at some point the author has to come clean: is the "meaning" he looks for no more than a projection of our hopes and desires (in which case critics of individualism will complain that it is not "objective" enough), or is it laid down by some nonhuman power (in which case the unbelievers will complain)? These are old questions; they were frequently directed at Dewey, and particularly after he published "A Common Faith." But they are inescapable, and they must make even the most sympathetic reader of "The Ethics of Authenticity" uneasy.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1017 words

HEADLINE: The Man Who Couldn't Stuff Himself

BYLINE: By Judith Dunford; Judith Dunford is working on a second novel.

 BODY:

TWICE UPON A TIME
Stories.
By Daniel Stern.
239 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company.
$19.95. 
 SOMEONE I know, a well-known literary critic, was once admiringly called "the boy who loves books." The same glorious title could surely be awarded to Daniel Stern. He has taken his passionate connection to things written and used it as the starting point for the six ingenious stories in this dandy collection, "Twice Upon a Time."
As in his earlier "Twice Told Tales," Mr. Stern's idea is that the list of grains in the soul that itch their way out into fiction -- "a love affair, a trauma, a house, a mother, a landscape, a lover, a job or a sexual passion" -- should include the literature that has stuck to our imaginative ribs. In this book, that includes two poems by Wallace Stevens, three unsettling masterpieces of the short story (by Kafka, Hawthorne and Melville) and -- to show that the possibilities are limitless -- "The Communist Manifesto," by Marx and Engels (remember them?).
Mr. Stern, who has also written nine novels, has avoided competing with the originals and also the easy trick of simply putting new hats or painting mustaches on them -- outfitting Bartleby the scrivener in blue jeans or transferring Kafka's hunger artist to Little Italy. Instead, he snakes the inspiring story in and out of his own fiction, uses it to color the situation, makes the story itself a character as well as a metaphor. Although Mr. Stern does not make it necessary to reread the original, he makes doing so rewarding. And if that sounds as though these stories were fusty, musty and bookish, they are anything but. Mr. Stern writes with an antic exuberance that makes you search for comparisons -- Bernard Malamud with a dash of S. J. Perelman, say, or with a smidgen of the propulsive energy of Dickens. For a lover, Mr. Stern has also kept his wits about him, choosing for inspiration what most people would agree are some of the seminal imaginative works in world literature.
If there ever were stories that could be called lovable, here they are -- funny, generous, subtle and alive with characters who are just self-deprecating enough to be taken directly to heart. The settings are urban (Los Angeles, New York, Boston), and the characters usually word people, people with an edge, writers, public relations types, movie world types, academics for whom "Where is it written . . .?" is not just an expression. They speak with a wired-up intelligence:
"I told her of Jamie, the lovely Pre-Raphaelite actress who wanted to marry me and have children at once . . . and how I teased her with promises of reform, of getting out of bed early in the morning . . . of getting a job, renting an apartment, opening an account with the New York Telephone Company; promises all welshed on as Jamie's delicate features, her soft gray eyes and light-line mouth, grew weary and finally bitter. Then, one day, she vanished with a road company of 'Saint Joan' and left me alone once again."
The two Stevens-based stories are marvelous. "Sunday Morning by Wallace Stevens" (that's the title) is about a professor of literature, Osterweil, who finishes class one day with the absolute certainty that he is going to die, and that the only thing he desires in what remains of his life is to get a copy of Gilels's recording of the Beethoven C minor Piano Sonata, Opus 111, to be played at his funeral. As it turns out, he seems to find that death is the mother of beauty, as Stevens would have it -- in this case, beauty in the form of a love affair with a student. "The Man With the Blue Guitar by Wallace Stevens" is about a couple surprised into sexual rapture by the excitement of reading great poetry aloud, poetry so great that it keeps them from seeing "things as they are."
In "A Hunger Artist by Franz Kafka" a noted writer, Brandauer, on the usual academic teaching circuit starves the curriculum down to teaching only that one 14-page story "about a strange custom of fasting as an art form." As the narrator, a glutton and consumer of life, tells it, Brandauer is a man who could not find the spiritual or emotional food he liked. If he had, he might, as Kafka's hero insists, have stuffed himself like anyone else.
My favorite piece in "Twice Upon a Time" is the nearly novella-length "Communist Manifesto by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels," about a hopeful, naively idealistic young writer (who, we discover, is a distant relative of Karl Marx). A Candide who tries to find an ideology to live by, he grows older, grows up as one position after another falls apart under the force of real-world complexities. At the end it is the complexities that seize his heart, the "universe of 'missed points': religion, art, war . . . commerce, economics . . . philosophy, love." What a beautiful ending.
In fact, unlike much current fiction that concludes by vaporizing, Mr. Stern's stories have powerful endings. Like the musician he is (he has been a professional cellist), he can draw everything together to swell into a resounding coda. In the silence that follows, you can hear the sound of your own pulse.
 
 
 
MUSIC TO DIE FOR
 When Osterweil finished teaching the [Wallace] Stevens class he knew with an absolute certainty that he was going to die and he set out to find the piece of music that he wanted played at his funeral. Not just the particular piece, but the one recorded performance that would suffice, and no other. . . .
The latest nuance was his browsing among the great works of music for exactly the right selection to be played when he could no longer hear it. It was a strange training for the ear -- to hear the ineffable, or to hear through the ears of others, his mourning family and friends. Which ears: Lorelei, with her austere love for German art songs, or Stepner, who, frankly, preferred pop classics? It must be what composers have to do, he thought. Listen through the imaginary ears of others. Poets, too. He would find a way to use all this in one of his classes. That would take some of the pain out. -- From "Twice Upon a Time."

HEADLINE: For Shopping Centers, Less Is Becoming More

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH; Isadore Barmash, a former New York Times reporter, writes about business topics from New York.

 BODY:
This year, Melvin Simon & Associates, the nation's second-largest developer of shopping centers, plans to open only 10 new ones, compared with 80 just five years ago. Simon is not alone.
"We in the industry have overbuilt everywhere," Matthew Bucksbaum, president of the General Growth Corporation, a Des Moines mall builder, told a trade meeting last month. "New construction as far as large regional malls are concerned will be limited, and the owners of existing ones will have to depend on getting more results from their present centers. It's a whole new ball game." 
 Indeed, the shopping center industry, once the most dynamic sector in the real estate business, is going through hard times. The number of centers under construction nationwide declined sharply last year, to 552, from 1,008 in 1990 and 1,642 in 1988, according to the New York-based International Council of Shopping Centers.
But the overall decline in growth is masking an important shift among shoppers away from the big indoor malls and toward smaller shopping centers, both old and new, including the humble strip mall, industry experts say. The ball game now, they add, often is being determined by basic changes in the nation's buying habits.
Recession-pressed consumers, short on time as well as money, are gravitating in increasing numbers to more modest, compact centers, the industry experts say. Some of the smaller centers win loyalty because they are closer to home and offer easier access than the sprawling malls. Some have clusters of factory outlet stores that promise steep discounts. And still others are built around so-called category killers -- giant specialty stores like Home Depot, Price Club, Toys 'R' Us, Staples and T. J. Maxx -- that offer enormous display space, huge inventories and lower prices.
"Consumers have simply changed the way they shop," said Allan Hutensky, president of the Hutensky Group, a Hartford-based developer of smaller centers. "Because many families have two workers and are facing time pressures, they have become completely destination oriented in their shopping." Translation: they no longer have as much free time to walk the malls.
To be sure, many big malls are doing quite well, including the biggest of them all in this country, the new Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn. And some smaller centers have been hurt by the recession and severe competition from other centers, both big and small. Still, as a group, the smaller centers are multiplying at a faster clip than their bigger siblings.
Between 1988 and 1991, the number of smaller centers, those under 400,000 square feet, grew at an overall rate of 16.8 percent, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers. Within that group, the so-called power centers, those with category-killer stores, jumped 22 percent. By contrast, the bigger complexes, those from 400,000 to more than a million square feet, grew by 12.4 percent.
What's more, the smaller centers appear to be closing the gap in annual sales per square foot. Centers ranging in size from 146,000 to 250,000 square feet, for example, gained $18 a square foot in sales, to $162.43, from 1987 to 1990, the last year for which data are available, according to the Urban Land Institute, a research organization. Regional malls, those with at least one department store, gained just $11 in that period, to $168.41.
THE smaller centers come in a variety of styles and shapes. There is, of course, the ubiquitous neighborhood strip center. But there are also factory outlet centers, like the upscale Woodbury Common Factory Outlets in Central Valley, N.Y., about 50 miles north of Manhattan. These seek to attract price-conscious customers who nonetheless want top brands and labels.
Spreading rapidly around the country, these outlet centers were kept in recent years 30 to 60 miles away from the suppliers' regular store accounts. But now, as suppliers are responding defensively to the protracted retailing slowdown, factory outlet developers are moving them closer to the prime retail markets, said Carleton Meyers, a consultant based in Burke, Va., who has brought producers and developers together in such centers for the last 12 years.
The power centers are the fastest-growing category of all. These belong broadly in the strip center group -- with about 200,000 to 400,000 square feet -- but unlike the general strip centers and regional malls, they do not need a big collection of small shops and service establishments to lure the public. The category killers are the "destination" virtually by themselves.
The Hutensky Group's Jordan Lane Shopping Center in Wethersfield, Conn., has two category killers -- T. J. Maxx, an apparel discounter, and Super Stop & Shop, a large food and general merchandise store -- among its 270,000 square feet.
The surge in retail complexes of moderate dimensions represents something of a U-turn for the shopping center industry. For years, developers promoted the huge malls as the wave of the future. And they were, for more than two and a half decades. But many malls are now shopworn and need renovation in look and in spirit.
The large regional malls, those with several department stores as anchors and the highest retail rents, have had a particularly bad time of it lately, clobbered by the lingering recession and a spate of department store bankruptcies. Developers, facing slumping demand, restraints on financing and a dearth of big building sites, have generally put the hold sign on anything but the most moderate new projects.
The sharp decline in the number of new malls "will allow for the absorption of existing vacant space as well as more deliberate decision-making by industry leaders to build centers where they are in demand," said John Konarski, research and education director of the International Council of Shopping Centers.
Ironically, one of the industry's biggest recent successes appears to be the truly huge Mall of America, which opened Aug. 11 in seeming defiance of the recession and industry trends.
At 4.2 million square feet, Mall of America dwarfs the Del Amo Fashion Center in Torrance, Calif., which had been the biggest in the country with three million square feet. By comparison, the Roosevelt Field mall in Garden City, L.I., has about two million square feet while the Galleria in White Plains and the Short Hills Mall in Short Hills, N.J., have about one million each.
The 78-acre Mall of America offers plenty of shopping in its nearly 400 stores. But it also offers large dollops of entertainment. Among its other attractions are several nightclubs and the world's largest indoor amusement park, the seven-acre Camp Snoopy.
"We're very pleased with the initial results," said Herbert Simon, president of Indianapolis-based Melvin Simon & Associates, co-developer of the mall.
A million visitors a week trooped into the mall in the first month, said Maureen Hooley, the mall's public relations manager. "We're already exceeding our goal of 40 million visitors a year, which we had set for 1996," she said.
IF Mall of America can draw such crowds, can the other big malls follow by rekindling customer interest and curiosity through merchandise creativity or show-business skills? Or is it a matter of waiting until the economy turns around?
At least one developer is convinced that the industry doesn't have to wait.
"We are becoming more target-driven in our marketing," said Paul F. Kastner, senior vice president of the O'Connor Group, a New York-based developer. He said O'Connor was developing a data base of customer profiles "so we can segment it in various ways." He added, "For the back-to-school season, for example, we know which customers have school-age children and we can contact the families via direct mail and mass media for our tenants and malls."
To guarantee a future, some mall operators have bitten the bullet and undergone ambitious renovation programs. Roosevelt Field, for example, signed up Abraham & Straus to replace the department store that the bankrupt Alexander's chain closed. A number of smaller shops also were added.
But whether face lifts and sharper marketing will do the trick long term is unclear, industry experts said. And it is far from a sure bet that a million people a week will flock to Mall of America a year from now, or 10 years from now.
Mr. Bucksbaum, the Des Moines mall builder, posed the big unanswered question in his trade talk last month. "Is the Mall of America the end of an era for big malls," he asked, "or the beginning of a new one?"

HEADLINE: Too Free for Texas

BYLINE: By David Herbert Donald; David Herbert Donald's books include "Charles Sumner and the Coming of the Civil War" and "The Politics of Reconstruction, 1863-1867."

 BODY:

THE FREEDMEN'S BUREAU AND BLACK TEXANS
By Barry A. Crouch.
Illustrated. 187 pp. Austin:
University of Texas Press.
$24.95. 
 AMERICANS have always been better at waging war than at winning the peace. From the War of 1812 to Desert Storm, our history shows that we have rarely known what we wanted to do once the fighting was over. The Civil War is a notable example of our failure to formulate clear war aims.
Aside from the preservation of the Union and (after the fighting began) the emancipation of the slaves, there was no agreement on the peace terms to be imposed on the South once the Confederate armies were defeated. Disagreement was sharpest over what was to be done for, or with, the more than three million African-Americans freed by the war. Many Northern whites thought that nothing more than liberty was due to the freedmen; others believed that they would need a generation or more of careful protection until they were used to the ways of freedom.
While this dispute raged, reports poured into Washington of the deprivation, suffering, hunger and disease among the "contrabands" who had flocked to the Union armies. Clearly something had to be done. Out of this need came the Freedmen's Bureau (technically the Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen and Abandoned Lands), established by Congress in 1865. The bureau was intended to be a temporary bridge from slavery to freedom. Under Gen. Oliver Otis Howard, the bureau gave out emergency Army rations to both whites and blacks in the South to prevent famine; it legalized marriages among the freedmen (which had been forbidden under slave law); it set up a system of free labor, under which the white landowners contracted with the black workers to grow the South's major staples; it encouraged education among the freedmen and, as far as possible, it tried to preserve public order. After 1868, when the Southern states adopted constitutions that guaranteed black suffrage, the bureau was, in effect, closed down; henceforth, presumably, blacks could protect themselves at the ballot box.
Historians unanimously judge that the Freedmen's Bureau failed to achieve its objectives. Even though W. E. B. Du Bois praised the "great work of social reform" the bureau attempted, and John A. Carpenter, Howard's biographer, claimed that it "performed near miracles," not even defenders of the bureau argue that it brought about a permanent improvement of race relations in the United States. Indeed, it is hard to see how anyone could so argue, for by the end of the Reconstruction period African-Americans continued to be treated as second-class citizens, continued to live in a virulently racist, segregated society and continued to be ruthlessly exploited in a sharecropping system that was little better than slavery.
But scholars have offered very different reasons for the failure of the bureau. George R. Bentley, whose "History of the Freedmen's Bureau" (1955) remains the standard account, charged that the bureau, by becoming a tool of the Radical wing of the Republican Party, sought "too much for the Negro too soon -- and not so much for his own sake as for the benefit of a faction of a party bent on the economic and political exploitation of the states where the Negroes lived." More recently William S. McFeely, in "Yankee Step father: O. O. Howard and the Freedmen" (1968), has argued that Howard and his subordinates failed because they were -- perhaps unconsciously -- racists, who sought to do what they thought was good for the freedmen without asking what the African-American community desired for itself.
"The Freedmen's Bureau and Black Texans," by Barry A. Crouch, a professor of history at Gallaudet University, approaches this subject from a different perspective. Because the papers of the bureau, which fill nearly 1,500 feet of shelf space at the National Archives in Washington, cannot be mastered by any individual scholar, most previous students have selectively sampled this vast collection and have written of the bureau from the viewpoint of its headquarters in Washington. Mr. Crouch has chosen to focus on a single state, Texas, and by concentrating on a few counties in that state he has been able to study all the relevant records, including some that were considered so local in interest that they were omitted from the 651-reel microfilm edition of the Freedmen's Bureau papers.
As a result he is able to show just how the bureau worked on the local level. Here are the day-by-day activities of the several assistant commissioners of the Freedmen's Bureau, who, with a skeleton staff of civilians and a handful of Union soldiers, were supposed to keep order in that huge state. Mr. Crouch concludes that, facing insuperable problems, "they acquitted themselves well." Here, too, are the stories of some of the sub-assistant commissioners, or agents, in charge of two to five counties each, whose reports, in pedestrian, bureaucratic prose, tell of former Confederates who, according to one agent, cherished a hatred of the national Government "as deep and damning as perdition itself," of race relations "bad as can be," and of Texans who flared into violence when blacks violated social protocol by "not walking out in the road when ordered to do so by the whites."
MR. CROUCH'S central chapter deals with one William G. Kirkman, a Freedmen's Bureau agent stationed in the village of Boston, in northeastern Texas. This Illinois-born agent tried to preserve order in a region comprising 1,838 square miles, where he had, at most, nine soldiers to help him. Boston was a violent community, where murder was an almost everyday occurrence. Though Kirkman initially reported to his superiors that most blacks and whites were attempting to "get along as quietly and as peacefully as possible," he soon discovered that the two races had "little sympathy for each other" and that whites' feelings toward their former bondsmen were "undescribable." He wanted to "pursue a mild and just course" of mediating between the races, but when he attempted to settle quarrels fairly between the freedmen and the landlords, he was ostracized by the entire white community.
Kirkman's life was repeatedly threatened, and the white sheriff of the county refused to give him any assistance or protection. A gang of white desperadoes vowed to kill him. Their leader was Cullen Montgomery Baker, a psychopath who enjoyed terrorizing local citizens and murdered blacks "for the mere sport of killing." Called out of his office at 2 A.M. on Oct. 7, 1868, Kirkman was gunned down in a fusillade fired from the shadows of a nearby house. His body, robbed of his revolver, his watch and three gold pieces, lay in the street for many hours, because the townspeople were too terrified to put their heads out of doors. "Capable, honest and persevering" is Mr. Crouch's epitaph for Kirkman, and it seems just.
Kirkman's assassination was a minor tragedy, not an event that changed the course of history. Yet it, and the other similar episodes in Texas Reconstruction history that Mr. Crouch relates, perhaps do more than broad generalizations to explain why the Freedmen's Bureau failed, and how we lost the peace after the Civil War.

HEADLINE: U.S. SET TO OPEN NATIONAL FORESTS FOR STRIP MINING

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is about to complete a policy change that will open millions of acres of national parks and forests to strip mining for coal except in cases where the Government buys the mineral rights from the families and energy companies that own them.
The policy change, in the form of a new Interior Department regulation that is due to become final shortly after Election Day, would give coal companies the authority to mine a mother lode of coal that now lies beneath 40 million acres of parks, preserves and protected lands in 24 states. The area holds roughly 16 percent of the nation's reserves. 
 Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. says that to prevent strip mining in 19 of the national parks, recreation areas and wildlife refuges that contain some of this coal the agency will buy the mineral rights from the owners.
 
Different Estimates of Value
 Mr. Lujan's aides said the coal reserves beneath these lands were worth just $11 million. But the coal industry and the National Wildlife Federation, an environmental group, said the Government would have to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to prevent mining in the national parks.
Last year, in one case alone, the United States Claims Court in Washington ordered the Interior Department to pay at least $150 million to a coal company barred from mining a protected area in Wyoming.
"It could be a bonanza for the coal industry," said L. Thomas Galloway, a Washington lawyer who specializes in environmental cases and an expert on strip-mining regulations. "They don't want to mine in the national parks. It would be too much of a public-relations disaster. But if they threaten to, the way this rule is set up, the Government would have no other choice but to pay them."
 
Ending 15 Years of Protection
 The new regulation, which has been in preparation for more than a year, would eliminate protections that Congress approved for these lands when it passed the Federal strip-mining law 15 years ago. The law bars mining in national parks and national forests and on millions of acres of private lands, except to those who hold a "valid existing right" to the coal.
But Congress never defined that term, and the Interior Department's efforts to do so have twice been struck down by a Federal District judge in Washington. As a result the Government adopted an unofficial policy that gave any coal owner who had sought to mine the coal up to the day the law was established, on Aug. 3, 1977, valid existing rights.
But a growing number of other Federal judges around the country have since ruled that this definition, never formally adopted, violates the Fifth Amendment, which prohibits the Government from taking property without just compensation.
The new regulation, in effect, adopts these more recent court rulings as Government policy. "We view this new policy as an affirmation of the Fifth Amendment and a correct interpretation of the surface-mining law," Steven Goldstein, the chief spokesman for the Interior Department, said today.
The issuance of the final rule, expected in November, awaits the completion of an environmental-impact statement by the Interior Department.
The department says the public lands with the richest coal reserves are in eight national forests in Ohio, Alabama, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Pennsylvania, Virginia and West Virginia.
In addition, hundreds of thousands of acres of state parks and wildlife refuges are likely to be opened for strip mining in Texas, Oklahoma, Illinois and Ohio.
The practice of strip mining in these public lands, in which layers of dirt and rock are blasted away to get at coal seams that often are 100 feet or more below the surface, largely ended in the 1980's under the Government's old interpretation of the strip-mining law.
For the past 15 months, President Bush has pressed for changes in environmental regulations, and he succeeded in relaxing restrictions on filling wetlands, cutting timber, exploring for oil, and mining copper, uranium and other minerals on Federal land.
 
Bush Advocates a Balance
 In a recent campaign appearance in Washington State, Mr. Bush said his development policy was vital to the American economy and balanced the interests of working people and conservationists. For their part, the Democrats' team, Gov. Bill Clinton and Senator Al Gore, say the Administration is sacrificing the nation's natural heritage for the short-term benefit of industry.
Mr. Goldstein said there was no political motivation behind the rule on strip mining. "Often times good policy is good politics," he said, "but that was not the motivation for this new rule."
Introduced in a little-noticed entry in the Federal Register on July 18, 1991, the rule is a departure for the Bush Administration, which angered the energy industry in 1989 by withdrawing a similar regulation proposed by the Reagan Administration to allow strip mining in national parks and national forests.
In doing so, the Bush Administration stepped into a long-running policy struggle over valid existing rights, the term Congress left undefined when it passed the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act in 1977.
 
Who Owns Mineral Rights
 Mineral rights in public parks, forests other lands are usually held not by the Government but by families and energy companies. The reason is that when the Government establishes a park or refuge or forest, it typically saves money by buying only what is on the surface. Anything below ground remains in the hands of the previous landowner, and the rights to it can be sold to others.
After passage of the 1977 law, the Carter Administration tried to define valid existing rights as those that were held by any mineral owner who had a permit to mine the coal.
But in 1980 that definition was struck down by Federal District Judge Thomas A. Flannery in Washington, who said it was too strict. He ruled that the authority to mine should also be given to mineral owners and lease holders who had made a good-faith effort to gain them before the law was passed.
Judge Flannery's opinion in effect became the Government policy for defining valid existing rights in most coal-mining states.
But with increasing frequency, other Federal judges have ruled that the policy still infringed on the right of families and coal companies to develop their holdings. Prompted by these decisions, the Interior Department worked up its new definition of valid existing rights.
 
Other Fights on Strip Mining
 There have been many battles over the years over the right to dig strip mines in national forests and on other public lands. But in recent months the debate has been thrown into sharp relief in southern Ohio, where coal has been mined since the early years of the century from hills that are thick with ash and oak.
In the Wayne National Forest, a plan by the Belville Coal Company to mine 7,200 acres has drawn attention in the Interior Department and the White House. The company's owner, 58-year-old Thomas J. Belville, who rose from a hardscrabble childhood and a high school education to help found Lawrence County's largest coal company, is also an active Republican and a Bush supporter.
Mr. Belville acknowledges that his political connections helped him in December 1988, when the Interior Department determined that he had the valid existing right to strip-mine more than 11 square miles of the national forest that may contain 15 million tons of coal.
But he was flabbergasted a year later when the department reversed the earlier decision, withdrew the right and prohibited the mining. "That was my thank-you for being so loyal to George Bush," he said.
 
Mine Owner Goes to Court
 Mr. Belville responded by filing a lawsuit in the Claims Court in Washington and two more in Federal District Court in Cincinnati asserting that what the Government did was illegal under the Constitution and the strip-mining law. The lawsuits are being closely followed by the coal industry because the legal precedents set here are likely to have implications in other states.
Mr. Belville won the two District Court lawsuits last year, including one in which the Federal judge said the Government had no authority to take away Mr. Belville's right to strip mine coal he owned or controlled. The Government is appealing both decisions. The Government also is seeking to settle the Claims Court suit by giving Mr. Belville the right to begin strip-mining 40 acres of the national forest.
Mr. Belville's opponents, including hunters and lumber companies, argue that strip mining represents the last wasteful stage of an industrial revolution that has run its course in Ohio and other Appalachian coal states, including Virginia, West Virginia, Tennessee and Kentucky.
 
Can Land Be Reclaimed
 "After mining, there is real doubt that there is a future sustainable economic practice available for that land," said Judith Dumke, a botanist and resident of Chesapeake, Ohio. "Most reclaimed land from strip mining produces little timber and is worthless as grassland. I have no animosity to Tom Belville. He does his best with reclamations. But we're still dealing with marginal soil types. After it's mined, it's not going to produce jobs."
Mr. Belville asserts that strip mines can be reclaimed and turned into rolling grasslands that can be used as pastures or habitat for wildlife.
Representative Nick J. Rahall, a West Virginia Democrat who heads the House Interior Subcommittee on Mining and Natural Resources, said the Administration's proposal would open too much public land to development and violated the intent of the strip mining law.
Mr. Rahall has proposed an amendment to the Energy Bill, now under discussion by a House-Senate conference committee, that would invalidate the Administration's rule and restore the definition of valid existing rights that has been used by the Government and most coal mining states since 1980.
Mr. Rahall, however, said that the amendment was under attack by the coal industry and Republican members of the conference committee and that it may not survive in Congress or the courts. "I'm quite sure that if the public knew how much of the nation's most beautiful lands were threatened with strip mining, they would not stand for what the Administration is doing," he said. "But the Interior Department has done a good job at keeping this quiet and I'm not sure we're going to be able to stop it."

HEADLINE: Weak Dollar Makes U.S. World's Bargain Bazaar

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The declining dollar has turned the world's wealthiest economy into the Filene's basement of industrial countries. Despite its rebound during the European currency crisis, the dollar, which fell to record lows this summer, remains extraordinarily weak by historical standards.
To the Swiss businessman just off the Concorde, the $120 tab for a room at the Plaza looks like the lunch check back home. To the teen-ager from Paris, the $9 sticker on the tape at Tower Records and the $30 tag on a pair of Levi 501's read like big signs that say buy one, get one free. 
 Life in the United States may not seem like a bargain to the many Americans whose incomes have been pinched by nearly four years of economic stagnation. But in fact, the weakling dollar has made the United States the least expensive rich country for people to visit and shop, and for businesses to manufacture their products.
The image of the United States as the world's bargain bazaar might suggest a kind of place where tourists flock for cut-rate vacations and where labor is cheap, living standards are low and products and services lack sophistication and quality.
But the United States is hardly a third world nation. Its citizens still enjoy the highest standard of living and are the world's most productive workers. Their pay, measured in terms of the goods and services it can buy in the United States as opposed to foreign countries, is higher than in Canada, Germany or Japan.
To some extent, the dollar's low value -- especially compared with the 1950's and 1960's -- does reflect the growing economic clout and economic prowess of other nations and America's shrinking economic lead.
But the dollar's weakness is not expected to be permanent, since it stems mostly from unusually high interest rates in Germany and unusually low rates in the United States -- and the momentarily different policy goals of Bonn and Washington.
"These are extraordinary times in Europe," said Philip Suttle, an economist at J. P. Morgan. "It's the mirror image of the extreme and unsustainable dollar spike in the 1980's."
Most foreign-exchange traders and forecasters expect the dollar to recover a bit more, as the gap in interest rates narrows again, which is likely when the German economy slows further and the American recovery gathers steam.
 
Bargain Bunch of Lilies
 Think of a low dollar as a special promotion of American-made products and services -- not a "going out of business" sale. Still, bargains clearly abound. For example, a $50 bunch of lilies ordered through Calyx and Corolla set a Japanese suitor back nearly 7,000 yen a year ago when it took 137 yen to buy a dollar. The same bunch costs him just 6,000 yen now, one reason the San Francisco flower mail-order house is doing a brisk overseas business.
One measure of how cheap the dollar became even before its latest bout of weakness, according to Michael Roberts at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris, is that it took just $100 in May of this year to buy the same basket of consumer goods and services in the United States that cost $170 in Sweden and $128 in Germany.
Despite economic troubles in many other rich countries, many travelers are taking advantage of the bargains here. More than 1.5 million Germans, 8 percent more than last year, are expected by the United States Tourism and Travel Agency this year, along with 3.4 million Japanese.
 
Not Much English Is Spoken
 "Some days very little English is spoken in our shop," said Thomas K. Woodard, a New York quilt dealer. "Most of our customers are in the enviable position of not having to worry about finances, but they are absolutely thrilled when they save money."
For foreigners in strong-currency countries, coming here is almost cheaper than staying at home. The weekend rate at the Hyatt Regency Chicago, for example, is $89 for a double per night, half the rate of comparable hotels in Munich, London or Rome. A Big Mac is one-third to one-half cheaper here. A movie ticket is one-fifth to one-half as much.
Or take that classic, a trip to Disney World. For a Frankfurt family, a week in Orlando could easily cost less than a visit to Euro Disney. As it turns out, one-third more foreign tourists than last year have arrived at Orlando International Airport.
 
More Than Theme Parks
 In addition to shaking hands with Mickey, tourists from abroad are definitely doing more shopping. Japanese tourists are crowding the counters at Tiffany's, where clerks are familiar with Japanese ring sizes. And computer-literate Germans are buying laptops -- available here at 20 to 30 percent below current retail prices in Germany.
Alert American entrepreneurs are looking for ways to capitalize on the trend. For example, Rex Fritchi, a Chicago travel agent, and Swissair are talking about offering a weekend shopping package this winter to enable Europeans to share the pleasures of off-price shopping at Gurnee Mall, a large mall outside the city. "We could fill up plane loads just coming over to buy bed sheets, shirts, socks and underwear," he said.
Some Europeans and Japanese are ordering directly from American catalogue emporiums. One of the most popular catalogues, L. L. Bean, the woodsy Maine clothier, has had to expand the number of customer service representatives who handle foreign orders to 60, from 12. Orders are up 50 to 100 percent this year over last, said Richard Leslie, director of international marketing.
The cheaper dollar also makes conventional American exports like aircraft, chemicals and machinery cheaper, especially in Europe. A Bureau of Labor Statistics index of prices of exports in various countries shows that prices of imports to the United States have risen about 40 percent more in dollars than prices of American exports.
"Every day the dollar gets weaker I'm very happy," said Andreas Barth, senior vice president at Compaq Computer's European division in Munich. "The Europeans are unhappy because it decreases the competitive position of their exports."
 
More Than Cheap Dollar
 Not all of the cost differentials stem from currency play. American factory productivity has been growing robustly for a decade and inflation in the United States compares favorably with Germany and Japan. Both trends hold down costs.
In fact, the United States has been one of world's low-cost producers since the late 1980's. American factory productivity remains, on average, the highest in the world -- 10 percent higher than in Japan and nearly 40 percent higher than in Germany. Pay measured in dollars at today's exchange rates is roughly the same as in Japan, and 25 percent lower than in Germany.
Arthur Neef, chief of the international division at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, says productivity is growing faster here than in Europe while wages are rising more slowly.
Take Hugo Boss Fashions, the Italian-German company that produces in Cleveland 80 percent of the $800 suits it sells in the United States. "We wanted to be close to the customer, American workers are extremely productive and, at the present value of the dollar, American wages are very competitive," said Jean de Jaegher, president and chief executive of IFAC, the holding company that owns Hugo Boss.
 
Slowdowns in Other Countries
 To be sure, the latest decline in the dollar is not likely to bring about an export boom or eliminate the trade deficit quickly, said Robert Lawrence, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. Europe and Japan are suffering economic slowdowns, preventing consumers and businesses from spending freely.
And foreigners are staying away from the stock, bond and real estate markets in droves. "You can go bargain hunting in goods and services and tourism," said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services. "But real estate is depressed everywhere. Stocks aren't bargains. And bonds are expensive."
Provided that the dollar's latest bout of weakness does not end in a panicky dumping of American assets, few economists consider a cheap dollar a big problem and most betit will strengthen a bit more as German rates come down and American rates stop falling -- perhaps sometime next year.
