HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN
The Governor: Clinton in Arkansas -- A special report.;
An Early Loss Cast Clinton As a Leader by Consensus

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
In a Victorian meeting room on the second floor of the Arkansas Capitol, the state's former governors, captured in oil paint, maintain an unblinking vigil. Among these white-haired figures, Bill Clinton, looking oddly youthful and overeager, has already taken his place.
Mr. Clinton has been Governor of Arkansas since 1982. But as his portrait indicates, he is also a former governor; his first term ended in defeat in 1980. More than his accomplishments, this defeat defined his identity. 
 Even now, 12 years later, Mr. Clinton still speaks about the mistakes that drove him from office and of the intense self-examination that enabled him to make a comeback two years later as if they were very much fresh in his mind.
"I spent a whole lot of time trying to figure out where I messed up," he said in a recent interview. "How did I turn people off? What did I do wrong? What decisions could I have made differently? How could I have maintained a stronger level of support for change?"
 
Talking to the Disaffected
 Mr. Clinton said what he learned from his two years out of office was to be more sensitive to the concerns of his constituents. Talking to the voters who had turned him out of office, he discovered "they thought I spent more time doing what I wanted to do and no time listening to them, no time taking them along and communicating with them."
But friends and opponents of Mr. Clinton say the lessons he learned were more complicated.
The young Governor had discovered the dangers of pushing through an agenda ahead of public opinion and the risks of fighting the state's business establishment. As a result, he became much more sensitive to the vagaries of public opinion and much more adept in the art of accommodation.
Betsey Wright, the Governor's former chief of staff and now a top campaign aide, describes the transformation this way: "What he learned from the loss was that government officials, no matter how smart and idealistic they are, cannot decide what's best for the people and just do it."
Others put it less delicately. Ernie Dumas, who wrote editorials at the now-defunct Arkansas Gazette, suggested that Mr. Clinton learned the art of compromise rather too well: "His greatest drawback is he does not like to make enemies."
By all accounts, Mr. Clinton's first term was a time of unusual energy and conflict, at least by Arkansas standards. The Governor, only 32 when he was elected, raised car license fees to finance a highway repair campaign, pushed for a new system of rural health clinics and held hearings to consider limits on clear-cutting in the state's forests. He had wide-ranging plans for improving education and developing industry and increasing energy conservation, and when his plans were blocked -- as they often were -- he did not hesitate to make his displeasure known.
David Matthews, a friend of Mr. Clinton and a former state Representative, recalled how in his first term the Governor used to keep a chart of how each state legislator had voted on his initiatives and call the recalcitrant ones down to discuss their positions. The legislators, many of whom were twice Mr. Clinton's age, were not amused. "It developed tremendous strains," Mr. Matthews said.
Mr. Clinton was slow to realize that his youthful activism was alienating Arkansas's essentially conservative electorate as well. Not until a few weeks before the election did he realize how far his support had eroded. Friends say that when he lost to Frank White, a Republican, he was devastated.
Upon leaving office, Mr. Clinton joined a law firm in downtown Little Rock and began the painstaking process of analyzing his loss and planning his comeback. He tried, he said, to sort out his political problems from the problems of the country as a whole. This analysis would consume him for most of the next two years.
"For the first time in my adult life, I could work a 40-hour week again," Mr. Clinton said. "I began to read as much as I could, trying to figure out what was happening to America, how we got into the economic tailspin we were in in 1980, those things that were beyond my immediate control that shaped the attitudes and the feelings and the lives of my folks. That was an extremely valuable time for me. What I tried to do when it was over was make it a learning experience."
 
A Change in Style
 The conclusions that Mr. Clinton reached during this period of reading and thinking were evident in the changes in his style. If his first term was characterized by brashness, contention and a lack of focus, the subsequent terms were marked by caution, compromise and a search for consensus.
"That defeat was really the seminal experience of his career," said Dick Morris, who served for many years as Mr. Clinton's chief political adviser but is currently not working for either Presidential candidate.
While some critics contend that his defeat transformed Mr. Clinton into little more than a political weather vane, a review of the Governor's 12 years in office suggests that this criticism is overstated.
Throughout his political career, Mr. Clinton continued to push for an activist government in Arkansas, one that worked to improve education and basic services.
But after his defeat, the Governor decided to adapt more to the political culture of Arkansas, which was dominated by the state's major industries and supported by an essentially anti-government electorate. He backed off from several proposals that had offended the state's most powerful businesses, and he shied from tackling Arkansas's historically regressive tax structure. And he began to rely much more heavily on polls.
"I think Bill Clinton has a very true compass," Mr. Morris, who now works only for Republicans, said. "I don't think that varies much with public opinion. But within the general proposition he wants to go north, he will take an endless variety of routes. He's constantly maneuvering, constantly picking the routes he wants to get there, maneuvering his opponents into positions where they can't get a clear shot at him. That is what leaves a legacy of 'Slick Willie.' "
 
Lessons
Conciliation Is Put At Top of Agenda
 In the 10 years since he returned to office, Mr. Clinton's devotion to consensus has assumed near-legendary proportions in Little Rock.
Indeed, so eager is the Governor to conciliate his opponents that his supporters complain, only half-jokingly, that it is often more advantageous to be his enemy than his friend. Mr. Clinton's most vocal critics often find themselves appointed to head state boards and commissions. And while other politicians may cultivate fear as a political weapon, at the Capitol in Little Rock, there is little fear of punishment from Governor Clinton.
Brownie Ledbetter, who is widely active in Arkansas political and social affairs, said, "Nobody is afraid of Bill."
Mr. Clinton's fall from grace in Arkansas was a product not just of political but also of cultural differences: many voters saw the Yale-educated Governor as an Easterner, and his habit of appointing out-of-staters to key posts in his first administration did little to persuade them otherwise. In his subsequent administrations, the Governor -- who generally gets decent marks for his appointments -- has filled the majority of high-level posts with Arkansans.
Often accused in his first term of being inaccessible, Mr. Clinton in his later terms became positively unavoidable. During the legislative sessions, he took to walking the white marble halls of the Capitol, coffee cup in hand, keeping tabs on legislation. He put in frequent appearances at committee hearings to lobby on behalf of his own proposals, and often he could be found squatting down next to some lawmaker's chair, trying to persuade him to come around.
During the 1983 session, Mr. Matthews recalled, Mr. Clinton spent so much time in the House members' lounge buttonholing lawmakers that the Legislature passed a rule expressly banning the Governor from their private domain.
Lawmakers describe him as tremendously persuasive; he often comes armed with statistics on how a bill will affect each legislative district. As a result, the Governor managed to amass a respectable record, persuading the Legislature to overhaul the state's job-development program, to increase money for health care, to create a statewide college scholarship program and to settle a longstanding school-desegration case.
To be sure, there have been several notable occasions when consensus failed and Mr. Clinton went head to head with the Arkansas Legislature, a body openly dominated by the state's utilities and its major industries, poultry and timber. But unlike in his first term, when the Governor took on the state's special interests on a number of fronts, he limited his fights in later years to a few well defined topics.
Supporters call this pragmatism. But critics call the Governor's decision to limit his goals a cynical calculation about what it takes to win re-election.
"From my perspective, Clinton has catered to certain parts of the business community," said Bruce McMath, an environmental lawyer in Little Rock who has pressed unsuccessfully for more vigorous regulation of the state's industries. "He's a consummate politician. He's done it all his life."
 
Priorities
Taxes Enacted To Help Schools
 Probably the most ferocious, and the most consequential, battles that Mr. Clinton has fought as Governor come under the banner of improving education. In 1983, responding to a court challenge to Arkansas's school aid formula, Governor Clinton pushed through legislation to increase spending on education, reduce class sizes and introduce teacher-competency testing. The package encountered fierce resistance from the state teachers' union, which resented the testing provision, and from many voters, who were disturbed by the increase in the state sales tax, to 4 percent from 3 percent. (Later the tax would be raised another half-cent.)
Even foes of the Governor give him credit for increasing school financing and slowly beginning to pull Arkansas up from the bottom of national education rankings. But many political observers in Arkansas accuse him of compromising too quickly on other issues, like environmental quality and tax fairness.
John Brummett, political editor of The Arkansas Times, said that both times Mr. Clinton raised the sales tax, he had promised to exempt food and utilities from the increase. But neither time did he fight for such an exemption.
"It was doable," Mr. Brummett said, "if only he had applied himself."
So reluctant is the Governor to offend that he sometimes creates confusion. In meetings with lobbyists and lawmakers, Mr. Clinton has the tendency to express sympathy with whatever group happens to be in the room. Aides to the Governor say that if callers mistake empathy for a firm commitment of support, this is their problem.
Many Arkansas politicians, however, say that the practice of nodding agreement in private, then insisting in public that no commitment has been made amounts to little more than duplicity. At a labor gathering in 1990, J. Bill Becker, president of the Arkansas A.F.L.-C.I.O., issued a famous denunciation of the Governor as a man who would "pat you on the back" and then proceed to urinate on your leg.
On occasion, too, the Governor's reluctance to antagonize has landed him in some curious binds.
In 1985, for instance, the Legislature approved a bill providing a tax credit of up to $200 for contributions to Arkansas colleges and universities. The Governor's staff urged him to veto the bill as far too costly, and he did so.
That evening, though, when he called the lobbyists who had backed the bill to inform them of his decision, they insisted that he had assured them otherwise. Rather than risk the enmity of the group, the Governor dispatched a state trooper to the Capitol and had him fish the bill out from under a door in the House of Representatives. Where he had stamped "Disapproved" on the bill, he crossed out the "dis" and signed his initials. Later, to slow the drain on the State Treasury, he was forced to call a special session to amend the bill.
With time, Mr. Clinton's relentless quest to convince every interest group in Arkansas that they are gathered under one oversized tent has naturally become more difficult, and several times he has faced strong challengers. But while other Southern governors with similar approaches (Buddy Roemer of Louisiana and Ray Mabus of Mississippi) have been defeated, Mr. Clinton has held on to office and, in fact, has remained popular.
Even a frequent critic like Ms. Ledbetter can, when discussing the Governor, sound oddly sentimental: "We know that Bill loves us and we love him. He cares about us, and that's the bottom line."
 
Strategies
Ready to Attack Or Apologize
 To say that Mr. Clinton continues to live by the lessons of his early defeat is, in a way, to understate the case. Even the campaign strategies he learned in his hard-fought comeback are the same ones he has used in this campaign. Among those lessons: make the most of charisma; be prepared to apologize for mistakes, and, when necessary, go negative.
The 1982 campaign started with a personal appeal to the voters who had turned him out. Within six months of his defeat, Mr. Clinton began traveling the state again, meeting with voters in small groups, listening to their concerns and fixing them with his earnest gaze. (When his Presidential campaign ran into trouble in New Hampshire, Mr. Clinton would turn to a similar kind of micro-campaigning to reverse a slide in the polls.)
"In May of '81, I actually started going out again, making high school commencement speeches," he recalled. "I'd make these little speeches, and I'd get whoever ran the county for me before to get up a group of people afterward and we'd just sit around and talk."
A lot of the talk ran toward the confessional. Many voters admitted that they had wanted to teach the overconfident young Governor a lesson, but now regretted his defeat; for his part, Mr. Clinton said he was sorry that he had lost touch and appeared arrogant.
In early 1982, Mr. Clinton took the unusual step of running a commercial, which aides called "Mea Culpa," explicitly apologizing for some of the mistakes of his first term and promising to heed his constituents more closely if he were re-elected.
"That experience of being able to handle criticism by apologizing is one that he has repeated time and again," Mr. Morris said. When in the wake of the Gennifer Flowers controversy, Mr. Clinton appeared on "60 Minutes" and expressed regret for any pain he had caused in his marriage, Mr. Morris said, "that was all out of that 1982 playbook."
Before losing the governorship, Mr. Clinton had eschewed negative advertisements; indeed, in 1980, when his opponent ran commercials calling him responsible for recent riots by Cuban refugees being housed in Fort Chaffee, Ark., the Governor had not even bothered to respond. This was a mistake he would not repeat.
In 1982, facing both a tough primary and a general election, Mr. Clinton ran rough negative advertisements against his Democratic rivals and later against his Republican opponent, Mr. White. He never let an attack go unanswered, a strategy that the Clinton campaign pursues today from its "war room" in Little Rock.
 
Ambitions
Blending Aptitude And Appetite
 That Mr. Clinton would one day run for office, perhaps even for the highest office in the country, has never been much in doubt.
Rick Stearns, now a judge in Massachusetts, met Mr. Clinton when the two were heading off to England with their fellow Rhodes scholars on the liner United States. While most of the young men were eyeing one another warily on the pier, Mr. Clinton was already busy introducing himself, exhibiting the same gregariousness that he would later use to such advantage with voters.
"Even at that age, Bill struck me as one of the most natural politicians I had ever met," Judge Stearns said. "When he talks to people, he has the ability to fix on them and give them the impression they are the most important people in the universe. I knew within 45 minutes of meeting him that he was going to run for President."
Like Judge Stearns, most of Mr. Clinton's friends speak admiringly and unreservedly about the innate political skills he has demonstrated ever since he was a boy.
David Leopoulos, a friend since grade school, recalled that even as a child Mr. Clinton was always ready to make the first overture. "He'd walk up to you and say: 'Hi, I'm Bill. What's your name?' " Mr. Leopoulos said.
To counter the notion of Mr. Clinton as a natural-born politician in this year of anti-political fervor, the Clinton campaign has been pushing an account of the candidate's youth that stresses adversity as the source of his strengths. According to this version of the Governor's biography, the fact that the Governor's stepfather, Roger Clinton, was a sometimes abusive alcoholic is supposed to explain, for example, why he has insistently sought affection and shunned conflict.
Interestingly enough, though, Mr. Clinton's childhood friends say they had no idea until the campaign began that he had had a troubled family. Neither Bill nor his mother gave any signs of being abused, and their house was a gathering place for local teen-agers.
Mr. Leopoulos recalls going over to the Clintons' after school to play touch football on the lawn and riding around town while Bill sang Elvis Presley songs.
 
Shaking Thousands of Hands
 Mr. Clinton made his first run for office in 1974; he was an unknown, 28-year-old law professor teaching at the University of Arkansas challenging a popular four-term Congressman. It was an unlikely race, and he lost. But during the campaign he met, by his own estimates, some 100,000 voters -- 10 percent of the state's electorate -- and on the strength of his energy and persuasiveness, he established a name for himself in Arkansas politics. Four years later he became Governor.
A politician who has always believed in his ability to win people over one by one, Mr. Clinton these days is running a national campaign very much on the same principle that he used to conquer Arkansas. Schedules have little meaning. Even with thousands of people waiting at his next stop and dozens of national journalists trailing him, he will still pause, as he did recently in Corsicana, Tex., and spend five minutes trying to win over a school teacher nervous about his program for education.
Variously celebrated as "responsiveness" and vilified as "slickness," Governor Clinton's ability to engage with voters might just be called good politics. In a year when politicking is much maligned, though, Mr. Clinton is reluctant to call it that. When asked in an interview whether he thought he was a "good politician," Mr. Clinton hesitated and then threw the question back: "How do you define that?"
Invited to interpret the term for himself, Mr. Clinton said: "If being a good politician means that I've been able to be re-elected in tough times as well as good times, and have been able to build a broad base of support for priorities that were both important and that required the people of my state to change, then I plead guilty."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Detail of a portrait of Gov. Bill Clinton in Arkansas Capitol. (Kelly Quinn for The New York Times) (pg. A1); Bill Clinton giving his inaugural address in 1979 at the House of Representatives in Little Rock, Ark., before serving his first term as Governor. (Office of the Governor in Arkansas) (pg. A12)
 
Chart: "Clinton as Governor: 12 Years at Arkansas' Helm
In April, The New York Times examined Bill Clinton's accomplishments in 12 years as Governor of Arkansas, focusing on several major areas he would have to tackle if he were President. Following is a summary of the main findings.
 
CIVIL RIGHTS
More blacks and women have been appointed to boards, commissions and departments under Mr. Clinton than under any Arkansas chief executive. Mr. Clinton has appointed blacks as the state's chief financial officer, health commissioner and head of the Department of Social Services.
Yet Mr. Clinton's achievements are no better than those of many other governors nationwide, and his administration has been criticized for its record in providing legal protection for blacks and in improving their economic conditions.
Arkansas is one of only nine states that have no law banning discrimination in the sale and rental of housing. It is one of only two states (Alabama is the other) with no civil rights law barring racial discrimination in hiring and promotion. Mr. Clinton supported such a bill in the Legislature last year, but it failed.
 
EDUCATION
Arkansas has done much to improve its schools under Mr. Clinton's leadership -- increasing expenditures, requiring competency tests for teachers, broadening curriculums, setting new academic standards, slowing the dropout rate and encouraging greater college attendance.
The gains resulted in part from a court order that instructed the state to improve its education system.
Even with the gains, the Arkansas school system, ranked among the worst in the nation when Mr. Clinton first took office, is still near the bottom in most national ratings.
 
ENVIRONMENT
Clinton supporters point to Arkansas' rich supply of natural resources, clean air and water as evidence of the Governor's successful balancing of economic goals and environmental protection. But critics say his hands-off approach to conservation is sacrificing the state's natural gifts to industrial interests.
The state has some serious environmental problems, including pollution of the Kings River with agricultural wastes. To deal with that, Mr. Clinton appointed a committee of executives and state officials and asked it to recommend ways to persuade farmers to improve waste disposal voluntarily, without tough regulations.
That approach was typical for Mr. Clinton, who has usually dealt with problems not by proposing new rules but through voluntary guidelines and tax incentives intended to encourage businesses to change their ways.
 
INCOME
One of the enticements to business in Arkansas has been that wages are relatively low. Seventy-five percent of the state's households earn less than $35,000 a year, as against 61 percent of households nationwide.
Some state officials say the low income figures are misleading because they are not adjusted for a lower cost of living.
 
JOBS
A generally warm and cooperative attitude toward business, including the tax breaks, has created robust job growth in the last decade. State officials point to a 3 percent rate of job growth last year, ranking Arkansas fifth in the nation. It ranked eighth the year before that.
State officials also like to note that the 200,000-plus jobs added in the last decade included a high concentration of manufacturing positions, particularly in food processing, one of the state's biggest industries.
 
TAXES
Arkansas has been cooperative about providing special tax provisions, like multimillion-dollar credits or exemptions from sales taxes, intended to attract businesses. In at least one case, however, a big tax break induced a company to modernize in ways that resulted in a reduction of jobs.
Mr. Clinton and other state leaders are hamstrung to an extent because the State Constitution prevents increases in the state income tax without three-quarters approval by the Legislature. Consequently, some of the business-tax preferences and other factors have forced the state rely increasingly on the sales tax for revenue.
Other taxes raised in Mr. Clinton's terms have included those on cigarettes, insurance premiums and gasoline.
But also during Mr. Clinton's terms, several thousand of the lowest-income taxpayers were given blanket exemptions from income taxes.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Clinton Uses Farm Speech to Begin New Offensive

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANOLA, Iowa, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Stripped across the top of The Des Moines Register this morning was a banner headline: "Clinton Explains Plans for Rural U.S."
The accompanying article, based on an interview with Mr. Clinton, was long and thoroughly positive in tone, as it outlined what the newspaper called the Democratic Presidential nominee's "plan to help rural America." 
 Campaign officials billed Mr. Clinton's speech today to a group of several thousand people gathered in a great, green meadow here about 20 miles south of Des Moines as the unveiling of a comprehensive economic plan for rural America.
But the speech did not include any major new initiatives in rural policy; it was instead a compilation of broad, vague promises to help farmers, along with the usual denunciations of his political opponent, President Bush.
The three-page policy memorandum the campaign provided to reporters outlined Mr. Clinton's farm policy ideas with more specificity, but almost all of those ideas have been around the Clinton campaign for some time. The ideas listed included improving rural health care, establishing not-for-profit rural "community banks" to make capital more available to farmers, supporting Federal farm export and subsidy programs at current or expanded levels and subsidizing a support program for the production of the corn-based fuel ethanol.
The paucity of new ideas suggests that the point of the lightning visit to a state where Mr. Clinton enjoys substantial support in the polls had much more to do with a new political offensive than with any new policy initiative.
It is part, Clinton aides said, of a mix of tactics intended to keep Mr. Bush on the ropes, defending his record and defending his electoral base.
In speeches, the offensive will have Mr. Clinton stressing the theme he introduced last week, that he was the sort of "new Democrat" who could lead the country into an era of change, and that Mr. Bush was some sort of Hooveresque retro-President, able to deliver the politics and policies of the past.
George Stephanopoulos, the Clinton campaign's communications director, said the offensive would also feature frequent trips into states previously regarded as safe Republican territory, to force Mr. Bush to spend valuable time trying to secure an electoral base that seems to be slipping away.
That tactic was in evidence Saturday when Mr. Clinton whipped through stops in New Hampshire, Vermont and Maine, states that have not voted Democratic in any Presidential election since the 1960's, but where polls show Mr. Clinton ahead of Mr. Bush.
It was on display again late tonight, when Mr. Clinton flew from Iowa to South Dakota, long considered a Republican safehold, to speak to several thousand people who waited for hours in a chill, blustery wind in the paddock of an Arabian horse ranch.
Standing on a makeshift stage in the town of Baltic, Mr. Clinton spoke for a half hour, then worked his way through the crowd, which surged around him as he moved. The Democrat took clear pleasure in finding such an audience in such a state, as he urged the crowd to take a chance on a Democratic ticket in November. "You don't have to be as bright as a tree full of owls to know that it's time America got rid of trickle-down economics," he said.
The campaign regards the use of speeches packaged as "policy initiatives" as a valuable part of the offensive. Dee Dee Myers, Mr. Clinton's press secretary, said the campaign would now roll out one or more such speeches a week. "They will not be a lot of new stuff, but be expansions of ideas we have already put forward, with a few new elements," she said. "They give us a hundred new weapons to talk about the economy and to say to voters that we've already put out a program, and Bush hasn't."
Mr. Clinton's oratory today -- a straightforwardly political combination of denouncing the opposition and promising the future -- made clear the real nature of this "policy" speech.
"Bush promised to expand farm exports, but when the opportunities come, he just sort of hems and haws about them," Mr. Clinton said.
He blamed the President for lost sales of pork and wheat to Russia, saying Mr. Bush had delayed the deals in hope of timing them to his political advantage. "He sat on it, and diddled around on it, and finally other country's got the sale and the farmers got the shaft."
Under a Clinton Administration, he said, things would be different. Export enhancement and farm subsidy programs would be supported and made to work better for farmers, health care would be better and illiteracy would vanish in five years.
And in an environment where environmentalists are less than popular, Mr. Clinton, who often criticizes the Bush Administration for an environmental policy that has limited environmental concerns when they ran afoul of commercial ones, struck a similar tone of compromise. "I believe we can find a way to deal with the environmental objection that have been raised as to ethanol usage," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Focuses on Patriotism as He Warns of Clinton

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WIXOM, Mich., Sept. 27

 BODY:
President Bush leaned into the microphones attached to the platform of his campaign train this morning and warned of economic disaster for a small Michigan town that relies on a Lincoln Continental plant for survival.
If Gov. Bill Clinton has his way with automobile pollution standards, Mr. Bush shouted, he will "toss 40,000 auto workers out on the unemployment line right here in Michigan." 
 A few miles along the track, in Milford, Mr. Bush evoked themes of patriotism and national pride. "I am proud that because of our leadership we have far less fear of nuclear weapons today," he said, declaring America "the greatest country on the face of the earth" and accusing Mr. Clinton of trying to "tear down America."
 
Borrowing Reagan Imagery
 All down the line in Ohio and Michigan, Mr. Bush tried to recapture the soft-focus imagery that put Ronald Reagan back in office in 1984, yearning for an America where "every day has that spirit of the Fourth of July."
And he summoned scary images of Mr. Clinton's "socialist" economic ideas and the "liberal guys" who Mr. Bush said evaded the Vietnam draft and now want to invade the "real America" to tear apart the traditions of the largely white, blue-collar precincts through which Mr. Bush's train rolled this weekend.
Touring these safely Republican districts, Mr. Bush tried to plug into every political channel he could find.
The train trip was part of that effort, as was Mr. Bush's removal of a Cabinet member, Secretary of Veterans Affairs Edward J. Derwinski, on Saturday under pressure from veterans' groups.
But aboard the train, behind the noise and movement, the Bush campaign seemed suspended, waiting for something to change and hoping it is not too late. The President's aides now say privately they are even hoping for the re-entry of Ross Perot into the Presidential race. As dangerous as that might prove to be, the aides say it would at least shake things up.
 
Trying to Show Relaxation
 Mr. Bush seemed intent on appearing relaxed and confident this weekend. But the state of his nerves was evident in the way he sent aides into the train to pick out reporters and usher them into his car in pairs, as one aide put it, "to see how much fun the President is having."
In his car, with its plush upholstery and mirrored windows, the President propped up his feet and waved to onlookers outside. "We've got time left," Mr. Bush said. "We're going to win it. You don't believe us."
With a correspondent who had been reporting on the Clinton campaign for some time, Mr. Bush seemed eager to show that his campaign had the same energy and support. "You're going to eat a lot of crow," he said.
He talked about Prime Minister John Major's come-from-behind re-election in Britain this spring. "I'm not wavering one tiny bit," he said, while Barbara Bush tried to change the subject to "all those lovely houses" along the route and, apropos of nothing in particular, to whether the animal "llama" was spelled with one "l" or two.
Onlookers gathered at virtually every crossing to watch the train go by with the Presidential standard snapping from a pole above the locomotive. They stood on rooftops to wave, leaned over their backyard fences to cheer and held up signs, most friendly.
But there were also knots of Clinton supporters and pockets of discontent. At one spot in rural Ohio on Saturday evening, near a hard-scrabble mobile home park, three barefoot children stood by a sign that said, "Buddy, we need jobs."
 
Efficient Presentation
 The weekend's events were efficiently executed. Aides released clouds of red, white and blue balloons precisely on cue, set off fireworks that dropped tiny American flags on tinier parachutes and bused in brass bands to every stop. The crowds were large, friendly and often enthusiastic.
But even among these committed Republicans, there was an air of expectations not quite fulfilled.
"I'm a little nervous about the polls," said Teresa Goins, 30 years old, of Marysville, Ohio, as she and her husband, David, tried to summon an enthusiastic endorsement for their candidate. "No, I AM enthusiastic," she said. "I mean it. He's done a really O.K. job as President."
Mr. Goins said he did not understand why Mr. Bush's campaign still seemed to be misfiring. "Why have they been so slow? Like after the hurricane, somebody should have realized that they had to hit a home run."
 
Searching for the Public Mood
 This is not the first time the Republican campaign has become frozen, waiting for some event -- for Mr. Bush to name his campaign team, to give his State of the Union Message, to hold his nominating convention and finally to bring his old friend James A. Baker 3d back into the White House.
But the problem may run deeper than simply timing. Some of Mr. Bush's friends and associates say the President has trouble reading the mood of the public as the pace of the election accelerates. In this year, that is an especially dangerous thing.
In recent days, Mr. Bush has all but abandoned his positive oratory in favor of an increasingly harsh attack on Mr. Clinton.
The attack grew more jeering at every stop. In Bowling Green on Saturday evening, the President even paused to talk about the Clinton supporter dressed in a chicken suit who has been showing up at every campaign event in recent days -- to suggest that Mr. Bush was afraid of a debate.
"I'm not sure if that chicken is from Oxford, England, or if he's the one that dumps that fecal coliform bacteria into the Arkansas River," Mr. Bush said.
Cecily Kumor, a 38-year-old auto parts manager, clutched two copies of Mr. Bush's economic pamphlet, "Agenda for American Renewal" at the rally here. "He's not coming out enough with what he plans on doing," she said. "This is the first I've seen of his agenda."
 
Random Attack
 At times, especially late in the day as he grew tired and hoarse, Mr. Bush seemed to stitch his attack lines together in random patterns.
Saturday night, in Plymouth, Mich., he combined the political hot button that his campaign believes will prove Mr. Clinton's undoing -- his draft record -- with an economic assault on the Arkansas Governor.
"Governor Clinton is already talking about pulling together the 'best and brightest' -- all the lobbyists, economists, lawyers -- all those guys, liberal guys that were hanging out with him in Oxford when some of you were over there fighting and have them solve America's problems," Mr. Bush said.
But Keith Greer, a 64-year-old employee of the Honda plant in Marysville and an enthusiastic Bush supporter, said he was tired of all the talk about the draft. "We want to talk about the economy," he said. "I've got 15 grandkids, 10 of them Navy kids, and they like Bush and not one of them ever talks about the draft."
Living by the demands of his office within a bubble of security and aides, Mr. Bush had little chance to mix with anyone on this trip and tried to make up for the lack with local references.
"Others can blow the saxophone," he said in Columbus, "but I'll stand with the Purple Pride of Pinkerton."
"You try to say that," he shouted triumphantly, as members of the band in question, from the town of Pinkerington, winced.

HEADLINE: U.S. SAYS HOSPITALS DEMAND PHYSICIANS PAY FOR REFERRALS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Federal investigators say that hospitals, under severe financial stress, are increasingly looking to doctors as a source of additional money and demanding payments for the referral of patients, in apparent violation of Federal Medicare law.
A recent study by the Department of Health and Human Services said there had been "a proliferation of contracts" requiring such payments by doctors in return for the hospitals' efforts to direct patients to them. Doctors who refuse to make the payments say they sometimes lose the right to practice at the hospital, a particular burden to radiologists and other specialists who are based in hospitals. 
 D. McCarty Thornton, chief counsel to the inspector general of the department, said these payments were often disguised as reimbursement for billing, marketing or other services. He said he had examined many contracts in which hospitals required doctors to provide "payments or remuneration far in excess of the fair market value of any services" supplied to the doctors.
 
Forms of Payment Vary
 In one case, he said, radiologists had to pay half of their gross receipts to a hospital's endowment fund. In another, a group of doctors had to pay 25 percent of their profits exceeding $120,000 to a hospital as a condition of running its radiology department. In a third case, a hospital insisted that pathologists buy billing services from a hospital subsidiary.
Hospital executives deny that the payments are illegal and say the Federal Government has no business interfering in contractual relationships between doctors and hospitals.
But Federal law prohibits the solicitation or receipt of any payment or remuneration -- direct or indirect, overt or covert -- in return for the referral of business financed by Medicare or Medicaid, the programs for the elderly and the poor. A hospital or doctor found to have violated the law is subject to civil penalties, including exclusion from Medicare and Medicaid, and criminal penalties, including fines up to $25,000.
The law reflects Congressional concern that kickbacks encourage the ordering of unnecessary medical services and thus contribute to higher costs. Nearly 50 percent of hospital patients are covered by either Medicare or Medicaid. The programs account for nearly 40 percent of total spending on hospital care.
Federal officials are investigating the complex ties between doctors and hospitals at a time when hospitals are facing severe financial pressures and are aggressively trying to increase their revenues. Hospitals find themselves in an intensely competitive medical marketplace. At the same time, hospital costs are soaring but insurers and other payers are restricting payments. Seven out of 10 hospitals will lose money caring for Medicare patients in 1993, the American Hospital Association says.
 
Lawsuit in Virginia
 In Culpeper, Va., a group of radiologists filed a lawsuit in 1990 charging that a local hospital terminated their right to practice there after they refused to buy billing and management services from a company owned by the hospital's parent corporation. The doctors contended that the hospital was demanding a kickback by requiring them to buy these services in exchange for the exclusive right to provide radiology services to patients at the hospital.
"I was a radiologist at Culpeper Memorial Hospital for 27 years, from 1961 until we were ousted in 1988," said Dr. Archibald C. Wagner, who is now 62 years old. "The hospital stripped us of our clinical privileges. We were unwilling to sign a contract proffered by the hospital because we felt it was unethical and our attorneys felt it was illegal. Under the contract, in order to maintain our privileges, we would have been required to pay the hospital for billing and so-called management services -- management services we had no need for."
William A. Gravely Jr., president of the 84-bed Culpeper Memorial Hospital, confirmed it had terminated a contract with Dr. Wagner's group, but said the radiologists' other accusations were "blatantly false."
"Everything we did is legal," Mr. Gravely said. "We violated no laws. I find it amazing that the Federal Government feels it necessary to interfere in this type of relationship between a hospital-based physician and a hospital. Even if we had done what we were accused of doing, I don't see that as a violation of the Medicare fraud and abuse law."
The doctors' lawsuit is scheduled for trial next year.
Health officials and economists say such disputes are not merely an intramural spat.
"Kickbacks have been shown to increase utilization" of medical services, said Mr. Thornton of the Department of Health and Human Services. "This, in turn, increases the costs of our health-care system. It can expose beneficiaries to unnecessary medical procedures. Moreover, kickbacks tend to lock up the market, making it harder for competitors to enter the market with better, less costly alternatives for providing the same services."
The study by the department says that hospitals are in a pivotal position to influence the flow of business under Medicare and Medicaid because they select radiologists, pathologists and anesthesiologists for hospital patients.
For example, the study said, if a hospital gets half of a radiologist's billings over $250,000, the hospital has a strong incentive to increase the use of X-rays and diagnostic imaging services, and the doctor may be tempted to do more procedures to offset the cost of the payments to the hospital.
At the same time, many doctors are complaining that hospitals decide whether to grant medical staff privileges on the basis of a doctor's ability to generate revenue for the hospital, not on the basis of the doctor's competence. Doctors have challenged these practices, known as economic credentialing, in lawsuits around the country.
Doctors generally cannot admit patients to a hospital or perform procedures there unless they have staff privileges. So the denial of privileges can severely limit the doctors' ability to care for patients and earn a living.
In Florida, Tallahassee Memorial Regional Medical Center allowed a doctor to perform thoracic surgery, but refused to let him do heart surgery while he had a contract with a competing hospital to develop its cardiac surgery program. A state judge ruled in June that Florida law allowed hospitals to consider economic factors in deciding whether to grant privileges to a doctor.
Lawyers say the case is the first in which a court has explicitly upheld a hospital's use of "economic considerations" in deciding whether to grant privileges.
In California, a group of doctors asserted last year that Anaheim General Hospital terminated their contract to perform radiology services after they refused to pay $181,000 to the hospital. The hospital described the money as marketing fees. The doctors said it was a kickback.
Historically, hospitals investigated the professional qualifications of doctors before deciding whether to grant staff privileges. Dr. Robert E. McAfee of Portland, Me., a trustee of the American Medical Association, said that economic credentialing shifted the focus.
"The inquiry is no longer whether the physician is qualified, but whether the physician is economically safe for the hospital," Dr. McAfee said.
The same law that prohibits hospitals from demanding kickbacks also forbids the payment of kickbacks. In a recent "fraud alert," the Federal Government warned hospitals that they might not pay doctors "any sort of incentive" or bonus for referring patients to the hospital.

HEADLINE: Russia Loans Being Delayed By Bureaucracy and Anxiety

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Bureaucratic red tape in Moscow and Western capitals, together with quarrels over the repayment of $70 billion in foreign debt incurred by the Soviet Union, has seriously slowed aid to Russia, international financial officials say.
The delays mean that Russia will not receive this year all the $24 billion promised in April by President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl, although most of the money should arrive by the end of March. 
 The delays are important because Russian factories and consumers need Western currency to buy the imports needed to revive industrial production. Western officials worry that continued economic decline could lead to unfavorable political changes.
 
Nervous Borrowers
 Some loans have not even been offered to Russia because of squabbles about the terms and overdue past debts, while some loans to pay for imports have been made available but are not being tapped as the plunging value of the ruble makes Russian enterprises leery of buying costly goods even with Government financing.
"The money is not getting in there, that is very, very true, and we need to get those credits in there," said Eugene K. Lawson, the vice chairman of the Export-Import Bank of the United States.
Viktor F. Kronyov, an adviser to President Boris N. Yeltsin who handles foreign-assistance issues, complained in Moscow last week, "All credit lines have been cut off because we have not been able to pay for the old ones. There are no credits now."
Mr. Kronyov may have been exaggerating. The United States Agriculture Department, for example, has just announced that it will guarantee loans for Russia's purchase of another $1.15 billion worth of American grain.
 
What Adds Up to $24 Billion
 The $24 billion pledge included $11 billion of bilateral aid. The International Monetary Fund has calculated that bilateral aid to Russia totaled nearly $6 billion in the first half of this year, suggesting that the $11 billion target would be reached.
The rest of the $24 billion is to come from the postponement of interest payments by Russia, new loans from multilateral institutions and a special fund to defend the value of the ruble.
But the specific makeup of the $24 billion has always been murky. "We received one contradictory document after another about what was in and what was not, and then the dates slipped," said Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard professor and economic adviser to the Russian Government.
 
Long List of Deferrals
 A variety of problems explain Russian officials' complaints that aid is behind schedule and less than they had expected. Central to the problems is Russia's inability to raise foreign currency to pay its 61 percent share of the Soviet debt:
*Deputy Prime Minister Aleksandr N. Shokhin of Russia said on Wednesday that Spain had frozen a $1.5 billion line of credit because Russia was $200 million behind on its debts.
*A British official has said the European Community will postpone the release of a $460 million food loan because the community has not received a $13 million interest payment.
*The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which was to lend up to $1 billion this year, has only recently agreed to lend $17 million because of difficulty in finding reliable borrowers.
*The I.M.F. granted Russia a $1 billion credit nearly two months ago, but no money has been used because the interest rate, 7.5 percent, is too high, Mr. Shokhin said on Wednesday. The World Bank approved a $600 million loan on Aug. 6, to pay for critical imports to help the energy, transportation and farm industries, but legal and technical disputes have prevented the signing of the loan, he added.
*A $6 billion ruble-stabilization fund included in the $24 billion plan was postponed last summer until 1993 because of slow progress in bringing inflation and Government spending under control. Another $3 billion loan from the I.M.F. included in the $24 billion plan is on hold until the end of the year for the same reason.
*United States Government backing for $2.2 billion worth of oil and gas deals in Russia has been held up by a dispute between the United States and the World Bank over whether the repayment plans would erode the World Bank's claim to receive precedence on any payments by Russia.
 
Crowded Cast of Donors
 With 22 countries and multilateral institutions now operating at least 230 different programs to help Russia, nobody knows the amount of financial assistance actually affected or the average length of the delays. But as financial officials met here last week for the annual meeting of the I.M.F. and the World Bank, a consensus began to form that transfers of money increasingly lag behind promises.
Most of the money was promised before the fall of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, when the Soviet Union was still a feared superpower rival; very little has been promised to President Yeltsin. The United States, with its food-loan guarantees and other programs, is the only country still making large commitments, said Mr. Kronyov, the adviser to Mr. Yeltsin.
To be sure, Russia is casting around for ways to raise some money, but some are alarming Western officials. Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev said on Thursday that a plan to sell three submarines to Iran for up to $750 million would not only improve the stability in the Persian Gulf but also help raise money. It is unclear whether the deal will be completed.
Russia's slowness in taking advantage of new loans has prompted a range of explanations. To some extent, Mr. Lawson said, the Russian reluctance may reflect a commendable caution.
But the worst fear of Western officials is that loans may not be tapped because the money may not be needed. Russia's industrial production shrank 27 percent in the year ended Aug. 31, suggesting that factories once in need of spare parts and other imports may no longer be operating.

HEADLINE: Democrat's Senate Bid Stumbles in Pennsylvania

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Lynn H. Yeakel, who won a stunning upset in the Democratic primary for the United States Senate, has stumbled in recent months and lost much of the momentum she had coming out of her April victory.
In an effort to regain some of that strength, the Yeakel campaign began blanketing the state this week with three image-building television commercials. A lot is riding on these advertisements and those that come in the next five weeks, because political analysts say Ms. Yeakel, a fund-raiser for women's charities who is making her first bid for elected office, has lost ground to the two-term Republican incumbent, Arlen Specter, who is seeking a third term. 
 New polls, taken by the candidates and an independent polling firm, Mason-Dixon Opinion Research, also suggest that Mr. Specter has moved into the lead. The race had previously been a dead heat, with Ms. Yeakel coasting on the momentum from her primary campaign.
Her primary victory is widely credited to her advertisement that rekindled voters' anger with Mr. Specter for his prosecutorial questioning of Professor Anita F. Hill in the confirmation hearings of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court.
 
Specter Has Money Advantage
 Her first three advertisements in the general election campaign do not mention the hearings. The 30-second commercials show newspaper clips of endorsements by workers, teachers and the elderly as evidence that Ms. Yeakel has the answers for improving the economy. "What I want to do in the United States Senate is put Pennsylvanians back to work and put Washington's priorities back in order," Ms. Yeakel says in one advertisement.
Mr. Specter's response is to attack Ms. Yeakel, and then deal directly with his own problem, the Thomas hearings.
The Specter campaign, which expects to spend $7.5 million on the general election, or about twice as much as the Yeakel campaign, had carefully prepared for Ms. Yeakel's advertising debut. For the last two months, Mr. Specter has run a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign, including 35 television commercials and 60 radio advertisements. These are filled with endorsements and details about Mr. Specter's 12-year record in the Senate on behalf of labor, women's health programs, jobs and the economy.
After putting out all those positive messages, Specter campaign officials say they are in a good position to become critical of Ms. Yeakel. Within hours of Ms. Yeakel's first general-election advertisement, Mr. Specter ran his first attack advertisement on statewide radio and television. It reminds voters that Ms. Yeakel failed to pay Philadelphia income taxes for 10 years, and only paid the $17,000 tax bill the day before announcing her candidacy. "The Philadelphia Inquirer asked, 'Was she being crafty or just sloppy?' " says a narrator. "Doesn't that concern you?"
And on Monday, the Specter campaign plans to start running a television commercial statewide that asks voters to look beyond the Senator's role in the Thomas hearings, in which he took the lead in questioning Professor Hill on her accusations of sexual harassment by Judge Thomas when the two worked together in Federal agencies.
In the advertisement, Teresa Heinz, the widow of Senator John Heinz, who was one of this state's most popular politicians, tells viewers: "I don't think you can agree with any Senator on every issue, and I certainly didn't agree with Arlen Specter during the Clarence Thomas hearings. Nevertheless, I'm supporting him." She adds, "Arlen's long standing commitment to women's rights, human rights, civil rights, to jobs and to health is one we cannot afford to lose."
Shanin Specter, the 62-year-old Senator's son and campaign adviser, explained the advertisement's timing. "It was apparent to us that we are in a position of strength and that it was time to address the core of Yeakel's supporters, the people upset about the hearings."
Yeakel campaign officials concede that Mr. Specter has gained in the polls, but they say there is plenty of time to catch up. "I think people were worried that we weren't on TV this summer, but it's all part of our strategy," said Catherine Ormerod, a spokeswoman for the Yeakel campaign. "It's been clear all along that Specter would outspend us enormously, but ours is a grass-roots campaign."
But the same political analysts who said Ms. Yeakel ran a nearly flawless primary campaign say her campaign has been listless and unfocused for months. "The Yeakel campaign has displayed a lethal mixture of arrogance and incompetence," said David L. Buffington, editor and publisher of The Pennsylvania Report, a political newsletter in Harrisburg.
In particular, Mr. Buffington and other analysts fault Ms. Yeakel for losing the support of traditionally Democratic unions to Mr. Specter. Because labor is split this year, the Pennsylvania A.F.L.-C.I.O. Council, which has played an important role in electing Democrats to statewide offices, did not endorse either candidate. During the last few months, the analysts also say that Mr. Specter has kept Ms. Yeakel on the defensive, keeping her busy with questions about her record, including her failure to pay Philadelphia income taxes.
Ms. Yeakel, 50, lives in Rosemont, a Philadelphia suburb, but maintains a legal residence in the city. She has said she did not know she had to pay Philadelphia taxes, and did so voluntarily when her lawyer brought it to her attention as she was preparing to start her campaign.
Political analysts also say that Ms. Yeakel has a good issue -- what she refers to as the "Bush-Quayle-Specter recession" -- but that she has not dealt with it in a way that resonates with voters.
"Every challenger has to provide compelling reasons for voters to reject the incumbent, as well as some compelling reason to vote for the challenger," said Michael L. Young, a professor of politics and public affairs at Pennsylvania State University at Harrisburg.
"Yeakel has successfully painted Specter as a symbol of male-dominated incumbency, but she hasn't yet given voters a positive reason to vote for her," he continued.
Some voters who oppose Mr. Specter are impatient with Ms. Yeakel. "I want to like her, but she's not giving me enough material," said Andrea Giles, 39, a banker who lives in Swarthmore, a western suburb of Philadelphia. Ms. Giles worked as a volunteer and fund-raiser for the Yeakel campaign until her enthusiasm cooled last month. "It was appropriate for Yeakel to be anti-Specter in the earlier stages of the campaign, but I am hoping for something a little more substantive and positive now."

HEADLINE: Ft. Dix Loses Recruits, Customers, Friends

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 23

 BODY:
This old Army post resembles a ghost town these days. No more raw Army recruits are getting their hair shorn, or doing push-ups for snarling drill sergeants, or struggling to tell their left foot from their right. Streets once filled with marching columns and throaty cadence calls are silent and empty.
Seventy-five years of tradition as the biggest Army boot camp in the Northeast formally ends here Wednesday, and Dix begins a new life as a summer and weekend training camp for reservists and National Guard members. 
 The switch, under way for months, will leave a multimillion-dollar hole in the already bleak economy of central Burlington County, thinner bank accounts for local merchants and fatter bills for some taxpayers, a half-filled new $17 million wing in one local high school, and all sorts of gaps in the social fabric of towns around the base.
"We've always had a fair number of military personnel in the congregation," said the Rev. Joan Watson, pastor of Grace Episcopal Church in Pemberton Township. "They're transient. They come and go. Now, everybody's gone or going and nobody's coming. We aren't used to the impact yet."
 
Losing High-School Classmates
 Military transfers have cost Grace Episcopal 2 of the 10 members of its choir, 2 of its 7 Sunday-school teachers, and 3 of the 20 teen-agers in the parish youth group.
And they may end the friendship between Anne Marie Perry and Alicia Dodson, two freshmen at Pemberton High. "She's my best friend and I don't feel like losing her," Miss Perry said today as she waited to play in the junior varsity soccer game. "Alicia just got here in the beginning of seventh grade. She doesn't really know what's going to happen with her father."
The Pentagon says Fort Dix's reduced military role will save American taxpayers a total of $60.5 million between this year and 1997 and $25.3 million a year after that.
Those figures provide little solace in Wrightstown, Pemberton Township and other nearby communities. A lot of money is vanishing. In 1988, when Washington started talking about reducing Dix's military role, it paid soldiers here nearly $213 million and civilian employees $64.2 million. Much of the money was pumped into the local economy for food, furniture, cars and services. The military payroll shrank to $13.4 million and the civilian payroll to $17.6 million from October 1991 through March.
 
'Cut Right Dead in Half'
 Last year, Dix paid $74.3 million for contracts for everything from repairing barracks to running the mess halls. Those expenses are expected to fall to $58 million this year.
Ernie Bozarth, a barber in Browns Mills for 30 years, says he has lost 50 percent of his business. "Back-to-school time used to be nonstop for me," Mr. Bozarth said in his empty shop today. "This year, there's been plenty of stopping. My business has been cut right dead in half. I haven't seen anyone with Army connections in eight months. Billy Hamilton and his family -- they're in Fort Hill, Virginia, now. They moved last year during wintertime to save his job. And Charlie Knight's brother -- the redhead -- he went to Indiana."
There are plenty of empty houses and apartments now, on post and off. "For sale" signs dot empty yards all around Pemberton, a sprawling 65-square-mile township of forests, farms and about 31,000 people.
 
Santa's Elves Transferred
 "At one time, 35 to 40 percent of my business was military; in the early 80's it may have been more than that," a Pemberton real-estate broker, John Davis, said. "Now it's probably 10 percent."
Since the end of 1988, the number of soldiers here, generals to privates, fell from about 11,000 to 4,283 at the latest head count on June 30, officials said.
The transfers have depleted the ranks of "Dix's elves." They are soldiers, from colonels to privates, who help each year with "Operation Santa Claus," an effort to collect thousands of new and used toys for needy children each Christmas. Three of the "elves" specialized in repairing and repainting old bicycles. They're gone. "Sergeant Rolf, he retired and went to Texas; Sergeant Lofland is over in Korea, and Sergeant Mann is in California someplace," said Imogene Greener, a volunteer with the group. "We lost quite a few."
Transfers have also depleted the ranks of coaches and players in the Pemberton Area Athletic League, which provides baseball, basketball, football, soccer and three other sports for 2,000 children from ages 7 to 13. Three of the 12 players on Anne Marie Major's baseball team left with their fathers in late spring and the team's final game was canceled.
Pemberton's schools are also suffering. Six years ago, 2,000 children who lived at Fort Dix attended town schools. Now about 1,300 do, said Robert Moore, a retired Pemberton superintendent who now is a consultant for the district. The reduced enrollment will cost the district about $3.4 million in education stipends from the Pentagon, Mr. Moore said.
Pemberton taxpayers, he said, will be paying over the next 20 years for a wing that opened at the high school this fall. The wing's auditorium, classrooms, cafeteria and gymnasium are largely surplus now.
"We're hurting," said Robert Holmes, the high school principal. "This is a school for 2,200 kids and we have 1,457."
Mr. Moore said: "When we did the demographics for it, we had no idea Fort Dix would be downsizing."
The Federal Government has moved to use some of Dix's empty space and soften economic losses. The F.B.I. will offer firearms training here and the Coast Guard is bringing in an small environmental team. Some empty Army barracks are to be converted into the nation's biggest Federal prison, a low-security institution for 3,200 convicted drug offenders and white-collar criminals. The proposed prison has a projected operating budget of $25.2 million and payroll of $17.8 million.
 
Bush Raises Hopes at U.N.
 In a speech at the United Nations the other day Sept. 21, President Bush offered Dix as a training site for a multinational peace-keeping force. But no definite plans for that are ready, a Pentagon spokesman said.
Joe Farago, a drill sergeant at Dix in 1967, has little love for the old base. Now he is Mayor of Wrightstown, whose bars once attracted droves of recruits. In recent years Dix has opened its grounds and PX to car washes, truck rentals, fast-food restaurants, dry cleaners and video arcades, catering to the thousands of retired soldiers who live near Dix. Those businesses, he said, might have opened in downtown Wrightstown.
"The good-neighbor policy went out the window quite a while ago," he complained. "If the Army is going to close Fort Dix, they should do it completely and throw they key away so we can get on with our lives and maybe start attracting industry."

HEADLINE: To Hold Jobs, New York City Revises Goals

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
For a decade, New York City's efforts to stem the exodus of business to the suburbs, the Sun Belt states and elsewhere has increasingly resembled a game of five-card-stud, complete with cash on the table and poker-faced bluffs. But rarely has the game been played more intensely than it was last week.
At stake were a financial services subsidiary of the First Chicago Corporation and Bradlees, a department store chain. Compared to many of the titans of Wall Street and midtown Manhattan, both are relatively small players. 
 Yet the deals and the negotiations involving the two businesses have broken new ground.
In the case of Bradlees, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced last week that the Braintree, Mass.,-based company had accepted a promise of city tax incentives to reopen two vacant Alexander's stores in the Bronx -- the first time the city has offered tax incentives to attract or retain a department store chain. Aides to the Mayor now say similar incentives would be considered for other retailers.
 
A Failed Effort
 In the case of First Chicago, the city ultimately lost out to New Jersey, which offered a generous package of cash and other inducements -- but not before the city had, for the first time, publicly announced that it had engaged -- and failed -- in an intense effort to keep a New York City business and that it had been willing to pay dearly for it.
Although the loss of First Chicago was described as a deep disappointment, it was the first time the city had made clear the limits to what it would offer large companies. Analysts say that drawing the line in such cases was long overdue, while city officials said the departing First Chicago subsidiary was not worth chasing because it holds little prospect for growth.
Still, the city's approaches still met with some harsh criticism.
"New York City has decided the most economic thing to do is offer bribes to business," said Peter Salins, an urban planner at Hunter College. "That leads to problems," including the threat that companies may leave, even if they have no intention to do so, to extract public subsidies.
To be sure, the inducements offered Bradlees and First Chicago were far from the first, and will not be the last. Under Mayor Edward I. Koch during the 1980's, and now under Mayor Dinkins, New York City has institutionalized a policy of picking out companies it hopes to attract or retain, and cutting their taxes, offering subsidized state electricity and other public benefits.
 
Dangling Incentives
 New Jersey has responded with giveaways of its own. And, as New York's senior economic development officials are quick to note, cities and states across the nation are poised to offer a treasure trove of incentives to lure companies away.
"The vast majority of companies whose leases expire in Manhattan are the targets of inducements from other cities," said Carl Weisbrod, the president of New York City's Economic Development Corporation and Mayor Dinkins's chief negotiator in charge of retaining business.
The landscapes of Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn are checkered with corporations that have received the city's special favors. In one of the most recent deals, Prudential Securities, which had threatened to move from Wall Street to Jersey City, received a pledge in August of $48.4 million in tax incentives from New York City and New York State, as well as $57.8 million in energy subsidies. In return, Prudential promised to stay in lower Manhattan for 20 years, saving the city 5,000 jobs.
In March, Bertelsmann, a diversified German publisher and record company, accepted a 15-year city package of tax exemptions, worth $11 million, to consolidate its United States headquarters, with 1,750 employees, in a new building on Times Square instead of moving part of its work force to Chicago from Manhattan.
And in June, 1991, Bear Stearns and Company, which had threatened to move 1,500 workers to New Jersey, said it would move them instead to Metrotech Center in downtown Brooklyn. Its reward from the city: $17.6 million worth of tax incentives and energy subsidies.
"Any responsible company with a lease running out is going to look at the costs and benefits of being in New York," said Ronald Shelp, president of the New York City Partnership, which has rallied top executives of several Wall Street firms and New York City's largest industrial corporations to help convince companies not to leave the city. "Many will also wonder, 'What will the city pay to keep us.' "
No one disputes the economic risks for New York if it were to lose such businesses. And no one can say for certain how many of the companies that have received what the city now calls "retention benefits" had any intention of leaving, even without city help.
"There is a lot of bluffing going on," said Mr. Salins.
 
Importance of Retailers
 Although the First Chicago and Bradlees deals were criticized harshly by some, both deals are receiving high marks by many analysts of New York City affairs; In the case of Bradlees for what the city did to attract the business, and in the case of First Chicago for what it did not do.
"Few things could be more important to the city than a large retailer," said Gary Alterman, executive vice president of New Spectrum Realty, a broker of stores and other retail space that is based in Manhattan. He said the Bradlees deal will "put people on the streets and anchor a neighborhood" in the Bronx.
In all, Bradlees said it had purchased or taken over the leases of six New York-area stores vacated when Alexander's Department Stores, a retail mainstay for more than 50 years, filed for bankruptcy in May. Besides the two stores in the Bronx, Bradlees said it will renovate and reopen two stores in Queens, one in Yonkers and one in Valley Stream, L.I.
But its incentives from the city apply only to the Bronx stores, where Mr. Weisbrod and other officials said the need for large department stores is greatest. So far, neither Bradlees nor the city has divulged what tax incentives are to be provided, saying they are still in negotiation. But people with knowledge of the deal say they are likely to include a cap on real-estate taxes, and the assurance that tax bills will not rise for a decade or more.
 
Special Case in the Bronx
 Critics said one risk for the city is that other department stores, or even small retailers, will expect similar tax breaks in the future. Merchants might argue that singling out Bradlees' Bronx stores gives the company an unfair advantage in a hotly competitive retail industry.
"It could be a Pandora's box," said Marc A. Weiss, director of the Real Estate Development Research Center at Columbia University. "Any time you start offering tax breaks, people will threaten to shut down unless they get one."
Still, Mr. Weiss and other experts said the special treatment of Bradlees is warranted in the Bronx, particularly at the store on Fordham Road.
Other merchants in the area said that while Bradlees' tax incentives and lower costs could give it an competitive edge in discounting merchandise, the benefits of having the store there outweigh the threat. Many compared Bradlees's role on Fordham Road to that of an anchor store in a shopping mall.
"That store is the heart of the neighborhood," said Vijal Dindyal, manager of Modell's Sporting Goods, just east of the vacant Alexander's on Fordham Road. "Bradlees will bring in people, and help us a lot."
 
Help From the State
 The decision by First Chicago to move to Jersey City, taking 1,000 jobs with it from Manhattan, was called a major disappointment in New York. The business that will move is a subsidiary of the Chicago-based bank holding company, which processes dividend checks, mails out annual reports and provides other shareholder services for large corporations.
Officials said First Chicago decided to move next year because the low operating costs in Jersey City could not be matched in Manhattan, even with city incentives. The company was pledged a $6 million grant from the state of New Jersey, and its rent in the Newport City Center in Jersey City will be far below comparable office space in Manhattan.
To match the terms in Jersey City, Mr. Weisbrod said New York City would have had to offer an incentive package worth $50 million, or $50,000 for each First Chicago job. In even the most generous incentive packages offered in the past, he said, the cost to the city was no higher than $20,000 per job.
"We looked at the cost and benefits, and we were simply unwilling to do it this time," he said Friday.
Despite the lost jobs, some experts said First Chicago's departure may eventually benefit New York City. For once, they said, city officials have made it clear that its corporate largess has limits. Therefore, other companies that ask for incentives in the future may be less ambitious in their demands for public support.
"You have to draw the line somewhere," said Mr. Shelp. "The trouble with these negotiations is that whenever you raise the ante for one company, the next one coming in will expect the same or more."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "CITY BUSINESS: Staving Off the Moving Vans"
 
Some of the major deals New York City has made in an effort to keep businesses from moving out:
 
Prudential Securities, in a deal announced Aug. 5, promised to stay in New York for 20 years, saving 5,000 jobs. The city and state provided $57.8 million in tax incentives and $48.4 million in energy savings, allowing the companyto buy low-cost power from the New York State Power Authority. Prudential estimates it will generate $830 million in tax revenues over the 20 years.
 
Bertelsmann, a German-based company that owns RCA Records, Bantam-Doublday-Dell Books and Parents Magazine among others, had planned to move 500of its 1,750 employees in Manhattan to Chicago and Indianapolis. Under an agreement announced March 1, Bertelsmann said it would keep the 500 jobs in the city and set up its North American headquarters in the city. In return city offered an $11 million, 15-year package of tax breaks.
 
Bear Stearns and Company, an investment company, had planned to relocate 1,500 workers in Manhattan to New Jersey. In a deal announced June 6, 1991, it agreed instead to move into the new Metro Tech Center in downtown Brooklyn. Because the company moved to another borough, it qualified for special incentives, including a full exemption on taxes for 11 years, a $500 tax credit for each worker it will relocate to Brooklyn over the next 12 years and low-cost power from the state. The company also received tax and energy savings worth $17.6 million.
 
After having considered a move to Harborside Financial Center in Jersey City, the chairen of the New York Mercantile Exchange, the Commodities Exchange, the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and the New York Cotton Exchange announced on Nov. 6, 1990, that they would move the exchanges to a city-owned site near the World Trade Center. They were later joined by the New York Futures Exchange. Under the agreement with the city and the state, the exchanges were to receive $145 million in incentives - $100 million to go toward reducing the costs of constructing and operating the new building, and $45 million in reduced taxes. The figures were later reduced after the Merchantile Exchanged dropped out of the agreement. The revised deal will save about 8,000 jobs for the city.
 
Merrill Lynch & Company, the securities company, announced in June 1989 that it would move 2,600 jobs form New York City to Jersey City. Mayor Edward I. Koch had told Merrill Lynch that the city would match any package of incentives it was offered to relocate elsewhere. But he said at the time that the company had refused to give city officials the "bottom line."
 
First Chicago Trust Company, a subsidiary of First Chicago Corporation, announced Friday that it was moving 950 employees to Jersey City, where they will occupy 24,000 square feet and become the anchor tenant in the Newport Office Tower. The city made an effort to keep them, presenting three alternative sites. Because no agreement was reached, city officials would not disclose what incentives were offered.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The weak dollar has turned the world's wealthiest economy into the Filene's basement of industrial countries. Despite its rebound during the European currency crisis, the dollar, which fell to record lows this summer, remains extraordinarily weak by historical standards. Indeed, the weakling dollar has made United States the least expensive rich country for people to visit and shop, and for businesses to manufacture their products. [Page A1.]
Prices for natural gas are at their highest levels of any of the last seven Septembers. Energy analysts say consumers who have benefited from falling or stable gas prices since 1984 should brace for higher winter heating bills. [D1.] 
 Orders for U.S.-made machine tools plunged 23.3 percent in August from the previous month's level. Analysts said the report was another sign of sluggishness in manufacturing. [D1.]
Silicon Valley is in the midst of a midlife crisis. Many top executives say their entrepreneurial zeal has been overtaken by worries about competition, regulation and the cumbersome size of some companies. [D1.]
The White House is planning to open millions of acres of national parks and forests to strip mining for coal unless the Government buys the mineral rights from the families and energy companies that own them. [A1.]
Ross Perot's bold plan to cut the Federal deficit is coming under new scrutiny in the Presidential election. [A1.]
New York City is working much more intensely to stem the exodus of business to the suburbs, the Sun Belt and elsewhere. [B1.]
 
International
While France and Germany apparently have the financial muscle to fend off currency speculators for now, it is not clear if they have the will to sacrifice jobs and output to manage the feat for any prolonged period. News Analysis. [D1.]
The Peruvian Government is being accused by its critics of overzealousness in its attack on inflation and budget deficit problems and its move toward a freer market economy. [D2.]
Central Europe has reacted coolly to President Bush's proposal for a free-trade zone. [D2.]
The new U.S. Ambassador to Canada is seeking a "mini-summit" meeting in an effort to settle some trade disputes. [D3.]
A top Canadian brokerage firm has been embarrassed by accusations of anti-Semitism in a $5 million complaint brought by a former vice president in New York. [D3.]
Red tape in Moscow and Western capitals has delayed foreign economic aid to Russia. [A7.]
 
The Media Business
The cable television reregulation bill may threaten the future of new cable networks like the Sci-Fi Channel, which started last week. The threat is that there will simply be no room for them in a industry whose revenues would be squeezed by new government restrictions on cable rates. Bill Carter: Television. [D1.]
Much of the credit for passing the cable bill goes to the chief lobbyist for the Consumer Federation of America, who played the television broadcasters against the cable industry. [D6.]
Toys "R" Us is joining forces with Western Publishing, the largest publisher of children's books, to make an aggressive push into book retailing. [D6.]
The strike against Pittsburgh's two newspapers has raised some tough questions about their future. [D6.]
A worldwide advertising campaign is planned to explain the benefits of advertising while countering criticism of it as intrusive, coercive and manipulative. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 
Today's Column
The head of Delphi Management is a stray Democrat amid Wall Street's Republicans, and he is betting on a modest turnaround in the economy -- especially if Gov. Bill Clinton becomes President. Market Place. [D4.]
