HEADLINE: Silicon Valley May Have Lost Its Way

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27

 BODY:
After more than three decades as a fertile breeding ground for hundreds of technologies, Silicon Valley is in the midst of a midlife crisis, wondering if it still has the right stuff.
"We are definitely the equivalent of a 40-year-old male who just discovered he has a little paunch," said T. J. Rogers, chairman of Cypress Semiconductor, a chip maker in Sunnyvalewho has long symbolized the Valley's fiercely independent management style. "We've got troubles here in Silicon Valley." 
 After working 70 hours a week for years on end, founding successful companies and becoming multimillionaires, many top executives here say their entrepreneurial zeal has been overtaken by worries about fierce global competition, increasing Government regulation and the cumbersome size of some companies, as well as the high cost of living, poor transportation and pollution.
 
The Doomsayers vs. the Optimists
 And Tom Hayes, an executive at Applied Materials, a producer of chip-making equipment in Santa Clara and the chairman of an industry group that recently issued a report on Silicon Valley, said: "High-tech jobs have been growing like crazy. They're just not growing here."
But a variety of new entrepreneurs and Valley veterans say that is nonsense, arguing that the doomsayers are overlooking the extent to which the Valley's best and brightest now work on software and related new design technologies rather than hardware.
"There are plenty of ideas around and plenty of personnel around," said Sheldon Breiner, who recently founded Quorum Software Systems in Menlo Park, Calif.
And Cyril Yansouni, the chairman of the Read-Rite Corporation of Milpitas, Calif., asserted: "As far as creative ideas, this remains the nation's hotbed. I can see a lot of reasons to be frustrated, but in the end we get better products."
Some people say the pessimists are nothing more than executives of established companies, whining because they cannot grow as quickly as they once did and because they oppose Government regulations intended to protect the environment and the Valley's workers against such things as the hazards of working in a semiconductor manufacturing plant.
"Everyone is screaming that we're losing our edge," said Anno Saxenian, a professor of regional planning at the University of California at Berkeley. "But there is a lot of dynamism under the surface."
 
Survived an Earlier Crisis
 The soul-searching found voice in the report by Mr. Hayes's panel, a study sponsored by some of the Valley's largest companies and business organizations. The report, titled "An Economy at Risk," cautioned that a range of warning signs on the horizon are pointing toward the decline of Silicon Valley as a center of innovation for business and technology.
"It's getting so darn expensive to live here that we're restricting the flow of bright new people coming into the Valley," said Gordon Moore, vice chairman of Intel and a member of the industry panel.
This is hardly the first time that the region -- 50 miles south of San Francisco and synonymous with the silicon chip, digital watch, hand-held calculator, video game and personal computer -- has found its competitiveness called into question. In the early 1980's, doubts arose about the Valley's ability to survive as a manufacturing center in the face of what appeared to be an overwhelming Japanese assault.
Silicon Valley survived that crisis by shifting its focus from chip making to product design. As manufacturing jobs fled to lower-cost regions, Silicon Valley did not wither. Start-up companies thrived, new industries like pen computing continued to emerge, and bearded programmers and corporate executives replaced the thousands of assembly workers whose jobs were shifted elsewhere.
But now a tangible mood of despair looms in Silicon Valley, leading to a debate about whether the very creativity that has defined the Valley is being exhausted.
"One of the things that is striking is that there has been a slowdown in the number of new businesses that are being formed," said Douglas Henton, assistant director in the center for economic competitiveness at SRI International, a research center in Menlo Park that prepared the original report. "That's a warning sign."
Some industry executives have called for an industry-government effort to shore up the Valley's economy -- a departure for business executives known for going their own ways.
"They're going from being cowboys to becoming collaborators," said Steven Levy, director of the Center for the Continuing Study of the California Economy, an economic research center in Palo Alto.
Optimists say studies that have charted the region's decline have overlooked part of the Valley's continuing success: the impact of high-technology growth in areas surrounding Silicon Valley. Many technology start-up companies have emerged as far away as San Francisco and Berkeley -- but they are directly tied to the Valley's economic infrastructure.
Another source of confusion is that much new growth in the Valley has been in software rather than in computer or semiconductor manufacturing. Because many software jobs are classified as service rather than manufacturing, the manufacturing employment numbers have not reflected this shift.
Economists say the service category hides the real growth in the Valley -- software and hardware design jobs that have made the region the world's microelectronic research laboratory.
Data collected by the Center for the Continuing Study of the California Economy show that manufacturing jobs in Silicon Valley fell to 258,500 last year from a peak of 291,600 in 1984. During that period, the number of service jobs grew to 219,900 from 179,200.
 
Less Seed Money?
 Another area of concern is the falling amount of venture capital that is available for start-up companies. In past years the availability of such investments allowed virtually any engineer or executive with a bold idea to strike out on his own.
But venture financing dropped to $1.09 billion last year from $1.24 billion in 1987, and the portion invested as seed money in new projects fell even more sharply. But not everyone is complaining.
"There's still plenty of venture capital," said Richard Shaffer, president of Technologic Partners, a New York firm that monitors high-technology start-ups. "In fact there is no place else in the world that compares to Northern California in terms of start-up activity. What's broken is the economy of the state of California."
And Wilf Corrigan, who founded the valley's largest chip maker, LSI Logic, and is a longtime engineer and manager there, said: "I'm one of those people who have great confidence in Silicon Valley. There are a lot of people who come to work in the morning believing that they work for Silicon Valley."

"That's a warning sign." (Fred Mertz for The New York Times) (pg. D5)

HEADLINE: California's Ratings Fall

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A leading credit-rating service lowered its ratings on California's bonds on Friday, saying the tardy state budget approved by Gov. Pete Wilson and the Legislature included a $1 billion "de facto deficit."
Fitch's Investors Service lowered the rating from AA+ to AA after a meeting at the state Treasurer's office in Sacramento. 
 "The long-term outlook for California has declined as the recession continues to be deeper than expected and employment loss is very significant, even though the full impact of defense reductions is yet to be realized," Fitch said.
The budget was balanced, in part, by shifting school money from one year to the next, a move that drew criticism from Fitch.
"Even if the plan succeeds, there will be a de facto deficit from a loan of nearly $1 billion to school districts which is outside the budgetary accounts," Fitch said.
The Republican Governor and the Democrat-controlled Legislature reached agreement on a $57.4 billion budget on Sept. 2.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Sports of The Times;
Politics and College Coaches

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. Rhoden

 BODY:
LATE last week, someone jokingly asked Joe Paterno whether it was significant that the President of the United States had asked the Penn State football coach and not the university's president to introduce him during a visit to the campus.
On Thursday, Paterno, the Nittany Lions' 65-year-old coach, introduced President Bush to 10,000 spectators in State College, in what was billed as a "Beat Maryland Rally." 
The President, referring to Penn State's 81-0 shellacking of Cincinnati last season, said he wanted to do to his Presidential opponent what the Nittany Lions had done to the Bearcats.
A day later, Paterno explained that he had been asked to introduce the President because they were friends and fraternity brothers. He also said that Joab Thomas, the Penn State president, was obliged to maintain a nonpartisan public stance.
"It's a political thing," Paterno said. "This is a state university."
How much less political is it, however, when the nation's most highly visible college football coach uses his visibility and a public university as a platform to help advance the cause of one candidate over the other?
This question speaks to the evolving role of "the coach" at a time when the volatile, highly visible intercollegiate athletics industry is attempting to define a more precise function as an appendage of higher education.
Paterno was sensitive to the issue. He recalled the reaction of some colleagues after he seconded Bush's nomination for President during the 1988 Republican convention.
"I caught a lot of flack for that, I mean a lot of flack," Paterno said.
Apparently some members of the Penn State faculty felt, first of all, that sports should remain separate from politics. Second, some felt that such a public endorsement by anyone so closely identified with the school was inappropriate.
The prevailing image of "the coach" is still that of the sage-like figure who has been at one institution for decades, preaching, cajoling and banging on lockers to implore teams to win, primarily for pride and honor.
This traditional image came to mind on Saturday as Johnny Majors, the head coach at Tennessee, made his 1992 debut. Majors, in his 16th season as the Tennessee coach, underwent quintuple-bypass heart surgery on Aug. 25. Last Monday, just four weeks after surgery, he was back on the practice field.
In a steady drizzle, Majors trotted out ahead of his team for the pre-game warmups. Then, he coached from the press box as Tennessee routed Cincinnati, 40-0.
It was the undefeated Volunteers' fourth consecutive victory and some speculated that the unexpected early season success had prompted Majors to accelerate his recovery. And indeed, the coach admitted that he was tired of being a spectator. But Majors said that what pulled him so quickly from surgery to the football field was stronger and deeper than a need to grab glory.
He was raised in Tennessee, where his father was a successful high school football coach before becoming head coach at the University of the South. He and his four brothers all played college football, three of them, including Majors, at Tennessee. Two, Majors and his youngest brother, were Volunteer all-Americans.
His brother Bill coached at Tennessee for three years and was on his way to a successful career when he was killed in an automobile accident in 1965.
"We've been on this field a long time," Majors said.
This sense of a deep and longstanding commitment to a single institution, which has largely disappeared from the college coaching ranks, is perhaps the lone thread that legitimately connects a largely commercial enterprise to the university.
Football coaches are often public -- albeit superficial -- ambassadors for their universities; they strengthen old ties to the institutions and nurture new ones with communities whose primary contact with the schools often comes through the athletic departments.
In some cases, this critical public-relations aspect of the job has been a barrier to hiring minority-group head football coaches at predominantly white Division I-A universities.
Three years ago, Ron Brown, the University of Nebraska receivers coach, was interviewed for the head football job at Brown, his alma mater. Before the interview, Brown said, the athletic director told him that there was unhappiness on the part of a small group of alumni that he was black.
"They said, 'We don't want to play that experiment here,' " Brown recalled.
The university offered Brown the job anyway, but he turned it down, in large part, he said, because he was concerned about the support he would receive.
But the mounting complexities surrounding the role of coaches go beyond race and sex identity. The greater predicament, from Alcorn to Arkansas, revolves around the question of how, indeed where, the modern-day football coach fits into higher education. Many are given tenure, but few are required to teach, and while the uncompromising mission of the institution is to educate, the coaches' primary mandate is to win.
The lines between politics and education, entertainment and economics, in intercollegiate athletics continue to blur. In their zeal to patch a problem, educators have concentrated too much on reform and not nearly enough on the more difficult task of definition.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
What to Buy If Optimistic On Economy

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla

 BODY:
SCOTT BLACK isn't happy to see that the Red Sox are in last place. The last time they finished in last place, Herbert Hoover was in office expounding that prosperity was just around the corner. And everybody knows what happened after that.
But Mr. Black, the proprietor of Delphi Management Inc., a money management firm in Boston, says that while the Red Sox are hopeless, the current economy is not. Social programs provide "built-in stimuli" to guard against a 30's-style depression, he says. 
 Besides, he adds, a Democrat will probably be the next person in the Oval Office. And that possibility suits the self-described old-fashioned New England Democrat just fine.
Wall Street tends to be made up of Republicans, give or take a stray liberal. Among the strays, Mr. Black is notably outspoken about his political views. Indeed, he talks more like a social worker than a hard-nosed manager calling the shots on $500 million in client money. A financier who favors drug outreach and child abuse programs, he advocates Government spending that could send a hard-core Republican into a cold sweat.
"I hate saying it, because it's not going to happen," he said. "But for the economy to pick up we need to educate our kids." That means spending big money on American schools, Mr. Black said.
A revved-up educational system or not, Mr. Black is still placing bets on a modest turnaround. He has been putting client money into cyclical stocks like Amax, Texas Industries and New Jersey Steel in recent months, figuring that "if the economy turns, these companies have a lot of leverage to do well." Amax, a producer of aluminum, gold, natural gas and coal, closed Friday at $17.125, down 37.5 cents. Texas Industries, a steel and building materials company, closed at $20, unchanged, and New Jersey Steel, a mini-mill, fell 50 cents, to $16.50.
He is also sanguine on recovery prospects for what he calls "washed-out technology companies" including LSI Logic, a Silicon Valley chip maker, and Bell Industries. LSI closed Friday at $6.375, off 37.5 cents, and Bell closed at $9.75, unchanged.
A value player, Mr. Black buys stocks only when they are selling below book value -- "the way Warren Buffett used to invest," he said with a chuckle.
Since founding his firm in late 1979, Mr. Black's accounts have outpaced the performance of the Standard & Poor's 500, rising sevenfold while the S.&P. rose fivefold. In 1990, a clunker of a year for him, his accounts fell 8.9 percent while the S.& P. fell only 3.2 percent. Client money began disappearing as value stocks languished in 1990: from a December 1989 peak of $900 million under management, Mr. Black's accounts shrunk to their current $500 million.
With value back in style this year, performance has picked up. Through the end of June, Mr. Black's clients have gained 5.8 percent, on average, while the S.& P. has declined about 1 percent. Unlike market commentators who have seized the opportunity to lay out their political investment menus -- one that applies under President Bush, another that applies under President Clinton -- Mr. Black shrugs and says it will not matter to individual stocks who wins the election. But the passionate Democrat takes care to assert that stocks, over all, have done better under Democratic administrations.
With his own money, Mr. Black has recently invested heavily in Ginnie Maes, securities of the Government National Mortgage Association, which buys mortgages, pools them and sells the securities to investors. The most recent came with interest coupons of 7 percent. Investors should keep in mind, however, that any purchases of the securities above par come with a risk: if Ginnie Maes decline in value, and an investor takes a loss, only the losses below par can be deducted from income taxes. Thus, the investor who sells a Ginnie Mae that fell from 101 to 100 -- or par -- has no deduction. The investor who bought at par and sold at 99, however, would be able to take a deduction.
Seven percent of Delphi's funds are invested overseas, with emphasis on Scandinavian countries, where Mr. Black likes the "indigenous work ethic" on which companies can capitalize. Mr. Black, who counsels clients that he does not hedge foreign investments by buying derivatives like futures and options, intends to increase his exposure to foreign stocks in the months ahead.
Currently, he owns shares of Atlas Copco, a Swedish machinery maker traded as an American depository receipt on the New York Stock Exchange. Trellebord, a Swedish metals company, is another Delphi holding. Investors must go directly to the Scandinavian markets to buy Trellebord, Mr. Black said.
Mr. Black's accounts also include shares of Hafslund Nycomed, a Norwegian maker of the contrasting agents used in medical imaging. It is traded as an A.D.R. and closed Friday at $24.25, off 50 cents.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
The Industry Is Set to Start A Global Self-Promotion

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
THE advertising executives who toil so diligently at selling products to skeptical shoppers will now try to sell the selling process itself.
The International Advertising Association is scheduled today to discuss the details of a worldwide pro bono campaign to explain the benefits of advertising to consumers while countering criticism of it as intrusive, coercive and manipulative. 
 The presentation, on the second day of the association's 33d World Advertising Congress in Barcelona, Spain, is the culmination of two years of work on the "Campaign for Advertising," initially proposed by Roger Neill, the organization's world president. It is the first such effort by the association, which has more than 3,200 members in 87 countries accounting for 97 percent of global advertising spending.
"People all seem to know what's bad about advertising," Norman Vale, the association's director general, said in a telephone interview last week from Barcelona. "It's time to tell them what's good about it."
Barry Day, vice chairman at Lintas Worldwide in London who plans to join Mr. Vale for the presentation, said, "As an industry, we've assumed everyone knows what we do, but that's less and less true."
"Advertising is like a brand," he added. "It needs to be presented and re-presented and refreshed."
The campaign's print advertisements and television commercials were developed by executives including Mr. Vale; Mr. Day; Michel Reinarz, visual communications director at Nestle S.A.; Jonathan Davies and Charles Molony, senior vice presidents at Grey Europe in London, and a creative team at Lintas New York.
One commercial asserts that curtailing sports sponsorships would hurt fans by limiting teams' revenue sources. The point is dramatized by making one of two teams playing in a soccer match vanish, as an announcer declares: "It would be, as they say, a whole new ball game."
And an ad created to appear in newspapers says: "Did you know that every ad in your newspaper helps pay for the rest of the essential pages? The fact is, your paper would cost you about $5 a day without advertisements. A price that would make news indeed."
The ads are being produced in two versions. In markets like Britain, France and the United States, where advertising has been an important element of their economies, the campaign will carry the theme "Advertising. The right to choose."
In developing markets like China, Poland and Russia, where advertising is still a fairly unfamiliar concept, the campaign will carry the theme "Advertising. That's the way it works" or "Advertising. That's the way it works for you."
The association hopes the campaign will run for at least the next two years, Mr. Vale said. Among the group's media members that have agreed, beginning this week, to donate advertising space and commercial time for the campaign, he listed the Cable News Network, The Economist, The International Herald Tribune, The New York Times, Newsweek, Reader's Digest, Time and The Wall Street Journal.
Mr. Vale said he was particularly pleased by CNN's agreement to run spots "on its entire network feed into 120 countries."
"Even Qaddafi can pick it up," he added.
Perhaps, then, someday ads will urge consumers around the world to buy a new brand of canned fruits and vegetables If it's "Libya, Libya, Libya, on the label, label, label."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
4 Months Into Strike, Pittsburgh Dailies Struggle Against Uncertain Future

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
An eerie calm, disturbed by the sporadic crackle of a police band radio, fills the newsrooms of The Pittsburgh Press and The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette.
Ears still turn toward the radio, and pencils jot down a note or an address. But there is little reason for reporters to grab a telephone or rush to the scene of a crime. Because for yet another day, there will be no daily newspaper. 
 The four-month-old strike against the two newspapers by the teamsters' union has stopped publication and has raised some tough questions: Will enough readers return after the strike to assure the survival of both newspapers? And are the newspapers being permanently eclipsed by other media?
Newspaper executives fear that many readers may be gone forever.
Before the strike, The Press had an average circulation of about 210,000 daily and 553,000 on Sunday, while The Post-Gazette's weekday circulation totaled about 155,000. Some of that circulation is almost certain to be lost; the question is how much.
USA Today has increased its circulation in the Pittsburgh area to more than 100,000 from 60,000 since the beginning of the strike. Suburban newspapers have also gained circulation.
 
Concerns About Advertising
 Moreover, Angus McEachern, editor of The Press, the afternoon and Sunday paper, worries that some advertisers may permanently defect to radio and television, leaving the papers much slimmer. "Maybe I won't have as much space for news when this is all over," he said.
Indeed, both papers are facing a crucial advertising deadline in the beginning of October. John G. Craig Jr., editor of The Post-Gazette, the morning paper, noted that many big advertisers would be making decisions then on their budgets for the rest of the year -- which includes the extremely ad-rich Christmas season. If advertisers do not know whether the papers will be publishing soon, he said, they are likely to commit much more money to television, radio and direct mail.
The problems extend to the news staffs, where many editors and reporters are idle and wondering about the future of their jobs and their newspapers. "The primary concern for journalists isn't money but uncertainty," Mr. Craig said.
The 150 members of The Post-Gazette's news staff who belong to the Newspaper Guild are idle and are collecting about $400 a week in unemployment benefits and strike pay.
At The Press, the news staff is not unionized; its 220 members have been coming to work and drawing pay since the strike began on May 17.
But without the daily newspapers, reporters have been deprived of the chance to cover Presidential politics, a baseball pennant race and appointments of top city officials.
"When Barbara Bush was in town, I was sent to monitor it, to make sure nobody shot her," said Ed Blazina, a general assignment reporter for The Press. "But if someone did, I couldn't write a story about it anyway."
 
Behind the Dispute
 In the first few weeks of the strike, no one worried much because it was presumed that the dispute would be settled soon. The labor issues included a switch from children to adults as paper carriers, a move that would reduce the number of truck drivers needed to service the carriers.
But by Labor Day, the mood turned sour.
"People are really getting down," Mr. Craig said. "The length of the strike increases the possibility that when the newspapers come back, readers will say, why bother?"
To maintain interest in local news -- and local newspapers -- The Press has been publishing a free alternative newspaper, The Allegheny Bulletin, which has advertisements and a few articles. The Press mails the newspapers twice weekly to about 250,000 households in zip codes where subscription rates are high. But the news is a week old when it arrives.
 
Looking to the Future
 The Post-Gazette has been producing a truncated edition delivered by fax to a few hundred subscribers, and its reporters have been reading news articles on radio stations in western Pennsylvania.
The newspaper has also been sponsoring a town crier dressed in colonial costume, a whimsical attempt to raise spirits and generate publicity.
But the strike has given The Post-Gazette a chance to test how it might be able to react when its joint operating agreement with The Press expires in the year 2000.
The Press, a Scripps Howard newspaper, owns the printing presses, circulation and advertising departments that The Post-Gazette now shares. Presumably, The Press will want to publish in the morning when the agreement expires, because readers increasingly prefer morning newspapers. Thus, The Post-Gazette, which is owned by the Block family of Toledo, Ohio, could wind up as it is now: a newsgathering organization with no way to publish.
The Post-Gazette's publishing alternatives, therefore, are as much a long-term survival strategy as a response to the strike.
Mr. Craig estimated that profits generated by selling advertising on The Post-Gazette's radio news programs could equal his newspaper's profits. Although he did not disclose those profits, he said the two newspapers had not been very profitable.

HEADLINE: Skepticism on Central Europe Trade Zone

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Central Europe has reacted coolly to President Bush's recent proposal to establish a free-trade zone with Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland.
Since the President raised the idea in a speech in Detroit on Sept. 10, policy makers and newspapers here have politely dismissed it as largely irrelevant and incompatible with efforts to speed the countries' integration into the European Community. 
 "We are very pleased with the offer, but we will have to examine it in the context of our relations with the E.C.," said Miroslav Somol, head of the multilateral trade policy department at Czechoslovakia's Ministry of Foreign Trade.
 
'Pre-Election Statements'
 Mr. Somol said United States officials had not consulted his Government on the idea. Suggesting that the proposal could have been a throwaway campaign phrase, Mr. Somol added, "Everybody knows how it is with these pre-election statements."
The official said, as did editorials in several Prague newspapers, that American exporters of grain and other products would be likely to benefit if trade barriers with the United States were removed. "It's obvious that Czechoslovak products would have much more difficulty exporting to the United States market," he said.
Although they have doubled during the last two years, Czechoslovak exports to the United States -- machinery, transportation equipment, textiles and glass -- still account for only 2.5 percent of the country's total exports.
A Hungarian Under Secretary of State, Istvan Major, wrote in a leading Hungarian newspaper that the idea was "not compatible with a full-fledged entry of Hungary into the European Community." But in an apparent prod at the European Community for faster movement, he added that Mr. Bush's idea could be "an acceptable alternative" if it appeared that Hungary's European integration would take more than 10 years.
Vaclav Klaus, Prime Minister of the Czech region of Czechoslovakia, said he would seek more details on the proposals from United States officials. But the Czechoslovak press agency has quoted him as saying it would be "absurd" to create a free-trade zone with the United States before creating one with Western Europe.
 
A Sharp Shift of Trade
 Since Communism collapsed, Central Europe has sharply shifted its trade away from other former Communist countries and toward the European Community, which now accounts for half of Czechoslovakia's and Hungary's foreign trade.
Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland have each signed an interim association agreement with the European Community intended to prepare them for full membership within 10 years. The agreements have increased the access of Central European goods to Western Europe while imposing few reciprocal obligations on their still-weak post-Communist economies.
But Czechoslovakia's plan to split into Czech and Slovak states in January has slowed the country's road to the West. This month the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, started discussing formal ratification of the association agreements with Hungary and Poland but put off discussion of Czechoslovakia.
European Community officials, eager to minimize the economic and political disruptions from the split, have told Czech and Slovak officials that they must conclude a strong, comprehensive customs union between themselves. If not, the two successor states were recently warned, each will have to renegotiate a new association agreement from scratch, possibly with less favorable terms.

LENGTH: 288 words

HEADLINE: Litter City

 BODY:
Simplified driving instructions for getting to New York City from Long Island: Drive west until you reach the garbage. Then you know you are in New York City.
The dividing line is precisely that clear. On major gateway highways, one abruptly sees old tailpipes, hubcaps and other refuse. Why? One reason, obviously, is money. New York has a financial crisis and many services have been curtailed. It would cost several million more a year to clean and maintain major highways properly. But another reason is determination. 
 When the Democratic National Convention came to town and it seemed important to put on a welcoming face to the world, Mayor David Dinkins found enough extra money -- $400,000 for overtime -- to do a cleanup along major arteries from the airports. Not only was heavy litter removed; the weeds were mowed and flowers were planted.
Now that the guests have departed, though, weeds the size of young trees sprout from the detritus of Detroit, a clear sign that no one cares. That's not simply the fault of government. The flowers that were planted along the Grand Central Parkway were soon stolen. Only days after city-organized volunteers removed graffiti from along the Prospect Expressway, new graffiti appeared.
Because most highways are state-owned, the state contributes to their maintenance, but the city contends that it doesn't get enough state funds and is pressing for more.
Even without more from Albany, the city retains an obligation to keep its highways clean. Yes, other needs rank higher on the list of municipal priorities. But cleaning up the filthy face that New York highways present to the world's visitors has -- literally -- fallen off the priority list altogether.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Reading J.A.B. III's Mind

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I am being blamed for a mistake I never made this summer and a mistake I am not making this fall.
The media, which I have been cultivating for these 13 years, is poised to hold me responsible for the delay in taking over the campaign before the disastrous Houston convention. (Is "poised" a good word, as in "poised for recovery"? Sounds effeminate; better tell Zoellick to drop it.) 
 They miss the whole point. The basic problem with the Bush campaign through June was not so much the nation's recession but the candidate's depression. Before I could come to the rescue of his mismanaged White House, I had to snap him out of his own double-dip. After I did, at least we had a fired-up candidate.
Granted, I had my hands full with the Arab-Israeli negotiations, and nobody sneezes at a chance at a Nobel prize, but even that delay had a campaign purpose: Rabin, who owes me his job, agreed to our sale of F-15's to the Saudis in return for the gift of some helicopters, and now we can bring off some sort of Syrian-Israeli agreement here in Washington the last week in October. That should help in Chicago and Miami.
All right, if I had been on top of things in Houston, we would never have given Buchanan prime time for his religious war unless we had rock-solid promises from the evangelicals to deliver, which they're not doing. And I would have squelched Marilyn Quayle (note to Tutwiler -- make certain it's known, not for attribution, that I came to the '88 convention too late to stop George's choice of Dan Quayle).
But I was the one who cut losses on the family-values fiasco and got Darman and Brady to swallow the no-pain economic stuff from Kemp, so at least we had a plan to wave. My Truman analogy drew a lot of media scorn, but now that Clinton is running like Dewey it may gain some new resonance.
And nobody denies we're organized. Our spokesmen are seized with a simple message, and Teeter and Black clobber Kantor and Carville on TV. (Get some pundit to praise Carville -- I want to see more of that evil grin.)
Now they say my mistake is in botching the debate debate. How little they know.
My strategy is to bust up the inevitability-of-Clinton factor first with a Perot ratings scramble, then with one killer three-way debate.
Our cover story for delay has been that we want a panel of reporters to protect us from a head-to-head contest with a Clinton great on specifics. As a result, the media have been falling all over themselves deriding their own questions that begin "What if your own son were gay and pregnant?" Now they assume a moderator-only debate to be in Clinton's interest.
They forget the way George tore Dan Rather's head off when he dared ask about Iran-contra four years early. They missed the way Bush recently scored on Brokaw's show, in the only joint appearance so far, while Clinton talked too fast.
The media have persuaded themselves, and the public, that George is too much the gentleman to do the dirty work of destroying his opponent's character. But I want the President of the United States positioned right in the middle of a threesome, between the little guy others deride as "the yellow Ross of Texas" and the puffy draft dodger we hit in ads as "Slick Willie."
All the better if the two of them gang up on the President. Then he's the lonely man in the middle, the only one who has proven courage in combat, the only one with a plan to stop terrorist missiles from raining down on America, the only one against tax hikes, the only one you can really trust -- against one guy with no experience in government and another guy with only experience in government. Take a chance -- hit Clinton for pandering to Perot.
How do we get people to stop voting against us and start voting against them? The trick is to shift attention away from the record of the past to the dangers of the future -- to high taxes and crippling inflation. To get back the women and the youth, we have to push Perot to isolation and Clinton to intervention and re-implant the simple fear of war.
It's a daring strategy, and it requires some forward momentum before the debate, but when you're this far behind this late, you have to roll the dice.
If it doesn't work, all my spin doctors know the four magic words: "Not even Jim Baker . . ."

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Triumph and Tragedy

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Two years ago, in the Persian Gulf crisis, President Bush summoned up a vision to support his call for international military action against Iraq. Whatever one thought of the war and the way he took us into it, the vision was inspiring.
"A new world order," he called it. The strong would be called to account if they attacked the weak. Human rights would be respected. America, the one superpower, would provide leadership by seeking international consensus through the United Nations. 
 It was an appealing vision and a promising one. It combined the Wilsonian idealism that has been so important in American foreign policy through the years -- the concern for individual and national rights -- with a realistic sense of changing power in the post-cold war world. So it seemed.
The hopes raised by Mr. Bush's rhetoric then have turned to dust. Today the phrase "a new world order" evokes nothing but cynicism.
Instead of seizing the moment for constructive American leadership, Mr. Bush funked one opportunity, one challenge after another. He was slow to understand and accept the breakup of the Soviet Union, slow to recognize its republics, slow to offer help to their struggling democracies. In China he sided with yesterday's men, the aging Communist tyrants. He has had no leadership to offer in the world's financial turmoil.
But the greatest failure, the one that will forever stain George Bush's reputation, has been in the former Yugoslavia. Bold American leadership, exercised in a timely way, could have prevented much of the political and human disaster. Mr. Bush wrung his hands. He is still wringing them.
The world has a short attention span for tragedy. How many times can we bear to hear about Serbian slaughter of innocent Bosnians? But the slaughter goes on, with terrible consequences not just for the Bosnians but for the peace of the world.
Within the last week we have heard reports of Serbs taking busloads of Bosnian men, Muslims, from a prison camp, supposedly to bring them to Bosnian-controlled areas. Instead the Serbs took the men to a ravine, shot them and threw the bodies in. Two prisoners escaped and lived to tell. The episode could have come from Yevgeny Yevtushenko's poem of the Holocaust, "Babi Yar."
It happened on George Bush's watch.
This past weekend the U.S. Government said it had corroborated reports of mass murder in Serbian prison camps. A statement said "as many as 3,000" Muslim men, women and children were killed in the camps in May and June.
It happened on George Bush's watch.
"Ethnic cleansing" by the Serbs -- removal of non-Serbian families from their homes -- has actually increased in recent days. So has the Serbian shelling of Sarajevo, the Bosnian capital, despite solemn promises. The attacks on civilians have been worse in the last month than at any time in the six-month Serbian siege of Sarajevo.
It is happening on George Bush's watch.
How is it possible to square the feeble, feckless Bush of these events with the gung-ho President who rallied the world against Saddam Hussein? Does the difference come down to oil? Has he been paralyzed by the prospect of the election?
Whatever the reason, the American public understands how weak his performance has been. The usual explanation for Mr. Bush's slide downward in the polls from his lofty ratings after the gulf war is that people care more about the economic distress at home. That matters a lot. But I believe the public is judging him on foreign policy, too.
What has happened is more important than Mr. Bush's political difficulties, and sadder. At a time when countries are breaking up and nationalism burning, a chance has been lost to demonstrate that, whatever the ambiguity of international boundaries, the slaughter of ethnic groups will not be tolerated.
It was a task for the United Nations. And at this unique moment in modern history the United Nations could have undertaken it -- if there had been American leadership.
What it required was vision, clarity and moral force from the American President. What we got from George Bush was fudge.

HEADLINE: Bush Plan Protects Both Owl and Logging

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Don't Blame the Owl" (editorial, Sept. 21) totally ignores the fact that President Bush has devised a sensible, balanced protection plan for the owl and for logging. 
 If Congress would only approve the Administration's owl preservation plan, some 2.8 million acres of old-growth forest, in addition to the 2 million acres already protected in wilderness and national parks, would be designated as conservation areas for the northern spotted owl. This plan is designed to preserve 1,300 nesting pairs of owls and an estimated 17,000 timber industry jobs.
This would provide time for an orderly economic transition in the Pacific Northwest, rather than imposing drastic changes on families and communities dependent on the timber industry. Advocating tourism to replace logging is not a quick cure-all, especially in light of worldwide economic conditions.
President Bush wants balance and he wants our endangered-species program used as a shield to protect nature rather than as a sword to slash the lifeline of jobs, families and communities.
 
MANUEL LUJAN JR.
Secretary of the Interior
Washington, Sept. 21, 1992

HEADLINE: Bush Plan Protects Both Owl and Logging;
Jobs and Timber

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Economists Strive to Find Environment's Bottom Line" (Science Times, Sept. 8), on the search for the economic benefits of environmental regulation, was a timely report on a topic that has become a Presidential campaign issue. 
 I take exception, however, to the comment of Dr. H. Ronald Pulliam, an ecologist at the University of Georgia, who asserts that all of the jobs in the forest products industry of the Pacific Northwest will be lost in 10 to 20 years if the remaining old growth is harvested.
The current harvesting rate for old growth is based on achieving sustained yield. When the forests in the Northwest are harvested, seedlings are planted to replace them. These seedlings mature and eventually provide new raw material for consumers. For example, trees planted on private land 70 to 80 years ago will be ready for harvest in another 20 years.
Unless more land is set aside, the current level of harvesting need not decline precipitously. A recent University of Washington study found that "timber harvesting in western Washington will decline just 4.6 percent over the next 100 years." When Dr. Pulliam says people will lose jobs if old-growth harvesting continues, he ignores sustained yield and how that strategy assures jobs and timber in perpetuity.
 
FRANK GLADICS
Vice President
National Forest Products Association
Washington, Sept. 10, 1992

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ross Perot;
Perot Plan to Attack Deficit Thrusts Issue at Opponents

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Sept. 27

 BODY:
In the 21 weeks from when his unorthodox campaign for President blasted off until it exploded, Ross Perot basically offered voters only himself and an outlet for their anger.
Now, as he flirts with reviving his candidacy, he is proffering something else: a bold, and some say drastic, plan to eliminate the Federal budget deficit in five years and reinvigorate the nation's economy. 
 Many economists and Congressional leaders have acknowledged that Mr. Perot's plan might actually be a realistic way to eliminate the deficit estimated at $350 billion for the current fiscal year. But even those who support the plan concede that its sharp tax increases and harsh cuts in popular Government spending programs make it too perilous to be embraced by a Presidential candidate who has any chance of winning in November.
Mr. Perot did not make his plan public until he had declared himself out of the running in mid-July. But now that he has re-emerged and leaders of the volunteer movement that put his name on the Presidential ballot in all 50 states are assembling here on Monday, his plan has been thrust into the political limelight, making it an issue that President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton will have to grapple with as long as Mr. Perot remains a factor in the Presidential equation.
Representatives from the two major-party candidates will meet with Mr. Perot's volunteers on Monday, and each delegation presumably will seek to persuade Mr. Perot's followers that its economic ideas are closer to those of the Texas businessman.
On his way into a dinner tonight with state coordinators at the Doubletree Hotel, where the meetings with the major-party delegations are to be held, Mr. Perot said there would be no decision on Monday about whether he would re-enter the race. He said the state coordinators would first have to report back to their chapters. "They have to go back and brief their people," he said, adding that there would no word "for a few days."
Mr. Perot's economic platform, set forth in his book, "United We Stand: How We Can Take Back Our Country," envisions a mix of tax increases, spending cuts and Government incentives for business. And while many experts praise it as fiscally realistic, others criticize it as politically naive.
 
Little Support Seen
 "It's easy for an outsider to get kudos for raising issues that nobody else has done," said Stuart Butler, director of domestic policy for the Heritage Foundation, a Washington public policy research organization. "But the reason nobody else has done it is because nobody can get it through Congress."
Mr. Perot's economic agenda was in the final stages of being drafted when he abruptly quit the Presidential race on July 16. Some news reports at the time suggested that when he learned the Draconian measures in the program, , he concluded that it would be too unpopular for him to run on.
Former Perot aides have said that the man who once asserted that he could eliminate the Federal deficit "without breaking a sweat," was taken aback by the economic plan. But John White, an executive with the Xerox Corporation who oversaw the drafting of the document, denied that. "The notion that he looked at the plan and therefore quit is nonsense," Mr. White said.
Among the program's proposals that may be difficult to sell are gasoline taxes that increase 10 cents a gallon every year for five years, increased taxes on Social Security benefits to upper-income beneficiaries, an increase to 33 percent from 31 percent in the marginal income-tax rate for individuals making more than $55,550 and joint filers earning more than $89,250 a year, and taxes on some employer-provided health care plans.
 
15 Percent Cuts
 On the spending side, Mr. Perot proposes cutting by 15 percent Federal spending for programs other than debt costs, the military and mandatory programs, also called entitlements, like Medicare, Medicaid, veterans benefits, food stamps and agricultural price supports that automatically pay benefits to everyone who is eligible. He would achieve that 15 percent cut by eliminating what he terms "unnecessary and outdated" Government programs as well slashing nonmandatory programs by 10 percent. Most mandatory programs would not be cut, but some recipients would be taxed on their benefits.
Mr. Perot would also reduce military spending by an $40 billion more than the cuts proposed by Mr. Bush, in part by eliminating weapons programs, including the B-2 bomber and the Seawolf submarine.
It is a far bolder and more specific attack on the deficit than anything offered so far by either the President or Mr. Clinton.
"This is the only proposal floating around in the public sector today published by anybody who's running for office that will solve the budget-deficit problem," said Carol Cox Wait, president of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, a nonprofit organization in Washington.
Mr. Bush asserts that the deficit can be brought under control without tax increases, largely through a vaguely defined ceiling on what he calls mandatory spending for programs like Medicare. He has also proposed allowing voters to earmark up to 10 percent of their tax payments for deficit reduction.
 
Clinton Also Has Plan
 Mr. Clinton promises that he would cut the deficit in half in four years. His plan, based on an optimistic pace of economic growth, envisions billions in savings through cutting administrative costs throughout the Government and improving management of the savings and loan bailout. He has also proposed sharp reductions in military spending, tax increases on the wealthy and collecting more taxes from foreign corporations based in the United States.
Economic prescriptions currently top Mr. Perot's agenda, but they are only one theme covered in his book. In assembling the delegations they are sending here, both the Republicans and Democrats seem to have taken into account Mr. Perot's concerns with foreign policy, urban affairs and campaign reform.
 
Calling for Sacrifices
 Indeed, the Bush campaign has taken an apparently unprecedented step by dispatching Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, on a political mission as part of the delegation. While some historians interviewed today said Mr. Scowcroft's journey to Dallas would be little different from appearing on a political talk show or addressing a party convention, others said it debased the post.
"Bush has lowered the prestige of the national security adviser's office by doing this and has injected it into the political dialogue," said Melvin Leffler, professor of diplomatic history at the University of Virginia.
On the surface, Mr. Perot's economic plan appears to call for sacrifices from all segments of the public. Mr. White said his marching orders from Mr. Perot in drafting the plan included an admonition to protect the poor. But calling for a 10 percent across-the-board reduction in all Federal spending except debt costs and military and mandatory programs would mean that programs like the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, a nutrition program for low-income families, would be cut by the same percentage as spending that aids the middle class.
With the exception of a gasoline tax, virtually all of Mr. Perot's tax increases are aimed at upper-income, but by no means rich, Americans.
The Texan would allow tax deductions for interest on only one house for the first $250,000 of mortgage. Deductions for interest are now limited to the first $1 million in mortgages, which can be for more than one house.
He would tax as income employer-paid health insurance plans with premiums of more than $135 a month for individuals and $335 a month for families. And he would have the more affluent pay Medicare taxes on all of their income. Currently, Medicare taxes are not levied on income above $130,000 a year.
Mr. Perot also proposes increasing taxes on the Social Security benefits of retirees who have incomes of more than $25,000 a year individually or $32,000 when filing jointly.
Mr. Perot's plan is intended to stimulate business activity through the elimination of capital gains taxes for small businesses and the reduction of capital gains taxes for long-term investment. He would also provide investment tax credits for businesses and research and development tax credits.
Campaigning in the Midwest today, Mr. Clinton said the team he was sending to Dallas would seek to sell his economic plan as the most likely to reduce the deficit.
"I expect it to be very straightforward," Mr. Clinton said about the pitch the eight-person Clinton delegation would make. "We're sending a delegation of people who can answer any questions they ask about." The Clinton group will also present the campaign's proposals on health care, national security and political reform, he said.
Mr. Bush, campaigning in Grand Blanc, Mich., today, also referred to the meeting with Mr. Perot's supporters.
"Tomorrow in Dallas, some supporters of Ross Perot will gather to hear what both campaigns have to offer," the President said, "and we're going to send a team just to make a case for the agenda that I offer for America. Mine is the only agenda that includes cutting the growth of mandatory Government spending, cutting the size of Government and reducing the Federal deficit, because that is the way to give the kids here today a better America tomorrow.
"Governor Clinton offers more of the old big taxes, big Government -- no serious plan to control the deficit. And when you compare our ideas, it is a very clear choice. He wants to do what is right to win an election, and I want to do what is right to win the global, economic competition."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 1, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Articles on Monday and Tuesday about Ross Perot's plan to reduce the Federal deficit referred incorrectly to John White, who oversaw the drafting. He is an executive of the Eastman Kodak Company, not the Xerox Corporation.

PUB-DATE: September 29, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1446 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ross Perot;
Nominees' Camps Make Their Cases to Perot Backers

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Top delegations from both Presidential campaigns conducted a careful courtship of the supporters of Ross Perot today, but the Texas billionaire kept everyone dangling. He suggested he would announce by Thursday whether he would re-enter the race.
It was a day choreographed to highlight Mr. Perot's power in Presidential politics, and the organizations of Gov. Bill Clinton and President Bush dutifully played their designated roles. At the invitation of Mr. Perot, each campaign sent high-level delegations to meet privately with the on-again, off-again candidate and his state coordinators, to brief them on their candidates' positions and to appeal for support. 
 Not suprisingly, the supporters gathered here indicated at day's end that they remained overwhelmingly loyal to Mr. Perot. On CNN's "Larry King Live" tonight, the talk-show host received only silence when he asked the state coordinators which candidate's presentation today they preferred. They erupted in applause when Mr. King asked if they wanted to see Mr. Perot re-enter the race.
 
'No Messianic Drive Here'
 Mr. Perot, clearly reveling in his return to the center stage of American politics, portrayed the day as a much-needed injection of real issues and ordinary people into the Presidential campaign, although the briefings were closed to the public.
He continued to present his decision on whether to re-enter the race as being up to his volunteers and supporters. "This is driven from the bottom up," he said. "There is no Messianic drive here to have a candidate or to have me as a candidate."
Over the next three days, Mr. Perot said, his state coordinators will convey the content of the briefings to the volunteers, and will then report back with their "consensus" on what should be done next. He was sketchy on the details of this process, and nobody knows how many of his volunteers will actually be reached and express their views.
On the Larry King show tonight, Mr. Perot said of his volunteers, "They could decide the responsible thing to do is not get involved. They could decide the responsible thing to do is support one party or the other. They could decide they want me to run."
 
Willing to Debate
 He proceeded to give an '800' number that viewers could call to urge him to enter the race. And he said that if he enters, he would immediately be willing to debate, a process currently stymied by the Bush campaign.
An ABC News-Washinton Post Poll released today showed that with Mr. Perot in the race, Mr. Clinton's lead over Mr. Bush would shrink to almost a statistical dead heat. The survey showed Mr. Clinton with 44 percent, Mr. Bush with 39 percent and 14 percent for Mr. Perot. The poll of 616 likely voters, conducted Sept. 23 to 27, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4.5 percentage points. It showed Mr. Clinton's lead had dropped dramatically over the last week.
Other polls taken within the last several days, all with smaller margins of sampling error, showed a smaller effect if Perot were to re-enter the race. When averaged, they gave Mr. Clinton 46 percent, Mr. Bush 33 percent and Mr. Perot 13 percent.
The nine-member Democratic delegation, led by Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, presented Mr. Clinton today as the true heir to the Perot movement's push for economic revival and sweeping change in the nation's direction. Senator Bentsen acknowledged that Mr. Perot and the Democratic Presidential nominee had their differences, notably on the pace of deficit reduction. But he added, "Every Perot and Clinton supporter knows that we're not going to have fundamental change by returning to office a President who offers nothing more than four years of the same."
 
G.O.P. in Awkward Position
 The Republicans' position here was more awkward by virtue of their fierce attacks on Mr. Perot earlier this year, and Mr. Perot's own frequently ventilated disdain for the President. But their delegation, led by Robert M. Teeter, the Bush campaign chairman, told reporters that Mr. Bush was far closer in philosophy to the Texas billionaire because both believed in private enterprise, steep cuts in the deficit and trimming the Government.
Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, among the Republican delegation, asserted, "We are serious about balancing the budget, and so is Ross Perot."
Mr. Perot said there was some "commonality" among the platforms of both candidates and his own views, although neither major party is embracing the stern package of taxes and spending cuts that Mr. Perot advocated in an economic plan made public after he left the race in July.
Many analysts say that a revived Perot campaign this late in the election season would be a symbolic effort with only marginal electoral significance. Mr. Perot's popularity has plummeted since July 16, when he abruptly bolted from the race. But recent days have demonstrated his ability to seize the spotlight -- and television time -- and thus influence the debate to a much greater extent than his poll ratings would suggest.
All of this explains why the delegations trooped to Dallas today for a careful show of respect, directed more to the millions of onetime Perot supporters around the country than to the small group in the room.
Mr. Perot said that if he re-entered the race he would wage a 50-state campaign that would go "all out." He also said that his running mate would be James B. Stockdale, a 68-year-old former Navy pilot who spent seven years as a North Vietnamese prisoner of war.
He said he would seek "an overwhelming consensus" from the volunteers on what do do next. "We think we can have it buttoned up Thursday," he said. "We're going to move heaven and earth to do it."
 
Old Innocence and Anger
 For much of the day, in his news conferences and television interivews, Mr. Perot seemed to be reaching back for the old, can-do, up-from-the people innocence of his early days as a potential Presidential candidate. But from time to time he also displayed some of the anger that marked the final days of his campaign, when he lashed out at the press for investigating his past.
After asserting that his effort, his movement and any ensuing campaign would be solely focused on issues, he asked, rhetorically, "What are you going to do when they bring up all this stupid stuff about you?" He answered his own question: "I'm going to ignore it. Now, that puts most of you out of work. But I'm going to ignore it unless it's issues, O.K.? We're going to stick to issues, fellows. And ladies."
The meetings between the campaign delegations and the Perot coordinators were closed to the public, Mr. Perot said, because the campaigns preferred it that way. After each meeting, the campaign officials trooped to a news conference with Mr. Perot, where they exchanged effusive courtesies -- more effusive, it seemed, among the Democrats than among the Republicans.
In a deft piece of politics, Felix G. Rohatyn, a former board member of Mr. Perot's company, was among the delegation chosen to represent the Clinton forces. Mr. Rohatyn, who is chairman of New York State's Municipal Assistance Corporation, told reporters today that he shared Mr. Clinton's inclination to reduce the deficit far more slowly than Mr. Perot advocated, and to put considerable emphasis on job creation through private and public investment. Still, Mr. Perot was noticeably complimentary of Mr. Rohatyn today.
The Democratic delegation, led by Senator Bentsen, included Mickey Kantor, the Clinton campaign chairman; Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., the former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; Senator David Boren of Oklahoma; Vernon Jordan, the former head of the Urban League; Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, Gene Sperling, a Clinton economic adviser, and Henry Cisneros, former Mayor of San Antonio.
Besides Mr. Teeter and Mr. Gramm, the Republican delegation included Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, and Mary Matalin, the deputy campaign manager.
Several campaign officials were careful to say that Mr. Perot's decision was up to him, that their task today was informational. Still, Jim Pope, a Perot supporter from Washington, said after the Clinton campaign's briefing: "Their whole pitch was the Perot volunteers could do more by giving Clinton a bigger mandate for change. The emphasis was on the need for change, and they saw Clinton as the vehicle for change. And what we did should just be supportive."
As the meetings with Mr. Perot's supporters were taking place in Dallas, President Bush was in the same city campaigning, but he did not meet with Mr. Perot or his backers.

PUB-DATE: September 29, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1328 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Pulse -- Missouri;
Missouri's Words of Advice to Bush: Jobs, Jobs, Jobs

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 26

 BODY:
In November 1976, Christopher S. Bond, then the Governor of Missouri, gathered family and friends for a party to celebrate what he confidently expected to be his re-election. But he lost, unable to overcome the drag of a losing Republican Presidential candidate, Gerald R. Ford.
Now seeking a second term in the Senate, Mr. Bond is haunted by the prospect of a repeat performance. President Bush is doing badly in Missouri, trailing Bill Clinton by more than 20 percentage points in the St. Louis Post-Dispatch poll and running behind in private surveys for the two parties as well. 
 "I told these guys a year ago that they ought to be talking about jobs, jobs, jobs," said Senator Bond, a moderate Republican. "How about giving some answers to people who ask me, 'Will my kid ever get as good a job as I have?' But instead they talk jobs for a day, then they drift off again."
Like his colleague, Senator John C. Danforth, also a Republican, Mr. Bond thinks his party has suffered grievously in Missouri from the strident oratory at the Republican National Convention, in particular its attacks on homosexuals and, in the view of many, on working women. Mr. Danforth called the convention "a total disaster that in no way stood for what George Bush or this party believes in."
 
'I'm Not Driving That Bus'
 "They've put a real hammerlock on the far right wing, maybe 10 per cent of the vote," said Mr. Bond in a sarcastic tone of voice, continuing his indictment of the Bush campaign. "That's not worth much in a two-way contest -- leaves a lot out there for the other guy. Well, I'm not driving that bus. I'll go my own way on my own little bicycle, and see if I can survive."
Unfortunately for the President, many voters here appear to identify him not with his own Houston speech, which was much less abrasive, but with those of Patrick J. Buchanan and the Rev. Pat Robertson and Marilyn Quayle. Partly as a result, many do not take him seriously when he tries to indict Bill Clinton as untrustworthy, extreme, not ready for Presidential responsibility.
So Mr. Bond, facing a serious challenge from Geri Rothman-Serot, and some other Republican candidates here (and still others in adjacent states where the situation is similar) have decided to go their own way. Former Senator Thomas F. Eagleton of Missouri, who was briefly the running mate of George S. McGovern on the Democratic ticket in 1972, has seen the phenomenon before, in his own party.
"The Republicans down the ticket are running away from Bush the way Democrats used to run away from McGovern and later from Mondale," he said. "It's a sure sign the national platform is out of touch with local ideas."
 
Bush Blamed for Economy
 David Leuthold, emeritus professor of political science at the University of Missouri, said: "People are upset about the economy. They blame it on Bush, so he is behind. He tries to shift the subject, first to family values, then to trust, then to Clinton's record as 'the failed Governor of a small state,' but none of it has really taken hold in this state so far.
"I think there are three reasons for that. Houston damaged his credibility, his support was never deep enough to stand up to trouble, and he was very late to prosecute his campaign with sufficient vitality."
Obviously concerned, the President has been pounding away lately with repeated campaign visits to the two parts of the state essential to Republican victory: the southwest, close to the Arkansas line, and St. Louis County, the belt of suburbs to the west of the city that now contains twice as many people as St. Louis itself. Right after the convention, in fact, Mr. Bush was in the Ozark resort town of Branson, displaying the "country music and horseshoes" side of his personality.
Missouri, which has 11 electoral votes, has always been considered one of the most typical states, with elements of the North and the South, of the East and the West. Very roughly speaking, it is slightly more than half urban and suburban -- big concentrations around Kansas City in the west and St. Louis in the east -- and slightly less than half small-town and rural. And in every Presidential election this century except 1956, when it somewhat inexplicably went for Adlai E. Stevenson, Missouri has voted for the national winner.
 
Seeking a Real Smoking Gun
 Can Mr. Bush pull it out here?
"Not," answered a Kansas City businessman with close ties to the White House, "unless we can prove that Clinton shot his mother or something."
But others, including Gov. John Ashcroft, a Republican whom many consider the state's most popular politician, say a victory for the President is still possible. On the basis of telephone calls to a quarter of a million homes by party election workers, he argued that "a lot of people, perhaps as many as 30 percent, haven't really focused on this yet." Having failed to push through a modest state tax increase for education last fall, the Governor says he thinks Missourians will eventually turn against Mr. Clinton because he has urged some higher taxes.
The key, here as elsewhere, appears to be the suburbs, and within the suburbs, the independent voters. As these white- and blue-collar enclaves have grown, in this state and elsewhere, the Republicans have prospered. But now property values are falling, jobs are scarce, and crime, drugs and traffic have migrated from the central cities, as if chasing the fleeing voters.
Mr. Bush appears to be gaining a bit in St. Louis County, which he carried by 10 percentage points four years ago. Early polls showed him trailing; now the race there appears to be even. To carry the state, the President must win big, especially since Mr. Clinton, with his small-town, tousle-haired appeal, is doing unusually well for a present-day Democrat in rural Missouri.
 
Jets, Aerospace Jobs, Votes
 St. Louis County is home to many of the workers at McDonnell Douglas, the state's biggest employer. By announcing there this month the sale of McDonnell Douglas F-15 jet fighters to Saudi Arabia, thereby preserving 7,000 jobs at the company's estimate, Mr. Bush spoke directly to the jobs issue and demonstrated Presidential clout.
But such tactics reach limited numbers of voters, and Mr. Bush is still not doing nearly well enough among Reagan Democrats, who accuse him of failing to extend the prosperity of the 1980's. The Missouri economy is hardly falling apart, with unemployment at about 6.2 percent, well below the national average of 7.6 percent, and the recession here is shallower than those of 1974 and 1982.
In those years, however, there was no Presidential race. Recessions seldom coincide directly with Presidential re-election campaigns, because most Presidents, whatever the longer-term consequences, contrive to massage the economy well enough to have recessions clearly on the wane by Election Day.
Mr. Bush, as Professor Leuthold commented, neither managed that nor seemed to realize until very late that failing to do so would hurt him badly.
 
Stress Money, Not Values
 Furthermore, the suburbs are full of women, many of them Republicans and Independents, who are deeply roiled by Mr. Bush's tough stand on abortion and his party's even tougher position. Harrison Hickman, a poll-taker working for Democratic candidates in Missouri, said that Mr. Bush's figures among white, independent, suburban, blue-collar women were "astonishingly poor."
Mr. Danforth said that if Mr. Bush could "get off the family values, get off all the other clutter, emphasize that we have to cut this deficit, we can't just write checks to everyone, call for sacrifice without putting the country in the dentist's chair and doing a root canal on every tooth," he could pull within hailing distance here.
"Then, obviously, they would have to go very negative on Clinton," the Senator added. "It saddens me to say it, I detest it, but without it, Bush has no hope in Missouri."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In St. Louis, President Bush's announcement earlier this month that he would approve the sale of 72 McDonnell Douglas F-15 jet fighters to Saudi Arabia preserved 7,000 jobs, according to the company's estimate. Employees worked on jets yesterday on the F-15 flight line. (Ted Reisinger for The New York Times)

 All polls have margins of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, except Washington Post/ABC News which had a 4.5 percent margin of error.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail;
At Bush Camp, a Debate On Whether to Debate

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

 BODY:
Now there seems to be a debate about debates within the Bush campaign itself.
When President Bush's aides first announced that he would not debate Gov. Bill Clinton unless the format was changed, the dispute seemed to be mainly with the commission that set up the debates. But to hear Mr. Bush's backers talk lately, there is no agreement within the Bush campaign about what kind of format there should be and, for that matter, no agreement about whether Mr. Bush should debate at all. 
 Some aides close to James A. Baker 3d, Mr. Bush's top political adviser, say Mr. Baker is increasingly leaning to the view that the President stands to lose more than he could gain from debating. Mr. Baker is said to worry that time-consuming debate preparations would make it even more difficult for Mr. Bush to gain campaign momentum. Further, he is said to believe that Mr. Clinton would gain political stature simply by being permitted to argue face-to-face with the President of the United States.
Other aides argue that debates may be Mr. Bush's last, best chance to reverse the flow of the campaign. They say he must take the risk because risk is about all he has left.
Still other aides contend that any and all debates would be to Mr. Bush's detriment, unless Ross Perot jumped into the race. Then, they say, Mr. Bush should agree to debate because, they are confident, he could dominate a three-way contest.
 
Making a Scene At a Bush Event
 It was billed as a by-invitation-only event. But 18-year-old Tony Rothert, president of the Young Democrats of St. Louis University, somehow managed yesterday to infiltrate St. Francis de Sales Church in St. Louis for an appearance by President Bush.
After sitting quietly for a few minutes, he slowly but determinedly lofted a Clinton-Gore sign.
News cameras swung toward him. But before they could focus, half a dozen Bush supporters crowded around Mr. Rothert, blocking the good shots, smugly smiling.
Then the police moved in and what had begun as a bit of political guerrilla theater instantly became a scene. There was no stopping the cameras and reporters after that. They had an action story to compete with the one about another Bush speech.
Now it was Mr. Rothert who wore the smug smile.
Shaking with frustration, Dan Hogan, the Bush supporter who led the effort to screen off and oust Mr. Rothert, lamented that his counter-guerrilla tactic had backfired. "My intention," he tried to explain, "was to ask a guest to leave when he was no longer welcome but . . ."
 
Trail Mix: It's 'Quail.' No Joke.
 About those placards advertising back-to-back "Bush" and "Quail" events the past few days at the Stouffer Concourse Hotel in St. Louis: No joke. The spelling was correct. The "Quail" event was for hunters.
What are the odds? Bookmakers cannot legally take bets on a Presidential race in the United States. But London bookies can. Recently, some have shortened their odds to 1 to 3 on Mr. Clinton and lengthened them 2 to 1 on Mr. Bush, meaning a bettor has to put up $3 in hopes of winning $1 with the Governor, and $1 in hopes of winning $2 with the President. Las Vegas bookies say that if they were betting people when it comes to politics, those odds would have the right look -- unless Ross Perot jumps in, in which case all bets are off.
By the numbers: After issuing their economic manifestoes for America earlier in the campaign, President Bush and Governor Clinton both posted telephone numbers and urged voters to call in for free copies. So what's the score? The Bush campaign (202-336-7080) says it has received "somewhere around" 225,000 requests for the President's "Agenda for American Renewal." The Clinton campaign (1-800-For-Bill) says it has received "at least" 100,000 requests for the Governor's "Putting People First." What all that adds up to is anybody's guess.
The real straw poll: Moviegoers at the 300 or so General Cinema theaters around the country can ask for either a Bush straw or a Clinton straw when they buy their movie drinks. So far, more than 670,000 "votes" have been cast. And the winner is: Bill Clinton, by 55 percent to 45 percent.
Incidentally, that margin is fairly close to national polls.
