HEADLINE: An Outsider's Amex Stewardship

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Struggling to survive as the nation's third-largest stock market, the American Stock Exchange in 1989 undertook a bold experiment: In search of a new chairman, the Amex reached outside Wall Street's clubby world to tap James R. Jones, a former Democratic Congressman.
The idea struck some on Wall Street as a worthwhile gambit. The exchange's future seemed to be in the hands of Washington as new rules that could reshape the industry were considered. So, the thinking went, who better to present the Amex's case to Government officials than one of their own? 
 But three years later, the experiment appears wobbly. A small but influential group of floor traders is working to derail a renewal of Mr. Jones's contract even as others -- including some supporters -- criticize what they contend is his failure to grasp the exchange's workings.
"He needs to learn more about our business," said George Reichelm, a prominent trader who says he supports the former Oklahoma Congressman, even while describing many of his accomplishments as "more facade than reality."
 
Morale Problems Arise
 The net effect of the criticism, which Mr. Jones and others contend is the result of traders angered about a market slowdown and his moves to shake up the Amex, is that while the exchange faces increasing competition from other exchanges, it must contend with morale problems; resumes from exchange managers are circulating.
Rumors that Mr. Jones, 53 years old, is a candidate for a job in a Clinton Administration has prompted some Amex veterans to hold their fire, they say, hoping the Presidential election resolves the issue. If not, they say the pressure could mount again after November.
The criticism of Mr. Jones involves management decisions, like his naming of two former Congressional aides with no exchange experience to senior posts and what some see as poorly timed dismissals of two executives. One was let go shortly after she disclosed her pregnancy and another within days of his mother's funeral.
Some at the exchange also look askance at his failure to select a president for the Amex for more than two years, for not consulting with traders or even board members on some decisions, for reorganizing the exchange in a way that raised conflict-of-interest questions as some compliance functions became part of the marketing division, and for spending time on what some contend are publicity gimmicks.
To be sure, criticism is an occupational hazard in the chairman's job, resulting from the anger arising from trying to balance competing interests of members and the public. And, Amex officials say, Mr. Jones is being unfairly blamed for the exchange's failure to increase trading volume.
Business at the exchange has been flat for years, with the average daily volume still below the 13.8 million share volume in 1987. This comes as the Amex -- like its bigger competitors, Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange -- is struggling with some of the leanest times in years, posting a loss last year. The Amex has begun to see stronger revenues in the first six months of 1992 for the first time in years.
"There is always going to be complaining during a volume slowdown," Mr. Jones said in an interview. "The entire time I've been here we had doldrums in the economy."
The Amex chairman also attributes the criticism to his moves into new endeavors that he says disrupt business as usual, including his reorganization of the Amex bureaucracy. "The industry is changing," he said. "Any kind of change brings criticism."
And Mr. Jones has won converts through his work. "Before he was selected, I was not someone who was in favor of Jim Jones because I thought we needed someone with more experience," said Jeffrey Silverman, chairman and chief executive of Ply-Gem Industries and a member of the Amex board. "Since seeing him and working with him, I like his style and I think he is doing a good job."
 
Some High Marks
 Moreover, Mr. Jones has won high marks in some of the areas where he was expected to bring benefits. The exchange has established close alliances in Washington and won speedy approval of numerous new products and proposals from the Securities and Exchange Commission, including for its new Emerging Company Marketplace, where companies that do not qualify under Amex listing standards can be traded through the exchange.
And he has also won praise for championing more electronic systems on the floor of the exchange, pushing projects on hand-held terminals and touch screen technology.
But, according to current and former directors, advisers, traders and others, most of whom spoke on condition they not be identified, the successes have not overcome a frustration in some quarters with the direction of Mr. Jones's administration. The troubles began early in Mr. Jones's tenure, professionals tied to the Amex say, when he created the impression that he trusted advisers who knew him more than those who knew the markets.
Some at the Amex expected Mr. Jones to recruit Wall Street executives for top posts to compensate for the fact that he is the only head of a major American exchange without a business background. But, within months, Mr. Jones hired two former Congressional aides, Christopher Finn and Philip Steele, for those spots.
Mr. Finn, a former press secretary for Mr. Jones, is now head of equities for the Amex although he does not have a business degree. His only business experience came from about a year working with the financing arm of an engineering services company.
Mr. Steele, who has a business degree from Stanford and also worked as a Congressional aide for Mr. Jones, is executive vice president in charge of strategic planning. His business experience comes from working as a consultant with the firm of Seidman & Seidman. Amex veterans criticized a number of Mr. Steele's projects, including a failed effort to open trading in Hawaii.
Mr. Jones defends the two selections, saying that Mr. Finn brought skills of marketing and dealing well with people, while Mr. Steele brought wide-ranging experiences from his consulting work. "I think we have a good team here," he said.
Within months of Mr. Jones's arrival, the management of the Amex changed significantly. Kenneth Leibler, the president, resigned. Mr. Jones said he had not named a successor in part because none of the managers were ready for the job.
Other executive changes have brought litigation. During Mr. Jones's first year, Katherine Walz was dismissed shortly after she informed the management that she was pregnant. The dismissal, court documents say, was at the direction of Mr. Jones. Ms. Walz was the director of strategic planning and had worked under Mr. Leibler, whose departure put her post in question.
When she was dismissed, Ms. Walz was given a severance agreement that would pay her the equivalent of about four months' salary and limited health benefits in exchange for agreeing not to file claims against the exchange regarding her termination and from discussing any Amex issue with the media. Ms. Walz refused to sign and threatened to file a sex discrimination suit.
 
Moved to Smaller Office
 The exchange quickly agreed to rehire Ms. Walz to work for Mr. Steele as if the dismissal had never occurred. Yet upon her return, court documents show, Ms. Walz was not allowed to return to her empty office on the executive floor but was instead moved to a smaller office in a neighboring building. She had little of her former contact with senior executives, and, at the end of the year, her bonus was a fraction of what she had received before.
Ms. Walz left the exchange, filing along with her husband a lawsuit contending she had been "constructively discharged" in retaliation for her discrimination threat. The Amex disputed the charge, saying Ms. Walz had significant assignments and chose to leave. This month, Federal District Judge Lawrence M. McKenna ruled that the case could go to trial, stating the exchange's actions raised "significant questions about the possibility of retaliatory motive."
Mr. Jones said he could not comment on the pending litigation.
The handling of other dismissals also created internal controversy. For example, in Mr. Jones's first year, Porter Morgan, a former executive vice president, was told within days of his mother's funeral that he was being let go.
The action left some executives feeling bitter about what they felt was insensitivity on the chairman's part. But Mr. Jones said that reaction was unwarranted. He said he was simply making changes he felt were needed at the exchange and was unaware of Mr. Morgan's personal situation. "That clearly was not intended, and if that is what occurred, I'm sorry," Mr. Jones said.
Mr. Morgan, who was given months by the exchange to find another job, was hired by Mr. Leibler, now president and chief operating officer of the Liberty Financial Companies. "I have had a number of resumes sent to me by a number of the management of the exchange," Mr. Leibler said.
Even as the changes were taking place in the executive offices, the Jones administration was worrying some traders. Some chafed in early 1991, when Mr. Jones said in a news report that the Amex had been headed for one of its best years in 1990 until investors got nervous after the invasion of Kuwait by Saddam Hussein in August. But the trading average on the exchange had reached its high for the year months earlier, on Jan. 5.
Even Mr. Jones's biggest success, the Emerging Company Marketplace, has brought some criticism. The concept for creating a separate Amex marketplace for companies that did not meet Amex listing standards had been around long before Mr. Jones came. But it was often dismissed for fear that it would attract companies whose listings would prove embarrassing.
It did. In what many now contend was a blunder, Mr. Jones expanded on the idea of simply offering an auction market option for over-the- counter companies by seeming to endorse certain issues. At a huge press conference, complete with balloons and flags, Mr. Jones said that an Amex committee, through a careful screening process, had uncovered the future jewels of the market. Those claims came back to haunt the exchange as the troubles with some of the issues started coming out, including PNF Inc., whose largest shareholder was banned years ago from association with the Amex.
Mr. Jones says that despite the troubles the new venture is a success and signals novel approaches for the exchange's future, although he does believe that some of the marketing for it was misplaced. But some Amex officials contend that the way the marketplace was presented and the way Amex reacted to the troubles reflect Mr. Jones's focus on public relations.
"There seems to be this tremendous concern and fear of the press," Mr. Reichelm, the trader, said. "With E.C.M., in response to the press, we should have listed 50 more stocks. Instead, we just froze at the wheel. We chose the Washington attitude of make it look good even if it is not."

HEADLINE: Hard Times for Women in Construction

 BODY:
Lisa Narducci gets up at 5 every morning to commute to the Coney Island Water Pollution Control Project. With the acrid stench of sewage rising around her, she drills and saws through plywood, crawls over hot concrete and lifts wooden planks -- all part of her day's work as a carpenter.
There are no separate changing rooms for her or the other five women on the job. There are no separate bathrooms. The trailers have pin-ups of naked women on the wall. Sometimes, a co-worker or supervisor says he doubts she can do her job. 
 Still, she is glad to be there.
Ms. Narducci and other women in the building trades find themselves fighting battles they thought they won years ago. They fight for the few jobs left in the depressed construction market. They face competitive fears and pejorative comments from their male co-workers. And they are reluctant to complain about working conditions or harassment, believing that troublemakers get dismissed quickly when there are plenty of unemployed replacements.
 
An Uneasy Peace
 After winning a foothold in the late 1970's and achieving an uneasy peace with male co-workers and bosses in the 1980's, women in the construction industry are seeing their numbers dwindle and their gains disappear. Some quit because the early hours, heavy lifting and danger of the work were not to their liking. But others left because they tired of what the felt was a hostile environment.
There are no definite figures about the number of women in the construction trades in New York City, in large part because union officials say they do not track their membership by sex. In 1990, the NOW Legal Defense Fund estimated that women made up about 4 percent of the almost 100,000 workers in the skilled trades, a number with which most industry experts agree. But they say the number has dropped since then.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics, which only keeps nationwide figures on the women in the construction trades, says women have dropped back from the minuscule advances they had made in the 1980's. The most recent figures show that women held 81,000 jobs in the building trades in 1991, or 1.9 percent of the total, down from 2 percent the year before.
In New York City, women may be having a particularly hard time because of the hard times hurting all construction workers: union officials estimate that between 50 and 60 percent of the work force is currently unemployed.
"Women who would have entered the industry are not entering because of the job situation," said Raymond O'Kane, assistant to the president of the District Council of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters. "And women who are part of the union but have a family to feed or themselves to feed are dropping out because they can't find work."
But Peggy Crull, the director of research for the city's Human Rights Commission, said the recession was not totally to blame.
 
'Women Are Discouraged
 "It's not that the numbers are dropping because of the recession," said Ms. Crull, who is compiling a report from hearings the commission held in 1990 on minorities in the construction trades. "The numbers are dropping because women are discouraged. My sense is that women are being discouraged."
The women who do remain readily admit such discouragement. Ms. Narducci, who began training as a carpenter 11 years ago, said she was less willing than she used to be to ask for such things as separate bathrooms.
"I am sticking my neck out," she said. "Here I am waltzing onto the job, telling them to hire more women, and now I want a bathroom."
And the stereotypes women encounter on the job have not changed very much, despite years of women getting the work done.
Paul McEnery, project manager for the Perini Corporation, the contractor on the Coney Island sewage plant site, which is actually in Sheepshead Bay, said women cannot be expected to lift 200-pound slabs of concrete, for instance. But Ms. Narducci and another carpenter, Dolores Laureano, built a small upper floor of the plant out of those very concrete slabs.
Ms. Narducci said one of her foremen had questioned whether she could carry the wooden poles used to make scaffolding.
"That really upset me, because once they think you can't handle something, then you're expendable," she said. "Even if the doubts are only in their imagination."
One of the general foremen on the site, Gene Kelly, said he could trust Ms. Narducci and Ms. Laureano to do any work he gave them. "The only problem," he joked, "is I can't yell at them the same way I do my other workers." Why? "I'm afraid they would cry."
In the face of such enduring stereotypes and of continued harassment, women are leaving or not entering the trades, and those that remain are trying to maintain the few concessions they have won over the years. Many of them regret that they did not do more to recruit other women in the 1980's, when openings were plentiful during the city's building boom.
"We all think that the heyday was in the 80's, but it wasn't much of a heyday," said Barbara Trees, a carpenter. "We were all learning our trades, trying to survive on our job sites, trying to get used to it all. I don't think we had a chance to build a movement."
That is why she and Ms. Narducci began a women's committee of carpenters this summer. They want to push to maintain the number of women in the trade and to look for ways to recruit more.
Both women were surprised when the District Council of the union responded favorably to their idea for a committee. In many ways, the women and their union leaders acknowledge they are working toward more common goals than ever before.
The women want job security and better working conditions, and they know the union must be part of providing those. The union leaders need more strong pro-union employees and enough women to fill hiring goals on government jobs, and they realize that their female members can help them with both.
At the Coney Island water pollution plant, as on most federally financed projects, the declining number of women vying for jobs means it is more difficult to meet the 6.9 percent hiring goal fixed by the Department of Labor. There are more than 90 workers on the site, 6 of whom are women.
That may sound like it is easier for women to get hired these days but that is not always the case. For instance, the contractor was only able to meet the goal when Ms. Narducci, who was not sent by her union, asked for a job and then recommended another female carpenter.
Most contractors do not have to meet hiring goals, because they only exist on Federal jobs. And they say they are glad to avoid the problem.
"It's difficult to set a number or a percentage and say there have to be that many women on the site," said K. Robert Najarian, a vice president of A-J Contracting Company Inc. "There may not be enough women in certain trades. That may create some false economics."
Frank McArdle, managing director of the General Contractors Association, said the contractors his trade group represents -- more than 700 heavy and highway construction companies -- must comply with Federal hiring numbers on Government jobs. He said the only trade that has caused a consistent problem has been the iron workers, who have had difficulty finding women who can pass the agility and confidence tests. The union and the State Department of Transportation have had meetings to discuss recruiting more qualified women for the trade.
Some women resent the pressure to put them on Government-financed jobs. But private jobs have all but ceased in New York, as have those financed by the city. And with them have gone most chances for younger women who want to break into the building trades. The electricians' union, for example, stopped its apprenticeship program this year.
Many contractors are also hiring nonunion employees, which means there is even less pressure to hire women.
Nontraditional Employment for Women, a local organization that provides training for women, has cut back its programs for would-be construction workers. In July the group began a new program to train women for maintenance and repair jobs, which pay less than construction jobs but have more openings at this time.
Even more experienced women are becoming fed up with continuing battles on the work site and in the union hall.
"There is a high dropout rate among women in general," said Laura Kelber, who has worked as an electrician for 11 years, "especially when they become journeywomen and realize that they're not going to be treated any better."
Mr. McArdle of the contractors' association said he did not see the high dropout rate in the construction trades as a gender issue. "A lot of people decide this is not what they want to be doing for the rest of their lives," he said.
But the women who remain in the construction trades say the benefits are worth fighting for, and many remain optimistic. "Think about those women 90 years ago, who died in jail on hunger strikes for their rights," Ms. Narducci said. "It could be worse."
The women point to the high pay they receive for the work they love and say that is all they've ever wanted -- to be able to do their work and earn wages equal to men's.
"Women working in the construction trades was not a romantic idea," Ms. Trees said. "We were saying, 'If you won't pay us equally for so-called women's work, we will go where you are and you will have to pay us the same.' "

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 25.94 in a Rebound From Last Week's Decline

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks closed sharply higher yesterday, rebounding on bargain hunting after the previous session's loss of nearly 38 points.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 25.94 points at 3,276.26. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was a modest 158.8 million shares, down from 213.7 million in Friday's active session.
In the broader market, advancing issues led declines, 908 to 791.
 
Decline in Nasdaq
 Despite the gain in blue chips, Nasdaq stocks ended lower on continued weakness in health-care issues and losses in some high-technology stocks.
A recovery in General Motors' stock after news of a tentative strike settlement at a Lansing, Mich., plant helped the entire Dow industrial average, said Ron Doran, director of institutional trading at C. L. King & Associates.
The strike that began on Friday, the second in a month for the auto maker, was tentatively settled yesterday afternoon, the United Automobile Workers union said. G.M.'s shares rose enough in late trading yesterday to finish at 32, unchanged from Friday's close.
Another analyst, David Holt, director of technical research at Wedbush Morgan, said of the market, "Right now, I don't see anything on the horizon that has the power to shake the market out of its trading range either on the upside or the downside."
News on the economy, earnings and politics has essentially remained the same, even though the possible re-entry of Ross Perot into the Presidential race has caused some nervousness.
"Oils were strong," one trader said. But other than that, he said, "there's no business going on."
Investors are eager to see if Friday's employment report for September will provide the Federal Reserve with a reason to lower interest rates.
Robert Caputo of the Swiss Bank Corporation said stocks were reversing some of last week's selling. "We took a lot of damage last week across the board," he said.
In addition, some of the drug stocks may be looking more attractive after their recent battering, he said.
Mr. Holt said the cessation of end-of-quarter portfolio adjustments also contributed to the slower trading. "Last Friday was the last day institutions could, on a trading basis, execute their window dressing," he said.
As for politics, Mr. Caputo said the market "seems to be trying to adjust to the probability of a Clinton win."
Amid the uncertainties, stock selection will be crucial, he said. "It has become a stock pickers' market without a clear trend other than it will stay choppy through the elections."
Some medical-related stocks continued to decline as concerns lingered about possible price controls on drugs and medical services.
United States Healthcare was down 3 1/4, to 61, and Amgen lost 1 3/8, to 62 1/2. Merck was off 3/8, to 43 3/8; Schering-Plough fell 1 3/4, to 55 1/2; United States Surgical sank 1 5/8, to 61 3/4; HealthSouth fell 2, to 18 3/4, and T2 Medical lost 5/8, to 21 1/4.
Among high-technology issues, Microsoft dropped 1 3/4, to 77, and Apple Computer slipped 3/4, to 44 3/4.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 2.27, to 416.62. But the American Stock Exchange index lost 1.24, to 377.25.
The New York Stock Exchange's composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.97, to 228.70. The average share gained 15 cents.
The Nasdaq index was down 1.86, to 575.34.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of Big Board, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 4,009.500, up 12.118, or 0.30 percent.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Competing Plans For Californians

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
CALIFORNIA, hit hard by a recession compounded by military cutbacks and permanently lost jobs in electronics, is giving special attention to health care policy and political issues. At least six million Californians do not have health insurance. With 9.8 percent unemployment, even more people are in danger of losing coverage.
This week Gov. Pete Wilson is expected to sign a measure that would make it harder for insurers to raise premiums steeply for small businesses when an employee becomes seriously ill. 
 In another important development, the Governor is expected to veto a bill sponsored by the State Insurance Commissioner, John Garamendi, that would take steps toward establishing a medical system financed by a 7.75 percent payroll tax.
And the California Medical Association, which has 38,000 physician members, is asking voters to approve Proposition 166 on Nov. 3. It would require employers to pay at least 75 percent of basic health costs for employees who work at least 17.5 hours a week.
The medical association proposal would require insurers to offer coverage to businesses with 100 or fewer employees, at premiums within 30 percent of a standard community rate in their geographic region. The doctors say the measure would assure coverage to at least four million small business employees and their dependents.
Dr. Richard Corlin, a Santa Monica gastroenterologist who is the association's president, said the proposal was favored by a 2-to-1 margin in polls commissioned by the group. But the measure has been attacked by consumer, business and labor groups. Anne Eowan, counsel of the Association of California Life Insurance Companies, said, "Their polls are different from our polls."
Maryann O'Sullivan, executive director of Health Access, which favors a government single-payer system like Canada's, said the insurance industry was expected to "spend millions against Proposition 166."
Ms. Eowan added, "The public is very sensitive to the effects the proposal might have on the economy -- jobs, jobs, jobs." A study by University of California economists for the Bay Area Business Group on Health, a group of 15 large employers, contends that Proposition 166 would cost small businesses $6.2 billion a year.
Patricia Powers, the group's executive director, contended that the uninsured would get less than one-fourth of the money because most of it would go toward lightening the load of large employers and insurers, which now pay indirectly for the uninsured through higher charges, and doctors and hospitals, who would have fewer unpaid bills.
As for the Garamendi proposal, the Commissioner's aides said he would continue to push it, even if vetoed. He may ask private foundations to finance a commission to flesh out the details.
Ms. O'Sullivan said there was "antagonism" between the Commissioner, a Democrat, and the Governor, a Republican, who are widely expected to end up as rivals in the 1994 governor's race. Dr. Corlin accused Mr. Garamendi of planning to use health care reform "as a campaign issue." Under the Garamendi bill, the Democrats would appoint a majority of the commission to carry out the proposal.
Many business executives and health policy experts say they are intrigued by the Garamendi plan. It calls for health maintenance organizations and other managed-care networks of doctors and hospitals to bid competitively on regional contracts, which would provide basic coverage for all Californians. In both the Garamendi plan and the doctors' Proposition 166, there would be a unified system, consolidating employee health benefits with medical coverage under workers' compensation and auto insurance. How to accomplish all this is still to be detailed. It would eventually require legislative approval.
Michael R. Peevey, president of the Southern California Edison Company, which has worked vigorously to keep employee medical costs under control, had urged the Governor to approve the Garamendi bill. "California's health care system is in crisis," Mr. Peevey said in a Sept. 17 letter to Mr. Wilson. Mr. Peevey added that a commission to work out "comprehensive and far-reaching reforms" would be "a very workable model" for seeking solutions to the problems of containing costs and providing universally available care.
But Dr. Corlin and Ms. Eowan at the life insurance association said the 7.75 percent payroll tax in the Garamendi plan could fall short in paying for universal coverage. "It might be grossly underfunded," Ms. Eowan said.
People on all sides of the California health insurance battle say that the state, which claims to have one-eighth of the nation's population and one-sixth of the national economy, can be a model for national solutions to the difficult problems of health care. But some noted that the new Congress and a possible Clinton Presidential victory would move the issue to Washington. Even if that happens, Mr. Garamendi will "go forward with developing and promoting this model in Washington and other states as well as California," said Walter Zelman, a deputy commissioner in the California insurance department.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Off the Trail -- Visits With Americans;
To Ex-Deserter, Urban War Should be the Real Debate

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Jack Colhoun wears a gray pigtail, a modest relic of a life disrupted by seven years of exile and protest in Canada as a military deserter during the Vietnam War.
The real pain for him in this year's Presidential campaign is that his old issue, the war, has emerged only as a kind of grotesque aside in his eyes, a cynical evasion of far more immediate problems, he says. He cites an issue haunting America right outside his window here: the nightly specter of teen-agers shooting at one another with semiautomatic pistols as a symptom of scandalous national failure. 
 "I'm not talking urban America in the abstract; I'm talking about my daily life, the gunfire, two killings in the last two months," says the 47-year-old freelance political writer and resident of the lethally tattered Capitol Hill neighborhood.
"I mean, Vietnam? This is an absurd debate," says this voter with a Ph.D. in American history who scoffs from ground zero at this year's Beltway political stratagems.
 
Two Separate Avoidances
 At first glance, considerable self-interest might be expected in Mr. Colhoun's abhorring the latest echo of Vietnam. But he rolls his eyes at the chance to debate the relative manliness of Bill Clinton and Dan Quayle in their separate avoidances of the military draft in the long-ago.
They only proved they were veterans in good standing among the Vietnam-era middle class, says Mr. Colhoun, begging the nation to look with a quick, cold eye at the statistics of that still unreconciled time and then shift its passion toward the future, not the past.
"It was the middle-class birthright to explore the many options for avoiding the draft," he says, recalling a candid, controversial memorandum 27 years ago by Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service. He wrote that manpower needs were only one task of a system that was also "heavily occupied" in shunting registrants toward deferments and so "developing more effective human beings in the national interest."
Mr. Colhoun notes, "The statistics clearly show that the vast majority of the male population of the Vietnam generation found ways within the system to avoid the war -- entirely legal loopholes built into the system."
"They paid no price, and the numbers are astounding," he says, reading from the uncontested documentation of the Ford Administration's clemency board. "There were 26.8 million men in the Vietnam generation and 15.4 million of them were deferred, exempted or disqualified. Those who served in Vietnam totaled 2.1 million." These, he notes, were largely the urban and rural poor and members of minorities. "So we're talking 15.4 mil people -- the majority -- who did something similar to what Bill Clinton did. Bill Clinton did the norm."
Mr. Colhoun, the son of a "patriotic, Republican family," had completed college as a second lieutenant in the Army R.O.T.C. when he decided the war was unjust, and when his term for service approached, he took exile in the flow of tens of thousands to Canada.
In having opted to pay a price of years away and public scorn for his views, Mr. Colhoun feels closer now to Vietnam veterans than to the majority of men in that era who found the legal loopholes. "We do need a debate of this issue, but it should be about reconciliation, not the debate going on now, this year's Willie Horton diversion from our real problems," he says, stressing truer issues of economic and sociological breakdown echoing in the gunplay outside his window.
Back in America since a general Presidential pardon 15 years ago, Mr. Colhoun remains one tough critic of his homeland. On the one hand, he accuses the Republicans of "chicken-hawk" hypocrisy in pressing the draft issue on Governor Clinton.
"Dan Quayle, Pat Buchanan, George Will, Newt Gingrich -- all these people were for the war," he says, enumerating a Beltway group, including bipartisan scores in Congress, who were part of the legally spared male majority. "They thought it was great; it's just that someone else would fight it for them. Bill Clinton at least was opposed to the war and didn't want to fight it. He can't make this point now because he wants the votes of the Bubbas and the 'burbs, the Reagan Democrats."
On the other hand, Mr. Colhoun accuses Mr. Clinton of skirting discussion of the urban decay and violence that are the most tangible symptoms of the economic issue. "I have to say he's two-faced and doesn't want to talk about the ills of urban America, because that means talking about black America, and he's afraid of alienating those Bubbas and 'burbs," says this voter, who is debating whether to leave his Presidential ballot blank.
Time has left Jack Colhoun something of a gray-bearded expert on the guilt that lurks around the Vietnam era, and this year he finds it decidedly undifferentiated.
"My own feeling is that whenever any male has an opinion on this issue -- whether a journalist or a politician -- they ought to say up front, like a Surgeon General's warning, 'This is what I did in Vietnam.' "

He visited the memorial sculpture by Joseph Hart in Washington last week. (George Tames for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For Absent Fathers, a Ray of Hope

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
In an old law office building on East Hanover Street here, a dozen men, all fathers of welfare children, are trying to leave the rootlessness of street life behind and learn how to become responsible parents, wage earners, maybe even husbands.
These are the goals of Operation Fatherhood, the New Jersey version of a federally assisted experimental program called Parents Fair Share. While there are numerous programs to help welfare mothers, the program's reasoning goes, little has been done to help the absent fathers straighten their often tangled lives so that they can take responsibility for their offspring and start paying child support. 
 But for the dozen or so men in the program here, the goal is a less lofty one: They just want a job that pays better than minimum wage. It does not have to be much better.
"Here's the difference this place makes for me," said Leroy Johnson, a recovering alcoholic who brought his 9-month-old daughter Aleena with him to class. "It's making $7 or $8 a hour instead of making $4 or $5 an hour. That's all I'm asking."
But even that step up from work in a fast-food restaurant to a job in a company mail room or as a security guard can be difficult for men without high school diplomas, with a history of arrests, and with a habit of ignoring small problems, like a traffic ticket, until they become catastrophic.
"They've been in a different society from the rest of us," said Al Walker, the executive director of Operation Fatherhood. "They're from the society of sneakin' and runnin' and duckin'. Now we've got to introduce them to the mainstream society."
Along the way, the program organizers hope, the man may learn to work things out in their relationships with women instead of simply running from them. They may even learn tenderness when, during a class on making relationships last, they field questions like, "What is your partner's favorite movie?" "What is her shoe size?" "What's the one thing she is really afraid of?"
 
Emphasis on Achievement
 Operation Fatherhood is open only to fathers of children on welfare who are not the parent with custody. About half a dozen participants, the older ones, have been referred to Operation Fatherhood by the Mercer County welfare office with the promise that their child-support obligations will be lowered or suspended while they are enrolled.
The younger men, who must acknowledge paternity of their child or children to remain in the program, come for the promise of help in getting a job.
But before they can join the Job Club and apply for work with sympathetic employers that Operation Fatherhood has recruited, they must take the four-to-six-week peer support program, the core of the program to change attitudes and outlooks.
"This is the first place I've been to where they tell you how life really should be," said David Chaviez, an 18-year-old who dropped out of school at 15 and who, a year later, became the father of Devonica, now being raised by her mother, who is on welfare.
"I was scared being out in the world," Mr. Chaviez said. "I didn't know what I was going to do from the next day to the next. I feel like I have some hope now."
Larry Davis, a 35-year-old who owes about $15,000 in child support for his three children, conceded that he had been coached earlier in his life on the basics of job hunting -- be on time, wear a tie, look the interviewer in the eye. But he credits Operation Fatherhood with having a higher level of caring.
"The mother of my children will only let me come around and see them when I got some money," he said. He recalled discussing the problem with the welfare caseworker, "and she said, 'Well, I guess you better go out and pick up some cans.' That's their attitude -- go pick up some cans."
Since Operation Fatherhood started in July, 12 men have been found jobs, with the rest of the participants still in training.
Mr. Johnson said he just likes the way Joseph Steele, the peer support teacher, talked with the participants.
"See, I never had a father," he said. "I was brought up by my mother, and I learned from a woman's point of view. Everything else I learned in the streets. Joe Steele, he teaches me from a father's point of view. It's like a refresher course."
Barbara Kelley-Sease, the executive director of Trenton's Industrial Home for Children, which administers Operation Fatherhood for the state Department of Human Services, said the men were not used to anyone paying attention to their problems.
"People call them deadbeat dads or runaway fathers," she said. "But nobody has ever addressed these questions with them, no one has taken the time to help them develop into the kinds of parents they would like to be."
The program tries to help the men put the troubles and the turmoil of the street behind them.
The other day, some of the fathers were standing out on East Hanover Street, taking a break from the classwork inside, when a police van drove slowly by. Jonathan Ledlow, a big man in overalls, instinctively stiffened, but Al Walker laid a reassuring hand on his arm.
"Relax, Jon," he said. "You're with us now."
Mr. Ledlow, who owes $10,500 in support for two children by two women, has decided that, with such support, the basic middle-class dream -- a home, a wife, kids and a picket fence -- could one day be his after all.
"Maybe not the picket fence," he said on reflection. "Probably a barbed-wire fence. But the wife, the kids, a home, yeah. Maybe I can."

Leroy Johnson, who brought his 9-month-old daughter Aleena with him to class, said all he wants is a job that pays better than the minimum wage. (Stephen Lefkovits for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Pace Slows a Bit For Mutual Funds

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
MUTUAL funds continue to attract investors who are dismayed by the low interest rates available on bank deposits, but the inflow of cash to stock and bond funds has slowed in recent weeks to its lowest level of the year, executives at mutual fund companies say.
"There has been some slowdown, but only compared to the pace earlier this year," said Jane White, a spokeswoman for T. Rowe Price Associates. "Any other year we would have thought our recent numbers were wonderful." 
 Stephen Gibson, director of retail marketing at Putnam Investments, a Boston-based mutual fund company, noted that the "sideways movement in the stock market and uncertainties created by the election" could account for the subsiding of investor demand. He added that holders of maturing bank certificates of deposit, who were a prime source of cash for mutual funds earlier this year, might now be more willing to renew their C.D.'s, even though interest rates are at their lowest in 20 years, with banks paying 3 percent or less on short-term C.D.'s.
The August inflow of cash to equity funds, at $3.5 billion, was the smallest since September of last year, according to data compiled by the Investment Company Institute. All of the gain for equity funds came from new investors, as exchanges of shares in one fund for those of another fund managed by the same company resulted in a $591 million decline for equity fund investments.
As investors seemed to become more wary, managers of funds also began treating their money more cautiously, holding 9.9 percent of the funds' assets in cash or short-term investments that are the equivalent of cash. The 9.9 percent cash level for equity funds was the highest since February of last year.
During September, Mr. Gibson said inflows of cash to equity funds, including reinvested dividends, were about 1 percent less than in August, with bigger declines of 7 percent in some taxable bond funds and 8 percent to 10 percent in tax-exempt bonds.
Michael Hines, senior vice president at Fidelity Investments, the biggest mutual fund company, said inflows of cash to equity funds in September were about the same as in August while inflows to bond funds were down slightly.
Bruce Speca, senior vice president at TNE Fund Group, an affiliate of the New England Company, said that reports from sales representatives show that "smaller investors are staying a little bit more on the sidelines, and most of the growth is coming from bigger customers." He added that all kinds of investors were taking longer to make investment decisions than was the case earlier this year.
Despite the decline in sales of stock and equity funds in August, mutual fund executives remain optimistic. Mr. Hines at Fidelity said that a monthly survey of investor sentiment it commissions from the University of Michigan showed that "people are now getting the same psychic gratification from investing as they used to get from spending." Among investors, he noted that those who intend to buy stocks in the near future far outweigh those who intend to sell, though the 33-point margin for September was down from 44 in August.
Analysts noted that the slower inflow of cash to mutual funds might reflect a growing awareness that stock prices, measured by the S.& P. 500 stock index, have been flat this year and have declined a bit in recent weeks. Since Aug. 3, the S.& P. 500 has fallen 2 percent.
Growth and income funds, a variety of equity fund that tends to avoid the riskiest stocks and focuses on better-known larger companies, fared the best during August, with a net gain of $1.9 billion. Aggressive-growth funds did not fare so well, as investors pulled $216 million from that sector, a sharp reversal from the previous three months when more than $2 billion flowed in.
Most of the decline in bond funds was among those that invest in tax-exempt issues of local governments. Only $1.76 billion of new cash flowed to those funds in August, down from $3.43 billion in July. Funds investing in mortgage securities attracted only $743 million of new cash, less than half the average pace of the previous three months.
Mr. Gibson of Putnam said he would expect some improvement in sales of municipal bond funds, because the yield on those funds remains well above the after-tax yield of most corporate and government bond funds.
The turmoil in foreign exchange markets and questions about the future of Europe's currency arrangements may have slowed the growth of overseas-oriented stock funds. International stock funds, which invest only in foreign markets, attracted $485.8 million of new cash in August, down from $641.7 million in July and the smallest amount since April. Global stock funds, which may invest in the United States and overseas, attracted $107.6 million, down from $195.2 million in July and the smallest amount since November 1991.
Global bond funds attracted $869.2 million in August, up from $558.6 million in July and the greatest monthly increase since January 1991.
Ms. White of T. Rowe Price noted that in September her group's international equity fund has been attracting more cash than its international bond fund. In fact, she said, the international stock fund is attracting more money than any other type of equity fund the company offers.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Move Up in Price

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday, lifted by speculation that forthcoming economic data could force the Federal Reserve to push down interest rates.
The price of the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond gained 7/32 point, or $2.19 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, fell to 7.33 percent, from 7.35 percent late Friday. 
 There was little news to affect the bond market. Traders said they expected that the Federal Reserve might lower interest rates again to stimulate the economy.
The main cause for this view is the Government's unemployment report for September, which is to be released Friday and is expected to show further weakness.
The August unemployment report caused the Fed to lower the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 3 percent.
The continuing weakness of the dollar in foreign exchange trading, however, is limiting any rally in bond prices. Another factor is that the higher interest rates available abroad are attracting investors who might otherwise put their money into United States Treasury securities.
At the Government's weekly auction, interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell to the lowest level in nearly 30 years.
The Treasury Department sold $10.2 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 2.73 percent, yielding 2.79 percent. An additional $10.3 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 2.85 percent, yielding 2.93 percent. The rates were the lowest since the fall of 1962.
 
Short-Term Maturities Up
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, short-term maturities were up 2/32 point to 8/32 point and intermediate maturities rose 9/32 point to 12/32 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 1.73, to 1,280.57.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 2.82 percent as the discount lost 3 basis points, to 2.77 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 2.91 percent as the discount gained 1 basis point, to 2.84 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 3.03 percent as the discount lost 1 basis point, to 2.93 percent.
A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity.
The Federal funds rate was quoted at 3 3/8 percent, up from 3 1/4 percent late Friday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 97 5/32 , up 2/32 point from late Friday. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 6.39 percent.

HEADLINE: Ministers Reaffirm Unity Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
European finance ministers said today that they opposed a "two speed" approach to monetary unification that would allow one group of nations to proceed quickly toward a single currency while leaving others to deal first with domestic economic problems.
The statement came at the end of a day in which European currency markets remained relatively stable. The franc gained in value against the German mark, removing the French currency from any immediate danger of devaluation. 
 [The dollar closed below 120 yen, falling to 119.65 yen Monday in New York from 120.75 yen late Friday, as traders grew increasingly concerned about the weak United States economy and the Presidential race, and sought a haven from the dollar and the turbulent European currencies. Page D17.]
Most European stock markets fell sharply, and analysts said investors were not yet convinved that the financial turmoil of the last several weeks was gone for good.
 
Exchange Rate System Backed
 The finance ministers, meeting in Brussels, issued a statement supporting their battered system of stable exchange rates and urging that all 12 European Community nations maintain their efforts to achieve a coordinated monetary policy and a single currency by the end of the decade.
They specifically tried to quell widespread speculation that Germany was set to lead a group of countries including France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg onto a "fast track" approach to monetary union.
"Everyone present emphasized their opposition to the concept of a two-speed Europe and reiterated that the object of the community was to proceed together," they said.
The statement said the exchange rate agreement, which was left in tatters after Britain and Italy withdrew earlier this month and Spain was forced to devalue its currency, should remain a key element in quashing inflation and bringing the diverse European economies into step with one another.
But the ministers did not say whether they would address the shortcomings in the exchange rate mechanism that became evident as the British pound, the Italian lira, the Spanish peseta and other currencies were swamped by waves of speculative selling.
British officials have called the exchange rate system flawed and have been pushing for discussions on ways to reform it when the heads of the European Community nations meet next month to try to salvage their treaty on European unification. But the finance ministers of several other countries told reporters today that they did not expect any significant decisions about the monetary system at the summit meeting, which is to be held on Oct. 16 in Birmingham, England.
"We shouldn't be talking about the failings of the European monetary system, but rather about the failure to apply the rules of the E.M.S. properly," said Horst Kohler, an official in the German Finance Ministry.
His statement suggested the continuing tensions between Britain and Germany over the causes of the currency crisis. British officials have blamed Germany for not blunting the rise in the mark by reducing interest rates; German officials in turn have suggested that the pound needed to be devalued and that Britain should have done so within the monetary system rather than pull out of it.
For now, at least, the currency crisis has ebbed. The French franc rose in value today to 3.3673 per mark at the close of trading in London today, stronger than its closing level on Friday of 3.3820 and well away from the floor price of 3.4305 to the mark allowed under the exchange rate agreement.
Still, the strains on some countries remain evident. Ireland, despite a severe recession and the highest unemployment rate in the European Community, pushed a key short-term interest rate up by three points, to 13.75 percent, today to defend the value of the punt. "This is a necessary short-term measure to cope with the turbulence on the money markets," Prime Minister Albert Reynolds said.
 
Anxiety in Stock Markets
 The uncertain outlook for Europe's economies also hurt equity markets. In Frankfurt, stock prices fell 2.5 percent as measured by the DAX index of 30 leading shares.
"Within Germany there are worries that the Bundesbank's tight monetary policies will slow the economy down and that the strength of the mark will hurt exports and dampen expectations for earnings in '93," said John Reynolds, the director of global strategy for County NatWest Securities in London.
In Paris, shares fell 4 percent on the CAC-40 index. Analysts said investors had decided there was little chance of an interest rate cut in France any time soon, despite the relative stability in the value of the franc.
Prices also fell by more than 1 percent in Zurich and by nearly 4 percent in Stockholm. In London, which has seen a sharp rise in prices since Britain pulled out of the Exchange Rate Mechanism and cut interest rates, shares fell today as investors stopped to take profits, analysts said. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares closed down 41 points, or 1.6 percent, at 2,560.0.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Currency Specialist Goes to Soros Management

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Robert Johnson, a managing director and foreign exchange specialist at Bankers Trust, yesterday joined Soros Fund Management, an investment firm with a reputation for making huge bets in the currency markets.
Mr. Johnson, a 35-year-old economist, says he likes the investment style of of George Soros, the firm's founder, and Stanley Druckenmiller, the chief portfolio manager, both of whom he has known for years. "They are fundamental, anticipatory risk takers with a longer-term time horizons," Mr. Johnson said. "And I believe that's my strength as well." 
 In the currency markets, Soros Fund Management, the investment adviser for the $4 billion in four funds in the Quantum group, is known as a classic speculator. Unlike the traders at banks, who typically try to anticipate currency movements for hours or days, patient speculators like the Soros Fund managers take longer bets.
"At Soros I'll be concentrating on a six-month to two-year time frame," Mr. Johnson said.
 
Political and Economic Trends
 These longer-term players try to unravel how political and economic trends around the globe translate into shifts in the direction of interest rates and currency values. The Hungarian-born Mr. Soros is known for his skill at taking such bets and his willingness to gamble huge sums of money that his judgment is correct. In 1991, Mr. Soros was one of the highest-paid people on Wall Street, earning $117 million, Financial World magazine reported, after making a multibillion-dollar bet in 1989 and 1990 that the German mark would rise after the collapse of the Berlin wall and the unification of Germany.
But not all his foreign exchange plays have been so deft. For example, Mr. Soros has admitted to guessing wrong in the currency markets during the 1981-85 period, when the United States dollar rose, steadily lifted by high interest rates, even though America's trade and budget deficits were climbing.
Mr. Johnson also focuses on longer-term trends. For example, he says he correctly saw that optimism last year about the strength of the American economy after the Persian Gulf war was overstated, meaning that the dollar was destined to fall in value once the underlying economic weakness became apparent.
Similarly, when the British pound surged this year after the Conservative Prime Minister, John Major, was re-elected, defying the predictions of opinion polls, Mr. Johnson again thought the currency move was unjustified and would be reversed after the post-election euphoria wore off. Once more, Mr. Johnson's judgment was on target.
 
Predictions Not Infallible
 Yet he says he expected German interest rates to peak this year perhaps four months sooner than they did, in July. And he recalls saying in a speech in Tokyo last December that the retreat of the Tokyo market had gone about as far as it should. Instead, the Tokyo market retreated a further 30 percent or so, before turning around in mid-August. "Perhaps there was too much economist in me and not enough trader," Mr. Johnson said.
Mr. Johnson, who earned his doctorate in economics from Princeton University, was the chief economist of the Senate Banking Committee before he joined Bankers Trust four years ago. An officer at Bankers Trust said Mr. Johnson's departure was amicable, adding that he was "highly thought of" at the bank.
At Bankers Trust, Mr. Johnson paid particular attention to smaller foreign exchange markets, including New Zealand, Finland, Malaysia and Thailand. The opportunities in the smaller markets, he says, can often be greater than in the currencies of major nations, which are more widely followed by analysts.
Looking ahead, Mr. Johnson says the dollar now appears to be undervalued compared with the major European currencies. So on the basis of currency values as well as underlying industrial competitiveness, the dollar and the dollar-linked currencies of Asian nations like Thailand, Malaysia, South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong seem attractive, Mr. Johnson says.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Macy's Slump: Losses and Sales Decline Continue

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
R. H. Macy & Company's sales and profits continued to hemorrhage in August, documents filed yesterday showed, as the weak economy and the company's strategy of curtailing profit-eroding promotions intensified the struggle to get out of bankruptcy.
The troubled retailer reported a $34.7 million loss in August in papers filed with the Federal Bankruptcy Court. From February through June, Macy lost $329.5 million; it will report its July loss in its third-quarter filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
 Sales have also gone into a tailspin. Excluding stores that have been closed, sales in August declined 8.2 percent, to $462.4 million. Sales in stores open at least one year, which analysts regard as a better barometer of a retailer's performance, dropped 10.1 percent.
The company warned that it did not expect to see a reversal in what has been a string of declining sales and mounting losses before December. It projected that sales would "increase slightly" in December and January.
"While these results clearly are not satisfactory, they are essentially what were expected during this transitional phase until the complete implementation of the company's new business plan," Macy said in a statement that accompanied the court papers. The company outlined a sketchy business plan last month.
 
Late Labor Day Affects Sales
 Macy said the late Labor Day holiday cost it about 2.5 percent in sales in August, which it expected to make up for with September sales. It also cautioned that the closing of 56 stores made comparisons difficult.
"These results are terrible," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retailing Marketing Inc., "and their own prognostication for the future does not inspire much confidence either."
Macy said, however, that only its West Coast division failed to meet its income and cash flow targets because of the weak performance in its 62 stores in California.
Macy's earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, a rough measure of cash flow, were $3 million in August. To satisfy the requirements of its post-bankruptcy financing agreements, Macy's cash flow must reach $10 million in the fourth quarter, which ends Oct. 31.
Suppliers have been concerned that the company would not meet that requirement, which could cause the banks to rescind their financing.
The company had $1.5 billion of current assets on Aug. 29.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Losses And Closes Below 120 Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday, closing below 120 yen to the dollar, as traders grew increasingly concerned about the economy and the Presidential race.
In New York, the dollar fell to 119.65 yen, from 120.75 yen late Friday. In Tokyo, the dollar also closed at 119.65 yen, down 1.20 yen from Friday's close, and in London, the dollar was quoted at 119.50 yen. 
 "Believe it or not, the yen is being looked at as a safe haven" at a time of turmoil in Europe and economic weakness in America, said Hugh Walsh, a trader with ABN Amro Bank in New York. The haven status is usually accorded to the dollar.
With little economic news to affect the market and with the turmoil in the European currency markets settling down, traders returned their attention to the weak domestic economy and the uncertainty over the Presidential race, Mr. Walsh said.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7280, from $1.7140 late Friday. In New York, the pound traded at $1.7295, up from $1.7150 Friday.
In European trading, the dollar fell to 1.4525 German marks, from 1.4870 on Friday. In New York, the dollar fell to 1.4525 marks from 1.4795.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's late rates, included: 1.26975 Swiss francs, down from 1.2945; 4.9000 French francs, down from 5.0070; 1,222.5 Italian lire, down from 1,238.5, and 1.24795 Canadian dollars, up from 1.24015.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday, were: 1.2690 Swiss francs, down from 1.2985; 4.8940 French francs, down from 5.0365; 1.6325 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6723; 1,221.00 Italian lire, down from 1,244.50, and 1.2478 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2403.
Gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $347.60 an ounce, down $1.70 from Friday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid of $347.85 an ounce, down $1.45.
Gold fell in London to $348.00, compared with $349.40 late Friday. In Zurich, the closing bid was $347.95, down from $349.35 late Friday. But in Hong Kong, gold was up $1.02 to close at $349.37.
Silver fell in London to a late bid of $3.74 an ounce, from $3.82 bid late Friday. On the Comex in New York, silver for current delivery was quoted at $3.730 an ounce, down from $3.799 late Friday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Slump Seen By Goodrich

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 28

 BODY:
B. F. Goodrich Inc. said today that the continued economic slowdown had undercut its performance and that it would report third-quarter 1992 earnings below what had been expected.
The specialty chemicals and aerospace company said its third-quarter results would be significantly below results from the second quarter and below the levels analysts had projected. The company said it expected to report only a modest profit for the third quarter. It did not provide dollar-figure estimates. 
 "Our specialty chemicals and polyvinyl chloride businesses depend in large measure on the strength and vitality of the economy, and improved results have been difficult to sustain under current conditions," the chairman, John Ong, said in a statement.
Goodrich said it had continued to take steps toward increased profitability, including cost-cutting measures and limited capital spending.
"When the economy rebounds, our businesses are well positioned to respond very positively," Mr. Ong said.
Goodrich's shares lost 50 cents each today to close at $41.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Aristide as a Hero of Haiti's Downtrodden

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Over the centuries, the Haitian people have known more than their share of misery. "Haiti: Killing the Dream" covers the most recent event, the military coup a year ago that sent the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the country's first democratically elected President, into exile.
Father Aristide, a young Roman Catholic priest who was influenced by the liberation theology movement, began gathering support among the poorest of his country's mostly poor and illiterate people after the overthrow of the unlamented Duvalier dictatorship. By tonight's account, his plans to take from the rich and give to the poor angered the country's elite, which joined with Army commanders and a bought Parliament to bring him down. The camera does not fail to contrast the fancy villas of a few with the shacks of the many. 
 "Haiti: Killing the Dream," which the narrator, Ossie Davis, calls insipidly "the saga of a priest who became President," follows the line set forth by the Haiti Commission for Inquiry Into the Sept. 30 Coup d'Etat, a long title for a few Americans assembled and led by Ramsey Clark, the sometime Attorney General and longtime critic of American foreign policy. Its conclusions are in accord with his predilections. Father Aristide, seen rallying supporters before the coup and in an interview afterward, is treated as a hero of the people, and the United States is criticized for being behind the coup or at least tolerating it.
Mr. Clark and Noam Chomsky are recurrent presences in this hour. Mr. Chomsky, the professor of linguistics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who is known for his tough language about Washington, accuses American business interests of seeking to restore the wealthy class to power in Haiti to keep a supply of cheap labor.
Father Aristide's supporters who are now on the run also express certainty that Washington did it. "With the pieces of information I have," says one, "I am absolutely certain that the coup has been engineered by the American Embassy." Few pieces of information are advanced to support the speculation, which is denied by a State Department official. In programs like this, the denials are never presented quite as forcefully as the charges.
But you don't have to accept all the premises of this well-made, if tendentious, documentary to sympathize with Father Aristide, who is to speak to the United Nations tomorrow afternoon. Whatever his failings (if he has any, they are not elaborated on here), he seems to have represented some hope to a beaten-down people.
And Washington's refusal of sanctuary to Haitians fleeing the current dictatorship may trouble even Americans who do not take the Clark-Chomsky conspiratorial line. Even if the Immigration and Naturalization Service position that most of the boat people are seeking economic improvement rather than political freedom has some truth, it is difficult to avoid the suspicion, voiced by Mr. Davis, that the fact that the refugees are black has more than a little to do with the way they have been treated.

HEADLINE: Manufacturers Urged to Make Environmentalism a Goal

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
When making commercial products, American companies should consider the effects on the environment at every stage in the manufacture and life of the product, the Office of Technology Assessment says in a new report.
Instead of focusing solely on the elimination of pollutants and solid waste that result from products, manufacturers should use a design process in which protecting the environment becomes a goal rather than a constraint, the Congressional agency said in the report released Friday. 
 Congress should encourage development of such a process, in part through new environmental regulations, such as requiring manufacturers to take back products once consumers discard them, the agency said. The manufacturing industry, though it supports companies' individual efforts to take such steps, says it is opposed to new regulations.
Representative George E. Brown Jr., the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology, said a crucial step in reducing waste was "to design commercial products from the beginning with the environment in mind."
Dr. Indira Nair of the department of engineering and public policy at Carnegie-Mellon University said a lot had been done to regulate pollution and waste but not enough had been done to prevent it.
"We have addressed the waste problem after it occurs," Dr. Nair said at a hearing Friday on environmental technology held by Mr. Brown's committee. "Waste prevention is a relatively new concept."
Despite fear in industry that environmental regulations undermine the economic competitiveness of companies, the report says that such design changes offered these economic benefits:
*Manufacturing costs can be reduced by lowering the quantity of materials used in products.
*The rising costs of pollution control and waste disposal can be cut by lowering the amount of hazardous materials used in products.
*Growing public concern about the environment can benefit companies that improve the environmental soundness of their products.
The manufacturing industry takes issue with the report. Mary Pigott, director of environmental quality at the National Association of Manufacturers, said: "We haven't seen their report, but N.A.M. believes that regulatory programs tend to stifle innovation. We do not support the promulgation of regulations because we believe that a new regulatory program won't give the same benefits of companies' efforts on their own."
Seventy percent of the cost to develop and manufacture a product is determined at the design stage, the report says.
New design could reduce the weight of packaging by 10 percent a year, the report said. Households in the United States produce about four pounds of trash per person each day.
Greg Eyring, director of the project that produced the report, cites the General Motors Corporation as one of the companies that had reduced its use of chemicals by turning to a single supplier whose profits depend on those from the plant's product, not on the amount of chemicals sold. So the supplier is concerned with the most efficient use of as few chemicals as possible, Mr. Eyring said.
In 1991, Germany passed a law that makes manufacturers and retailers responsible for taking back and recycling parts when a car is discarded. As a result, car companies like BMW and Volkswagen are producing cars whose plastic parts can be dismantled into parts that are recyclable. Traditionally, companies remove batteries and fuel tanks from a car and then shred what remains. The metals are removed from the shredded material and the plastics go into landfills.
But these plastics are "semi-hazardous" waste, contaminated with oil, automotive fluids and lead.

HEADLINE: Gregory Needed the Divorce

 BODY:
After Gregory Kingsley was allowed to "divorce" his natural mother, the 12-year-old boy greeted Florida circuit court judge Thomas Kirk, who made the ruling, with a smile and a handshake. The decision struck a valid blow for children's rights. Beyond the smile, however, is the painful recognition that the interests of children and their parents are not always the same.
With all the Presidential campaign rhetoric about "family values," this may look to some people like a dangerous precedent. But given the troubled circumstances, it's the right result. 
 During his young life, Gregory had been placed in foster care at least three times because his biological mother, Rachel Kingsley, a 30-year-old unemployed waitress, was unable to care for him. She had last returned him to foster care in 1990, leaving him in Orlando, Fla., while she went to Missouri and tried to provide for his two younger brothers.
After staying in a youth center, Gregory was placed with George and Lizabeth Russ, who have eight children of their own, and who wanted to adopt him. He became eligible for adoption when he remained in foster care about twice the 18-month period required before state authorities can move to terminate parental rights.
Florida authorities at first sought to reunite Gregory with his mother. But Gregory, encouraged by his foster father, who happens to be a lawyer, sued to sever ties with his mother. He accused her of alcohol and drug abuse and said he had been a victim of neglect and "mental and emotional abuse." The judge found convincing evidence that Gregory had been "abandoned and neglected." For her part, Ms. Kingsley said she only meant to leave Gregory in foster care temporarily until she pulled herself together financially. But in fact, Gregory only lived with his mother a total of seven months over the last eight years. His father surrendered his parental rights in May.
Gregory's ties with the Russes are so much stronger than his estranged relationship with his mother that the judge's decision seems the best for his welfare.
The decision need not and almost assuredly will not lead to a flood tide of suits by children seeking to "divorce" their parents. Not every child who has been neglected or abused has the maturity to act in his own behalf, even with the help of foster parents like the Russes, who could negotiate the legal system.
In most cases social service agencies are designated and best suited to determine what setting would be in a child's best interest. But such agencies, understaffed and overworked, are not infallible. It is useful, as a last resort, to have another avenue of legal redress for children in trouble.
Gregory's case vindicates the views of Hillary Clinton, a longtime advocate of children's rights. Her suggestion that children, in extreme cases, be given legal standing independent of their parents has been caricatured by Republicans as inviting children to sue their parents to avoid taking out the garbage.
But Gregory presented just the kind of extreme circumstances in which the divergent interests of a child and parent ought to be recognized by the law.
