Boeing tentatively agreed to sell Iran Air nearly $1 billion of commercial jetliners, provided it can persuade the Administration to change its policy and permit the sale. [D5.]
The Amex plans to offer insurance and pensions at reduced rates to its listed companies and member firms. [D5.]
Porsche said that it was eliminating 1,000 jobs and that all areas of the German sports car company would be restructured. [D5.]
 
The Economy
The leading economic indicators slipped two-tenths of 1 percent in August. The drop in the Government's chief index for predicting the economy, plus a slide in consumer confidence reported by the Conference Board, suggested to analysts that the current torpor would extend at least into early 1993. [D1.]
The Senate approved a broad election-year tax package with a medley of benefits, including incentives for businesses to invest in impoverished neighborhoods. [D1.]
Steven D. Wymer pled guilty to nine counts related to charges he cheated municipal governments out of $100 million. [D15.]
Bargain-hungry shoppers, many with high incomes, redeemed 4.1 billion cents-off coupons in the first six months of 1991. [D14.]
Markets
The Dow industrials lost 9.46 points to close at 3,266.80, despite a sharp gain by Sears. But advancing issues led declines 865 to 810. Investors awaited Friday's unemployment report. [D10.]
The dollar fell sharply, particularly against the mark, reflecting concerns that the Federal Reserve Board would cut rates again soon because of continued weak economic data. [D20.]
The dollar's drop depressed bond prices, and the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.36 percent in late trading. [D19.]
Orange juice futures prices tumbled on expectations of a bumper crop, and oil futures fell. [D20.]
 
Business Technology
The National Science Foundation's 21 supercomputers are to be combined into a weapon capable of attacking such formidable scientific problems as decoding the human genome. [D8.]
An Encoal pilot plant turns 1,000 tons of coal daily from Wyoming's Powder River Basin into valuable hydrocarbons. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Millions Cast Votes in Angolan Election Amid Fears of a Return to Violence

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUANDA, Angola, Sept. 29

 BODY:
Under intense international scrutiny, millions of Angolans voted today in the first broadly contested democratic elections in this war-ravaged country's history.
But as they voted in the first of two days of balloting, Angolans were surrounded by uncertainties about whether they were making a great democratic leap or were about to slip into the sort of disorder, violence and ethnic antagonisms that plagued them in 16 years of civil war. No violence was reported today, however. 
 Although there are 13 parties and 18 candidates vying for seats in the new Parliament and as President, the focus is largely on the contest between the governing party's leader, Jose Eduardo dos Santos, and the veteran guerrilla leader Jonas Savimbi, each of whom insists that in a fair election he would be the sure winner.
 
Close Vote Expected
 The outcome is likely to be close, most analysts say. Initial returns are expected on Wednesday.
The Government is believed to have more support in the towns, while Mr. Savimbi's group is dominant in rural areas, especially the central highlands, where his power base, the Ovimbundu ethnic group, live.
Angolans and foreign diplomats say they believe that both sides have stored large amounts of arms in case the fighting resumes.
Mr. dos Santos has spent the last two days in Luanda, the national capital, while Mr. Savimbi has traveled to Huambo, the main city in the Ovimbundu people's home region.
 
An Extension of the Cold War
 Both the governing Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola and its main rival, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita, fought Portuguese colonial rule from the 1960's onward. After independence in 1975, they turned on each other and ended up as proxies for the world's superpowers in the cold war, with the Soviet Union and Cuba backing the Popular Movement, which won control of the country.
Unita, with American- and South African-backing, waged a guerrilla struggle until a truce agreement, brokered by the United States and the Soviet Union, was signed in Washington in June 1991. That accord provided for today's election.
On the surface, the balloting today seemed to be relatively smooth, with strong signs of a heavy voter turnout and no clear evidence of obvious and widespread fraud.
 
Polling Stations Closed
 Arthie Schimmel, a member of Parliament in the Netherlands and an election monitor here, said the first three polling stations she stopped by this morning were all closed: at one, there were no keys to open the building, at another there were no tables and chairs, and at the third the ballots were not ready.
Still, Ms. Schimmel voiced optimism about the process. "It's a bit disorganized, and it's starting slowly, but it's working," she said.
At the Maianga polling booth in a suburb south of Luanda, Muteba Jesus, a 39-year-old plumber, complained about the "incredible amount of confusion here." He said people had begun lining up as early 4 A.M. at polls that were supposed to open at 7 A.M. However, the doors were not opened until 9 A.M. Asked who he would vote for, he said that he is a "M.P.L.A. man."
"I just don't like Unita's mentality," he added. "They're not the right people for me."
At another polling booth in the Luanda suburb of Rocha-Pinto, Mgonanau Yanba, a mechanic, was Asked which party he expected to vote for. Mr. Yanba responded that it was a secret. His answer and similar replies by many other voters today apparently reflected the National Electoral Council's repeated statements urging voters to make their own decisions about who to vote for and they need not reveal it to anyone.
Much will depend on popular perceptions of whether the balloting today and on Wednesday are tainted by major irregularities. The biggest fear, analysts say, is that if the vote is close, the loser will reject it.
 
Unita Charges Fraud
 Just hours before the voting began, Unita held a news conference to denounce what it asserted were the Government's attempts to rig the elections, giving rise to suspicions that the group is laying the groundwork for a challenge of the results if the vote does not go its way.
Violent clashes have flared between rival political groups during the monthlong campaign, leaving more than 40 people dead and antagonisms so severe that they may not be easily soothed.
But Margaret Anstee, head of the United Nations observer delegation, said the level of violence could have been much higher.
"There will be some violent incidents," she told reporters, "but as long as things do not get out of hand, I do not see that as reason for declaring the elections not free and fair." Nearly 1,000 international observers are here to supervise the polls.
 
Defection of Savimbi Aides
 When Mr. Savimbi agreed to the truce last year, most political commentators and Western analysts here thought he would win handily. However, two of Unita's senior commanders, Miguel Nzau Puna and Tony Da Costa Fernandes, deserted the movement and accused the 57-year-old Mr. Savimbi of atrocities, including the summary execution of two high-ranking party leaders whose opinions differed from his own, along with their wives, children and guards.
The accusations of the former Unita members, which have been repeated constantly on the Government-controlled radio and television networks, have become a major campaign issue, at least in the cities.
Mr. Savimbi and other opposition leaders have focused their attacks on the dismal economy, picturing Mr. dos Santos and other Government leaders as disciples of failed Marxist ideals.

HEADLINE: Quiet on the Set: Costs Mire New York in a Film Slump

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER

 BODY:
Chris Rosen has a steadily growing circle of friends in Los Angeles, a city that holds little appeal for him -- or them. But that's where a number of New York film technicians are migrating as a two-year slump in the movie business drags on.
"They would have preferred to stay here," he said. But the work has gone west, and elsewhere. 
 For almost a decade, Mr. Rosen, 33 years old, had more jobs than he could handle as a gaffer, or head electrician on the set of commercials and movies. But Mr. Rosen's business has slipped by at least a third since a seven-month-long boycott of New York by film producers that ended in May 1991. In the early months of 1992, Mr. Rosen said, "I don't think I worked a day." And though he says he could never follow his friends, he is not optimistic about the film business here: his appointment calendar has only two days blocked out.
The producers boycotted New York during protracted labor negotiations with several theatrical unions. Although consultants are only now beginning to assess the lingering financial impact of the boycott, it is clear that what was once one of the city's largest industries is only a shadow of its former self.
 
On to Baltimore
 
 
Six feature films are now shooting in the city, a fraction of the usual fall activity. Through August of this year the city had issued about 50 film permits, compared with more than 80 for the same period a year ago -- despite the boycott that was in effect for the first five months of 1991. In 1989, the year before the boycott, 110 film permits were issued. Most of the moviemakers found that certain streets in Baltimore and Pittsburgh could be made to look like New York's -- in many cases at a lower cost.
As a result, a number of grips, who rig cameras and block lighting, have gone into carpentry. Camera assistants, who move and clean heavy film equipment, are accepting jobs as laborers. And while actors and others in the film industry have always waited tables and sold shoes to survive between jobs, the current crisis has forced a number of professionals to accept other work for the first time.
 
Lowered Expectations
 "Actors cater; assistant directors don't cater," sniffed Alan S. Gordon, Eastern executive secretary of the Directors Guild of America. Or they did not, he said, until recently.
Patricia Curtice, who had worked steadily for 20 years as an assistant director, is now planning parties and weddings to pay her bills while she waits for the business to come back.
Last week, as Ms. Curtice signed up prospective clients at a bridal fair aboard the Spirit of New York, she still could not help but feel responsible for the fair's set. Swaying back and forth with the motion of the boat, vendors were having a hard enough time shouting over background music and a loud wedding video. But after the sun set, the vendors also found themselves working in almost total darkness.
"Are you with this boat? Can you get us some lights?" Ms. Curtice shouted to a man in uniform. He turned out to be the disk jockey, but she eventually got the lights turned on. Having worked on hundreds of commercials, she did not need such practice.
Along with the departing film industry veterans, even the next generation of film makers seems to be leaving New York.
 
Following the Business
 "People coming out of film schools go to L.A. now," said Mona Mangan, executive director of the Writers Guild of America, East. She said there was a growing feeling in the film industry that New York is too difficult and expensive, and they feared being left out of an increasingly insular California film community.
Writers and directors who cannot or will not leave New York have long complained that the city has done little to woo producers back from locations in Chicago or Toronto that they discovered during the boycott.
Many in the business also fear that any problems in upcoming negotiations between the major studios and the theatrical local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in New York, whose members deliver equipment and drive actors' trailers, could lead to a renewed boycott. The teamsters contract with most of the major studios expires at the end of October.
Labor leaders fear the film studios will use the contract negotiations to break the union. "The producers wanted to make sure they hurt us very badly during the negotiations" that led to the recently ended boycott, said Myron Odegaard, a spokesman for Local 52 of the Motion Picture Studio Mechanics.
 
Pessimism Among Producers
 Martin Bregman, who has produced films like "Serpico" and "Sea of Love," is among those who feel a renewed boycott is almost inevitable. "My strong perception is there will be a boycott unless somebody in the city gets involved -- the Mayor," he said.
Jennifer Kimball, a spokeswoman for Mayor David N. Dinkins, said the Mayor "stands ready to lend his good offices" if called into the negotiations. And James Leavey, of Teamsters Local 817, dismissed the dire predictions.
"I don't think it's as dismal as everybody's making it out to be," Mr. Leavey said. He said preliminary contacts had been promising, and cited good relations with a growing number of independent film makers.
But Mr. Bregman said New York's film industry has already been decimated. "We've lost the industry here; it's gone," he said. "It won't be back in my lifetime."
 
Search for Important Post
 He blames the Dinkins administration for failing to grasp the enormity of the industry's problems.
A permanent replacement still has not been named to fill the post of director of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, a job last held by Jaynne C. Keyes, who resigned five months ago. A successor who would attract business is seen as vital in the local film industry.
But more than a month after city officials trumpeted a fresh start in the search, which was taken over by an executive search firm, there are few signs of progress. The search firm, Russell Reynolds Associates, only recently received a job description for the post.
In a Sept. 21 memo to members of the Mayor's Advisory Council for Film, Television & Commercials, the acting director of the Mayor's film office, Nina Streich, noted that the City Council is considering tax incentives for producers and suggested that news reports of the proposed incentives could substitute for action. "If concept is circulated by media," she wrote, "resulting attention may revive NYC industry regardless of whether model is ever realized."
While a pitched battle over the job vacancy continues, it seems unlikely that any director of the Mayor's film office can be expected to orchestrate an economic turnaround. Worldwide, English-language feature film production declined 20 percent in the first six months of 1992.
New York film technicians frequently argue that New York is not as expensive a location as it may first appear because the experienced technicians based in the city can complete their work more quickly than apprentices in other cities. But in the current environment, budget projections are crucial, and financial considerations even more likely than usual to prevail over creative factors, like the way the city looks on film.
"The film industry is changing a lot in this economy," said Ms. Streich. And, she warned, New York could continue to lose out to other locations "if you're looking solely to the bottom line."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Deutsche Bank Names U.S. Chief

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Deutsche Bank, pushing to take advantage of its financial strength and expand its American business when some other banks are licking their wounds, said yesterday that it had hired John A. Rolls to be chief executive officer of its business in North America, effective Nov. 1.
Mr. Rolls, who is 51 years old, has never worked for a bank. Rather, he has spent most of his career as a corporate finance officer responsible for selecting banks and arranging the best possible terms for his employer. Since 1986 he has been chief financial officer at the United Technologies Corporation, and before that he was with the RCA Corporation and the Monsanto Company. Though he was familiar with the Deutsche Bank name, he has never done business with it, he said. 
 "Now I must make the transition from being a buyer of banking services to being a salesman," Mr. Rolls said, adding that the task should be easier because Deutsche Bank's financial strength is held in high esteem by corporate treasurers. As one of a handful of banks with top-notch triple-A credit ratings from every major rating agency, Deutsche Bank is well positioned for arranging transactions, like interest rate swaps, with corporations that want to make sure that their partners in such swaps will be able to meet their obligations.
"In this weak economy, with questions about some financial institutions, corporate treasurers are much more interested in cultivating good relationships with strong banks," Mr. Rolls said. "A lot of people have been made nervous by the disappearance of large banks who once devoted a lot of resources to corporate lending. They want a bank that is sure to be there when it is needed."
The lack of a banking background was not unusual for Deutsche Bank, which has hired top executives from other industries. Alfred Herrhausen, Deutsche Bank's chief executive until he was assassinated in 1989, was formerly a utility executive, and Ronaldo H. Schmitz, Mr. Rolls's boss and one of 13 directors who run the German banking company, was hired from BASF, the chemical company, and given a mandate to run the North American business.

HEADLINE: Senate Approves a Tax Bill Offering Benefits for Many

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
Six months after the Los Angeles riots unleashed a Congressional drive on urban aid, the Senate today finally approved a broad package to give tax incentives to businesses investing in impoverished city neighborhoods -- along with a medley of tax benefits for every other economic group.
With the memory of the disturbances fading, the legislation sailed to passage on election-year crosscurrents. Provisions tacked on ranged from $500 million in fresh financing for social programs like Head Start for the poor, to an expansion of individual retirement accounts for the middle class, to a cut in luxury taxes on furs, yachts and expensive automobiles for the wealthy. 
 But the lawmakers would also make permanent two tax increases for the very wealthiest taxpayers to pay for many of the $32 billion in revenue that would be lost over five years. President Bush agreed to the two provisions -- limiting itemized deductions and gradually discontinuing personal exemptions for the wealthy -- as part of the 1990 budget deal. Since the Republican convention, however, he has insisted he would veto any legislation that raised taxes.
The bill passed by a vote of 70 to 29, with 22 Republicans joining 48 Democrats supporting the measure; 8 Democrats and 21 Republicans voted to defeat the bill.
During four days of often fractious debates, Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, accused Senate Democrats of attempting to set a campaign trap for Mr. Bush by forcing him to veto another popular bill. But many Republicans joined the Democrats in supporting the measure, some because of last week's attachment of a politically attractive measure cutting health costs for the self-employed and small businesses.
"It's a traditional Christmas tree tax bill," said a senior White House official, who said President Bush would veto the bill unless it was radically changed in conference.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the Democratic chairman of the Finance Committee and primary sponsor of the bill, said the package fulfills "goals like revitalizing our cities, increasing savings and capital formation, aiding troubled families, and improving business competitiveness."
Indeed, the Senate tax package would touch the lives of almost all Americans, even if in modest ways, in the unlikely event it is enacted. Middle-income families would receive a tax credit of up to $2,500 for buying a first home. Disadvantaged children would become eligible for expanded foster care and nutrition services.
And in a modest concession to the White House, Senate Democrats included a capital gains write-off on long-term investments made by small start-up business ventures, halving the top tax rate on the earnings to 14 percent for investments held at least five years.
The Senate bill would expand individual retirement accounts to allow nearly all taxpayers to deduct their installments, up to $2,000 annually. In addition, middle- and upper-income taxpayers would benefit from the establishment of a new form of I.R.A. The "special I.R.A." would allow taxpayers to make nondeductible contributions, with nontaxable withdrawals of capital gains, interest and dividend earnings as long as the funds were kept in the I.R.A. for at least five years.
"The list of winners in this bill goes on and on and on, each group narrower than the last, each group reaping benefits at the expense of all of the rest of the taxpayers," said Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, as he noted that tax write-offs were being distributed like so many pork barrel projects to cotton warehouse owners, ferry boat operators and gunsmiths. "This bill has been promoted as an urban aid bill, but for an urban aid bill, surprisingly little goes to the poor in our inner cities."
The bill would establish 125 enterprise zones around the country, 75 of them in inner-city neighborhoods, set up with $6 billion in tax benefits. Businesses would receive up to $4,500 in tax credits for wages to employees who live in the zones, up to $30,000 in first-year deductions for purchases of equipment and accelerated depreciation schedules for construction and equipment. It also authorizes the issuance of tax exempt bonds for building new businesses in the zones.
After the Los Angeles riots in April, the Bush Administration dusted off a $1.9 billion plan setting up 50 zones, 15 of them in rural areas. For businesses expanding or locating in the zones, the Administration wanted to eliminate capital gains taxes on the sale of investments made in the zones and held for at least two years. It also proposed to give tax deductions of up $50,000 a year for people who buy stock in small companies doing business in the zones.
Mr. Bentsen struggled for months to keep capital gains write-offs out of the enterprise zones because, he said, "capital gains preferences benefit people who sell businesses." He added, "Preferences don't support businesses while they struggle to become vital long-term enterprises, and that is what we're trying to do after all."
Some urban experts have expressed little enthusiasm for enterprise zones, saying those that have been tried in 36 states have a mixed record at best. But other experts say enterprise zones cannot be judged until the tax benefits include write-offs on Federal taxes.
 The House has passed a far smaller bill -- its cost is $17 billion -- that contains far fewer new I.R.A. benefits and enterprise zones. But the 50 it does establish would reduce the capital gains tax rate on new assets in zones held for five years to 14 percent.
"We'll have to get closer to the provisions of the House bill for enactment," predicted Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, in an interview today.
"There's a lot of work to be done in a very short time," added the Illinois Democrat, who will serve as chairman of the conference committee. "If it can't be done in a few days, it won't be done. The critical question is whether the President will accept tax hikes."
Under the Senate bill, the Housing Secretary and other Cabinet members would select which urban and rural areas would qualify for the tax write-offs, making it difficult to predict how New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will ultimately benefit.
Brad Johnson, Washington counsel to Gov. Mario Cuomo, said a provision to grant tax credits to low-income housing builders would provide New York State with $22 million in annual credits. But he said he was concerned about the limitation on itemized deductions for the wealthiest taxpayers, which he said would raise New Yorkers' Federal taxes by $700 million in 1996 and 1997 when the current rule is extended. An aide to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, however, said he was confident that measure would not be in the final bill. He said New York City would certainly qualify for enterprise zones, and that Buffalo would be in the running.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
In Their Own Words

 BODY:

 PRESIDENT BUSH
In a speech yesterday at a campaign rally in Knoxville, Tenn.
"Governor Clinton wants you to trust that the American economy is going to improve if you turn full control of your paycheck over to the crew that already runs the United States Congress. And he wants tax-and-spend Government planners, those kind of planners, to have total control over the executive branch, too.
And they tried this 12 years ago. And we ended up with double-digit inflation. We had interest rates sometimes as high as 18 percent. And we had a misery index over 21 percent, unemployment and inflation added together. And it took years to wring inflation and high interest rates out of the American economy. 
 And I want to strengthen our economy and protect your paycheck from the ravages of inflation. We cannot go the tax-and-spend route any more."
 
GOV. BILL CLINTON
In a speech yesterday to a campaign rally in Louisville, Ky.
"I want America to promote progress, not poverty. And it doesn't serve the interests of the workers in the United States or Central America when employers close their factories down here that provide workers with a decent standard of living and open up sweatshops to pay starvation wages in another country.
"60 Minutes, " listen to this, the "60 Minutes" program actually showed film of a United States Government employee promising what he thought was a business prospect that there would be no union activity in the Central American country because -- listen to this, listen to this -- because the prospective troublemakers could be fired and blacklisted so they would never be hired. That is a violation of all of our trade agreements, and this Administration has supported it."
 
 SENATOR AL GORE
In response to a question about debates as he arrived yesterday in New Castle, Del.
"Governor Clinton was in Michigan ready to debate. He was in Louisville ready to debate. And he will be in San Diego ready to debate this Sunday. Let's start the debate's right there, and then sit down with the commission and work out the all of the other details of other debates that will be forthcoming. We're ready to go. Governor Clinton will be in San Diego, and if Bush is serious, he will be there also to start the series of debates."
 
 VICE PRESIDENT DAN QUAYLE
In a speech yesterday at Ronald Reagan's boyhood home in Dixon, Ill.
"When Jimmy Carter went out of office, interest rates, interest rates were at 21 percent. Where are they today? About 6 percent. Inflation? Inflation was at 13 percent. Today it's about 3, 3 1/2 percent. Remember the misery index that Jimmy Carter created during the 1976 campaign: unemployment and inflation? Well it was about 20 percent on Carter's watch, and now under our watch it's about 10 percent. We've cut it in half, and we're proud of it.
 When Ronald Reagan became President, 22 nations around the world were Communist. Today, five. We now have, thanks to the Republican leadership, we have a stronger America. Our children are safer today than they've ever been before. We have got a great record, and now it's time to take our agenda for the future to the American people. "

HEADLINE: Questions on Race

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Without making a ruling or filing a lawsuit, the Department of Education has managed not only to change the way the law school at the University of California at Berkeley admits minority students, but also to cast a pall of uncertainty over all college admissions policies that have to do with race.
On Monday, the department's Office of Civil Rights announced that after a two-year investigation, the law school had voluntarily agreed to end its practice of giving special consideration to minority students by having them essentially compete only against each other, not against the general pool of applicants. 
 Berkeley officials did not admit that their policy violated anti-discrimination laws, as had been alleged. They said only that they would change their procedures so that applicants would not be separated by race.
Berkeley's decision to alter policies that it continues to say are proper and legal raises questions about what other colleges and universities might do about their own minority admissions policies.
 
'A Good Hard Look'
 Nearly every college and university catalogue includes a stated goal of increasing the enrollment of minority students. While such efforts entail heavier recruitment and a special understanding of minority student needs, they usually also mean that at some point special consideration is given to an applicant's race.
"The department knows good and well that every college and university in the country that has programs designed to do what Berkeley's intended to do is going to take a good hard look at it," said Robert H. Atwell, president of the American Council on Education, which represents most of the nation's colleges and universities, "and they may pull back for fear of what it could lead to."
The agreement between the department and Berkeley is likely to cause the same sort of anxiety and uncertainty that surrounded several other department decisions dealing with the delicate balance between forging diversity and setting quotas.
When Michael L. Williams, Assistant Secretary of Education for civil rights, tried to end scholarships based on race, starting in December 1990, he kicked up a furor that turned into a political embarrassment for the Bush Administration. The department eventually backed down from its original stand and adopted a less rigid policy that allowed race to be considered as one factor but not the determining factor in decisions about scholarship aid at colleges and universities that receive Federal funds.
College officials remain confused about what is allowed and what is not. The Secretary of Education, Lamar Alexander, has issued proposed regulations on minority scholarships that seems to go both ways, saying that such scholarships violate anti-discrimination laws but that they are allowable in certain circumstances and under certain provisions. The regulations, proposed last Dec. 4, have not yet been formally adopted.
The department has also challenged the use of a "diversity standard" by the organization that grants accreditation to colleges and universities in the Northeast.
All these actions were guided by the precedent set in the 1978 decision by United States Supreme Court that a white man, Allan Bakke, had been denied admission to medical school at the University of California at Davis because of rigid racial quotas. Since that decision, conservative concerns about ending anything resembling quotas have driven ever more deeply into university affairs.
The Education Department's actions involving admissions, financial aid and accreditation standards all seem to complement each other. In essence, they form a rigid approach to questions of access saying that while, for the good of society, race can be considered in education decisions, it cannot stand as the sole determining factor.
This position draws on conservative fears of racial quotas, while trying to avoid the appearance of being racist. Richard A. Samp, chief counsel of the Washington Legal Foundation, a conservative public interest and policy organization, called the Berkeley agreement "an encouraging sign." The foundation filed the complaints that led to the department's ruling on minority scholarships.
"Colleges around the country know that 'quota' is a dirty word so they lie and cover up to make it look as though they are using race as just one factor," Mr. Samp said. "The only difference between Berkeley and hundreds of others schools is that Berkeley simply didn't cover up what it was doing."
Not everyone is persuaded that Berkeley's agreement represents a significant new issue for colleges and universities. Some believe its admissions policy was so specifically drawn that few other institutions would be subject to the same restraints.
The department also has been investigating Berkeley's undergraduate admissions policies as well, but Patrick S. Hayashi, the associate vice chancellor, said he was confident the practices will be found to be in compliance with anti-discrimination regulations.
Mr. Hayashi said the university admitted about half its students strictly on test scores, grades and other academic standards. The other half, he said, must be among the top one-eighth of all high school students in California but are chosen with race, economic standing, age and other factors taken into consideration.

TYPE: News Analysis

HEADLINE: Arthur Mosher, 82, International Expert On Agricultural Aid

BYLINE: By LEE A. DANIELS

 BODY:
Arthur T. Mosher, a former president of the Agricultural Development Council, an international agricultural development organization, died Sunday at his home in Black Mountain, N.C. He was 82 years old.
Dr. Mosher, who lived for many years in Ithaca, N.Y., before moving to North Carolina last year, suffered from Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease for several years, his son Richard said. 
 For nearly two decades Dr. Mosher headed the agricultural council, a nonprofit organization founded in 1953 by John D. Rockefeller 3d. The council helps train people in economic development and agricultural extension services in countries around the world. He was the council's executive director from 1957 to 1967, and its president from 1967 to 1973.
Dr. Mosher, a native of Ames, Iowa, received a bachelor's degree in agriculture from the University of Illinois in 1932, a master's degree in agricultural economics from that university in 1941 and a doctorate in economics from the University of Chicago in 1946.
He spent part of the 1930's as a missionary for the Presbyterian Church in India and then returned to India in 1948, serving for five years as principal of the Allahabad Agricultural Institute.
Dr. Mosher was a member of the President's Science Advisory Council's Panel on World Food Supply from 1966 to 1967, and was chairman of the Research Advisory Committee of the Agency for International Development from 1965 to 1971. He retired in 1973.
Among his many awards was the Presidential World Without Hunger Award in 1984, and in 1976 he was named a Fellow of the American Agricultural Economics Association, that organization's highest honor.
He is survived by his wife of 57 years, the former Alice Wynne Hall; a daughter, Anne Wimsatt, of Lewistown, Pa.; three sons, William, of Swannanoa, N.C., Ted, of Laurel, Md., and Richard, of Minneapolis, and five grandchildren.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Boeing Asks To Sell Jets To Iran Air

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
The Boeing Company has tentatively agreed to sell nearly $1 billion of commercial jetliners to state-owned Iran Air, if American policy changes to allow such exports, two Boeing spokesmen and a lawyer for Iran Air said today.
But Richard Boucher, a spokesman for the State Department, said at a news briefing today that the Administration continued to bar the sale to Iran of American planes or aircraft with many American components. A Boeing spokesman said the company's executives were trying to get the policy changed and had met with Commerce Department and Justice Department officials. 
 Iran Air is particularly unlikely to benefit from any change in American policy because the Commerce Department is already accusing it of illegally buying American equipment for testing aircraft navigational gear. The equipment, which consisted of radio-signal generators, is on a list of products that may not be sold to most non-Western countries without an export license from the Commerce agency. Iran Air denies that the purchase violated American law.
Boeing has a small chance of winning the policy change because the American economy is weak, an American official said. "People don't start new policy initiatives four or five weeks before an election except if there's $900 million in sales -- then the policy gets reviewed," the official said, citing President Bush's recent decision to allow the sale of advanced American fighter aircraft to Taiwan despite Chinese objections.
The tentative accord calls for Iran Air to buy 16 Boeing 737-400 jetliners with option to buy four more, according to an affidavit filed last Friday in the Iran Air case against the Commerce agency. The aircraft would be equipped with CFM-56-3C jet engines from the General Electric Company and Snecma of France.
Boeing competes for market share with Airbus Industrie, a four-nation European consortium. Iran Air is threatening to do business with Airbus if Boeing does not get the licenses. "If they're not granted, Iran Air is going to look elsewhere," said Thomas J. Whalen, a partner at Condon & Forsyth here who represents Iran Air.
Airbus said in April that it would sell two A300 jets to Iran Air, an order valued at an estimated $170 million. These aircraft use G.E. engines, so the export of the planes to Iran required the Commerce Department's approval.
Iran Air bought the American-made signal generators in Germany seven years ago and says that it was not told that the generators could not be re-exported without a license. The Commerce agency contends that Iran Air should have known about the requirement, and last month the department imposed a $100,000 fine and banned American companies from doing business with Iran Air for as long as two years.
The airline has appealed the ban to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, which on Monday blocked the fine and the ban from taking effect until the case was resolved.

HEADLINE: Yields on Deposits at Banks Have Another Down Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit trended down in the week ended today, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a Florida-based interest rate publication.
Analysts at The Monitor said the pace of the decline had slowed from the previous week, but they cautioned that yields might continue to decline amid a struggling economic recovery and the possibility of another Federal Reserve move to lower interest rates. 
 Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, said, "If the Fed does cut the discount rate, it will be the fifth cut this year, with the first four producing zero results." This Friday's employment figures will decide what course the central bank takes, he added.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three-and six-month bills held Monday, rates took a downturn, reaching their lowest levels in nearly 30 years.
The auction is regarded as a reliable indicator of the rates that banks could set on deposits in the weeks ahead. The average rate for a three-month bill at Monday's auction was 2.73 percent, down 18 basis points from last week, while the six-month bill fell 8 basis points, to 2.85 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The combined average yield on money market accounts in the New York area showed a moderate decline of 3 basis points, to 2.88 percent, while yields of three-month and six-month certificates of desposit were both off a basis point, to 2.92 percent and 3.09 percent, respectively.
Among the commercial banks, yields showed a decline only for money market accounts, off 3 basis points, to 2.71 percent, with three-month and six-month certificates unchanged at 2.79 percent and 2.93 percent, respectively.
Depositors at savings banks saw yields fall across the board, with a money market account down 3 basis points, to 3.05 percent, and three-month and six-month certificates both down 2 basis points, to 3.06 percent and 3.25 percent, respectively.
Banks making the largest adjustments on deposits during the latest week include Hudson City Savings Bank of New Jersey, which dropped the average yield on a money market account by 26 basis points, to 3.30 percent, and Banco Popular, which added 20 basis points to its three-month certificate, for a yield of 2.99 percent, and 41 basis points to its six-month, for a yield of 3.30 percent.
Outside the New York market, yields at the 20 large banks surveyed were unchanged for money market accounts, which remained at 2.77 percent, but were down for six-month C.D.'s, falling 3 basis points, to 2.92 percent.

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Drop 0.2%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
The Government's chief index for predicting the economy slipped two-tenths of 1 percent in August, suggesting to analysts that the current torpor will extend at least into early 1993.
"The economy is going nowhere," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch in New York. "It looks like the stagnation will persist another three to six months." 
 It was the second decline in the index in three months, following an unbroken string of advances from January through May. And while the Commerce Department report contained no significant surprises -- most of the components of the index of leading indicators were published previously -- it served to confirm assumptions that a spirited recovery is still not in sight.
 
'Insufficient Momentum'
 "There's just insufficient momentum to move the economy ahead," said David L. Littmann, chief economist for Comerica Bank, Detroit. He noted that over the last 18 months or so, the economy had expanded only about half as much as the 3 percent that many analysts believe is required to prevent the unemployment rate from moving higher.
On Friday the Labor Department is to report on the labor market for September, the final reading before Election Day. Expectations are that the report will show payroll jobs fell an additional 100,000 or more, while the unemployment rate remained about unchanged at 7.6 percent.
And the mood of the consumer, whose spending accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, showed no sign of improvement. Measured by the Conference Board, consumer confidence slipped in September to 56.4 from an August reading of 59. This was the third straight decline and brought confidence near the early-1992 lows, the worst in more than a decade.
The decline of two-tenths of 1 percent for the leading indicators was accompanied by drops of nine-tenths of 1 percent for its index of coincident indicators and one-tenth of 1 percent for its index of indicators that lag behind turns in the economy.
Without Hurricane Andrew, however, the coincident indicators -- gauging current economic conditions -- would have risen two-tenths of 1 percent, a department spokesman said. The hurricane's main impact was on personal incomes, but industrial production was also hurt.
 
Positives and Negatives
 Seven of the 11 leading, or predictive, indicators contributed to the August decline, with lower prices for materials especially sensitive to the business cycle having by far the biggest effect.
The other factors dragging on the index were higher first-time claims for unemployment insurance, faster deliveries to businesses from suppliers, lower backlogs of unfilled orders for durable goods, lower new orders for manufactured consumer goods, a decline in building permits and a lower M-2 money supply.
The three positive components were higher consumer expectations, an advance in share prices as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, and higher contracts and orders for new plant and equipment.
The Government's index uses University of Michigan data to assess consumer attitudes, and that series, unlike the Conference Board's, rose in August.
The 11th component, the length of the average workweek, was unchanged, the department reported.
Two privately compiled forecasting gauges showed little or no change for the month. Safian Investment Research in White Plains said its index edged up one-tenth of 1 percent as 10 components rose, 12 fell and 2 were unchanged. Herzog Heine Geduld's index was unchanged with a reading of plus 155.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Consumer Confidence
 By Reuters -- Consumer confidence fell in September for a third straight month, the Conference Board said yesterday.
The report was seen as bad news for supporters of President Bush's re-election hopes.
The board's consumer confidence index fell to 56.4, from 59 in August. Economists had expected only a half-point drop in the index, which is based on a 1985 average of 100.
"It's certainly not a good omen for George Bush," said James Fralick, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
The Conference Board said that over the last two decades the incumbent party has lost the Presidency whenever the index reading fell below 100 this close to an election. The previous lowest level just before an election was 80 in 1980, when Ronald Reagan defeated the Democratic incumbent, Jimmy Carter.
Economists said that the lack of a pickup in jobs was likely to be one of the biggest obstacles in Mr. Bush's re-election bid.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Sharply Again, Mainly Against the Mark

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN, By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply again yesterday, pushed lower by concerns that the Federal Reserve Board will respond to continued weak economic data by cutting short-term interest rates again soon, possibly as early as Friday.
The dollar lost the most ground against the German mark, because a rate cut in the United States that is not accompanied by a similar move from the German central bank would widen the already enormous differential between short-term American rates and short-term German rates. Currently, that spread is 6.5 percentage points. 
 The dollar closed at 1.4126 marks, down from 1.4530 marks yesterday. The drop brought the dollar closer to its low of 1.3860 marks, set Sept. 2. As recently as Friday, the dollar was trading at 1.49 marks.
The possibility that Germany will accede to intense pressure and cut its interest rates seemed to fade yesterday, when Lothar Mueller, a Bundesbank official, said German rates must remain high. Mr. Mueller said he hoped Germany would be in a position to cut rates in about six months.
"The currency markets are reacting to the notion that the Fed will be stampeded into easing monetary policy on Friday, and the fading possibility that the Germans will do anything friendly," said Joseph Liro, chief economist at S. G. Warburg & Company.
Speculation that the Fed will move to cut both the overnight Federal funds rate and its discount rate was heightened yesterday after the Government reported that its index of leading economic indicators fell in August for the second time in the last three months, suggesting the economy's extreme sluggishness will extend through the fourth quarter and into early 1993.
In addition, analysts and traders alike expect that September employment data, scheduled to be released on Friday, will also be weak. The Fed cut short-term rates earlier this month after a surprisingly bad August employment report.
Nervousness over the twists and turns in this year's campaign for the Presidency is also hurting the dollar, analysts said.
"The dollar collapsed the last time Ross Perot announced he was a candidate," said Richard E. Witten, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "That may happen again."
The dollar also slumped against the Japanese yen, falling to 119.31 from 119.65 yesterday. Its closing level yesterday is just above its all-time low of 119.14 yen.
In other trading, the British pound closed at $1.7806, compared with $1.7303 on Monday. The dollar also lost ground against the Swiss franc, falling to 1.2292, from 1.2682 francs on Monday, and 4.7865 French francs, from 4.9 on Monday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Making Coal More Useful By Cooking Out the Water

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The Powder River Basin in Wyoming has huge amounts of very clean coal, but nature does not organize itself for mankind's benefit: the deposit is a long way from market and shipping costs are bloated because the coal has a low energy content per pound.
But coal, like oil, can be refined, and this month a pilot plant built by Encoal, a subsidiary of Shell Oil, began full operation. The plant daily cooks 1,000 tons of coal from the Buckskin Mine in Gillette, Wyo., turning it into more valuable hydrocarbons. The process was developed by SGI International, a developer of energy technologies based in La Jolla, Calif. 
 The raw material is low-sulfur coal with a heat content of 8,300 British thermal units a pound -- about half the energy in a pound of gasoline. Some 30 percent of the coal's weight is moisture. The coal can be pyrolyzed -- subjected to heat and pressure -- to give off a gas rich in water and hydrocarbons. The hydrocarbons are condensed into a liquid that resembles heavy fuel oil.
The remaining coal, which weighs less because it has much less moisture, has a heat content of about 12,000 B.T.U.'s a pound. The lighter weight cuts about 45 percent off the price of shipping a million B.T.U.'s. More important, once processed, the coal can be used in the boilers of utilities in the East and Midwest that are designed for local grades of coals.
The SGI process is the only one that produces two products from coal, said William M. Owens, chairman and chief executive of the company. "Even if oil is at $10 a barrel, this has the potential to be competitive," he said.
The pilot plant cost $72 million, half paid by the Department of Energy. Mr. Owens said he thought a larger plant would be economically competitive even if unsubsidized.
The Clean Air Act is creating demand for low-sulfur fuel. Another potential market for the technology may be Indonesia and other places in East Asia, where clean, low-B.T.U. coal is common and shipping systems are not well developed.

GRAPHIC: Diagram: "Refining Low-Sulfur Coal"
 
An experimental process by Encoal at a Wyoming plant enables low-energy, low-sulfur coal to be refined into a liquid resembling heavy fuel oil and a coal that contains about 45 percent more energy per pound than the raw material.
 
The pyrolyzer subjects the coal to light heat and pressure and separates the resultant hydrocarbon gass from the coal solids.
 
(Source: Department of Energy)

HEADLINE: China Warns Of Trade War

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 29

 BODY:
A senior Chinese trade official warned today that Americans would lose jobs and business opportunities and pay higher prices for toys and shoes if the United States began a trade war with China.
Tong Zhiguang, Vice Minister of Foreign Economic Relations and Trade, said the United States would be entirely to blame if a trade war broke out. 
 Washington plans to impose punitive tariffs of up to 100 percent on $3.9 billion worth of Chinese products if Beijing does not agree by Oct. 10 to open its markets and dismantle trade barriers like import quotas and licensing fees. The final round of negotiations on the barriers is to open in Washington on Thursday.
"China will naturally take relevant measures should the United States hit China with high tariffs," Mr. Tong told the official New China News Agency. "However, we do not wish to see it happen."
American trade officials have been negotiating with the Chinese for nearly a year to open up China's markets. But Michael Moscow, the deputy United States trade representative, said two weeks ago that "a significant gap" remained.

HEADLINE: Bailout Near For Insurer

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: NEWARK, Sept. 29

 BODY:
New Jersey regulators said today that they expected to get the insurance industry's backing for the $800 million bailout of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company by the end of the week.
So far, the plan has the backing of insurance guarantee associations in 33 of 42 states where policyholders are residing, officials said. The insurer has $8 billion in assets. 
 In most cases, policyholders in states that do not back the reorganization would receive 88 percent of their benefits under the plan. Connecticut, Illinois, Michigan and New York -- four of six states with the highest concentration of Mutual Benefit policyholders -- have yet to back the plan, and officials have said their guarantees are crucial.
Creditors have until Nov. 16 to file claims against Mutual Benefit, and Judge Paul G. Levy of Superior Court has set a Jan. 28 hearing to consider certifying the reorganization, said Mary Ann Green, a company spokeswoman.
Mutual benefit has an $800 million deficit, but the state estimates that the value of its real estate and other investments will improve enough to make up 75 percent of that over seven years.
Under the bailout plan approved Aug. 4, the state guarantee associations would assure full death, disability and retirement benefits, full account values and minimum interest rates for Mutual Benefit policyholders and tax-deferred annuity holders.
Mutual Benefit had $14 billion in assets and $14.8 billion in liabilities when it was seized in July 1991 after reports of weak real estate investments touched off a run on the company by policyholders.

HEADLINE: Consumers' Use of Shopping Coupons Is Up

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The weak economy is creating a nation of coupon clippers.
Bargain-hungry shoppers redeemed 4.1 billion coupons in the first six months of the year, an increase of 10 percent from a year earlier, according to NCH Promotional Services Inc., a large coupon processing firm in Chicago.
And manufacturers, in response to the demand for cost savings, issued 193 billion coupons in that period, an increase of 7 percent, according to CMS Inc., a coupon processor in Winston-Salem, N.C. 
 Food companies and the coupon processors said, however, that for the full year the percentage of coupons redeemed would probably be about 7.7 percent, the same rate as last year. The redemption rate may even fall for the year, they said, if food companies end the year with a flurry of coupons.
CMS said that in 1991 "the recession seemed to jump-start consumer response to couponing," with the redemption rate increasing by 5 percent over 1990.
"There is a strong link between consumer confidence and coupon usage," said Jane Perrin, senior vice president of marketing for NCH. "Since the end of 1990, we've seen a growth in coupon usage among consumers because of the economic situation."
Kerry J. Smith, managing editor of Promo magazine, said that the latest wave of coupon use seemed to be attracting more than the traditional customers. In the past the typical coupon user had an annual income of $29,000.
A recent NCH survey found that 74 percent of those who earn more than $50,000 a year have used coupons, compared with 86 percent of those who earn between $40,000 and $50,000. The survey also found that 83 percent of those who earn less than $15,000 have used coupons.
Jeffrey Nedelman of the Grocers Manufacturers Association, a trade association for the largest food companies, said the proliferation of coupons was leading to a great deal of "brand hopping" among consumers. "We are dealing with the most value-conscious, least brand-loyal consumer we've ever encountered," he said.
NCH said the face value of coupons continued to rise, to an average of 51 cents this year, compared with 47 cents last year.

HEADLINE: Personal Health

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody

 BODY:
THE symptoms can run the gamut from headaches and chest pains to memory loss and extreme apathy. The diagnoses can range from heart disease to Alzheimer's. But the real cause is often depression, a disorder of epidemic proportions that is typically unrecognized, misdiagnosed or improperly treated.
According to various surveys and studies, fewer than half of Americans consider depression to be a health problem, and more than two in five say it is a sign of personal weakness. People who complain of depression are commonly admonished to snap out of it. Countless others with physical symptoms like recurring headaches or backaches never realize that their complaints emanate from depression. 
 As a result, many depressed people never bring their problems to medical attention. And when they do, they typically see doctors who are not specialists in mental health and who are likely to miss the diagnosis of severe depression at least half the time, according to the findings of a 1989 study by the Rand Corporation, a research institution in Santa Monica, Calif.
The rate of misdiagnosis is even higher for the more common milder forms of depression. Even when the diagnosis is correct and medication prescribed, it is frequently the wrong drug or too low a dose. Such mistaken treatment, in turn, feeds into the popular notion that not much can be done about depression, when in fact at least 80 percent of patients can obtain significant relief through modern antidepressants and relatively brief psychotherapy.
 
Free Screenings
 Mental health professionals are striving to reverse the pessimistic view of depression, alert people to its many signs and properly recognize and treat patients with this life-impairing disorder. On Thursday, Oct. 8, National Depression Screening Day, psychiatrists and other mental health professionals in all 50 states will volunteer their time in an effort to uncover some of the millions of cases of undiagnosed depression. The program was developed by Dr. Douglas Jacobs, a Harvard University psychiatrist, in cooperation with the American Psychiatric Association, Harvard's Department of Psychiatry and the National Depressive and Manic-Depressive Association.
Free screenings for signs of clinical depression will be offered to an estimated 30,000 people at more than 300 hospitals, mental health centers and college health services. A toll-free number, (800) 562-8686, has been set up to help people find out where and when to go for a confidential screening.
Last year's screening day saved the lives of at least three people with strong suicidal feelings who required immediate hospitalization. In addition, more than half the people screened, who, of course, were self-selected, were found to score positive for depression.
 
Size of the Problem
 The magnitude of depressive illness in this country dwarfs many other major health problems that receive far more public and professional attention. Each year, according to the National Institute of Mental Health, depression strikes 15 million Americans. At any one time, according to experts at the University of Michigan Medical Center, 6 percent to 10 percent of the population is clinically depressed, with women twice as likely as men to be suffering from this debilitating problem.
The cost to society is staggering, but it is usually poorly measured and underappreciated. In 1986 the economic burden of depression was estimated by psychiatric and public health experts at Duke University to be $16.3 billion a year for major depression alone. Lesser degrees of depression are far more common and, as a result, even more costly. People who suffer from depression miss more days of work than those with heart disease. While they are at work, their productivity commonly suffers, and at home their family and other personal relationships often become severely strained.
Depressed people are also more likely to seek medical care, frequently ending up on a medical merry-go-round, moving from one doctor to another in search of a cause for physical symptoms that are commonly the guise of depression.
 
Disguises
 In its most classic forms, depression results in feelings of sadness, loneliness, apathy, worthlessness, guilt, pessimism or hopelessness. Normal drives are severely diminished, resulting in a loss of appetite and sex drive, sleep disturbances and emotional withdrawal. Memory may be impaired and mental functions and body movements may be slowed.
But instead of telling doctors that they feel sad or hopeless, at least half of depressed patients complain of a physical problem: headache, constipation, chronic fatigue, weight loss, insomnia, backache or indigestion, prompting a battery of tests that reveal nothing about the real cause and may result in mistreatment.
Some patients, unaware that they are depressed, instead admit to feeling extremely irritable, angry or hostile. Or they may complain of an overwhelming listlessness, apathy and a loss of interest in things they once enjoyed.
As if depression in adults was not hard enough to detect, in children and adolescents the symptoms may be even more obscure. A depressed infant may fail to grow properly, a toddler may have protracted tantrums, a nursery school child may become overly aggressive or withdrawn, a child in elementary school may try to avoid school and an adolescent may refuse to eat, notes Colette Dowling in her recently published book "You Mean I Don't Have to Feel This Way?: New Help for Depression, Anxiety and Addiction" (Charles Scribner's & Sons, $19.95).
The physicians at Duke University Medical Center believe a revision is needed in the diagnostic criteria used in determining whether a person is depressed. Too many patients with significant though lesser degrees of depression are now missed, they found through personal interviews in five counties of North Carolina. Yet those with such minor depression, which is also highly treatable, are at increased risk of having an anxiety disorder or suffering a major depression within one year, their follow-up survey showed.
 
Treatment
 Although most depressed people get better on their own within 6 to 24 months without treatment, early diagnosis and treatment can dramatically reduce the length and intensity of depression. Treatment may also help to reduce the chances that the depression will recur. If the depression is severe or if the symptoms interfere seriously with a person's life, antidepressant medication is commonly prescribed. These drugs are not addictive and do not adversely affect behavior.
Instead of medication or in addition to it, psychotherapy may be offered. One popular approach is short-term counseling that focuses on the patients' distorted thinking and negative views of themselves and the world. Another relatively brief approach focuses on the patients' conflicted relationships with others. Longer-term analytical therapy that seeks insights into a person's childhood rarely achieves better results in alleviating depression, although this approach may be desirable for other reasons.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Are You Depressed?"
 
This test, offered by the organizers of National Depression Screening Day, can help you assess whether you are suffering from a serious depression.
 
1. I feel downhearted, blue and sad.
2. I don't enjoy the thinks that I used to.
3. I feel that others would be better off if I were dead.
4. I feel that I am not useful or needed.
5. I notice that I am losing weight.
6. I have trouble sleeping through the night.
7. I am restless and can't keep still.
8. My mind isn't as clear as it used to be.
9. I get tired forno reason.
10. I feel hopeless about the future.
 
Rating your responses: If youagree with at least five of the statements, including either item 1 or 2, and if you have had these symptoms for at least two weeks, professional help is strongly recommended. If you answered "yes" to statement 3, get help immediately.
 
If you want information and help in obtaining proper treatment, send a stamped, self-addressed envelope, with a suggested contribution of $5, to the National Foundation for Depressive Illness Inc., P.O. Box 2257, New York, N.Y. 10016.

HEADLINE: AUTO RACING;
Small Garage Gives Big, Ritzy Indy-Type Racers a Run for the Money

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARRINGTON, Pa.

 BODY:
Along Route 611 in this town a few miles north of Philadelphia is the Ritz Garage, an antique-car showroom. A few yards behind it is another garage, one that by Indy-car standards is decidedly less ritzy.
It is the home of Derrick Walker Motorsports, a team that is battling rivals that have more than triple its budget and manpower. But if money means so much in Indy-car racing, the Scotsman Derrick Walker and his Canadian driver, Scott Goodyear, have at least proved that with enough hard work and heady driving, it doesn't mean everything. 
 This is the team that came from last place to within half a car length of winning the Indianapolis 500 on May 24. And on Aug. 2, Goodyear showed that was no fluke by winning the only other 500-mile race on the Indy-car circuit.
"I will say that the guys are working harder than any other team," Goodyear said recently.
 
Hard-Working Small Staff
 Hard work is their only choice. Walker's building here is small compared with most Indy teams' headquarters. His full-time staff, 12, is about a third the size of Bobby Rahal's. Walker has only two cars; Paul Tracy, a driver for Penske Racing, has destroyed more than that in 1992.
Walker's office is at the end of a loft that overlooks the work floor of the 6,500-square-foot building. The big silver trophy from the 500-mile victory in August sits on his office floor, as if it feels too ashamed to be seen in such humble surroundings.
"I don't think we're so special at getting the most out of a dollar," the 47-year-old Walker said, his Scottish accent still evident after 13 years in the United States. "It's just that we don't have a lot of money, and so we've just got to concentrate on getting the most out of what we've got."
Each of Goodyear's pit stops is proof of that. At Indy, the team had the lowest aggregate pit time, and it finished second in the seasonlong pit stop competition.
 
Close Look at the Competition
 "The technology isn't the competition," Walker said of pit stops. "The competition is man-to-man, so that's an area we look at and say that's an area we can win in."
Walker also takes more chances with race strategy than front-running teams, something he learned as vice president of racing for Penske.
It can backfire, as it did at Loudon, N.H., in July when Walker called Goodyear into the pits too soon after a yellow flag came out. "We could have won that race," Walker said. "That was one I threw away."
His matter-of-fact tone makes you believe he would try it again. He notes that for a time during that race, the TV announcers were focused on his car -- and his sponsor. "They're only going to talk about you if you're doing something," Walker said.
Looking down at the lone 1992 Lola-Chevy on the floor of Walker's garage, you realize it is a fragile vessel to be carrying the team's hopes over tempestuous, crash-filled seas.
But Walker has a steady navigator in the 32-year-old Goodyear. "He has a particular driving style that suits our economic situation," Walker said. "He doesn't take a lot of unnecessary chances. He drives with his head."
Walker concedes one thing to his better-heeled rivals. "They all have the ability to dig into their own pockets if they have unexpected expenses," Walker said. "I'm sure they don't have to lay people off. Yet I would have to if I got short."
This weekend, Walker will have a chance to add something to the lint in his pockets at Pennsylvania International Raceway, a one-mile oval in Nazareth, about two hours from New York and 50 miles north of here.
On Saturday, a 100-mile exhibition race, the Marlboro Challenge, offers $300,000 to the winner, and Goodyear will be one of the 10 starters. With a good finish in Sunday's 200-mile main event, the penultimate race on the tour, Goodyear can hold on to fifth place in the title standing, which will pay $100,000 at season's end. That $400,000 would represent about 10 percent of the team's 1992 budget, Walker said.
Last February, all this was close to never existing. "At that point, I was about two to three weeks from scuttling the whole company," Walker said. With the season opener a little more than a month away, he and his 1991 driver, Willy T. Ribbs, had no sponsor. "We had tried everything," he said, describing his search for a driver with some money behind him, "from Willy to anybody who had two legs and a helmet."
Goodyear was in the opposite fix: a driver with a sponsor -- Mackenzie Financial, a Canadian firm -- but no stable team. "There were many times in 1991 I was on the phone with Neil Mickelwright, my team manager, trying to find out what was really going on because we were being told different stories by the team owner," Goodyear said.
 
A Team Without a Rudder
 When Mickelwright left the team, it was rudderless. Walker heard about it and offered a deal to Robert Tezak, the team owner. If Tezak signed over his contracts, he would give him some shares in Walker Motorsports.
Tezak agreed, and pretty soon, Goodyear was still making frequent phone calls to his team, but the topics were considerably less troubling. "It's about totally different things," Goodyear said. "It's about down the road and the future and what we need to do to win races."
At least one richer team owner has already tried to woo Goodyear away, and another has presented him with a lucrative offer for next season. Walker said he expects a decision from Goodyear this weekend, but if the driver leaves, the sponsorship may go with him, leaving Walker back where he was last February except, of course, "with a lot of fond memories of 1992."
Walker thinks Goodyear will consider the human element, which will be in his favor, when weighing the offers available to him.
"It hasn't gone to his head," Walker said, "like we're no longer good enough for him."

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
Mamet's Real Estate Sharks and Their Prey

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
They're guys on the edge. They are real estate salesmen on the North Side of Chicago, working out of a shabby office with a water cooler, trying to make ends meet by selling second-rate home sites in Florida and Arizona with names like Glengarry Highlands and Rio Rancho. Everything they earn comes from commissions, which can mount up. Yet it's not easy selling real estate even in the best of times. When money is tight, forget it.
The salesman has to hustle. He has to go out on "sits." That's when he hangs around for hours in the clients' kitchens, eating yesterday's store-bought crumb cake, while the clients lean this way and that until, at last, it's apparent they have no intention of buying anything. They just like having company. 
 Times are tough indeed in "Glengarry Glen Ross," the splendid film adaptation of David Mamet's 1984 Broadway play, adapted by him for the screen and directed by James Foley in a manner that should finally put him into the big time. Most of the members of the ensemble cast are already in the big time, but not one has ever done better work: Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Alec Baldwin, Ed Harris, Alan Arkin, Jonathan Pryce and Kevin Spacey. Here is a movie for which everybody deserves awards.
"Glengarry Glen Ross" is a mordantly funny "Death of a Salesman" for the 1990's, though it's not a tragedy. Nor is it quite a comedy. Instead of Arthur Miller, it more often suggests the work of Georges Feydeau, at least in part because it is played with the self-absorbed intensity of classic farce. At the end, there's even a bewildered policeman wandering around the premises trying to find out exactly what happened.
Yet unlike a Feydeau farce, "Glengarry Glen Ross" is about actions that have real consequences, sometimes brutal ones. The reason the film prompts laughter, and finally elation, is not because it's jolly or has any feel-good words to live by. It's because of the utterly demonic skill with which these foulmouthed characters carve one another up in futile attempts to stave off disaster. It's also because of the breathtaking wizardry with which Mr. Mamet and Mr. Foley have made a vivid, living film that preserves the claustrophobic nature of the original stage work.
In adapting his play, Mr. Mamet has introduced a vital new character who sets the scene for everything that comes after. Blake (Mr. Baldwin) is an emissary from "downtown," that is, from Mitch and Murray, who run this real estate firm and who, though remaining off-screen throughout the film, take on the importance of twin deities, probably in polyester suits. Mitch and Murray hire and fire. They make the rules. At the beginning of "Glengarry Glen Ross" they dispatch Blake to the North Side to whip up enthusiasm for the latest sales drive.
Blake is unsmiling and coldblooded. He's a shark in neat haberdashery. He begins his pitch by recalling a few tired slogans, including A.I.D.A., meaning attention, interest, decision and action. The men groan. Blake tells them matter-of-factly that they are tired, incompetent, lazy, stupid and old. They've lived the easy life too long. The men listen, bemused. They already know that the contest's first prize is a Cadillac Eldorado and that the second prize is a set of steak knives. The third prize? Says Blake, "You're fired."
The office's star salesman, Ricky Roma (Mr. Pacino), doesn't bother to come to the meeting. He's across the street at the China Bowl, romancing James Lingk (Mr. Pryce), someone who has chanced to sit in the next booth and become a potential client. Ricky is a kind of poet. Talking fast and with terrific sincerity, he dazzles the shy, prissy Lingk with a monologue composed of a magnificent assortment of non sequiturs. Too much of life, he says, is spent looking forward or backward. He pauses, then asks, "Where is the moment?" Moving on as if possessed, he touches on marriage, sex and spiritual aspirations, which somehow lead into a sales pitch.
Meanwhile, back at the office after Blake's departure, the other men are coming apart at the prospect of losing their jobs. Shelley Levene (Mr. Lemmon), who was once the star salesman and now sweats a lot, is past his prime but refuses to accept the fact. He can't afford to quit, but his sales record is lousy. He blames the young office manager, John Williamson (Mr. Spacey), for not giving him the good leads. Dave Moss (Mr. Harris) is younger but equally desperate. He's also devious and full of dangerous fury. He goes out for a drink with the mild-mannered George Aaronow (Mr. Arkin) and proposes a plan that would make some easy money for both of them and humiliate the loathed Mitch and Murray.
This is by way of being the setup for the darkly farcical events that provide "Glengarry Glen Ross" with what, onstage, would be its second and final act. The payoff is simultaneously priceless and heartbreaking. It's been said that "Glengarry Glen Ross" is about the evils of the free-enterprise system, which may be true, though that's to underrate the breadth of Mr. Mamet's vision. The film, which seems to address the 1990's even more accurately than the play did the 1980's, is as much about fate and the cosmos as about any particular economic system.
That's what forever separates Mr. Mamet from his contemporaries. Though "Glengarry Glen Ross" deals in particulars, with the ways in which this real estate office works and with the jargon of the trade, Mr. Mamet has the vision of a moralist outside of time. He never nudges the audience toward what it's supposed to think. He also has an evil angel's gift for a spoken language that sounds realistic, but is a kind of shorthand for psychic desperation.
Even when they are face to face, Mr. Mamet's real estate salesmen talk to one another as if communicating through a faulty long-distance telephone wire. They speak at the same time, loop back to earlier unfinished thoughts, don't listen or simply repeat the last thing the other said. They are barely in touch, which is why the moments in which they do connect are so moving.
Among this cast of equals, Mr. Pacino and Mr. Lemmon stand out, if only because each has, in the recent past, been hobbled by material that didn't allow him to express the explosive measure of his talent. In Ricky Roma, Mr. Pacino has a character he can inhabit with deceptive ease. Ricky is a big, complex, driven personality, also a little mad. For Mr. Lemmon, Shelley Levene is a variation on all the other end-of-the-tether characters he's played, but one stripped of sentimentality. Shelley is not only desperate; he is also tough. The superb quality of the writing is reflected in the clean, sharp edge of the performance.
The contemporary plays most difficult to turn into films are those that, like "Glengarry Glen Ross," are set in severely restricted but supposedly realistic locations. How to open them up so they don't look like filmed theater, but without losing the theatrical life?
Mr. Foley and Mr. Mamet do it gently, with extreme care and intelligence, as if handling a soap bubble, or maybe nitroglycerine. They crosscut between simultaneous actions. They follow Shelley out on a night when every call he makes ends in defeat, sometimes hilariously. Yet they never push the camera around just to create the sense of movement when there is none. They are stingy with close-ups, which then count when they're used.
The film makers' ultimate secret: they trust the text.
"Glengarry Glen Ross" is very fine. There's not another such adaptation I can think of at this minute that comes anywhere near it. Or: go.
"Glengarry Glen Ross," which has been rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), is stuffed with language that is vile, obscene and gratuitously vulgar, which is its method.
