HEADLINE: Mr. Perot: Where's the Cattle?

 BODY:
There was never a question about Ross Perot's appeal to millions of disenchanted Americans, or about his ability to articulate widespread frustration with economic decline and political stalemate. The big question about him was always this: Is he fit to lead? With Mr. Perot flirting shamelessly with a late re-entry into the Presidential race, that question burns more brightly than ever.
Mr. Perot would best serve the nation by not running at all. He has no chance of winning. And his eleventh-hour entry may only confuse an increasingly sharp battle between two candidates who, unlike him, have stayed the course. But if Mr. Perot goes through with the charade of honoring a "summons" from his hand-picked supporters, he'll have a final chance to display the political courage that he has conspicuously failed to show during his quixotic and self-indulgent journey. 
 Ross Perot certainly hasn't lost his capacity to inspire political fear. Witness Monday's obsequious pilgrimage to Dallas by high-level emissaries from President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton. Their task was to persuade him and his 50 state coordinators that they share his concern about the Federal budget deficit.
The state coordinators said they were not impressed, and chances are that in a few days they'll return to Dallas and persuade Mr. Perot to run. At which point the questions that so annoyed him the first time around will begin anew -- although he will have artfully reduced the time in which to ask them to less than five weeks.
There were, to begin with, questions of character. Reporters dug up impressive evidence of his penchant for espionage and intimidation. There were questions about his willingness to seek favors from the Washington establishment he professed to despise; and questions about his theories of governance -- particularly his devotion to an "electronic town hall" that would bypass the constitutional powers of Congress.
Maddeningly, he refused to adopt and defend a set of reasonably clear policy proposals. He was contemptuous of reporters who wanted to know his positions "on everything from mosquitoes to ants." He promised to produce a platform within 60 days, then reneged. He finally produced a detailed economic program -- but only after withdrawing from the race.
So here's one more question for the next phase of the Perot campaign, assuming there is one. Is he willing to take his ideas to the people? His economic program is detailed in a book called "United We Stand: How We Can Take Back Our Country." It calls for higher taxes for many Americans, new taxes on some beneficiaries of entitlement programs, sharp limits on deductions for mortgage interest and cuts in many Federal programs.
These are powerful ideas. To many economists, they would reduce the deficit too fast, causing economic harm during a recession. To many pundits they're political suicide.
Still they are worthy of serious debate. But all Ross Perot has really done is wave the book at talk-show audiences and say, "read this," while asking Bill Clinton and George Bush to do the dirty work. That's not leadership. So far, as Lyndon Johnson might have said, Mr. Perot has been "all hat and no cattle."

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
A Feeling Called Mama

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
At Children's Village, a residential treatment center for 300 kids in New York's Westchester County, there are boys who will tell you that Mama walks on water. Could be that Mama said she was coming on visiting day and didn't show. Could be that Mama said they'd live together soon and then disappeared. Could be that Mama hit hard and said mean things.
Doesn't matter. It's not Mama they're really thinking of. It's something they can't put a name to, something like being under a warm blanket on a cold morning with sunshine coming through the blinds. It's security and stability. It's being happy. 
 At the moment Gregory Kingsley stopped thinking of that feeling as Mama, Rachel Kingsley had already lost him.
In a landmark custody case, 12-year-old Gregory got his own lawyer, went to court and said he'd been bounced around long enough by his 30-year-old mother and a system that had served them both poorly. Over Rachel Kingsley's objections, a judge ruled last week that Gregory is now the adopted son of the Florida couple who took him from a group home.
The case may not set any sweeping legal precedent, despite the fears of some conservatives. But perhaps it will serve notice on policy makers. It was as though Gregory had shouted: Remember the Children.
"I just thought she forgot about me," he said of his biological mother.
Instead he dismissed her. He found a happy home, and he wanted to stay, to know where he would wake up from month to month, year to year. Ms. Kingsley's attorneys argued that the boy merely chose an affluent home over a poor one, but it seemed more likely that he chose stability over uncertainty.
He'd lived with Rachel Kingsley for only seven months of the last eight years, been placed in foster care three times. The black eye Gregory said his mother got from her boyfriend, the late-night parties he testified occupied her time, the vagaries of hard luck -- the trial testimony was sad and sordid, pitting needy mother against triumphant child.
Rachel Kingsley made some good points in court about how the system treats the poor. In New York City, for instance, an unemployed mother with two young children receives $577 a month in public assistance, according to the Human Resources Administration. If each of those children goes to a foster home and their mother remains on welfare, the total comes to around $1,250. An intact family gets half as much financial support as what you might call an untact one.
Rachel Kingsley says she put Gregory in foster care because she couldn't support him. That's how lots of children wind up there. We give parents time to get their lives together. But the clock is running on the kids.
Nan Dale, the executive director of Children's Village, says that it is not uncommon for the facility to get children who have lived in half a dozen foster homes. Some are as young as 5 and will never be freed for adoption or reunited with their biological mothers. "Not only the child but the system clings to this fantasy that biology is always better," says Ms. Dale.
Here's heresy: There's nothing magical about motherhood if you don't work at it. The phrase "natural mother" should be retired; it is insulting both to those women who have adopted children and those who have to work so hard -- "natural" implying effortless -- to nurture their kids. Rachel Kingsley didn't write and she didn't call. She didn't send a card at Christmas. She says Gregory was always in her thoughts. That's just not enough. He was in limbo, too.
The extraordinary thing about this case is not that it is believed to be the first time a minor was granted independent legal status to sue his parents. It is that Gregory Kingsley was whole enough to envision a future and fight for it. Ms. Dale says that at Children's Village they now have kids violent and angry beyond words, whose nomadic existence from rejection to rejection has taught them, above all, that they are subhuman.
Children like these are being sacrificed for a false ideal that Gregory Kingsley refused to accept, the ideal that biological is always better. The child welfare system in this country is driven by that ideal today, and because of it we are victimizing thousands of children who wait in foster homes and group homes and treatment centers for parents who, like Godot, somehow never come. We demand that young children sacrifice for the sake of what's best for their parents. It's supposed to be the other way around.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Weak Dollar Brings Rise in Rates

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
A sharp decline in the dollar kept United States credit markets from enjoying any gains yesterday from the sort of economic reports that usually propel bonds higher.
A decline in the leading economic indicators and a disappointing consumer confidence survey reported yesterday both implied that a robust recovery was still many months away, a condition that tends to support bond prices and lowers rates. 
 But as investors sold dollars for marks, pounds and yen, most interest rates rose. The 30-year Treasury bond yielded 7.36 percent in late trading yesterday, up from 7.33 percent Monday.
Supporting the dollar has been a low priority for American policy makers, well behind such imperatives as stimulating the economy and getting re-elected. For Americans, all the European talk about the need to defend currencies might as well be in a foreign language.
 
Brake on Federal Action
 Yesterday's activity, some traders and economists said, offered evidence that the currency markets might somewhat limit Washington's ability to stimulate the economy through lower interest rates.
"The dollar is not viewed as a profitable place to be," said Matthew F. Alexy, a government trading strategist at First Boston.
The dollar's decline, some said, largely resulted from expectations that the Federal Reserve would respond to a downbeat unemployment report on Friday by cutting its rates, making dollar-denominated debt less attractive. The Bundesbank also sent signals that it was unlikely to lower its short-term rates anytime soon, a posture that strengthens the mark against the dollar.
Add to these misgivings the questions about who will be running the country in January, and whether any candidate can reduce the deficit.
"It's economic uncertainty and political uncertainty," said Patrick Rothstein, the head of government trading at Merrill Lynch. "The marketplace doesn't seem too excited about either of these candidates."
 
Rally Is Halted
 Yesterday's retreat halted a three-day rally in expectation of news on Friday that the number of jobs continued to shrink in September. The Wall Street consensus is that jobs will increase by about 30,000 over all, but fall by 125,000 in the private sector, with the unemployment rate rising one-tenth of 1 percent, to 7.7 percent.
The risk is that bond prices already reflect a weak report and a Federal Reserve easing that is by no means certain. The Dow Jones news service quoted Jerry Jones, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, as cautioning against a rate cut in response to the report.
Many were trading with a light hand yesterday, unwilling to make major commitments until they have the unemployment numbers. Volume was weak and the range of prices fairly narrow.
"The credit markets are locked into the unemployment number and fairly oblivious to other things that might be going on," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates.
The 30-year bond was offered late in the day at 9821/32 , down 9/32 , or about $2.81 for each $1,000 of face value, to yield 7.36 percent. Prices were down at shorter yields as well: the two-year note fell 3/32 to yield 3.80 percent, and the five-year note was off 9/32 to yield 5.33 percent.
The discount rate on one-year bills rose two-hundredths of a percentage point, to 3.04 percent.
 
Municipal Refinancings
 Municipals fared better than governments, with prices largely unchanged despite a heavy, $7 billion schedule of new long-term issues this week. But about half the new bonds are going to pay off older, higher-yielding issues, limiting the net increase in supply.
"The issuers are selling bond issue A, using the proceeds and calling bond issue B," said James J. Cooner, who leads the tax-exempt bond management division at the Bank of New York. "It is a recycling operation."
The possibility of a Federal tax increase, making the tax-free income from municipal bonds more valuable, has also supported prices, he said.
Nonetheless, the heavy supply has recently raised yields in the short end of the municipal spectrum. As California prepares to sell a record $5 billion in notes maturing in January, April and May today, short-term tax-free yields exceed the taxable yields available on Treasury issues with similar maturities.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 1, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about trading in the credit markets misstated Wall Street's expectations about the September unemployment report. The consensus is that while payrolls fell by 125,000, the private sector gained about 30,000 jobs.

HEADLINE: Brazil's House Impeaches Collor; Suspended, He Faces Senate Trial

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Sept. 29

 BODY:
President Fernando Collor de Mello was impeached today by the lower house of the Brazilian Congress, clearing the way for a trial on charges that his family and friends had accepted huge bribes on his behalf in return for Government favors.
 Losing by a 441 to 38 margin in the Chamber of Deputies, the President, who in 1989 won Brazil's first presidential elections in 30 years on a clean-government platform, will be stripped of his powers for 180 days and will face a trial in the Senate. 
As early as Wednesday, Vice President Itamar Franco will become acting President, assuming stewardship of the world's fifth largest nation and ninth largest economy.
 
President Called Indignant
 Mr. Collor made no statement tonight. But his spokesman, Celio Borja, said that although the President had received the news "with great indignation," he planned to allow the transfer of power to the Vice President "as fast as possible."
 "There is no need to procrastinate," said Mr. Borja, Brazil's Justice Minister. The President also asked his ministers, who submitted their resignations today, to remain in office until Mr. Franco has chosen a new Cabinet.
 The impeachment is the first time in Brazil's 103-year republican history that a President has been removed by constitutional means other than by election. The commitment to democratic procedures came in a country that until 1985 was run as a military dictatorship.
 "Today, our country gave an example to our suffering America and the world," said Ibsen Pinheiro, president of the Chamber of Deputies. "We are proud that such a deep crisis has been resolved entirely within constitutional norms."
 Aristides Junqueira, the nation's chief independent prosecutor, said on Monday, "We are showing ourselves that it is possible to resolve a political crisis within constitutional channels, without swerving off into an authoritarian or arms solution.".
 Alfred Stepan, a Columbia University political science professor, said that this was the first impeachment of a President in any country in at least 50 years. "Usually talk of impeachment in Latin America ends in a military coup," Mr. Stepan said. "Or, if the Congress tries it, the President closes the Congress."
 Fireworks, samba dancing and joyous block parties erupted across the nation as Brazilians learned the outcome of the vote. In the afternoon, this nation of 150 million people largely stopped work to watch live broadcasts of the debate and vote in the Chamber of Deputies. Hundreds of thousands of students and workers gathered before huge television screens mounted in the central squares of major cities.
 The 43-year-old Mr. Collor is unlikely to return to public office in this decade. Two-thirds of Brazil's senators have said they intend to vote for a conviction, which under the Brazilian Constitution would strip him of his right to run for office for eight years.
 Today's impeachment vote marks a precipitous plunge for a leader who only four months ago won international acclaim as the host of the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, the largest diplomatic gathering in history.
 An outsider in national politics, Mr. Collor campaigned in 1989 disdaining major party support. Vowing to slash inflation and to wipe out corruption, he swept Brazil's first direct presidential elections in three decades.
 Mr. Collor was largely responsible for the dismantling of Brazil's nuclear bomb program, reducing Amazon deforestation, doubling reservation land for Indians, starting a program to privatize state companies, and opening Brazil's highly protected economy to free trade.
 
Lost Opportunity Lamented
 But in his two and a half years in office, consumer prices rose by about 8,500 percent and the nation plunged into a deep recession. Efforts to correct these problems collapsed in recent weeks after congressional investigators charged that an influence trafficking ring run by Mr. Collor's former campaign treasurer, Paulo Cesar Farias, funneled at least $32 million to friends and family of the President, including his wife, Rosane.
 "I feel very frustrated," said Jarbas Passarinho, a pro-impeachment senator who resigned as Mr. Collor's Justice Minister in January. "We have lost an excellent opportunity in Brazil to modernize, to privatize, and to break up monopolies."
 A congressional corruption inquiry, televised live in June, July and August, provoked millions of Brazilians to demonstrate in favor of impeachment in the last month.
 Fearing riots if the President won the vote, the police mounted the largest security operation seen in the 32-year history of this modernistic capital on Brazil's high plains. The federal district's entire police force, 13,500 men and women, was deployed to protect the Congress building, the presidential palace and the headquarters of two federally run banks that the Government used recently to funnel millions of dollars to patronage projects favored by swing-vote members of Congressional.
 
'Thief! Thief! Thief!'
 A half-mile security cordon was placed around Mr. Collor's private residence, a lakefront estate that became a symbol of scandal this month with the revelation that a $2.5 million garden had been built there with proceeds from the trafficking ring.
 "Thief! Thief! Thief!" chanted a crowd of more than 100,000 who camped outside the Congress building this afternoon.
 Inside the bowl-shaped hall of the Chamber of Deputies, votes for impeachment crossed Brazil's political spectrum. Roberto Campos, a 75-year-old free-market advocate, arrived here today on a stretcher from a Rio de Janeiro hospital in order to cast the first vote in favor of impeachment.
 Gambling on the unpopular President's removal, Sao Paulo's stock market rose eight percentage points today. Last week, spreading certainty that the President would be impeached helped push stock values up 26 percent.
 A dwindling minority accused their fellow members of Congress of trying to mount a legal coup d'etat.
 "They're not voting for morality, they're voting to grab power," said Ronaldo Caiado, an anti-impeachment deputy.
 But Mr. Collor faced solid opposition from Brazil's major business groups, from major newspapers, magazines and television networks, and from 23 of 26 state governors. In an impeachment debate on Monday afternoon, only 4 of 38 deputies argued in favor of Mr. Collor's staying in power.
 In a national poll made public today, 80 percent of those surveyed wanted the President removed. In the event of an impeachment vote by the lower house, 68 percent wanted the President to resign.
 According to a Gallup Poll made public on Sunday, 8.5 percent of those polled nationwide described the performance of the President as "good" or "very good." In contrast, 79.5 percent described his performance as "bad" or "very bad." Those are the worst ratings for a Brazilian President that Gallup has measured since 1980.
 
Lawyers Are Divided
 Reflecting the effect of four months of corruption charges, the percentage of respondents who "don't trust Collor" jumped from 54 percent in June to 72 percent this month.
 Without any precedents as guides, constitutional lawyers were divided today over the timing of the transfer of presidential powers from Mr. Collor to Mr. Franco, Brazil's 61-year-old Vice President.
Opposition lawyers argued that Mr. Collor would lose his powers on Wednesday when a Senate secretary is to go to the presidential palace to deliver a letterfrom the president of the Senate formally telling him of the vote in the lower house.
 Government lawyers argued that the Senate must name a 21-member committee to review the chamber's impeachment actions and then vote to accept or refuse the chamber's request for a Senate trial.
 This process could have taken up to 10 days, but the announcement by Mr. Collor's spokesman that he would not impede the transfer of powers appeared to make the issue moot.
 
Criminal Charges Expected
 According to newspaper polls, more than two-thirds of Brazil's 81 senators intend to vote to convict the President.
 Until the Senate's verdict, the President will have the right to half of his $22,000 salary, to live in the official presidential residence and to enjoy protection and secretarial assistance.
 If the Senate convicts the President, Mr. Franco automatically assumes the title of President until the end of Mr. Collor's term on Jan. 1, 1995. If the Senate finds Mr. Collor not guilty or is unable to reach a verdict within 180 days, he reassumes full presidential powers.
 This week, Brazilians noted proudly that the political crisis had been handled without any factions calling on the army, a traditional arbiter of politics here for the last century.
 Directing a parallel investigation of the President's reported benefit from the corruption ring, Mr. Junqueira, the chief independent prosecutor, said of Mr. Collor, "There is no doubt that he committed various crimes."
 The prosecutor said that he expected to ask Brazil's Chamber of Deputies for authorization to indict Mr. Collor on criminal charges by early November. For a criminal indictment and trial in the Supreme Court, the prosecutor also needs approval of two-thirds of the Chamber of Deputies.


GRAPHIC: Chronology: "Collor's Fall: How a Scandal Unfolded"
Photo: The impeachment of President Fernando Collor de Mello being celebrated yesterday on the floor of the Brazilian Chamber of Deputies. Mr. Collor, stripped of his powers, is to face a trial in the Senate. (Associated Press) (pg. A8)
March 1992 -- Two ministers accused of profiting from Government contracts resign. President Fernando Collor de Mello shuffles his Cabinet to curb criticism.
May 23 -- Pedro Collor, the President's younger brother, accuses Collor's former campaign treasurer, Paulo Cesar Farias, of running a multimillion-dollar influence-peddling racket and sharing the proceeds with the President.
June 4 -- Congress appoints an investigative panel to examine Pedro Collor's accusations. A former chauffer for the Collor household says Farias routinely deposited money in bank account of Collor's personal secretary and that the money was used to pay Collor's expenses.
July 20 -- Congressional panel reveals a network of secret bank accounts that it says were used by Farias to funnel money to President's closest aides. Investigators said Farias bought Collor a new car and paid for renovation of his apartment and landscaping of his home in Brasilia. July 27 -- A former Collor aide, Claudio Vieira, tells Congress that millions of dollars from a 1989 campaign loan moved into bank accounts belonging to Collor and his family.
Aug. 3 -- Education Minister Jose Goldemberg resigns, saying he is disgusted with corruption.
Aug. 16 -- Tens of thousands of demonstrators march in cities to call for Collor's ouster.
Aug. 24 -- Congressional panel releases report saying Collor profited from an influence-peddling racket run by Farias. It suggests legal action against the President.
Sept. 1 -- Lawyers and press associations formally ask Congress to begin impeachment process against Collor.
Sept. 21 -- Collor's chances of surviving impeachment vote decline when Supreme Court decides voting will be open.
Sept. 29 -- The lower house of Congress votes 441 to 38 to impeach Collor. The President now faces trial by the Senate.
 (Source: Reuters) (pg. A8)

PUB-DATE: September 30, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 25; Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1491 words

HEADLINE: Blueprint for a Wider War

BYLINE: By George Kenney; George Kenney was the State Department desk officer for Yugoslavia until Aug. 25, when he resigned to protest U.S. policy.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Everything in the Yugoslav conflict follows from Serbia's fundamental goal of creating a larger, ethnicallly pure state. Only counterbalancing force -- Western air power, arms and training for the Bosnians -- can halt Serbian aggression. Only a military standoff will lead to a lasting peace, by reversing Serbian expansion.
The consequences will be much more tragic in the former Yugoslavia if the U.S. and Western Europe do not intervene militarily. Thousands of people have already been killed, and the Yugoslav refugee tide is already causing strains in Europe. If nothing is done, hundreds of thousands of innocent people may die, and the refugees will destabilize the Continent. 
 Conflict will spread through the Balkans, drawing in Islamic nations. Two NATO members, Greece and Turkey, may take opposite sides. Ultimately, the West may be forced to intervene militarily, but costs will rise exponentially as we delay.
Given the risks, consider how events might unfold.
Serbia has three short-run strategic aims it will not abandon unless it confronts a credible deterrent. First, it wants control of a corridor across northern Bosnia linking Serbia and Serbian-occupied ares of Croatia. Second, it demands an eastern corridor along the Bosnian-Montenegrin border, giving Belgrade access to its only naval base on the Adriatic. A Greater Serbia demands that "ethnic cleansing" continue in these areas until all non-Serbs are killed or driven out. Third, Serbia wants the destruction of Sarajevo, symbol of multi-ethnic Bosnian statehood.
About 400,000 non-Serb Bosnians remain in northern Bosnia. Most are in a pocket above Bihac in the northwest, surrounded by Serbian forces. Perhaps an additional 100,000 remain along the border with Montenegro. "Cleansing" these areas leaves no one to object to local puppet governments that work to "legitimize" a Greater Serbia. Although Serbian forces have not fully consolidated control over these areas, they have advantages in mobility and logistics. Given current conditions, they will achieve their aims over time.
Nevertheless, in the north and southeast, near the coast, some intense fighting will continue. To the north, Croatia will try to break Belgrade's supply lines and cut off parts of Serbian-occupied Croatia. By the coast, Croatian forces do not intend to cede control of the hills above Dubrovnik. Serbia is set on denying Croatia control of this region, which dominates the entrance of the bay leading to Serbia's only naval base.
A further 100,000 or so Bosnians -- Muslims and Croats as well as "disloyal" Serbs -- are interred in Serbian concentration camps. A typical camp consists of a cattle shed or other structure housing about a thousand men on straw pallets. Many die of sickness, hunger and beatings; guards dispose of others in "recreational killings." This winter, most internees will die of exposure. The International Committee of the Red Cross, the U.N. and the West will continue to demand access to all camps and supervision of camp conditions -- demands the Serbs will continue largely to ignore. Prisoners will be shifted from camp to camp in a shell game while Western negotiators visit detainees in model camps. Western governments will remain loath to force access.
The winter war may take up to 350,000 Bosnian lives. Freezing temperatures will greatly help the Serbian sieges around Sarajevo and other towns. Snow will close roads. Cutbacks in humanitarian aid will hurt; getting fuel to the large towns will be nearly impossible. Scores of besieged hamlets, whose names we do not know, will be wiped off the map.
Belatedly, the West will acknowledge a defeat. Cynically citing humanitarian concerns, Western diplomats will agree to terms with Serbian forces for a massive exodus of Bosnians from concentration camps and besieged areas to areas out of Bosnia.
Croatia will turn further refugees away. It has nowhere to put them, nor can it afford them. Having little choice, hundreds of thousands will pour across the borders of Austria, Germany and Italy, despite attempts by those countries to refuse asylum. Austria already views Yugoslav refugees as a threat to its national security. Germany and Italy will soon share that view. In 1991, the Italian Government was damaged by its inability to handle Albanian refugees; this new influx will add significantly to Italian political instability. Germany will face increased neo-Nazi violence.
From the first, the Serbians said they planned to strangle Sarajevo. They are patient. Whether Sarajevo withstands the siege or falls, its defenders will strain trust among ethnic communities. Bosnians, Croats and Serbs will turn away from the Government; it will become predominantly Muslim and radicalized.
Moderate leaders will seek help from Islamic states; Iran and Libya will respond, as will Turkey, which is troubled by what it perceives as its responsibility to Balkan Muslims and also wishes to use the crisis to provoke Greece over other disputes.
Throughout the winter, Serbian forces will make incremental gains. Fighting in Bosnia will enter a false lull. In Croatia, Serbians will continue to violate terms for the cease-fire in U.N.-protected areas. Serbian refugees from other regions will move in, non-Serbs will be forced out, often brutally. Local legal and administrative procedures and political institutions will be modeled increasingly on Serbian standards. Because the cease-fire agreements do not specify how U.N.-protected areas are governed, Serbians will be able to claim they are only defending their "rights."
By spring, the Croatian Government will conclude that further time in negotiations means more opportunity for Serbia to lock in its gains. Zagreb will regroup; by spring, its forces will become far stronger than Serbian forces in Croatia, though not yet a military match for the entire Serbian Army. The Croatians will decide to recover territory by force but will wait for the right tactical moment.
Croatia will appear calm. Bosnia will be quieter, even though Serbians will not control it fully. Western governments will move forward with the Geneva talks. They dare hope for a settlement despite the winter deaths, the refugee problem and disconcerting signs of the involvement of Muslim states. The West will continue to refuse to believe a military deterrent is necessary. Belgrade will talk while it fights.
But sanctions begin to have a big effect on politics as the Serbian economy collapses. President Slobodan Milosevic then does what dictators typically do: He turns attention elsewhere -- to Kosovo, a rally point for Serbs.
No Serb, whether of the opposition or a Milosevic supporter, would give up the "cradle of Serbian civilization." Kosovo's 90 percent Albanian population, however, demands independence. Conflict is inevitable. Serbian militants in Kosovo are armed and trained; they despise the Albanians and plan an ethnic cleansing, to push as many Albanians as possible into Albania. At Mr. Milosevic's signal, Serbian irregulars attack, backed by the army and air force.
It is worse than Bosnia. It is a massacre. Albanian Kosovars are neither armed nor organized. Indiscriminate shelling and air bombardment kills thousands. A half-million Kosovars, about a quarter of the population, flee to Albania.
The Government of Albania mobilizes immediately and goes to war. Macedonia, with a 30 to 40 percent ethnic Albanian population of its own, decides it has a better chance of survival by joining Albania. It is too risky for Macedonia to wait and face a victorious Serbia alone. Each side inflicts heavy casualties; the war bogs down. Muslim states are outraged. Mr. Milosevic made a fatal error by discounting the possibility of their intervention. They openly send "volunteers" and arms.
In Kosovo and Bosnia, Serbian forces, which were never so strong, fall back. Croatia seizes the opportunity to reopen its own front against Belgrade. U.N. forces in the region come under attack from all sides. Greece cannot conceal its ambitions for a slice of Macedonia; it weighs the opportunities and risks of coming to the aid of Serbia. Turkey threatens Greece. NATO, torn by refugee problems, by indecision, flounders. The West cannot stop the conflict from spreading.
This is not a worst-case scenario. In my judgment, the probability of such a chain of events is greater than 50-50, the point being that the U.S. is unlikely to get for free the option of non-involvement. It may well be that by next spring, the U.S. will find itself proposing to lead a force of Western ground troops under U.N. auspices to make peace in the ex-Yugoslavia and keep the peace in Europe.
Should we choose not to deter Serbian aggression when we can? Compare the likely cost of intervention tomorrow with the cost of limited military intervention today and consider that the cost will keep going up and the problem won't go away.
